a=)ra/w (a=)rh/), act. only pres. inf. a=)rh/menai, Od. 22.322; mid. fut. a=/rh/somai, aor. h)rhsa/mhn: pray to the deity, and in the sense of wish; *dii+/, dai/mosi, pa/ntessi qeoi=si (see cut for attitude); polla/, ‘fervently’; eu)xome/nh d' h)ra=to, ‘lifted up her voice in prayer,’ Il. 6.304; with inf., Od. 22.322, etc.; stugera=\s a=)rh/set' e)ri=nu=s, ‘invoke,’ ‘call down,’ Od. 2.135; in the sense of wish, Il. 13.286, Od. 1.366, and often.

a)rgale/os: hard to endure or deal with, difficult; e(/lkos, e)/rgon, a)/nemos, desmoi/, o(do/s, etc.; a)rgale/os ga\r *)olu/mpios a)nt fe/resqai, Il. 1.589; a)rgale/on de/ moi e)sti\.. pa=si ma/xesqai, Il. 20.356; comp., a)rgalew/teros, *o 121, Od. 4.698.
*)argea/dhs: son of Argeus, Polymēlus, a Lycian, Il. 16.417†.

*)argei=os: of Argos, Argive; *(/hrh *)argei/h, as tutelary deity of Argos), Il. 4.8, Il. 5.908 ; *)argei/h *(ele/nh, Il. 2.161, etc.; pl., *)argei=oi, the Argives, freq. collective designation of the Greeks before Troy; *)argei/wn *danaw=n, Od. 8.578, is peculiar.

*)argei+fo/nths: Argeïphontes, freq. epith. of Hermes, of uncertain signification; the traditional interpretation, ‘slayer of Argus’ (root fen) is more poetical than the modern one, ‘shiner,’ ‘shining one’ (a)rges-), because it refers to a definite legend, instead of a vague mythical idea.
a)rgenno/s (root a)rg): white shining; o)/ies, o)qo/nai, Il. 3.198, 141.
a)rgesth/s, a=o (root a)rg): rapid; epith. of the south wind, Il. 11.306 and Il. 22.334.
a)rgh/s, h=tos (root a)rg), dat. a)rgh=ti and a)rge/ti, acc. a)rgh=ta and a)rge/ta: dazzling white, glistening; epith. of lightning, linen, fat, Il. 8.133, Il. 3.419, Il. 11.818.
a)rgi-ke/raunos: god of the dazzling bolt, epith. of Zeus. (Il.)
a)rgino/eis, acc. -enta: white-gleaming, epith. of towns in Crete, because of chalk cliffs in the vicinity, Il. 2.647, 656.
a)rgi - o/dous, ontos: white - toothed; epith. of dogs and swine.
a)rgi/ - pos, podos: swift - footed, Il. 24.211†.
*)/argissa: a town in Thessaly, Il. 2.738†.
a)/rgma (a)/rxesqai): only pl., a)/rgmata, consecrated pieces of flesh, burned at the beginning of the sacrifice, Od. 14.446†.
*)/argos (1): Argus, the dog of Odysseus, Od. 17.292†.

*)/argos (2), eos: Argos, a name with some variety of application.—(1) the city of Argos in Argolis, the domain of Diomed, Il. 2.559, Il. 6.224, Il. 14.119, Od. 3.180, Od. 15.224, Od. 21.108; epithets, *)axaiiko/n, i(ppo/boton, polu/pu=ron.—(2) in wider sense, the realm of Agamemnon, who dwelt in Mycēnae, Il. 1.30, Il. 2.108, 115, Il. 4.171, Il. 9.22, Il. 13.379, *o 30, Od. 3.263.—(3) the entire Peloponnēsus, Il. 6.152, Od. 3.251, Od. 4.174; and with Hellas (kaq' *(ella/da kai\ me/son *)/argos) for the whole of Greece, Od. 1.344, Od. 4.726, 816.—(4) *pelasgiko/n, the domain of Achilles, the valley and plain of the river Penēus, Il. 2.681, Il. 6.456, Il. 24.437, Od. 24.37. In some
passages the name is used too vaguely to determine its exact application.
a)rgo/s (root a)rg): (1) white shining; goose, Od. 15.161; of oxen, ‘sleek,’ Il. 23.30.— (2) swift; epith. of dogs, with and without po/das, *a 50, Od. 2.11.
*)/argosde: to Argos.
a)rguro-di=/nhs (di=/nh): silver-eddying; epith. of rivers. (Il.)
a)rguro/ - hlos (h)=los): ornamented with silver nails or knobs, silver-studded; cifos, qro/nos, fa/sganon, Il. 2.45, h 162, Il. 14.405.
a)rguro/-peza: silvery-footed; epith. of Thetis, a Nereid fresh from the seawaves. (Il., and Od. 24.92.)
a)/rguros (root a)rg): silver.
a)rguro/ - tocos (to/con): god of the silver bow; epith. of Apollo; as subst., Il. 1.37.
a)/rgufos = a)rgu/feos, epith. of sheep, Il. 24.621, Od. 10.85.
*)argw/: the Argo, ship of the Argonants, Od. 12.70†.
a)rdmo/s (a)/rdw): watering, wateringplace for animals, Od. 13.247.
*)are/qousa: name of a fount in the island of Ithaca, Od. 13.408†.
a)reih/ (a=)rh/): cursing, threatening. (Il.)
a)/reios: see a)rh/ios.

a)rei/wn, a)/reion (root a)r, cf. a)/ristos, a)reth/): comp. (answering to a)gaqo/s), better, superior, etc.; ple/ones kai\ a)rei/ous, ‘mightier,’ Od. 9.48 ; pro/teros kai\ a)rei/wn, Il. 23.588; krei=sson kai\ a)/reion, Od. 6.182; (pai=des) oi( ple/ones kaki/ous, pau=roi de/ te patro\s a)rei/ous, Od. 2.277; adv., ta/xa de\ fra/setai kai\ a)/reion, Od. 23.114.
*)arei/wn: Arīon, name of the horse of Adrastus at the siege of Thebes, Il. 23.346.
a)/-rektos (r(e/zw): undone, unaccomplished, Il. 19.150†.
a)re/sai, a)re/sasqai: see a)re/skw.

a)re/skw, act. only aor. inf. a)re/sai, mid. fut. a)re/ssomai, aor. imp. a)re(s)sa/sqw, part. a)ressa/menos: act., make amends, Il. 9.120, Il. 19.138; mid, make good (ti\) for oneself or for each other, appease, reconcile (tina/); tau=ta d' o)/pisqen a)resso/meq), ei ti kako\n nu=n | ei)/rhtai, Il. 4.363; e)/peita/ se daiti\ e)ni\ klisi/h|s a)resa/sqw, with a feast of reconciliation, Il. 19.179.
a)re/sqai: see a)/rnumai.
a)reta/w (a)reth/): come to good, thrive, Od. 8.329 and Od. 19.114.
*)areta=/wn: a Trojan, slain by Teucer, Il. 6.31†.

a)reth/ (root a)r, cf. a)rei/wn, a)/ristos): subst. (answering to the adj. a)gaqo/s), excellence (of whatever sort), merit; e)k patro\s polu\ xei/ronos ui(o\s a)mei/nwn | pantoi/a=s a)reta=/s, h)me
 po/das h)de\ ma/xesqai, all kinds of ‘prowess,’ Il. 15.642, cf. Il. 22.268; intellectual, e)mh=| a)reth=| (boulh=| te no/w| te) | e)kfu/gomen, Od. 12.212; of a woman, e)mh
 a)reth
 (ei)=dos te de/mas te) | w)/lesan a=/qa/natoi, my ‘attractions’ (said by Penelope), Od. 18.251 ; th=s a)reth=s (Od. 2.206) includes more. The signif. well-being, prosperity (Il. 20.242, Od. 13.45) answers to eu)= rather than to a)gaqo/s.
a)reth/s, h=tos: a)reth=ta, a conjectural reading, see a)ndroth/s.

a=)rh/, h=s: prayer; and in bad sense, curse, imprecation, hence calamity, destruction; in good sense, Od. 4.767, Il. 15.378, etc.; bad, Il. 9.566, Od. 17.496 ; a=/rh
 kai\ loigo
 a)mu=nai, Il. 24.489; a=/rh
 a)po\ oi)/kou a)mu=nai, Od. 2.59.
a)/rhai: see a)/rnumai.
a)rh/gw, fut. a)rh/cw: aid, support, succor (tini/); (e)moi\) e)/pesin kai\ xersi\n a)rh/cein, Il. 1.77. (Il.)
a)rhgw/n, o/nos (a)rh/gw): helper, fem., Il. 5.511 and Il. 4.7.
a)rhi/ - qoos (*)/arhs, qoo/s): swift in battle. (Il.)
*)arhi/-qoos: (1) father of Menesthius, the ‘club-swinger,’ from Bœotia, Il. 7.10, 137.—(2) a Thracian, charioteer of Rhigmus, Il. 20.487.
a=)rhi - kta/menos (*)/arhs, ktei/nw); slain by Ares or in battle, Il. 22.72†.
*)arhi/-lukos (Ares-wolf): (1) father of Prothoēnor, Il. 14.451.—(2) a Trojan, slain by Patroclus, Il. 16.308.

a)rh/ios, a)/reios (*)/arhs): martial, warlike; of men, *mene/la=os, *ai)/a=s, ui)=es *)axaiw=n, etc.; also of weapons and armor (teu/xea, e)/ntea); tei=xos a)/reion, ‘martial’ wall, Il. 4.407, Il. 15.736.
a)rhi/ - fatos (root fen): slain by Ares or in battle.
a=)rhme/nai: see a=)ra/w.
a=)rhme/nos: overcome, overwhelmed, burdened; u(/pnw| kai\ kama/tw|, Od. 6.2; gh/rai+ lugrw=|, Il. 18.435; du/h| a=)rhme/non, Od. 18.53.
a)rh/n: see a)rno/s.
a)rhrome/nos: see a)ro/w.
*=)arh/nh: a town subject to Nestor, Il. 2.591, Il. 11.723.

*<*>)/arhs, gen. *)/areos and *)/arhos, dat. *)/arei and *)/arhi, acc. *)/arhn and *)/arha, voc. *)/ares (*)=ares, Il. 5.31, 455): Ares (Mars), son of Zeus and Hera, the god of war and the tumult of battle, Il. 5.890 ff; insatiate in bloodshed, headlong and planless in warfare, thus forming a contrast to Athena, with whom he is at variance, Il. 5.853 ff., Il. 21.400 ff.; a brother of *)/eris, father of *dei=mos and *fo/bos; his favorite abode is among rude, warring peoples, Il. 13.301 ff., Od. 8.361; his mien and stature imposing and magnificent, Il. 5.860, cf. 385, Od. 8.267 ff.; fights now for the Trojans and now for the Greeks (a)llopro/sallos); other epithets, a)=tos pole/moio, brotoloigo/s, deino/s, a)ndrei+fo/nths, *)enu=a/lios, qoo/s, qou=ros, miai/fonos, o)/brimos, talauri=no\s polemisth/s, xa/lkeos, etc. The name of Ares is used by personification (though not written with a capital letter in some edd.) for his element, battle, combat; cuna/gein *)/arha, kri=/nesqai *)/arhi, e)gei/rein o)cu\n *)/arha, Il. 2.381, 385, 440.
a)/rhsqe: see a)/rnumai.
*=)arh/th (a=)ra/omai, cf. Od. 7.54, 64 f.): Arēte, wife of Alcinous, king of the Phaeacians, and mother of Nausicaa.
a=)rhth/r, h=ros (a=)ra/omai): one who prays, priest.
*)arhtia/dhs. son of Arētus, Nisus, Od. 16.395.

a=)/rhtos: doubtful word, wished-for (if from a=)ra/omai), a=)/rhton de\ tokeu=si go/on kai\ pe/nqos e)/qhkas, ‘hast awakened the desire of lamentation’ (cf. i=(/meros go/ou), Il. 17.37, Il. 24.741; according to others, for a)/rrhtos (r(hqh=nai), ‘unspeakable.’
*=)/arhtos: (1) a son of Nestor, Od. 3.414.—(2) a son of Priam, Il. 17.535.
a)/rqen: see a)rari/skw.
a)rqme/w (a)rqmo/s, root a)r), aor. part. du. a)rqmh/sante: form a bond, be bound together in friendship, Il. 7.302†.
a)/rqmios (a)rqmo/s, root a)r): bound in friendship, allied, Od. 16.427†.
a)ri- (root a)r): inseparable intensive prefix, very.
*)ari - a/dnh: Ariadne, daughter of Minos, king of Crete, who gave Theseus the clue to the Labyrinth, Od. 11.321, Il. 18.592.
a)ri/ - gnwtos (gignw/skw): recognizable; r(ei=a d' a)ri/gnwtos, ‘right easy to recognize,’ Od. 4.207, etc.; w)= a)ri/gnwte subw=ta, thou ‘unmistakable,’ Od. 17.375.
a)ri - dei/ketos (dei/knu=mi, digito monstrari): distinguished, illustrious, Od. 11.540; usually w. part. gen., pa/ntwn a)ridei/kete la=w=n, ‘among,’ Od. 8.382.
a)ri/ - zhlos (dh=los): conspicuous, clear, Il. 18.519, 219, Il. 2.318.—Adv., a)rizh/lws, Od. 12.453†.
a)riqme/w (a)riqmo/s): count, reckon up, Il. 2.124 ; di/xa pa/ntas h)ri/qmeon, ‘counted off’ in two companies, Od. 10.304.
a)riqmo/s: number.
*)/arima, pl.: name of a region in Cilicia, Il. 2.783.
a)ri-preph/s, e/s (pre/pw): conspicuous, distinguished; *trw/essin, ‘among the Trojans,’ Il. 6.477.
*)ari/sba=s: a Greek, father of Leocritus, Il. 17.345†.
*)ari/sbh: a town in the Troad; *)ari/sbhqen, from Arisbe, Il. 2.838.
a)ristero/s: left (opp. decio/s), hence sinister, ill - boding (o)/rni=s, Od. 20.242); e)p' a)ristera/, ‘on the left,’ Il. 12.240 ; e)p' a)ristero/fin, Il. 13.309.
a)risteu/s, h=os (a)/ristos): best man, chief, Il. 3.44 ; a)ndro\s a)risth=os, Il. 15.489; usually pl., a)risth=es, Il. 2.404, etc.
a)risteu/w (a)risteu/s), ipf. iter. a)risteu/eskon: be the best or bravest; usually w. inf. (ma/xesqai); also w. gen., Il. 6.460.
a)/riston: breakfast; in Homer taken not long after sunrise; only e)ntu=/nonto a)/riston, *w 124, Od. 16.2.

a)/ristos (root a)r, cf. a)rei/wn, a)reth/), w)/ristos = o( a)/ristos: best, most excellent (see the various implied meanings under a)gaqo/s); *zeu/s, qew=n u(/patos kai\ a)/ristos, Il. 19.258; freq. w. adv. prefixed, me/g(a), o)/x(a), e)/cox(a), Il. 1.69, Il. 12.103;
often foll. by explanatory inf., dat., or acc. (ma/xesqai, boulh=|, ei)=dos); h)= soi\ a)/rista pepoi/htai, ‘finely indeed hast thou been treated,’ Il. 6.56.
a)ri - fradh/s, e/s (fra/zomai): very plain, easy to note or recognize; sh=ma, o)ste/a, Il. 23.240; adv., a)rifrade/ws. v. l. in Od. 23.225.
*)arkadi/h: Arcadia, a district in the Peloponnēsus, Il. 2.603.
*)arka/s, a/dos: Arcadian, inhabitant of Arcadia, Il. 2.611.
*)arkeisia/dhs: son of Arceisius, Laertes, Od. 4.755, Od. 24.270, 517.
*)arkei/sios: son of Zeus, and father of Laertes, Od. 16.118.
*)arkesi/ - la=os: son of Lyeus, and leader of the Boeotians, Il. 2.495, Od. 15.329.

a)rke/w (root a)rk, a)lk), fut. a)rke/sw, aor. h)/rkesa: keep off (tini/ ti), hence protect, help (tini/); a)lla/ oi( ou)/ tis tw=n ge to/t' h)/rkese lugro\n o)/leqron, Il. 6.16; ou)d) u(mi=n potamo/s per a)rke/sei, *f 131, Od. 16.261.

a)/rkios (root a)rk), helping, to be depended upon, certain; ou)/ oi( e)/peita | a)/rkion e)ssei=tai fuge/ein ku/nas h)d' oi)wnou/s, ‘nothing shall avail him’ to escape, Il. 2.393 ; nu=n a)/rkion h)\ a)pole/sqai | h)e\ sawqh=nai, a ‘sure’ thing, i. e. no other alternative presents itself, Il. 15.502; so, misqo\s a)/rkios, *k 304, Od. 18.358, unless the word has here attained to its later meaning of sufficient. Cf. a)rke/w.
a)/rktos: bear, Od. 11.611; fem., the constellation of the Great Bear, Il. 18.487, Od. 5.273.

a(/rma, atos: chariot, esp. the warchariot; very often in pl., and with i(/ppoi, Il. 5.199, 237, Il. 4.366; epithets, a)/gkulon, e)u/coon, e)u/troxon, qoo/n, kampu/lon, daida/lea, kollhta/, poiki/la xalkw=|. For the separate parts of the chariot, see a)/ntuc, a)/cwn, r(u=mo/s, e(/stwr, i)/tus, e)pi/sswtra, plh=mnai, knh/mh, di/fros, zugo/n. (See cut No. 10, and tables I. and II.)
*arma: a town in Boeotia, Il. 2.499†.
a(rmato - phgo/s (ph/gnu=mi): a)nh/r, chariot-builder, Il. 4.485†.
a(rma - troxih/ (troxo/s): wheel - rut, Il. 23.505†.
a)/rmenos: see a)rari/skw.
a(rmo/zw (a(rmo/s, root a)r), aor. h(/rmosa, mid. pres. imp. a(rmo/zeo: fit together, join, mid., for oneself, Od. 5.247, 162; intrans., fit, h(/rmo te d' au)tw=| (sc. qw/rhc), Il. 3.333.
*(armoni/dhs: a ship-builder of Troy, Il. 5.60†.
a(rmoni/h (a(rmo/zw): only pl., bands, slabs, one side flat, the other curved, serving (Od. 5.248, 361) to bind together the raft of Odysseus; fig., bond, compact, Il. 22.255.
*)arnai=os: the original name of Irus, Od. 18.5†.
a)rneio/s: ram; with o)/is, Od. 10.527, 572.
a)rne/omai, aor. inf. a)rnh/sasqai: deny, refuse, say no, decline; do/menai/ te kai\ a)rnh/sasqai, Od. 21.345.
a)rneuth/r, h=ros: diver, Il. 12.385, Il. 16.742, Od. 12.413.
*)/arnh: a town in Boeotia, Il. 2.507, Il. 7.9.
a)rno/s, gen. (root arn.), no nom. sing., acc. a)/rna, dual. a)/rne, pl. a)/rnes, a)rnw=n, a)/rnessi, a)/rnas: lamb, sheep.

a)/rnumai, aor. 1 h)ra/mhn, 2 sing. h)/rao, aor. 2 a)ro/mhn, subj. a)/rwmai, 2 sing. a)/rhai, opt. a)roi/mhn (a)re/sqai and a)/rasqai are sometimes referred to a)ei/rw, ai)/rw, q. v.): carry off (usually for oneself), earn, win; freq. the pres. and ipf. of attempted action, ou)x i(erh/ion ou)de\ boei/hn | a)rnu/sqhn, were not ‘trying to win,’ Il. 22.160 ; a)rnu/menos h(/n te yu=xh\n kai/ no/ston e(tai/rwn, ‘striving to achieve,’ ‘save,’ Od. 1.5, cf. Il. 6.446; aor. common w. kle/os, ku=dos, eu)=xos, ni=/khn, a)e/qlia, etc.; also of burdens and troubles, o(/ss' *)oduseu\s e)mo/ghse kai\ h)/rato, ‘took upon himself,’ Od. 4.107, Il. 14.130, Il. 20.247.
a)roi/mhn: see a)/rnumai.
a)/rosis (a)ro/w): ploughing, arable land.
a)roth/r, h=ros: ploughman.
a)/rotos: ploughing, cultivation, pl., Od. 9.122.†
a)/rotron: plough.

a)/roura (a)ro/w): cultivated land (pl., fields), ground, the earth; te/mei de/ te te/lson a)rou/rhs (sc. a)/rotron), Il. 13.707 ; o(/te fri/ssousin a)/rourai, Il. 23.599; plhsi/on a)llh/lwn, o)li/gh d' h)=n a)mfi\s a)/roura, Il. 3.115; zei/dwros a)/roura, d 229, Od. 19.593 (personified, Il. 2.548).
a)ro/w, perf. pass. part. a)rhrome/nh: plough, Od. 9.108, Il. 18.548.

a(rpa/zw, fut. a(rpa/cw, aor. h(/rpaca, h(/rpasa: seize, snatch; esp. of robbery, abduction, and attacks of wild animals, o(/te se prw=ton *lakedai/monos e)c e)ratei/nhs | e)/pleon a(rpa/ca=s, the ‘rape’ of Helen, Il. 3.444 ; w(s o(/de (ai)eto/s) xh=n' h(/rpace, Od. 15.174; ku=ma me/g) a)rpa/can, Od. 5.416.
a(rpakth/r, h=ros: robber, Il. 24.262†.
a(rpale/os: eagerly grasped; ke/rdea, Od. 8.164; adv., a(rpale/ws, greedily, Od. 14.110. (Od.)
*(arpali/wn: son of Pylaemenes, Il. 13.644.
a(/rph: a bird of prey, perhaps falcon, Il. 19.350†.

a(/rpuia: harpy, ‘snatcher;’ the horses of Achilles had Zephyrus as sire and the harpy Podargē as dam, Il. 16.150; usually pl., a(/rpuiai: supernatural powers, by whom those who had mysteriously disappeared were said to have been snatched away (perhaps a personification of storm-winds), Od. 1.241.
a)/-rrhtos (root ver, r(hqh=nai): unspoken, unspeakable.
a)/rshn, enos: male.
*)arsi/ - noos: father of Hecamēde, of the island of Tenedos, Il. 11.626†.
a=)rsi/pos: see a)ersi/pos.
*)artaki/h: name of a fountain in the country of the Laestr&ymacr;gons, Od. 10.108†.
a)rtemh/s, e/s: safe and sound, Il. 5.515, Od. 13.43.

*artemis: Artemis (Diana), daughter of Zeus and Leto, and sister of Apollo; virgin goddess of the chase, and the supposed author of sudden painless deaths of women (see a)gano/s); women of fine figure are compared to Artemis, Od. 4.122, Od. 17.17, 37, Od. 19.56, cf. Od. 6.151 ff.; her favorite haunts are wild mountainous regions, Erymanthus in Arcadia, Taÿgetus in Laconia, Od. 6.102; epithets, a(gnh/, i)oxe/aira, xru=shla/katos, xru=sh/nios, xru=so/qronos, a)grote/rh, keladeinh/.
a)rti - eph/s, e/s (ve/pos): ready of speech, Il. 22.281†.
a)/rtios (root a)r): suitable; only pl., a)/rtia ba/zein, ‘sensibly,’ Il. 14.92, Od. 8.240; o(/ti oi( fresi\n a)/rtia h)/dh|, was a ‘congenial spirit,’ Il. 5.326, Od. 19.248.
a)rti/-pos: sound-footed, nimble-footed, Il. 9.505, Od. 8.310.
a)rti/-frwn (frh/n): accommodating, Od. 24.261†.
a)/rtos: bread. (Od.)

a)rtu=/nw, a)rtu/w (root a)r), ipf. h)/rtuon, fut. a)rtune/w, aor. part. a)rtu=/na=s, mid. aor. h)rtu=na/mhn, pass. aor. a)rtu/nqhn: put in place, make ready, prepare; purghdo\n sfe/as au)tou\s a)rtu=/nantes, (‘forming close ranks,’ cf. Il. 15.618), Il. 12.43 ; a)rtu/nqh, ‘was made ready,’ ‘began,’ Il. 11.216; esp. of craft, do/lon, yeu/dea, o)/leqro/n tini a)rtu/ein; mid., h)rtu=/nanto d' e)retma\ tropoi=s e)n dermati/noisin, ‘their’ oars, Od. 4.782 ; pukinh\n h)rtu=/neto boulh/n, ‘was framing,’ Il. 2.55.
*)aru/ba=s: a Phoenician of Sidon, Od. 15.426†.
a)rxe/-kakos: beginning mischief, Il. 5.63†.
*)arxe/-loxos: a Trojan, son of Antēnor, Il. 14.464.
*)arxe - pto/lemos: son of Iphitus, charioteer of Hector, Il. 8.128.
a)rxeu/w: be commander, command, w. dative. (Il.)

a)rxh/ (a)/rxw): beginning; ei(/nek' e)mh=s e)/ridos kai\ *)aleca/ndrou e(/nek) a)rxh=s, and ‘its beginning by Alexander,’ said by Menelāus, making Paris the aggressor, Il. 3.100 ; e)c a)rxh=s, ‘of old.’
a)rxo/s: leader, commander.

a)/rxw, reg. in act. and mid., but without perf., and without pass.: I. act., lead off, begin (for others to follow), lead, command; toi=s a)/ra mu=/qwn h)=rxe, ‘was the first’ to speak; h)=rx' a)goreu/ein, h)=rxe d) o(doi=o, ‘lead the way,’ Od. 5.237 ; pa/ntes a(/ma, *zeu\s d' h)=rxe, ‘headed by Zeus,’ Il. 1.495; in the sense of ‘commanding,’ foll. by dat., h)=rxe d' a)/ra sfin | *(/ektwr, Il. 16.552, etc.; with part., e)gw\ d' h)=rxon xalepai/nwn, ‘was the first to offend,’ ‘began the quarrel,’ Il. 2.378, Il. 3.447, different from the inf.— II. mid., begin something that one is himself to continue; h)/rxeto mu=/qwn, began ‘his’ or ‘her’ speaking; h)/rxeto mh=tin u(fai/nein, etc.; e)/k tinos a)/rxesqai, make a beginning ‘with’ something, or ‘at’ some point, sometimes gen. without a prep., se/o d' a)/rcomai, *i 97, Od. 21.142; of ritual observance (beginning
a sacrifice), pa/ntwn a)rxo/menos mele/wn, Od. 14.428 (cf. a)pa/rxomai).
a)rwgh/ (a)rh/gw): help, aid in battle; ti/ moi e)/ridos kai\ a)rwgh=s, ‘why should I concern myself with giving succor?’ Il. 21.360.
a)rwgo/s (a)rh/gw): helper, advocate, Od. 18.232, Il. 18.502.
a)=sai: see (1) a)a/w, (2) a=)/w.
a=)/saimi: see a=w.
*)asai=os: a Greek, slain by Hector, Il. 11.301†.
a=)/samen: see a=)/esa.
a)sa/minqos: bath-tub.
a=)/sasqai: see a=)/w.
a=)/sato: see a)a/w.
a)/-sbestos (sbe/nnu=mi): inextinguishable; flo/c, Il. 16.123; mostly metaph., ge/lws, me/nos, boh/, kle/os.
a=)/sesqai: see a=)/w.
a)-sh/mantos (shmai/nw): without a guide (shepherd); mh=la, Il. 10.485† (cf. Il. 15.325).
a)=sqma, atos: hard breathing, panting. (Il.)
a)sqmai/nw: pant, gasp. (Il.)
*=)asia/dhs: son of Asius.
*)asi/nh: a town in Argolis, Il. 2.560†.
a)-sinh/s, e/s (si/nomai): unmolested, Od. 11.110 and Od. 12.137.
*asios (2): (1) a Phrygian, son of Tymas, and brother of Hecuba, Il. 16.717. —(2) son of Hystacus, from Arisbe, an ally of the Trojans, Il. 12.95.
a)/sis: slime, Il. 21.321†.
a)/-si=tos: without food, Od. 4.788†.
*)aska/lafos: a son of Ares, one of the Argonauts, Il. 2.512.
*)askani/h: (1) a district in Phrygia, Il. 2.863.—(2) in Bithynia or Mysia, Il. 13.793.
*)aska/nios: (1) leader of the Phrygians, Il. 2.862.—(2) son of Hippotion, Il. 13.792.
a) - skelh/s, e/s (ske/llw): withered, wasted, Od. 10.463; adv., a)skele/s, obstinately, persistently, Od. 1.68, Od. 4.543 ; a)skele/ws, unceasingly, with ai)ei/, Il. 19.68.

a)ske/w, ipf. 3 sing. h)/skein (for h)/skeen), aor. h)/skhsa, perf. pass. h)/skhmai: work out with skill, aor., wrought, Il. 18.592 ; xitw=na ptu/ssein kai\ a)skei=n, ‘smooth out,’ Od. 1.439; the part., a)skh/sa=s, is often used for amplification, ‘elaborately,’ Od. 3.438, Il. 14.240.
a)skhto/s (a)ske/w): finely or curiously wrought, Od. 23.189 ; nh=ma, ‘fine-spun,’ Od. 4.134.
*)asklhpia/dhs: son of Asclepius, Machāon, Il. 4.204, Il. 11.614, Il. 14.2.
*)asklhpio/s: Asclepius (Aesculapius), a famous physician, prince of Thessalia, father of Podaleirius and Machāon, Il. 2.731, Il. 4.194, Il. 11.518.
a)/-skopos (skope/w): inconsiderate, Il. 24.157.
a)sko/s: leather bottle, usually a goat skin (see cut, after a Pompeian painting), Il. 3.247 ; boo/s, a skin to confine winds, Od. 10.19.
a)/smenos (root svad, a(nda/nw): glad; e)moi\ de/ ken a)sme/nw| ei)/h, 'twould ‘please me’ well, Il. 14.108.
a)spa/zomai, only ipf. h)spa/zonto: greet warmly, by drawing to one's embrace, make welcome; xersi/n, Od. 3.35; xersi\n e)pe/essi/ te, Od. 19.415; decih=| e)pe/essi/ te, Il. 10.542.
a)spai/rw: move convulsively, quiver; mostly of dying persons and animals; po/dessi, x 473, Od. 19.231.
a)/-spartos (spei/rw): unsown, Od. 9.109 and 123.

a)spa/sios (a)spa/zomai): (1) welcome; tw=| d' a)spa/sios ge/net) e)lqw/n, *k 35, Od. 9.466; so nu/c, gh=, bi/otos, Od. 5.394 (cf. 397).—(2) glad, joyful, Il. 21.607, Od. 23.238. —Adv., a)spasi/ws, n 33, Il. 7.118.
a)spasto/s: welcome; a)spasto/n, ‘a grateful thing,’ Od. 5.398.
a)/-spermos (spe/rma): without offspring, Il. 20.303†.
a)-sperxe/s (spe/rxw): vehemently; ‘busily,’ Il. 18.556.

a)/-spetos (root sep, e)/spete): unspeakable, inexpressible, with regard to size, numbers, or quality; hence, immense, endless; u=(/lh, ai)qh/r, dw=ra, etc.; a(lmuro\n u=(/dwr | a)/speton, ‘vast as it is,’ Od. 5.101; in a)/speton ou)=das the epith. is regularly due to the pathos of the situation, Il. 19.61, Od. 13.395, etc.; klaggh\ suw=n, ‘prodigious squealing,’ Od. 14.412; adv., trei=t' a)/speton, Il. 17.332.
a)spidiw/ths: shield-bearing, Il. 2.554 and Il. 16.167.

a)spi/s, i/dos: shield.—(1) the larger, oval shield, termed a)mfibro/th, podhnekh/s. It is more than 2 ft. broad, 4 1/2 ft. high, and weighed about 40 lbs. (For Agamemnon's shield, see Il. 11.32-40). The large shield was held over the left shoulder, sustained by the telamw/n and by the po/rpac, or ring on the inside.— (2) the smaller, circular shield, pa/ntos' e)i=/sh (see cut), with only two handles, or with one central handle for the arm and several for the hand (see cut No. 12). It was of about half the size and weight of the larger a)spi/s, cf. the description of Sarpēdon's shield, Il. 12.294 ff. The shield consisted generally of from 4 to 7 layers of ox-hide (r(i=noi/, Il. 13.804); these were covered by a plate of metal, and the whole was firmly united by rivets, which projected on the outer, convex side. The head of the central rivet, larger than the rest, was the o)mfalo/s or boss, and was usually fashioned into the form of a head. Instead of the plate above mentioned, concentric metal rings (dinwth/s, eu)/kuklos) were sometimes substituted. The rim was called a)/ntuc, and the convex surface of the shield bore some device analogous to an heraldic coat of arms, Il. 5.182, Il. 11.36, cf. Il. 5.739. The shield of Achilles (Il. 18.478-608), in describing which the poet naturally did not choose to confine himself to realities, does not correspond exactly to either of the two a)spi/des described above.
a)spisth/s = a)spidiw/ths, only pl., warriors. (Il.)
*)asplhdw/n: a town in Boeotia, Il. 2.511†.
a)-spoudi=/ (spoudh/): without exertion; always in the phrase mh\ ma\n a)spoudi=/ ge, at least not ‘without a struggle,’ Il. 8.512, Il. 15.476, Il. 22.304.
a)/ssa = tina/.
a(/ssa = a(/ tina.
*)assa/rakos: son of Tros, and grandfather of Anchīses, Il. 20.232 f.
a)=sson (comp. of a)/gxi), double comp. a=)ssote/rw: nearer, w. gen.; usually with i)e/nai, Il. 1.335.
a)/staxus, uos: ear of grain, pl., Il. 2.148†.
a)-stemfh/s, e/s: firm, unyielding, Il. 2.344; as adv., still, Il. 3.219.
*)aste/rion: a town in Thessaly, Il. 2.735†.
*)asteri/s (Star Island): a (probably fabulous) islet S. of Ithaca, Od. 4.846†.
a)stero/eis (a)sth/r): starry; ou)rano/s, Il. 4.44, etc.; then, ‘spangled,’ ‘star-like,’ qw/rhc, Il. 16.134; do/mos, Il. 18.370.
*)asteropai=os: son of Pelagon, leader of the Paeonians, Il. 12.102, Il. 21.179.
a)steroph/: lightning. (Il.)
a)sterophth/s: god of the lightning, epith. of Zeus. (Il.)
a)sth/r, e/ros, dat. pl. a)stra/si: star; a)sth\r o)pwri=no/s, the dog-star, Sirius, Il. 5.5; of a ‘shooting-star,’ Il. 4.75.
a)sto/s (a)/stu): citizen, pl., Il. 11.242 and Od. 13.192.
a)stra/galos: neck-vertebra, Od. 10.560; pl., game of dice (cf. our ‘jack-stones’), Il. 23.88. (See cut, after an ancient painting in Resina.)
a)stra/ptw, aor. part. a)stra/ya=s: lighten, hurl lightning. (Il.)
a)/stron (a)sth/r): constellation, only pl., ‘stars.’

a)/stu, eos (va/stu): city (esp. as a fortified dwelling - place); ei)s o(/ ken a)/stu kixei/omen *)ili/ou i=(rh=s, Il. 21.128; pollw=n d' a)nqrw/pwn i)/den a)/stea, Od. 1.3; o(/ppws ke po/lin kai\ a)/stu saw/seis, i. e. his country and its capital, Il. 17.144, cf. Od. 6.177 f.—a)/stude, to the city.
*)astu/alos: a Trojan, Il. 6.29†.
*)astu-a/nac (Master of the City): Astyanax, a name given by the Trojans to Scamandrius, the son of Hector, in honor of his father, Il. 6.402 f.
a)stu - bow/ths (boa/w): calling throughout the city, Il. 24.701†.
*)astu/-noos: (1) a Trojan leader, Il. 5.144†.—(2) a Trojan, son of Protiāon, Il. 15.455†.
*)astu - o/xeia: mother of Tlepolemus, Il. 2.658†.
*)astu-o/xh: mother of Ascalaphus and Ialmenus, Il. 2.513†.
*)astu/-pulos: a Paeonian, Il. 21.209†.
a)sufhlo/s: doubtful word, rude, Il. 9.647 (as adv.) and Il. 24.767.
a) - sfale/ws (a)sfalh/s): without swerving, steadily; a)goreu/ein, ‘without faltering,’ Od. 8.171.
a)-sfalh/s (sfa/llw): only neut. as adv. (= a)sfale/ws), a)sfale\s ai)ei/, ‘forever without end,’ Od. 6.42.
*)asfali/wn: a servant of Menelāus, Od. 4.216†.
a)sfa/ragos: windpipe, Il. 22.328†.

a)sfodelo/s: leimw/n, the asphodel meadow, in the nether world, Od. 11.539. (The asphodel is a liliaceous plant, with pale bluish flowers; it was planted about graves in Greece by the ancients as now.) (Od.)

a)sxala/w, a)sxa/llw: be impatient, vexed, fret; with causal gen. (Od. 19.159, 534), also with part., Od. 1.304, Od. 2.193 ; ge/ronta magis e)/xon a)sxalo/wnto/, ‘beside himself’ with grief, Il. 22.412.
a)/-sxetos (sxei=n) and a)a/sxetos: irresistible; pe/nqos, ‘overpowering,’ Il. 16.549, Il. 24.708.
*=)aswpo/s: a river in Boeotia, Il. 4.383.
a) - ta/lantos (ta/lanton): like in weight, equal.
a)tala/-frwn (a)talo/s, frh/n): merryhearted, Il. 6.400†.
a)talo/s (a)ta/llw): frisking, merry; a)tala\ frone/ontes, ‘light-hearted,’ Il. 18.567, cf. Od. 11.39.

a)ta/r (a)ta=/r, e 108, Od. 19.273): but yet, but, however; freq. corresponding to me/n in the previous clause, Il. 1.166, Il. 6.86, 125; to h)= mh/n, Il. 9.58; but often without preceding particle, and sometimes with no greater adversative force than de/, e. g. ma/y, a)ta\r ou) kata\ ko/smon, i. e. ou)de\ kata\ k., Il. 2.214, Od. 3.138; in apod., like de/, Il. 12.144. a)ta/r is always the first word in the clause, but a voc. is not counted, *(/ektor, a)ta\r su/ moi/ e)ssi path\r kai\ po/tnia mh/thr, ‘but thou, Hector.’ With this arrangement there is nothing peculiar in the force of the particle; it refers here, as always, to what precedes (expressed or implied) even when the voc. introduces the whole passage, *(/ektor, a)ta/r pou e)/fhs, ‘doubtless thou didst think,’ etc., Il. 22.331, cf. Od. 4.236. (Weakened form of au)ta/r).
a)-tarbh/s, e/s (ta/rbos): fearless, Il. 13.299†.
a)-ta/rbhtos (tarbe/w): undaunted, Il. 3.63†.
a)tarpito/s (a)tarpo/s): path, Il. 18.565 and Od. 17.234.
a)tarpo/s: by-path, path, Il. 17.743 and Od. 14.1.
a)tarthro/s: doubtful word, harsh, abusive, mischievous, Il. 1.223, Od. 2.243.
a)tasqali/h (a)ta/sqalos): pl., criminal folly, infatuation, wickedness, Od. 1.7.
a)tasqa/llw: act wickedly, wantonly, Od. 18.57 and Od. 19.88.
a)ta/sqalos (cf. a=)/th): wicked, wanton, Il. 22.418; mostly of actions, Od. 22.314; esp. in pl., a)ta/sqala r(e/zein, mhxana=sqai, Od. 3.207.
a(/te, a(/ te: never as adv. in Homer, see o(/s te.
a)-teirh/s, e/s (tei/rw): not to be worn out, unwearied, unyielding; xalko/s, and of persons, me/nos, kradi/h, Il. 3.60.
a)-teleu/thtos (teleuta/w): unfinished, unaccomplished, unfulfilled.
a)-telh/s, e/s (te/los): unaccomplished, unconsummated, Od. 17.546†.
a)te/mbw: stint, disappoint, Od. 20.294, Od. 21.312 ; qu=mo/n, Od. 2.90; pass., be deprived, disappointed of, go without; tino/s, *l 705, Il. 23.445.
a)/ter: without, apart from, w. gen.
a)-te/ramnos (tei/rw): hard, inexorable, Od. 23.167†.
a)-terph/s, e/s (te/rpw): joyless.
a)/-terpos = a)terph/s, Il. 6.285†.
a=)te/w: only part., a=)te/onta, foolhardy, Il. 20.332†.

a=)/th (a)a/w): ruinous mischief, ruin, usually in consequence of blind and criminal folly, infatuation; h)= me mal' ei)s a=)/thn koimh/sate nhle/i u(/pnw| (addressed to the gods by Odysseus; while he slept his comrades had laid hands on the cattle of Helius), Od. 12.372, cf. Il. 2.111, Il. 8.237 ; to\n d' a=)/th fre/nas ei(=le, ‘blindness’ (cf. what follows, sth= de\ tafw/n: Patroclus stands dazed by the shock received from Apollo), Il. 16.805 ; ei(/nek' e)mei)=o kuno\s kai\ *)aleca/ndrou e(/nek) a=)/ths (said by Helen), Il. 6.356; pl., e)ma=\s a=)/ta=s kate/lecas, Il. 9.115, *k 391, Il. 19.270. The notions of folly and the consequences of folly are naturally confused in this word, cf. Il. 24.480, and some of the passages cited above.— Personified, *=)/ath, Ate, the goddess of infatuation, pre/sba *dio\s quga/nhr *=)/ath, h(\ pa/ntas a)a=tai, Il. 19.91 (see what follows as far as v. 130, also Il. 9.500 ff.).
a)-ti/zw (ti/w): part., unheeding, Il. 20.166†.
a)-ti=ma/zw (ti=mh/), ipf. iter. a)ti=ma/zeskon, aor. h)ti=/masa: treat with disrespect, dishonor, maltreat; *)atrei/dhs h)ti=masen a=/rhth=ra (the best reading, vulg. h)ti=/mhs)), Il. 1.11.
a)-ti=ma/w = a)ti=ma/zw.
a) - ti=/mhtos: unhonored, slighted, Il. 9.648 and Il. 16.59.
a)-ti=mi/h: contumely, only pl., a)ti=mi=)h|sin (the quantity a necessity of the rhythm), Od. 13.142†.
a)/-ti=mos, comp. -o/teros, sup. -o/tatos =a)ti=/mhtos, also without compensation; as adv., Od. 16.431, see ti=mh/.
a)tita/llw, aor. a)ti/thla: rear, cherish; of children, Il. 24.60, etc.; of animals, ‘feed,’ ‘keep,’ Il. 6.271, Od. 15.174.
a)/-ti=^tos (ti/w): unpaid, unavenged.
*)/a-tla=s (tlh=nai): Atlas, the father of Calypso, a god who knows the depths of the sea and holds the pillars that keep heaven and earth asunder, Od. 1.52, Od. 7.245.
a)/-tlhtos (tlh=nai): unendurable, Il. 9.3 and Il. 19.367.
a)=tos (for a)/-a=tos, a=)/w): insatiable.
a)trapito/s = a)tarpito/s, path, Od. 13.195†.
*)atrei/dhs, a=o or ew: son of Atreus, Atrīdes, meaning Agamemnon when not otherwise specified; dual. *)atrei/da=, pl. *)atrei=dai, the sons of Atreus, the Atrīdœ, Agamemnon and Menelāus.
*)atrei/wn, wnos = *)atrei/dhs.
a)treke/ws: unerringly, truly.
a)trekh/s, e/s: only neut., as adv., exactly, true, real.
a)/trema(s) (tre/mw): adv., motionless, quiet, still.
*)atreu/s, e/os: Atreus, son of Pelops and Hippodamīa, father of Agamemnon and Menelāus; his sceptre, Il. 2.105.
a)/-triptos (tri=/bw): unworn by toil, unhardened, soft, Od. 21.151†.
a)/-tromos (tre/mw): intrepid, fearless. (Il.)
a)tru/getos: barren; epith. of the sea, and once of the sky, Il. 17.425. This is the ancient and traditional interpretation of the word, but according to some moderns it means restless.
*)atru=tw/nh: Atrytōne, a name of Athēna, perhaps meaning the ‘unwearied,’ ‘invincible;’ always *dio\s te/kos *)atrutw/nh, Il. 2.157.
a)/tta: a term of endearment used in addressing elders, ‘father,’ ‘uncle.’

a)tu/zomai, only part. pres. and aor. a)tuxqei/s: bewildered, dazed, distraught, the effect of fear, grief, etc.; h(/meq' a)tuzo/menai, ‘shocked,’ while the suitors were being killed, Od. 23.42 ; a)tuzome/nhn a)pole/sqai, in a ‘dead fit,’ Andromache, Il. 22.474; w. acc., patro\s o)/yin a)tuxqei/s, ‘terrified at,’ Il. 6.468 ; a)tuzo/menoi fobe/onto, Il. 6.41; hence with motion implied in the word itself, (i(/ppw) a)tuzome/nw pedi/oio, ‘scouring wildly’ o'er the plain, p. gen. of place, Il. 6.38, etc.
*)atumnia/dhs: son of Atymnius, Mydon, Il. 5.581†.
*)atu/mnios: (1) father of Mydon, a Paphlagonian, Il. 5.581.—(2) son of Amisodarus, of Caria, Il. 16.317, 328.

au)=: again, on the contrary, on the other hand; temporal, Il. 1.540, Od. 20.88, etc.; oftener denoting sequence or contrast, d' au)=, deu/teron au(=, nu=n au)=, etc.; sometimes correl. to me/n, *l 109, Od. 4.211, and scarcely stronger than de/, *b 493, Il. 11.367.
au)ai/nw (au)/w): only aor. pass. part. au)anqe/n, when it was dry, Od. 9.321†.
au)ga/zomai (au)xh/): discern, Il. 23.458†.
*au)geiai/: (1) a town in Laconia, Il. 2.583†.—(2) in Locris, Il. 2.532†.
*au)gei/a=s: Augēas, a king in Elis, known from the cleansing of his stables by Heracles; father of Agasthenes, Phyleus, and Agamēde, Il. 11.701, 739.
au)gh/, h=s: beam, gleam, glow; esp. of the sun, u(p' au)ga=\s *)heli/oio, Od. 2.181.
*au)ghia/dhs: son of Augēas, Agasthenes, Il. 2.624†.

au)da/w, impf. au)/da=, ipf. 3 sing. hu)/da=, aor. iter. au)dh/saske, part. au)dh/sa=s: speak loud and clear, cf. au)dh/, *ste/ntori ei)same/nh megalh/tori, xalkeofw/nw|, | o(\s to/son au)dh/sasx' o(/son a)/lloi penth/konta, Il. 5.786; tou= de\ *poseida=/wn mega/l) e)/kluen au)dh/santos, ‘heard his loud boastful utterance,’ Od. 4.505 ; o(moklh/sa=s e)/pos hu)/da=, Il. 6.54; often w. acc. in the phrase a)nti/on hu)/da=, ‘addressed.’

au)dh/, h=s: voice, properly the human voice with reference to its pleasing effects; tou= kai\ a)po\ glw/sshs me/litos gluki/wn r(e/en au)dh/, of Nestor as orator, Il. 1.249 ; qeoi=s e)nali/gkios au)dh/n, Phemius, the minstrel, Od. 1.371; said of a bird, h(\ d) (the bowstring) u(po\ ka=lo\n a)/eise, xeli=do/ni ei)ke/lh au)dh/n, Od. 21.411.

au)dh/eis, essa: possessed of voice, voiceful; esp. with regard to the power of song, Circe, Od. 10.136, Calypso, Od. 12.449, Ino, Od. 5.334 ; *leukoqe/h, h(\ pri\n me\n e)/hn broto\s au)dh/essa, i. e. a ‘tuneful’ mortal, not a ‘mortal speaking with human voice;’ of Xanthus, the horse of Achilles, au)dh/enta d' e)/qhke qea=/, ‘endowed him with voice’ (i. e. human as contrasted with equine utterance).
au)eru/w (a)na/, veru/w), aor. au)e/rusa: draw up or back; of drawing a bow, Il. 8.325; loosening props, Il. 12.261; and esp. of bending back the heads of victims, for the knife, Il. 1.459.
au)=q): (1) = au)=te, before an aspirated vowel.—(2) = au)=qi before a vowel.

au)=qi: (right) there, (right) here, Il. 1.492, Il. 7.100; often foll. by a prep. with subst., specifying the place, au)=qi par' a)/mmi, Il. 9.427; au)=qi menw= meta\ toi=si, Il. 10.62; au)=q) e)pi\ ta/frw|, Il. 11.48; e)n *lakedai/-
moni au)=qi, Il. 3.244; of time, on the spot, i. e. ‘at once,’ Od. 18.339, Il. 5.296.
au)iaxo/s (viaxh/): shouting loudly together, pl., Il. 13.41†.
au)/leios: belonging to the au)lh/, of the court. (Od.)

au)lh/, h=s: court - enclosure, court, court yard, farm-yard; the au)lh/ of a mansion had gate-way, portico, stables, slave-quarters, altar, and rotunda (qo/los); see table III. An au)lh/ is attributed to the cabin of Eumaeus, the swine-herd, Od. 14.5, to the tent of Achilles, Il. 24.452, and even to the cave of Polyphēmus, Od. 9.239.
au)/lh (au)lo/s): music of flutes; au)/lh| a conjectural reading for au)lh=|, Od. 10.10.
au)li/zomai (au)lh/): only part., au)lizomena=wn, being penned in, of cattle and swine. (Od.)
au)=lis, idos: place of rest; ‘encampment,’ Il. 9.232; ‘roosting-place,’ Od. 22.470.
*au)li/s: Aulis, a town in Boeotia, on the Euripus, the rendezvous of the Greeks before sailing for Troy, Il. 2.303.

au)lo/s: flute, a wind-instrument more like the clarinet than the modern transverse flute, Il. 18.495, Il. 10.13; then any tube, channel, as the ‘socket’ in which the point of a lance was fitted, Il. 17.297; ‘holes’ or ‘eyes,’ receiving the tongue of a buckle, Od. 19.227; of a ‘jet’ of blood, Od. 22.18.
au)lw=pis, idos (au)lo/s): with upright tube, to receive the plume of a helmet, Il. 5.182. (Il.) (See cuts 16, 17.)
au)=os: dry, neut. as adv., of sound, hoarse, grating, Il. 12.160, Il. 13.441.
a)/-upnos: sleepless.
au)/rh (a)/vhmi): breeze, Od. 5.469†.
au)/rion: to-morrow; e)s au)/rion, au)/rion e)/s, Il. 7.318.
a)ustale/os (au)=os): dry, unanointed, unkempt, squalidus, Od. 19.327†.
au)t - a/gretos (au)to/s, a)gre/w): selftaken, attainable, ‘if men could have every wish,’ Od. 16.148†.

au)=tar (au)=te, a)/ra): but, however, marking a contrast or transition like de/, and weightier than de/ only in being disyllabic and not post-positive (cf. h)/toi); answering to h)/toi or me/n in a previous clause, Od. 24.155, Il. 1.68, etc.; often at the beginning of a sentence without distinct correlation, esp. au)=tar e)pei/, Il. 3.1.

au)=te (au)= te): again, on the other hand, however, but; ei)/ pote dh\ au)=te, Il. 1.340; o(ppo/t) a)\n au)=te, Od. 8.444, and esp. in questions of impatient tone, ti/pt' au)=t) ei)lh/louqas, Il. 1.202; te/wn au)=te brotw=n e)s gai=an i(ka=/nw, ‘whose country am I come to now?’ Od. 6.119; very often denoting contrast or transition, like de/, nu=n au)=te, e)/nq' au)=te, d) au)=te, and correlating to me/n, Il. 3.241; also in apod., Il. 4.321.

a)u=te/w (a)u=th/), only ipf. a)u=/tei, a)u=/teun: call aloud; with makro/n, me/ga, *u 50, Il. 21.582; with acc., Il. 11.258; of inanimate things, sound, resound; ko/ruqes, Il. 12.160. Cf. au)/ Od. 24.2.
au)t-h=mar: on the same day.
au)ti/ka (au)to/s): forthwith, straightway.

au)=tis (au)=), Attic au)=qis: again, back again, anew; often pa/lin au)=tis, a)\y au)=tis, deu/teron au)=tis, and standing alone, au)=tis i)w/n, going ‘back,’ Il. 8.271, etc.; tau=ta metafraso/mesqa kai\ au)=tis, by and by, Il. 1.140; also merely transitional, toi=s d' au)=tis mete/eipe, o 439, Od. 18.60.

a)utmh/: breath, blast, fumes; of breathing, Il. 9.609, Il. 10.89; wind, Od. 11.400, 407 (from the bellows, Il. 18.471); fire, Il. 21.366, Od. 9.389 (smoky, Od. 16.290); savors, fragrances, Il. 12.369, Il. 14.174, Od. 12.369.
a)utmh/n, e/nos: breath, blast; of men and winds, Il. 23.765, Od. 3.289.
au)to - di/daktos (dida/skw): selftaught, epith. of the inspired bard, Od. 22.347†.
au)to/ - dion (au)to/s): on the spot, straightway, Od. 8.449†.
au)to/-etes (ve/tos): in the same year, Od. 3.322†.
au)to/q) =au)to/qi.
au)to/qen: from (right) there or here, from where he or she was; (mete/eipen) au)to/qen e)c e(/drhs, ou)d' e)n me/ssoisin a)nasta=/s, *t 77, Od. 21.420.
au)to/qi: (right) there, (right) here, on the spot; often with more definite limitation following, au)to/qi mi/mnei | a)grw=|, Od. 11.187, so e)n w. dat., Od. 9.29, Il. 9.617.
au)to - kasignh/th: own sister, Od. 10.137†.
au)to-kasi/gnhtos: own brother. (Il.)
*au)to/ - lukos: Autolycus, father of Anticlēa, and grandfather of Odysseus; he dwelt on Parnassus and was gifted with the sly arts that were inherited by his grandson, Od. 19.394 -466, Il. 10.267.
au)to/-matos (root ma, me/maa): selfmoving, moving of oneself. (Il.)
*au)to-me/dwn: son of Diōres, charioteer of Achilles, Il. 17.536, Il. 16.145.
*au)to - no/h: a handmaid of Penelope, Od. 18.182†.
*au)to/-noos: (1) a Greek, Il. 11.301†.— (2) a Trojan, Il. 16.694†.
au)to-nux<*>i=/: this very night, Il. 8.197.

au)to/s, h/, o/: same, self.—(1) pronoun of identity, h)=rxe de\ tw=| au)th
 o(do
 h(/n per oi( a)/lloi (the same way, like th
 au)th/n in Attic), Od. 8.107, Il. 12.225. (The article when joined to au)to/s in Homer is demonstrative, e. g. tw\ d' au)tw\ ma/rturoi e)/stwn, ‘these’ two men themselves, not ‘the same’ two, Il. 1.338, Od. 16.334; once occurs crasis, wu(to\s a)nh/r, ‘that’ same man, Il. 5.396).—(2) pronoun of emphasis and antithesis, as one person is contrasted with another, or with some possession or part of himself, the extent to which this antithetic idea is carried forming a highly characteristic feature of the Homeric style; polla=\s d' i=)fqi=/mous yu=xa=\s *)/aidi proi+/ayen | h(rw/wn, au)tou\s de\ e(lw/ria teu=xe ku/nessin, hurled their souls to Hades, but made them, i. e. their bodies, a prey to dogs, Il. 1.4 ; ei)seno/hsa bih
 *(hra=klhei/hn | ei)/dwlon: au)to\s de\ met' a=)qana/toisi qeoi=sin | te/rpetai, ktl., Heracles himself in heaven, his ghost in hell, Od. 11.602 ; dhsa/ntwn se o)rqo
 e)n i(stope/dh|, e)k d' au)tou= pei/rat) a)nh/fqw, let them tie you standing up on the mast-block, with the rope ends fastened to (the mast) itself, Od. 12.51 ; *pria/moio do/mon cesth=|s ai)qou/sh|si tetugme/non, au)ta e)n au)tw=|, i. e. in the house itself, as distinguished from its corridor, Il. 6.243, and so continually. (The occurrence of au)to/s in the oblique cases as simple unemphatic personal pronoun is denied altogether to Homer by some scholars, and in most of the seeming instances an emphasis or contrast may be detected, as clearly e. g. Il. 3.365; still the approach to the later use is sometimes uncomfortably close, e. g. Il. 2.347).— Here belong such expressions as u(po\ lo/fon au)to/n, ‘directly’ under the plume, Il. 13.615, Od. 10.158 ; du/w i(/ppous au)toi=sin o)/xesfin, ‘chariot and all,’ Il. 8.290 ; au)to/s per e)w/n, ‘by himself,’ i. e. alone, Il. 8.99, Od. 14.8, 450.—Here, too, belong the reflexive uses, Od. 4.247, etc.; au)tw=n ga a)pwlo/meq' a)fradi/h|sin, by our own folly, Od. 10.27 ; th
 au)tou= file/ei, loves his own, Il. 9.342, Od. 2.125; similarly, au)tw=n ga sfete/rh|sin a)tasqali/h|sin o)/lonto, Od. 1.7; ta\ s(a\) au)th=s e)/rga ko/mize, Il. 6.490, ‘their own,’ ‘thine own.’
au)to-stadi/h (i(/sthmi): hand to hand fight, Il. 13.325†.
au)to-sxeda/ = au)tosxedo/n.
au)to-sxedi/h (sxedo/n): close combat; adv., au)tosxedi/hn, ‘at close quarters.’
au)to-sxedo/n: hand to hand, ma/xesqai, etc.

au)tou= = au)to/qi. Usually with following specification, au)tou= e)ni\ *troi/h|, Il. 2.237; a)lla/ pou au)tou= | a)grw=n, somewhere there ‘in the country,’ i. e in the island of Ithaca, though not in town, Od. 4.639; with temporal effect, Il. 15.349, Il. 21.425, Od. 4.703, Od. 18.212.
au)to/fi(n) = au)tw=|, Il. 3.255; = au)tw=n, Il. 11.44; = au)toi=s, Il. 13.42; always with a preposition.
*au)to/-fonos: father of Polyphontes, of Thebes, Il. 4.395†.
au)to-xo/wnos (xo/anos, melting-pit): just as it was cast, of a massive quoit in its rough state, Il. 23.826†.

au)/tws (au)to/s): in the same way, just as it is, merely, in vain; a word admitting great variety of paraphrase, but in signification always answering to some force of au)to/s. gumno
 e)o/nta | au)/tws w(/s te gunai=ka, all unarmed, ‘exactly’ like a woman, Il. 22.125 ; a)/puron le/bhta, leuko
 e)/t' au)/tws, still ‘quite’ bright, Il. 23.268 ; o)knei/w d' i(/ppwn e)pibai/nemen, a)lla\ kai\ au)/tws | a)nti/on ei)=m' au)tw=n, ‘just as I am,’ Il. 5.256 ; h(\ de\ kai\ au)/tws m' ai)e
 neikei=, even ‘as it is,’ i. e. without special
provocation, Il. 1.520 ; a)ll' au)/tws a)/xqos a)rou/rhs, a ‘mere’ burden to the ground, Od. 20.379 ; au)/tws ga/r r() e)pe/ess' e)ridai/nomen, ‘just as we do,’ i. e. to no purpose, Il. 2.342.
au)xe/nios (au)xh/n): of the neck; te/nontes, Od. 3.450†.
au)xh/n, e/nos: neck, of men and animals.
au)xme/w (au)xmo/s): be dry, unanointed, squalid, Od. 24.250†.

au)/w (2), ipf. au)=on, aor. h)/u=sa, a)/u=sa, inf. a)u=sai, part. a)u=/sa=s: call aloud, with exertion of the voice, halloo; often with makro/n, ‘afar,’ Il. 3.81, etc.; e)/nqa sta=s' h)/u=se qea=\ me/ga te deino/n te | o)/rqia, Il. 11.10; with acc., Il. 11.461, Il. 13.477, Od. 9.65; of inanimate things, resound, ring, Il. 13.409. Cf. a)u=th/.

a)f-aire/w, a)po-aire/w, aor. a)fei=lon, mid. pres. imp. a)poai/reo, fut. inf. a)fairh/sesqai, aor., 2 sing., a)fei/leo, pl. a)fe/lesqe: take away (tino/s ti), mid., for oneself, esp. forcibly or wrongfully (tina/ ti or tini/ ti); w(s e)/m' a)fairei=tai *xru=shi/da *foi=bos *)apo/llwn, Il. 1.182; au)ta\r o(\ toi=sin a)fei/leto no/stimon h)=mar, Od. 1.9.

a)f-amarta/nw, only aor. 2 a)fa/marte and a)ph/mbrote: miss (fail to hit), lose; kai\ ba/len, ou)d' a)fa/marte, Il. 11.350; e)moi) de/ ke ke/rdion ei)/h | seu= a)famartou/sh| xqo/na du=/menai, ‘bereft’ of thee, Il. 6.411.
a)f-amarto-eph/s: missing the point in speech, ‘rambling speaker,’ Il. 3.215†.
a)f-anda/nw: displease; mu=qos a)fanda/nei, Od. 16.387†.
a)/-fantos (fai/nw): unseen, ‘leaving no trace,’ (Il.)
a)/far: instantly, at once, Od. 2.169, Il. 17.417 ; w)=|d' a)/far, Il. 10.537; a)/far au)ti/ka, Il. 23.593.
*)afareu/s: a Greek, son of Calētor, Il. 13.541.
a)f-arpa/zw: seize away from, aor. inf., Il. 13.189†.
a)fa/rteros (comp. of a)/far): swifter, Il. 23.311†.
a)fauro/s, -o/teros, -o/tatos: insignificant, weakly, Il. 7.235, Od. 20.110.
a(fa/w (a(/ptw): only part., a(fo/wnta, busy with handling; to/ca, Il. 6.322†.
*)afei/da=s: an assumed, fictitious name, Od. 24.305†.
a)fei/h: see a)fi/hmi.
a)/fenos, neut.: large possessions, riches.
a)fe/cw, a)fe/comai: see a)pe/xw.
a)/f-hmai: only part., a)fh/menos, sitting apart, Il. 15.106†.
a)fh/twr, oros (a)fi/hmi): the archer, viz. Apollo, Il. 9.404†.
a)/-fqitos (fqi/w): unwasting, imperishable.

a)f-i/hmi, imp. 2 pl. a)fi=/ete, part. fem. a)fi=eisai, ipf. 3 sing. a)fi/ei, fut. a)fh/sw, aor. a)fe/hka, a)fh=ka, 3 du. a)fe/thn, subj. a)fe/h|, opt. a)fei/h, part. a)fei/s, mid. ipf. a)fi=/eto: let go from.—I. act., of sending away persons, Il. 1.25, Il. 2.263; hurling missiles, lightning, Il. 8.133; lowering a mast, i(sto\n proto/noisi, Il. 1.434: grapes shedding the flower, a)/nqos a)fi=ei=sai, Od. 7.126; met., of ‘dismissing’ thirst, Il. 11.642; ‘relaxing’ force, Il. 13.444. —II. mid., deirh=s d' ou)/ pw pa/mpan a)fi=/eto ph/xee leukw/, ‘let go her’ arms from his neck, Od. 23.240.
a)f - ika=/nw: be come to, arrived at (from somewhere); deu=ro, pro/s ti, always with perf. signif., exc. Od. 9.450, and in Od. always w. acc. of end of motion.

a)f-ikne/omai, fut. a)fi/comai, aor. a)fi=ko/mhn, perf. inf. a)fi=xqai: come to, arrive at, reach (one point from another); usually w. acc., sometimes w. prepositions; tou=ton (di/skon) nu=n a)fi/kesqe, ‘come up to’ that now, Od. 4.255; met., o(/te m' a)/lgos a)fi=/keto, Il. 18.395.

a)f - i/sthmi, aor. 2 a)pe/sthn, perf. a)fe/state, a)festa=si, opt. a)festai/h, part. a)festa=w/s, plup. a)festh/kei, a)fe/stasan, mid. aor. 1 subj. a)posth/swntai: of act. only intrans. forms occur, stand off or away (tino/s); pali/norsos, Il. 3.33; no/sfin, Od. 11.544; mid., aor. 1, causative, get weighed out for oneself, ‘demand pay for,’ xrei=os, Il. 13.745.
a)/flaston: aplustre, an ornamental knob on the stern of a ship, Il. 15.717†.
a)floismo/s: foam, froth, Il. 15.607†.
a)fneio/s (a)/fenos), -o/teroi, -o/tatos: wealthy, rich in (tino/s).

a)f-opli/zw: only mid. ipf. a)fwpli/-
zonto, divested themselves of their armor; e)/ntea, Il. 23.26†.
a)f - orma/omai, only aor. pass. opt. and part. a)formhqei=en, -qe/ntes: start from, depart, Il. 2.794, Od. 2.375.
a(fo/wnta: see a(fa/w.
a)-frade/w: be foolish.
a)-fradh/s, e/s (fra/zomai): inconsiderate, foolish, senseless, Od. 2.282, Od. 11.476.— Adv., a)frade/ws.
a) - fradi/h (fra/zomai): ignorance, folly; dat. sing., Il. 2.368, elsewhere only dat. plural.
a)-frai/nw (frh/n): be senseless, mad, foolish.
a)fre/w (a)fro/s): foam; only ipf. a)/freon de\ sth/qea (sc. i(/ppoi), ‘their breasts were covered with foam,’ Il. 11.282†.
a)-frh/twr (frh/trh): without clan or clansmen; a)frh/twr, a)qe/mistos, a)ne/stios, ‘friendless, lawless, homeless,’ Il. 9.63†.

*)afrodi=/th: Aphrodīte (Venus), goddess of love, daughter of Zeus and Diōne, Il. 5.370, and in the Odyssey wife of Hephaestus, Od. 8.267 ff.; her magic girdle described, Il. 14.214 ff.; attended by the Graces, Od. 18.192. She favors the Trojans in the war of which she was herself the cause, and in protecting her son Aenēas receives a wound from Diomed, Il. 5.331.—The name of Aphrodīte is used once by personification for her works, love, Od. 22.444. Cf. *)/arhs.
a)-frone/w: be foolish, part., Il. 15.104†.
a)fro/s: foam. (Il.)
a)- frosu/nh: folly; pl., foolish behavior.
a)/-frwn (frh/n): thoughtless, foolish.
a)/-fullos (fu/llon): leafless, Il. 2.425†.
a)fu/cein: see a)fu/ssw.
a)fusgeto/s: mud, Il. 11.495†.

a)fu/ssw, fut. a)fu/cw, aor. h)/fusa, part. a)fu/ssa=s, mid. aor. h)fusa/mhn, a)fussa/mhn, part. a)fussa/menos: draw (water or wine), mid., for oneself, often by dipping from a larger receptacle into a smaller (a)po\ or e)/k tinos, or tin<*>s); oi)noxo/ei gluku\ ne/ktar, a)po\ krhth=ros a)fu/sswn, for the other gods, Il. 1.598 ; a)fussa/menoi me/lan u=(/dwr, for their own use, on ship-board, Od. 4.359 ; dia\ (adv.) d' e)/ntera xalko\s | h)/fuse, pierced and ‘opened,’ (cf. ‘dip into’ him), Il. 13.508, Il. 17.315, Il. 14.517; met., a)/fe- nos kai\ plou=ton a)fu/cein, ‘draw off,’ i. e. accumulate riches for another man, Il. 1.171.
*)axaiai/: Achaean women. (Od.)
*)axaia/s, a/dos: Achaean woman.
*)axaiiko/s: Achaean.
*)axaii/s, i/dos: Achaean (gai=a), and without gai=a, Achaea, i. e. Northern Greece; pl., as subst., Achaean women; contemptuously, *)axaii/des, ou)ke/t' *)axaioi/, *b 235, Il. 7.96.

*)axaioi/: the Achaeans, the chief tribe of Greeks in Thessaly, Messēne, Argos, and Ithaca; mostly as a collective appellation of the Greeks before Troy, Il. 1.2, etc.; epithets, a)rhi/filoi, di=oi, e(li/kwpes, e)uknh/mi=des, ka/rh komo/wntes, mega/qu=moi, me/nea pnei/ontes, xalkoxi/twnes.
a)/-xaris, comp. a)xari/steros: unpleasant, unwelcome, Od. 20.392†.
a)-xa/ristos =a)/xaris, neut. pl., Od. 8.236†.
*)axelw/ios = *)axelw=|os: Achelōus, river-god; (1) in Greece, Il. 21.194.—(2) in Phrygia, Il. 24.616†.
a)/xerdos: wild pear - tree, prickly pear, Od. 14.10†.
a)xerwi/s: white poplar, Il. 13.389. (Il.)
*)axe/rwn, ontos: Acheron, river of the nether world, into which flow Pyriphlegethon and Coc&ymacr;tus, Od. 10.513†.
a)xeu/w (a)/xos): only part., grieving, usually w. causal gen., Od. 14.40 ; tou=g' ei(/neka qu=mo\n a)xeu/wn, ‘troubling his soul,’ acc. of specification, Od. 21.318.
a)xe/w = a)xeu/w, only part., a)xe/wn, a)xe/ousa.
a)/xqos, eos (root a)x): burthen, weight, Il. 20.247, Od. 3.312; prov., a)/xqos a)rou/rhs, a useless ‘burden to the ground,’ Il. 18.104, Od. 20.379.

*)axileu/s, *)axilleu/s, h=os, dat. -h=i and -ei=: Achilles, son of Peleus and Thetis, king of the Myrmidons, and the hero of the Iliad, as announced in A 1. For his relations to Phoenix and Cheiron the centaur, see I; his destiny, Il. 9.410 ff.; expedition against Troy, Il. 2.681; forays, Il. 9.328, Il. 1.392, Il. 2.690; death
of Patroclus, Il. 16.827; mhni/dos a)po/rrhsis, Il. 19.56; *(/ektoros a)nai/resis, *x; *(/ektoros lu/tra, *w. The death of Achilles is mentioned in the Odyssey, Od. 5.310, Od. 24.37 ff. Epithets, dai+/frwn, dii/filos, qeoei/kelos, qeoi=s e)piei/kelos, pelw/rios, poda/rkhs, podw/khs, ptoli/porqos, r(hch/nwr, po/das taxu/s, and w)ku/s. (See cut from Panathenaic Amphora.)
a)xlu=/s, u/os: mist, darkness, Od. 7.41, Il. 5.127, Od. 20.357; often met., of death, swooning, Il. 5.696, Il. 16.344.
a)xlu/w: only aor., h)/xlu=se, grew dark, Od. 12.406. (Od.)
a)/xnh: foam of the sea, Il. 11.307; chaff, pl., Il. 5.499.

a)/xnumai (root a)x), ipf. a)/xnuto: be distressed, grieve; tino/s, ‘for’ some one; often w. acc. of specification (kh=r); also kh=r a)/xnutai, a)/xnutai qu=mo\s e)ni\ sth/qessin e)moi=sin, *c 38, Od. 14.170. Cf. a)kaxi/zw.
a)/-xolos: without wrath; nhpenqe/s t' a)/xolo/n te, ‘cure for grief and gall,’ Od. 4.221†.
a)/xomai = a)/xnumai, Od. 18.256 and Od. 19.129.

a)/xos, eos (root a)x): anguish, distress, for oneself or for another (tino/s), pl. a)/xea, woes; a)lla/ moi ai)no\n a)/xos se/qen e)/ssetai, w)= *mene/la=e, | ai)/ ke qa/nh|s, Il. 4.169; so a)/xos ge/neto/ tini, a)mfexu/qh, ei(=len, e)/labe/ tina, qu=mo\n i(/ka=nen, etc.; e)/xw a)/xe) a)/krita qu=mw=|, Il. 3.412, *z 413, Od. 19.167.
a)-xrei=os: useless, aimless; only neut. as adv., of the foolish look of the punished Thersites, Il. 2.269, the forced laugh of Penelope, Od. 18.163.
a) - xrhmosu/nh: indigence, want, Od. 17.502†.
a)/xri(s): quite, quite close, Il. 4.522, Il. 16.324, Il. 17.599; until, Od. 18.370.
a)xurmih/ (a)/xuron): place where chaff falls, chaff-heap, pl., Il. 5.502†.

a)/y: back, backward, back again, again; freq. with verbs of motion, a)\y i)e/nai, a)pie/nai, a)ponostei=n, stre/fein, etc.; so a)\y dido/nai, a)fele/sqai, a)\y a)re/sai, Il. 9.120; a)\y pa/lin, a)\y au)=qis, *s 280, Il. 8.335.
*)ayeudh/s: a Nereid, Il. 18.46†.
a)yi/s, i=dos: mesh, pl., Il. 5.487†.
a)yo/-rroos (r(e/w): back-flowing; of the stream of Oceanus that returns into itself, Il. 18.399†.
a)/wros (a)ei/rw), cf. mete/wros: dangling; of the feet of Scylla, Od. 12.89†.
a)/wrto: see a)ei/rw.
a)wte/w: sleep soundly, w. u(/pnon, ‘sunk in slumber,’ Il. 10.159 and Od. 10.548.
a)/wtos or a)/wton (a)/vhmi): floss, fleece; of wool, Od. 1.443, Od. 9.434; and of the ‘nap’ of linen, Il. 9.661.

div1.head: *b
div1.entryFree: ba/dhn (bai/nw): step by step, Il. 13.516†.

ba/zw, perf. pass. be/baktai: talk, speak, mostly with reference to one's way of thinking, and consequently of expressing himself; a)/rtia, pepnu=me/na, eu)= ba/zein, and often in bad sense, a)nemw/lia, metamw/nia, a)path/lia ba/zein, pa/i+s w(\s nh/pia ba/zeis, pratest, Od. 4.32 ; ou)/te pot' ei)n a)gorh=| dix) e)ba/zomen ou)/t) e)ni\ boulh=|, ‘expressed divided sentiments,’ Od. 3.127 ; e)/pos d' ei)/per ti be/baktai | deino/n, ‘if a harsh word has been spoken,’ Od. 8.408.
baqu - di=nh/eis, entos (di/nh): deepeddying.
baqu-di=/nhs = baqudi=nh/eis, epith. of rivers; *)wkeano/s, Od. 10.511.
baqu/-zwnos (zw/nh): deep-girdled, i. e. with girdle low down over the hips, epith. of women. (See cut.)
*baqu - klh=s: a Myrmidon, son of Chalcon, Il. 16.594†.
baqu/ - kolpos: deep - bosomed, i. e. with deep folds in the garment, above the girdle over which the folds fell; epith. of Trojan women. (Il.) (See cut.)
baqu/ - leimos (leimw/n): with deep (grassy) meadows, epith of towns. (Il.)
baqu-lh/ios (lh/ion): with deep (highwaving) grain, Il. 18.550†.
baqu=/nw: deepen, hollow out, Il. 23.421†.
baqu-rrei/ths, a=o (r(e/w): deep-flowing, deep-streaming; *)wkeano/s, Il. 21.195†.
baqu/-rroos =baqurrei/ths.

baqu/s, ei=a, u/, gen. baqei/hs and baqe/hs, acc. baqei=an and baqe/hn, sup. ba/qistos: deep; au)lh/, deep as regards its high environments, Il. 5.142, Od. 9.239; similarly h)iw/n, or, as others interpret, ‘deep-bayed,’ Il. 2.92; naturally w. *ta/rtaros, lh/ion, u=(/lh, a=)h/r, lai=lay, etc.; met., to\n d' a)/xos o)cu\ kata\ fre/na tu/ye baqei=an, ‘in the depths’ of his heart, altamente, Il. 19.125.
baqu/ - sxoinos: deep (grown) with reeds, Il. 4.383†.

bai/nw, fut. bh/somai, aor. 1 e)/bhsa, aor. 2 e)/bhn or bh=n, bh=, du. e)bh/thn, bh/thn, ba/thn, pl. e)/bhsan, bh=san, e)/ban, ba/n, subj. bw=, bei/w, bh/h|s, bh/h|, inf. bh/menai, perf. be/bhka, 3 pl. beba/a=si, inf. beba/men, part. bebaw/s, -w=ta, fem. bebw=sa, plup. 3 sing. bebh/kein, 3 pl. be/basan, mid. aor. (e))bh/seto: walk, step, go, perf., tread, stand (have a footing); strictly of moving the legs apart, hence to denote the attitude of standing over to protect one, a)mfi\ d' a)/r) au)tw=| bai=ne le/wn w(/s, Il. 5.299; hence, too, the phrase bh= d' i)e/nai, bh= de\ qe/ein, ‘started for to go,’ a graphic periphrasis for h)/|ei, etc.; often in the sense of departing, h(\ d' *ou)/lumpo/nde bhbh/kei, ‘was gone,’ Il. 1.221 ; e)nne/a beba/a=sin e)niautoi/, ‘have passed,’ Il. 2.134 ; ph=| dh\ sunqesi/ai te kai\ o(/rkia bh/setai h(/min, ‘what is to become of?’ Il. 2.339; so, e)/ban fe/rousai, bh= feu/gwn, etc.; bh/seto di/fron, ‘mounted,’ apparently trans., really w. acc. of limit of motion, Il. 3.262; causative, aor. 1 act., fw=tas e)ei/kosi bh=sen a)f' i(/ppwn, made to go, ‘brought’ down from their cars, Il. 16.180 ; bh=sai i(/ppous e)pi\ *bouprasi/ou, ‘bring’ horses to B., Il. 11.756.
ba/lanos, h(: acorn.
*bali/os: name of one of the horses of Achilles, Il. 19.400.

ba/llw, fut. balw=, bale/w, aor. e)/balon, ba/lon, subj. ba/lhsqa, opt. ba/loi-
sqa, plup. 3 sing. beblh/kein, pass. perf. 3 pl. beblh/atai, plup. beblh/ato (also, but only w. metaph. signif., bebo/lhto, bebolh/ato, bebolhme/nos), mid. aor. with pass. signif., blh=to, subj. blh/etai, opt. 2 sing. blei=o, part. blh/menos: throw, cast, mid., something pertaining to oneself; hence often in the sense of shoot, hit; kai\ ba/len ou)d' a)fa/marte, Il. 13.160; e(/lkos, to/ min ba/le *pa/ndaros i=)w=| (mi/n is the primary obj.), Il. 5.795; metaph., filo/thta met' a)mfote/roisi ba/lwmen, ‘strike,’ ‘conclude,’ Il. 4.16 ; su\ d' e)ni\ fresi\ ba/lleo sh=|sin, ‘bear in mind’ (note the mid.), Il. 1.297, etc. The various applications, literal and metaphorical, are numerous but perfectly intelligible.—Intrans., potamo\s ei)s a(/la ba/llwn, Il. 11.722; i(/ppoi peri\ te/rma balou=sai, Il. 23.462; mid. aor., with pass. signif., blh/menos h)\ i=)w=| h)\ e)/gxei+, Il. 8.514; pass., of the mind only, a)/xei=+ mega/lw| bebolhme/nos h)=tor, ‘stricken,’ Il. 9.9, 3, Od. 10.347.
bambai/nw: totter with fear, or, as others interpret, stammer, part., Il. 10.375†.
ba/n: see bai/nw.
ba/ptw: dip, Od. 9.392†.
barbaro/ - fwnos: rude (outlandish) of speech, Il. 2.867.
ba/rdistos: see bradu/s.
bare/w: see baru=/nw.

baru=/nw, ipf. or aor. 1 (e))ba/ru=ne, pass. aor. part. barunqei/s, perf. 2 bebarhw)s: weigh down, oppress by weight; ei(/mata ga/r r() e)ba/ru=ne, while swimming, Od. 5.321 ; ka/rh ph/lhki barunqe/n, Il. 8.388; mid., oi)/nw| bebarho/tes, ‘drunken,’ Od. 3.139, Od. 19.122.

baru/s, ei=a, u/: heavy, oftener figurative than literal; sxe/qe xei=ra barei=an, stayed his ‘heavy hand,’ suggesting power, Il. 1.219 ; barei/a=s xei=ras e)poi/sei, ‘violent’ hands, Il. 1.89; of ‘grievous’ pains, Il. 5.417; ‘dread’ fates, Il. 21.548; ‘low,’ ‘gruff’ voice, Od. 9.257, etc.; adv., baru/ and bare/a stena/xein, sigh ‘deeply.’
barustena/xwn: see baru/s, fin.
basi/leia: queen; the queen's daughter, the princess, is termed basi/leia in Od. 6.115 ; basi/leia gunaikw=n, ‘queen among women’ (cf. di=a gunaikw=n), Od. 11.258.

basileu/s, h=os: king, exercising the functions of commander - in - chief, priest, and judge; pl., basilh=es, kings, nobles, chiefs, termed skhptou=xoi, diogenei=s, diotrefei=s.—Used adjectively w. a)nh/r, Il. 3.170; a)/nac, Od. 20.194; hence comp. basileu/teros, sup. basileu/tatos, more, most kingly, princely.
basileu/w: be king or queen, Il. 6.425.
basilhi/s, i/dos: royal; ti=mh/, Il. 6.193†.
ba/skw (bai/nw): only imp., in the phrase ba/sk' i)/qi, haste and fly! addressed to the Dream-god, to Iris, and to Hermes, Il. 2.8, Il. 24.144, 336.
basta/zw: raise (move by lifting), Od. 11.594, (weigh in the hands), Od. 21.405.
ba/thn: see bai/nw.
*bati/eia (ba/tos, ‘Thorn-hill’): name of a height on the plain of Troy, before the city, Il. 2.813†.
ba/tos, h(: pl., thorn - bushes, thorns, Od. 24.230†.
beba/a=si, be/bamen, bebaw/s: see bai/nw.
bebarho/ta: see baru=/nw.
bebi/hke: see bia/zw.
beblh/atai, bebolh/ato, bebolhme/nos: see ba/llw.
bebrw/qw (parallel form of bibrw/skw): eat, devour, only opt., Il. 4.35†.
bebrwkw/s, bebrw/setai: see bibrw/skw.
be/h|, bei/omai: see be/omai.
bei/w: see bai/nw.
be/lemnon = be/los, only plural.

be/los, eos (ba/llw): missile, shot; anything thrown, whether a shaft (arrow or dart), a stone, or the footstool hurled at Odysseus in Od. 17.464; of the effects of a shot, Il. 8.513 ; be/los o)cu/, sharp ‘pang,’ Il. 11.269 ; e)k bele/wn, out of ‘range.’
be/lteros: better, only neut. sing., be/lteron (e)sti/), foll. by inf., be/lteron ei), Od. 6.282.
be/nqos, eos (baqu/s): depth, also pl., depths; qala/sshs pa=/shs be/nqea oi)=den, Od. 1.53; be/nqea u=(/lhs, Od. 17.316; a(lo\s be/nqosde, ‘into deep water,’ Od. 4.780.

be/omai, bei/omai, 2 sing. be/h|, pres. w.
fut. signif.: shall (will) live, Il. 15.194, Il. 16.852, Il. 22.22, 431, Il. 24.131.
be/reqron: abyss, chasm, Il. 8.14, Od. 12.94.
bh=: see bai/nw.
bhlo/s (bai/nw): threshold. (Il.)
bh=men, bh/menai: see bai/nw.
bh/samen, bh=se, bh/seto: see bai/nw.
*bh=ssa: a town in Locris, Il. 2.532†.
bht-a/rmwn, onos (bai/nw, root a)r): dancer, pl., Od. 8.250 and 383.

bia/zw and bia/w (bi/h), pres. 2 pl. bia/zete, perf. bebi/hka, mid. and pass. pres. bia/zetai, bio/wntai, opt. biw/|ato, ipf. bia/zeto, bio/wnto, mid. fut. bih/somai, aor. (e))bih/sato, part. bihsa/menos: force, constrain, mid., overpower, treat with violence; met., a)/xos bebi/hken *)axaiou/s, ‘overwhelmed,’ Il. 10.145; pass. bia/zesqai bele/essin, Il. 11.576; o)/nos par' a)/rouran i)w\n e)bih/sato pai=das, ‘forces his way in spite of the boys,’ Il. 11.558 ; nw=i e)bih/sato misqo/n, ‘forcibly withheld from us’ (two accusatives as w. a verb of depriving), Il. 21.451 ; yeu/dessi bihsa/menos, ‘overreaching,’ Il. 23.576.
bi/aios: violent; e)/rga, ‘deeds of violence,’ Od. 2.236.—Adv., biai/ws. (Od.)
*bi/a=s: (1) father of Laogonus and Dardanus, Il. 20.460.—(2) a leader of the Athenians, Il. 13.691.—(3) a Pylian, Il. 4.296.
bia/w: see bia/zw.

biba/w, biba/sqw, bi/bhmi (parallel forms of bai/nw), pres. part. biba/sqwn and biba=/s, acc. biba/nta and bibw=nta, fem. bibw=sa: stride along, stalk; usually makra\ biba=/s, ‘with long strides,’ u(/yi biba/nta, Il. 13.371.
bibrw/skw, perf. part. bebrwkw/s, pass. fut. bebrw/setai: eat, devour; xrh/mata bebrw/setai, Od. 2.203.

bi/h, hs, dat. bi/hfi: force, violence, in the latter sense usually pl., sing. Od. 23.31 ; bi/h kai\ ka/rtos, Od. 4.415; ou)k i=)\s ou)de\ bi/h, Od. 18.4; a)reth=| te bi/h| te, Il. 23.578; rarely of the mind, ou)k e)/sti bi/h fresi/, Il. 3.45; often in periphrases w. gen. of proper name, or w. adj., bi/h *(hra=klhei/h, *ai)nei/a=o bi/h, the might of Heracles, i. e. the mighty Heracles, etc.; bi/h|, by force, in spite of, bi/h| a)e/kontos, d 646, Il. 1.430.
*bi-h/nwr: a Trojan, Il. 11.92†.
bi/os: life. (Od.)
bio/s, oi=o: bow.
bio/w, aor. 2 inf. biw=nai, imp. 3 sing. biw/tw, mid. aor. e)biwsa/mhn: live; mid., causative, su\ ga/r m' e)biwsao, ‘didst save my life,’ Od. 8.468.
biw/|ato, bio/wntai, bio/wnto: see bia/zw.
bla/bomai: see bla/ptw.

bla/ptw, bla/bw, aor. e)/blaya, bla/ya, pass. pres. bla/betai, perf. part. beblamme/nos, aor. 1, 3 pl., e)bla/fqhsan, part. blafqei/s, aor. 2 e)bla/bhn, 3 pl. e)/blaben, bla/ben: impede, arrest; to/n ge qeoi\ bla/ptousi keleu/qou, Od. 1.195; (i(/ppw) o)/zw| e)ni\ blafqe/nte, ‘caught’ in, Il. 6.39, Il. 15.647 ; bla/ye de/ oi( fi/la gou/nata, Il. 7.271; so pass., bla/betai gou/nata, ‘totter,’ Od. 13.34 ; beblamme/non: h)=tor, ‘arrested in life's flow,’ i. e. ‘wounded in the heart,’ Il. 16.660; metaph., harm the mind., infatuate; to\n de/ tis a=)qana/twn bla(ye fre/nas, Od. 14.178; and without fre/nas, (-*)/ath) bla/ptous' a)nqrw/pous, Il. 9.507; pass., blafqei/s, Il. 9.512.
blei=o: see ba/llw.
blemeai/nw: exult haughtily in, rave with; regularly with sqe/nei+, also (qu=mo/s) peri\ sqe/nei+ blemeai/nei, the heart ‘beats high’ in its strength, Il. 17.22.
ble/faron: eyelid, only dual and pl.
blh/etai, blh/menos: see ba/llw.
blh=tron: rivet (or ring, band), Il. 15.678†.
blhxh/: bleating, Od. 12.266†.
blosuro/s: doubtful word, ferocious, Il. 7.212; perh. ‘bushy,’ Il. 15.608.
blosur-w=pis (w)/y): with ferocious looks, epith. of the Gorgon, Il. 11.36†.
blwqro/s: tall, of trees.
blw/skw (for mlw/skw, root mol), aor. 2 e)/molon, subj. mo/lh|, part. molw/n, -ou=sa; perf. me/mblwka: go, come.
bo-a/grion: shield of ox-hide, pl., Il. 12.22 and Od. 16.296.
*boa/grios: a river in Locris, Il. 2.533.

boa/w (boh/), boa/a|, boo/wsin, inf. boa=n, part. boo/wn, aor. (e))bo/hsa, part. boh/sa=s, bw/santi: shout; me/ga, makra/ (‘afar’), smerdno/n, smerdale/on, o)cu/, etc.; of things, ku=ma, h)io/nes, ‘resound,’ ‘roar,’ Il. 14.394, Il. 17.265.
bo/eios, bo/eos (bou=s): of an ox or of oxen; de/rma, neu=ra, and (‘of oxhide,’ ‘leather’) i(ma/ntes, knhmi=des, Od. 24.228.—As subst., boei/h, boe/h, ox-hide, hide.
boeu/s, h=os (bou=s): thong of ox-hide, on sails, Od. 2.426, Od. 15.291.

boh/, h=s: shout, shouting, outcry; freq. of the battle-cry, boh\n a)gaqo/s, i. e. good at fighting; also of a call to the rescue, alarm, Od. 10.118, Od. 14.226, Od. 22.77; and of a cry of pain, Il. 6.465, Od. 24.48, Od. 9.401 ; boh\n e)/xon (fo/rmigges), ‘kept sounding.’ Il. 18.495.
*bohqoi+/dhs: son of Boethoüs, Eteōneus. (Od.)
boh-qo/os (boh/, qe/w): running to the shout, battle-swift; a(/rma, Il. 17.481, and of men. (Il.)
bo-hlasi/h (bou=s, e)lau/nw): cattlelifting, Il. 11.672†.
bohtu=/s, u/os (boa/w): clamor, Od. 1.369†.
bo/qros: hole in the ground; for planting trees, for sacrificial blood, Od. 11.25; of a natural trough for washing clothes, Od. 6.92.
*boi/bh: a town in Thessaly, Il. 2.712†. —Hence *boibhi\s li/mnh, Il. 2.711†.
*boiw/tios: Boeotian; subst. *boiwtoi/, Boeotians.
bolh/ (ba/llw): throw, throwing, pelting, only pl.; o)fqalmw=n bolai/, ‘glances,’ Od. 4.150. (Od.)
bo/lomai: see bou/lomai.
bombe/w: of sounds that ring in the ears, hum; of a quoit whizzing through the air, Od. 8.190; of oars dragging and ‘rustling’ in the water, Od. 12.204.
boo/wn: see boa/w.
bore/hs, a=o, bore/w: north wind; epithets, ai)qrhgene/ths, ai)qrhgenh/s, a)kra=h/s, kraipno/s.—Personified, Boreas; *bore/hs (- -) kai\ *ze/furos, *i 5, Il. 23.195.
bo/sis (bo/skw): food; i)xqu/sin, Il. 19.268†.

bo/skw, fut. boskh/sw, mid. ipf. (e))bo/sketo, iter. boske/skonto: I. act., feed. pasture; of the herdsman, bou=s bo/sk' e)n *perkw/th|, Il. 15.548, and of the element that nourishes, (nh=sos) bo/skei ai)=gas, Od. 9.124; *)amfitri=/th kh/tea, Od. 12.97; gai=a a)nqrw/pous, Od. 11.365, etc.—II. mid., feed, graze, Od. 4.338, Od. 21.49.
bota/nh (bo/skw): fodder, grass, Il. 13.493 and Od. 10.411.
both/r, h=ros: shepherd, pl., Od. 15.504†.
boto/n: only pl., bota/, flocks, Il. 18.521†.
botru=do/n (bo/trus): in clusters; of swarming bees, Il. 2.89†.
bo/trus, uos: cluster of grapes, pl., Il. 18.562†.
bou/-botos: kine-pasture, Od. 13.246†.
bou/ - brwstis (bou=s, bibrw/skw): ravenous hunger, Il. 24.532†.
boubw/n, w=nos: groin, Il. 4.492†.
bou-ga=/i+os: braggart, bully; a term of reproach, Il. 13.824, Od. 18.79.
*bou/deion: a town in Phthia, Il. 16.572†.
boukole/w (bouko/los), ipf. iter. boukole/eskes: act., pasture, tend cattle; mid., graze, i(/ppoi e(/los ka/ta boukole/onto, Il. 20.221.
*boukoli/dhs: son of Bucolus, Sphelus, Il. 15.338†.
*boukoli/wn: a son of Laomedon, Il. 6.22†.

bouleu/w (boulh/), fut. inf. bouleuse/men, aor. (e))bou/leusa: hold counsel, deliberate, advise, devise; abs., Il. 2.347 ; boulh/n, boula=\s bouleu/ein, Il. 9.75, Il. 10.147; bouleu/ein tini, Il. 9.99; o(do\n fresi\ bouleu/ein, Od. 1.444; kako/n tini, Od. 5.179; foll. by inf., I thought to, Od. 9.299; by o(/pws, Od. 9.420; mid., devise, determine upon, a)pa/thn, *b 114, Il. 9.21.

boulh/: (1) counsel, plan, decree; boulh\ de\ kakh\ ni=/khsen e(tai/rwn, Od. 10.46; *dio\s d' e)telei/eto boulh/, the ‘will’ of Zeus, Il. 1.5 ; ou)/ toi a)/neu qeou= h(/de ge boulh/, Od. 2.372, also in plural.—(2) the council of nobles or elders, gero/ntwn, Il. 2.53, 194, 202, Od. 3.127, distinguished from the a)gora/, or assembly.

bou/lomai, bo/lomai (bo/letai, bo/lesqe, e)bo/lonto): will, wish, prefer; *trw/essi de\ bou/leto ni=kh/n, Il. 7.21, etc.; often with foll. h)/, bou/lom' e)gw\ la=o\n sw=n e)/mmenai h)\ a)pole/sqai, Il. 1.117.
bou-lu=to/s (bou=s, lu=/w): time of unyoking oxen from the plough; h)e/lios meteni/sseto boulu=to/nde, began to verge towards eventide, Il. 16.779, Od. 9.58.
bou-plh/c, h=gos (plh/ssw): ox-goad, Il. 6.135†.
*boupra/sion: an ancient town of Elis, Il. 2.615.

bou=s, boo/s, acc. bou=n (bw=n), pl. dat. bousi/ and bo/essi, acc. bo/as and bou=s: cow or ox, pl., kine, cattle; bou=s a)/rshn, Il. 7.713, Od. 19.420; tau=ros bou=s, Il. 17.389; usual epithets, a)gelai/h, a)/graulos, ei)li/podes, e(/likes, e)ri/mu=koi, o)rqo/krairai.— Also, as fem. subst., ox-hide, shield of ox-hide, acc. bw=n, Il. 7.238, 474, Il. 12.137.
bou-fone/w: slaughter cattle, Il. 7.466†.
bo-w=pis, idos (bou=s, w)/y): ox-eyed; epith. of women (cf. ‘eyes of a gazelle,’ ‘ox - eyed daisy’), Il. 7.10, Il. 18.40; often bow=pis po/tnia *(/hrh.
*bow/ths (= bou/ths, Herdsman): Boō¨tes, the constellation Arctūrus, Od. 5.272†.
bradu/s, ei=a, u/, sup. ba/rdistos: slow.
braduth/s, h=tos: slowness, Il. 19.411†.
braxi=/wn, onos: arm; prumno/s, upper arm, shoulder.

( bra/xw ), aor. e)/braxe, bra/xe: clash, crack, bray, (a word whose applications are difficult to reconcile); of armor, an axle, Il. 5.838; the earth (cf. ‘crack of doom’), Il. 21.387; a river, Il. 21.9; a door, Il. 21.49; the wounded Ares, Il. 5.859, 863 a horse, Il. 16.468.
bre/mw, mid. bre/metai: roar.
bre/fos: unborn young (of a mule foal), Il. 23.266†.
brexmo/s: forehead, Il. 5.586†.
*bria/rews: Briareus, a hundredarmed water-giant, Il. 1.403.†
briaro/s (root bri): heavy. (Il.)
bri/zw: be drowsy, nod; part. fig., ‘napping,’ Il. 4.223†.
bri-h/puos (h)pu/w): loud - shouting, Il. 13.521†.
*bri=qosu/nh (bri=/qw): weight, Il. 5.839 and Il. 12.460.
bri=qu/s, ei=a, u/: heavy, ponderous.
*bri=seu/s: Briseus, king and priest in Lyrnessus, the father of Brisēis, Il. 1.392, Il. 9.132, 274.
*bri=shi/s, i/dos: Brisēis, daughter of Briseus, a captive beloved by Achilles, Il. 1.184, Il. 19.282. (See cut, after a Panathenaic Amphora.)
brome/w: buzz, Il. 16.642†.
bro/mos (bre/mw): roar, crackling, Il. 14.396†.
bronta/w, aor. (e))bro/nthse: thunder, only with *zeu/s as subject.
bronth/, h=s: thunder.
bro/teos (broto/s): human; fwnh/, Od. 19.545†.
broto/eis (bro/tos): bloody, gory. (Il.)
broto - loigo/s: man - destroying; epith. of warriors and of Arcs.
broto/s (for mroto/s, root mer, mor): mortal; broto\s a)nh/r, brotoi\ a)/ndres, and as subst., mortal man; epithets, qnhtoi/, Od. 3.3; deiloi/, o)izu=roi/, me/ropes, e)pixqo/nios.
bro/tos: blood (from a wound), gore.
broto/w: only perf. pass. part. bebrotwme/na, made gory, Od. 11.41†.
bro/xos: noose, Od. 11.278 and Od. 22.472.
*bru=seiai/: a town in Laconia, Il. 2.583†.
bru=xa/omai, perf. w. pass. signif., be/bru=xa, part. bebru=xw/s, plup. 3 sing. e)bebru=/xein: bellow, moan of waves, and of mortally wounded men, Il. 16.486, Od. 5.412.
bru/w: teem, swell, Il. 17.56†.
brw/mh, hs (bibrw/skw): food. (Od.)
brw=sis, ios: eating, food.
brwtu=/s, u/os: food.
bu/kths (bu/zw): whistling, howling, of winds, Od. 10.20†.
busso-domeu/w (busso/s, de/mw): build in the depths, brood, always in bad sense; kaka\ fresi/, Od. 17.66. (Od.)
busso/s (= bu/qos): the deep, depths, Il. 24.80†.
bu/w: only perf. pass. part. bebusme/non, stuffed full, Od. 4.134†.
bw=los: clod, Od. 18.374†.
bwmo/s (bai/nw): step, pedestal, Od. 7.100, stand, platform, rack, Il. 8.441, and esp. altar. (See cut.)
*bw=ros: (1) a Maeonian, father of Phaestus, Il. 5.44†.—(2) son of Periēres, husband of Polydōra, the daughter of Peleus, Il. 16.177.
bw=n: see bou=s.
bw/santi: see boa/w.
bwstre/w: call loudly upon, Od. 12.124†.
bwti-a/neira: nourishing heroes, Il. 1.155†.
bw/twr, oros (bo/skw): shepherd; pl., and w. a)/ndres, *m 302, Od. 17.200.

div1.head: *g
div1.entryFree: gai=a, gh=: earth, land; distinguished from the heavens, (ki=/ones) ai(\ gai=a/n te kai\ ou)rano\n a)mfi\s e)/xousin, Od. 1.54; geographically, *)axaii/da gai=an, esp. native land, patri/da gai=an, pl., ou)de/ tis a)/llh | fai/neto gaia=/wn a)ll' ou)rano\s h)de\ qa/lassa, Od. 14.302; as substance, xuth\ gai=a, for a grave, Il. 6.464 ; kwfh\ gai=a, ‘silent dust,’ Il. 24.54; prov., u=(mei=s pa/ntes u(/dwr kai\ gai=a ge/noisqe, Il. 7.99. The form gh= is of less common occurrence, Od. 13.233, Od. 23.233, Il. 21.63.—Personified, *gai=a, Il. 15.36; *gh=, Il. 3.104, Il. 19.259.
*gaih/ios, ui(o/s: son of Earth, Od. 7.324† (cf. Od. 11.576).
gaih/ - oxos (e)/xw): earth - holding; epith. of Poseidon.
gai/w: only part., ku=/dei+ gai/wn, exulting in his glory. (Il.)
ga/la, ga/laktos: milk.
gala - qhno/s (qh=sqai): milk - sucking, sucking; nebroi/, Od. 4.336 and Od. 17.127.
*gala/teia (cf. galh/nh): Galatēa, a Nereid, Il. 18.45†.
galh/nh, hs: calm surface of the sea; a)/nemos me\n e)pau/sato, h( de\ galh/nh | e)/pleto nhnemi/h, koi/mhse de\ ku=/mata dai/mwn, Od. 12.168.
galo/ws, dat. sing. and nom. pl. galo/w|: husband's sister. Il.
gambro/s (game/w, ‘relative by marriage): son-in-law, Il. 6.249; brother-inlaw, Il. 13.464 and Il. 5.474.

game/w, fut. game/w, aor. e)/ghme, gh=me, mid. game/esqai, fut. game/ssetai, aor. opt. gh/maito, inf. gh/masq(ai): marry; act. of the man, mid. of the woman
(nubere); once mid. of the parents, ‘get a wife for their son,’ Il. 9.394.
ga/mos: marriage, wedding, marriage-feast.
gamfhlh/, h=s: only pl. and of animals, jaws. (Il.)
gamy-w=nuc, uxos (o)/nuc): with crooked claws, talons, ai)gupioi/.
gana/w: shine, be bright.
ga/numai (ga/nos), fut. ganu/ssomai: be glad.
*ganumh/dhs: Ganymede, son of Tros, and cup-bearer of Zeus, Il. 5.266, Il. 20.232.

ga/r (ge/, a)/ra): for, namely; but often not to be translated, as in strong asseverations (esp. h)= ga/r), Il. 1.293, 342, 355, and in questions, w)= *ki/rkh, pw=s ga/r me ke/leai soi\ h)/pion ei)=nai, ‘how canst thou bid me?’ Od. 10.337; similarly after interjections, and in wishes, ai)\ ga/r, ei) or ei)/qe ga/r. The causal (for) and explanatory (namely) uses need no illustration. a)lla\... ga/r, but yet, but really, Il. 7.242, Od. 10.202; freq. in combination (ga/r) dh/, ou)=n, r(a/, te/, toi/.
*ga/rgaron: name of the south peak of mount Ida in the Troad. (Il.)
gasth/r, e/ros (also gen. gastro/s, dat. -tri/): belly; the womb, Il. 6.58; met. for hunger, Od. 6.133, etc.; paunch, haggis, Od. 18.44.
ga/strh: belly of a caldron.
gaulo/s: milk-pail, Od. 9.223†.

ge/: enclitic particle, used to give prominence to a word or a statement; sometimes to be translated, at least, at any rate, but for the most part untranslatable, and only to be represented in English orally by the tone, in writing by italics; ei) zwo/n g' *ai)/gisqon e)ni\ mega/roisin e)/tetmen | *)atrei/dhs, ‘had Menelāus found Aegisthus at home alive!’ Od. 3.256 ; ei)/per ga/r te xo/lon ge kai\ au)th=mar katape/yh| | a)lla/ te kai\ meto/pisqen e)/xei ko/ton, ‘though he swallow his wrath... yet he retains a grudge, etc.,’ Il. 1.81; hence ge may convert a slight word into a strong one, lending, as it does, another syllable, and preserving the acute tone, o(\ becomes o(/ ge, de\ becomes de/ ge, etc.; even by preventing elision it is a means of force, you may call it a ‘stop-gap,’ yet it is not otiose. With other particles, a)/ra ge, ei)/ ge, pri/n ge, pa/ros ge, e)pei/ ge, etc.; freq. in neg. sentences, where it may sometimes be translated by an interjected no, as in affirmative sentences occasionally by yes. For repetition of ge/, cf. Il. 5.287 f.
ge/gaa, gega/a=si, gegaw/s: see gi/gnomai.
ge/ghqa: see ghqe/w.
gei/nomai (root ga), aor. e)geina/mhn: pres. and ipf., be born; aor. causative, bear, beget, of both father and mother; e)ph\n dh\ gei/neai au)to/s, after thou hast thyself created them, Od. 20.202.
gei/twn, onos: neighbor. (Od.)
gelasto/s (gela/w): ridiculous; e)/rga, doings that bring ridicule upon the speaker, Od. 8.307†.

gela/w, gelo/w, part. gelo/wntes, gelw/ontes, ipf. 3 pl. gelw/wn, aor. (e))ge/la(s)sen, 3 pl. ge/la(s)san, part. gela/(s)sa=s: laugh, h(du/, ‘heartily;’ a(palo/n, a)xrei=on, dakruo/en, xei/lesin, only ‘with the lips,’ i. e. not from the heart, Il. 15.101; fig., ge/lasse de\ pa=sa peri\ xqw\n | xalkou= u(po\ steroph=s, Il. 19.362; e)mo\n d' e)ge/lasse fi/lon kh=r, ‘laughed within me,’ Od. 9.413.
geloia/w: geloi/wn, geloi/wntes, restored readings gelw/wn, gelw/ontes, see gela/w.
geloi/ios (ge/lws): laughable, Il. 2.215†.
ge/los: see ge/lws.
gelo/w, gelo/wntes, gelw/ontes: see gela/w.
ge/lws, ge/los, dat. ge/lw|, acc. ge/lw and ge/lon: laughter; ge/lw| e)/kqanon, ‘laughed themselves to death,’ Od. 18.100.
geneh/, h=s: birth, lineage, race; geneh=| u(pe/rteros, ‘rank,’ Il. 11.786 ; o(plo/teros, ‘age,’ Il. 2.707; ‘breed’ of horses, Il. 5.265; ‘generation,’ Il. 6.149, pl. Il. 1.250.
gene/qlh, hs (parallel form of geneh/): race, stock; a)rgu/rou, ‘home,’ Il. 2.857.
geneia/s, a/dos (ge/neion): pl., beard, Od. 16.176†.
geneia/w: only aor. part. geneih/santa, just getting a beard, Od. 18.176 and 269.
ge/neion: chin; ge/neion labei=n, a(/yasqai, done in supplicating a person, Il. 1.501. (See cut under gouno/omai.)
ge/nesis: generation, origin; *)wkeano/n, qew=n ge/nesin, Il. 14.201, 246, 302.
geneth/, h=s: birth; e)k geneth=s, ‘from the hour of birth,’ Od. 18.6.
gennai=os (ge/nna): according to one's birth, native to one; ou) ga/r moi gennai=on, ‘not my way,’ Il. 5.253†.

ge/nos, eos (root ga): family, race, extraction; h(miqe/wn, a)ndrw=n, bow=n ge/nos, and of the individual, ‘scion,’ a)nh\r... so\n ge/nos, Il. 19.124, etc.; ge/nei u(/steros, ‘birth,’ ‘age,’ Il. 3.215 ; ge/nea, ‘generations,’ Od. 3.245.
ge/nto, defective aor. 3 sing: grasped. (Il.)
ge/nus, uos, acc. pl. ge/nu=s: under jaw, jaw, of men and animals.
gerai/rw: honor (with a ge/ras), show honor to, Il. 7.321, Od. 14.437.
*geraisto/s: name of the promontory at the S. extremity of Euboea, now Geresto, Od. 3.177†.
ge/ranos, h(: crane. (Il.)
ge/raros, comp. gerarw/teros: stately, Il. 3.170 and 211.

ge/ras, aos, pl. ge/ra: gift of honor, honor, prerogative; nobles and esp. the king received ge/ra from the commonalty, ge/ras q' o(/ ti dh=mos e)/dwken, Od. 7.150; of the kingly office itself, Il. 20.182, Od. 11.175; of offerings to the gods, and burial honors of the dead, to\ ga\r ge/ras e)sti\ qano/ntwn.
*gerh/nios: Gerenian, epith. of Nestor, from Gerenia in Laconia or Messenia; *gerh/nios i(ppo/ta *ne/stwr, also *ne/stwr... *gerh/nios, ou)=ros *)axaiw=n, Od. 3.411, etc.

ge/rwn, ontos, voc. ge/ron: old man (senex), and specially, mostly in pl., elders, members of the council (boulh\ gero/ntwn), cf. Lat. senator.—As adj., path\r ge/rwn, Il. 1.358, neut. ge/ron sa/kos, Od. 22.184.

ge/fu=ra, only pl.: dams, dikes; to\n d' ou)/t) a)/r te ge/fu=rai e)ergme/nai i)sxano/wsi, Il. 5.88; met., ptole/moio gefu=rai, ‘bridges of war,’ the lanes between files and columns on the battle-field.
gefu=ro/w, aor. gefu=/rwse: dam up a river, Il. 21.245 ; ke/leuqon, ‘make a causeway,’ Il. 15.357.
gh=, *gh=: see gai)=a.
ghqe/w, aor. gh/qhsa, perf. ge/ghqa: rejoice, be glad; freq. w. part., gh/qhsen i)dw/n, etc.; sometimes w. acc., ta/de, Od. 9.77; acc. of part., ei) nw=i... *(/ektwr ghqh/sei profane/nte, Il. 8.378.
ghqosu/nh (ghqe/w): joy, gladness, dat., Il. 13.29 and Il. 21.390.
ghqo/sunos: glad.
ghra=/s: see ghra/skw.
gh=ras, aos, dat. gh/rai+ and gh/rai: old age.
ghra/skw, aor. 2 e)gh/ra=, part. ghra=/s: grow old; of fruit, ‘ripen,’ Od. 7.120.
gh=rus: speech, Il. 4.437†.
*gi/gantes: the Giants, a wild race related to the gods, Od. 7.59, 206, and Od. 10.120.
