h)e/lios: the sun; of rising, a)nie/nai, a)norou/ein, Od. 3.1; a)nanei=sqai, Od. 10.192; stei/xein pro\s ou)rano/n, Od. 11.17; noon, me/son ou)rano\n a)mfibai/nein, Il. 8.68; afternoon, metani/ssein boulu=to/nde, Il. 16.779; a)/y e)pi\ gai=an protre/pesqai, Od. 11.18; setting, du/ein, e)pidu/ein, katadu/ein, e)mpi=/ptein *)wkeanw=|, Il. 8.485; of shining, e)pila/mpein, a)kti=si ba/llein, e)pide/rkesqai a)kti=/nessin, also fa/os h)eli/oio, often as typical of life, Od. 11.93, Il. 18.11, 61, Od. 4.540; au)gh/, ai)/glh, me/nos, *y 190, Od. 10.160; epithets, a)ka/ma=s, lampro/s, leuko/s, pamfano/wn, faesi/mbrotos. Expressions for east and west, Od. 13.240, Il. 12.239, Od. 10.191 .—*)he/lios, *(/hlios (Od. 8.271),
Helius, the sun-god, son of Hyperion, Od. 12.176, Od. 1.8; father of Circe, and of Phaethūsa and Lampetie, Od. 10.138, Od. 12.133; propitiated by sacrifice, Il. 3.104, Il. 19.197; oath by the sun, Il. 19.259; the kine of Helius, Od. 12.128, 322, t 276, Od. 23.329.
h)=en: see ei)mi/.
h)e/per: see h)/per.
h)ere/qomai (a)ei/rw): flutter, float, Il. 21.12 ; fre/nes, ‘are unstable,’ Il. 3.108.
*)heri/boia: Eriboea, the second wife of Alōeus, step - mother of Otus and Ephialtes, Il. 5.389.
h)e/rios: adj., at early morn, always used predicatively, Il. 1.497, Od. 9.52.

h)ero-eidh/s, e/s (ei)=dos): misty, murky, gray; po/ntos, spe/os, pe/trh, Il. 23.744, Od. 12.80, 233; o(/sson d' h)eroeide\s a)nh\r i(/den o)fqalmoi=sin, sees ‘into the dim distance,’ ‘through the haze,’ Il. 5.770.
h)ero/eis, essa, en (a=/h/r): cloudy, gloomy, mostly with reference to the nether world, Il. 8.13, Il. 15.191, Od. 20.64.
h)e/ros: see a=)h/r.
h)ero/-fwnos: loud - voiced; (if from a)ei/rw) ‘raising the voice,’ (if from a=/h/r) ‘sending the voice abroad.’
*)heti/wn: Eetion.—(1) king of Thebe in the Troad, the father of Andromache, Il. 6.396, Il. 1.366.—(2) an Imbrian, a guest-friend of Priam, Il. 21.43.—(3) a Trojan, Il. 17.590.
h)/hn: see ei)mi/.
h)qei=os (e)/qos, h)=qos): familiar, beloved, dear; usually the voc., h)qei=e, also h)qei/h kefalh/, ‘dear heart’ we should say, Il. 23.94 ; a)lla/ min h)qei=on kale/w, ‘dear master,’ Od. 14.147.
h)=qos (vh=qos), pl. h)/qea: accustomed places, haunts, Il. 6.511; of ‘pens,’ Od. 14.411.
h)/i=a, h)=|a: (1) provisions, food, Il. 13.103. (Od.)—(2) gen. h)i/wn qhmw=na, heap of chaff, Od. 5.368†.
h)/ie: see ei)=mi.
h)i/qeos: unmarried youth, bachelor; parqe/nos h)i/qeo/s te, *s 593, Od. 11.38.
h)/ikto: see e)/oika.
h)/i=ce: see a=)i=/ssw.

h)io/eis, essa: doubtful word, with changing banks, Il. 5.36†. (The above interpretation assumes a derivation from h)iw/n, some rivers like the Scamander, in warm countries, with their sources in neighboring mountains, have in consequence of rains a broad rugged bed out of proportion to the ordinary size of the stream, and banks ragged and often high.)
h)/ion: see ei)=mi.
*)hio/nes: name of a sea-port in Argolis, Il. 2.561†.
*)hioneu/s: (1) father of the Thracian king Rhesus, Il. 10.435.—(2) a Greek, slain by Hector, Il. 7.11.
h)/ios: epithet of Apollo in the apostrophe, h)/ie *foi=be, *o 365, Il. 20.152; perhaps ‘far-darting’ (i(/hmi).
h)/isan: see ei)=mi.
h)i+=/xqh: see a=/i=/ssw.
h)iw/n, o/nos: sea-bank, shore, Il. 12.31, Od. 6.138.
h)=ka (vh=ka): gently, softly, slightly, Il. 20.440, Il. 18.596, Od. 20.301.
h(=ka: see i(/hmi.
h)/kaxe: see a)kaxi/zw.
h)ke/ssato: see a)ke/omai.
h)/-kestos (kente/w): ungoaded, hence untamed, Il. 6.94. (Il.)
h)/kistos (vh=ka): slowest, most sluggish, Il. 23.531†.
h(/kw: am come, Il. 5.478, Od. 13.325.
h)la/kata, pl.: wool, or woollen thread on the distaff; strwfw=sa, strofali/zete, ‘ply the distaff,’ Od. 18.315. (Od.) (See the first of the cuts below.)
h)la^ka/th, hn (a)ra/xnh): spindle, Il. 6.491. (Od.) (See the cuts, representing distaff and spindles.)
h)/lasa, h)lasa/mesqa: see e)lau/nw.
h)laska/zw (h)la/skw): wander about; trans., e)mo\n me/nos, ‘try to escape’ by dodging, Od. 9.457.
h)la/skw (a)la/omai): prowl about, swarm about, Il. 12.104, Il. 2.470.
h)la=to: see a)la/omai.
h)/ldane: see a)ldai/nw.
h)le/: see h)leo/s.
*)hlei=oi: the Elēans, inhabitants of Elis, Il. 11.671†.
h)/lektron: amber, Od. 4.73. (Od.)
h)le/ktwr: beaming (sun), with and without *(uperi=/wn, *t 398, Il. 6.513. (Il.)
h)leo/s, h)lo/s: crazed, infatuated, with fre/nas, *o 128, Od. 2.243; in active sense, oi)=nos, Od. 14.464.
h)lh/lato: see e)lau/nw.
h)li/batos: towering, lofty, Od. 9.243, Il. 15.273.
h)/liqa (a(/lis): sufficiently, always h)/liqa pollh/(n), ‘very much’ (satis multum), Il. 11.677, Od. 5.483.
h(liki/h (h(=lic): time of life, age, for concrete, mates, fellows, Il. 16.808. (Il.)
h(=lic, ikos: pl., equal in age, Od. 18.373†.
h(/lios: see h)e/lios.
*)=hlis, idos: Elis, a division of the Peloponnēsus on the west coast, inhabited in the north by Epeians, in the south by Achaeans, Il. 2.316, Od. 4.635.
h)/lite: see a)litai/nw.
h)lito/-mhnos (a)litei=n, mh/n): untimely born, Il. 19.118†.
h(/lkhse: see e(lke/w.
h(=los: pl., nails, studs, only used for ornamentation, Il. 1.246, Il. 11.29, 633. (Il.)
h)/luqon: see e)/rxomai.
*)hlu/sion pedi/on: the Elysian fields, the abode of the blest, Od. 4.563 ff.
h)=lfon: see a)lfa/nw.
h(/lw: see a(li/skomai.
h)lw/mhn: see a)la/omai.
*)hlw/nh: a city in Phthiōtis, Il. 2.739†.
h(=ma, atos (i(/hmi): throw; h(/masin a)/ristos, best ‘at javelin - throwing,’ Il. 23.891†.
*)hmaqi/h: Emathia, the ancient name of Macedonia, Il. 14.226†.
h)maqo/eis (a)/maqos): sandy, epithet of Pylos.

h(=mai, h(=s (ai), h(=stai, h(/meqa, h(=sqe, e(/atai and ei(/atai, imp. h(=so, inf. h(=sqai, part. h(/menos, ipf. h(/mhn, h(=sto, h(/sqhn, h(/meqa, h(=nto and e(/ato and ei(/ato: sit; often w. a part. to denote some condition of mind or body, h(=sto o)du=ro/menos, qauma/zwn, o)lighpele/wn, etc.; and, in general, the verb may denote a settled condition of any sort, ‘stay,’ ‘keep,’ e(ka\s h(/meqa patri/dos ai)/hs, Il. 15.740, Il. 24.542; si=gh=|, a)ke/ousa, siwph=| h(=so, Il. 4.412.

h)=mar, atos: day; divided by Homer into h)w/s, me/son h)=mar, and dei/lh, Il. 21.111, Od. 7.288 ; h)=mar xeime/rion, o)pwri=no/n, also ai)/simon, mo/rsimon h)=mar, nhle/es h)=mar, no/stimon h)=mar, dou/lion and e)leu/qeron h)=mar, mostly poetic periphrases for the noun implied in the adj.; h)/mata pa/nta, e)p' h)/mati (see e)pi/), pa=n, pro/pan h)=mar, freq. formula h)/mati tw=| o(/te.
h)ma/tios: by day, Od. 2.104; daily, Il. 9.72.
h)/mbroton: see a(marta/nw.
h(mei=s and a)/mmes, gen. h(me/wn and h(mei/wn, dat. h)mi=n and encl. h(=min, also a)/mmi(n), acc. a)/mme, h(me/as (encl. h(=mas, Od. 16.372): we, us.
h)me/n: always in correlation, usually with h)de/, both.. (and), as well.. (as), Il. 2.789, Od. 14.193; also correl. to de/, kai/, or te/, Il. 12.428, *o 664, Od. 8.575.
h(me/rh, pl. h(me/rai: day; other forms than the nom. are supplied by h)=mar.
h(meri/s (h(/meros): cultivated (not wild) vine, Od. 5.69†.
h)/meros: tame, domesticated, Od. 15.162†.

h)mi/: only ipf., h<*>= (dixit), at the beginning of the verse, and regularly foll. by kai/ and a verb expressing action; h)= r(a, kai\ e)k xeiro\s xei=ra spa/sat' *)antino/oio, ‘he spoke,’ and drew his hand away, Od. 2.321, Il. 3.355; in slightly different combination, Od. 18.356, Il. 6.390.
h(mi-: half- (semi-), in composition.
h(mi-dah/s (dai/w): half-burnt, Il. 16.294†.
h(mi/-qeos: demi-god, pl., Il. 12.23†.
h(mi-o/neios: of mules; a(/maca, zugo/n, mule-wagon, mule-yoke, Od. 6.62, Il. 24.268.
h(mi/-onos (o)/nos): mule; the name designates the hybrid, cf. ou)reu/s.—As adj., Il. 23.266.
h(mi - pe/lekkon (pe/lekus): half-axe, one-edged axe. (Il.)
h(/misus, seia, su: half; sing. only neut. as subst., Il. 6.193, Il. 9.579, 580; pl., h(mi/sees la=oi/, *f 7, Od. 3.155, 157; gen. h(mi/sewn plei/ous, Od. 24.464.
h(mi-ta/lanton: half a talent, half a pound (gold), Il. 23.751, 796.
h(mi-telh/s: half-finished, Il. 2.701†.
h)=mos: when, at the time when, always at the beginning of a verse, exc. Od. 12.439; followed in the apod. by th=mos, dh\ to/te, dh/. kai\ to/t' e)/peita.

h)mu/w, aor. h)/musa: nod, bow, droop; with ka/rh or karh/ati, *q 308, Il. 19.405; of a field of grain, e)pi/ (adv.) t' h)mu/ei
a)staxu/essin, ‘nods its heads to the breeze,’ Il. 2.148; fig. of cities, ‘sink to earth,’ Il. 2.373, Il. 4.290.
h(/mwn, onos (i(/hmi): darter; h(/mones a)/ndres, ‘javelin men,’ Il. 23.886†.
h)/n (ei), a)/n): if; for constructions see ei), a)/n, ke/n. Sometimes called ‘interrogative,’ ‘in case that,’ Od. 1.282, and often. For h)/nper, h)/n pou, h)/n pws, see the several particles.
h)nai/neto: see a)nai/nomai.
h)/neika, h)nei/kato: see fe/rw.
h)nemo/eis, essa, en (a)/nemos): windy, breezy, airy, of towns, trees, and mountain-tops.
h(ni/a, pl.: reins; often adorned with gold or ivory, si=galo/enta, Il. 5.226.
h(ni/ka: when, at the time when, Od. 22.198†.
*)hniopeu/s: son of Thebaeus, a charioteer of Hector, slain by Diomed, Il. 8.120†.
h(nioxeu/s, h=os = h(ni/oxos. (Il.)
h(nioxeu/w: be charioteer, hold the reins, drive.

h(ni/-oxos (h(ni/a, e)/xw): holding the reins, qera/pwn, Il. 5.580; charioteer. The charioteer usually stood at the left of the pro/maxos. (Among the Assyrians, as shown by the cut, the warrior, armed with a bow, had also a second attendant as shield-bearer with himself on the chariot. The Egyptian monuments represent only one warrior or triumphing king upon the war-chariot.)
h(ni=/pape: see e)ni/ptw.
h)=nis, ios, acc. pl. h)/ni=s: a year old, yearling; thus the word was understood by the ancients.
h)=non: see a=)/nw.
*)hnopi/dhs: son of Enops, Satnius, Il. 14.444†.
h)nore/h (a)nh/r), dat. h)nore/hfi: manliness, manly courage, prowess.
h)=noy, opos (vh=noy): bright, gleaming, xalko/s.
*)=hnoy: (1) a Mysian, the father of Satnius and Thestor, Il. 14.445.—(2) father of Clytomēdes, from Aetolia, Il. 23.634.
h)/nper: see h)/n and pe/r.
h)/nteon: see a)nta/w.
h(=nto: see h(=mai.
h)/nuto: see a)nu/w.
h)nw/gea, h)nw/gei: see a)/nwga.
h)=ce: see a)/gnu=mi.
h)oi=os (h)w/s): fem. h)oi/h, as subst., morning, dawn, Od. 4.447; adj., eastern (opp. e(spe/rioi), Oriental, a)/nqrwpoi, Od. 8.29.
h(=os: see e(/ws.
h(=par, atos: liver.
h)/pafe: see a)pafi/skw.
h)pedano/s: feeble, weakly.

h)/peiros: land (terra firma), as opp. to the sea, Il. 1.485, Od. 5.56; mainland, as opp. to the islands, Il. 2.635, Od. 24.378;
designating inland as opp. to coast, Od. 9.49 .—h)/peiro/nde: landwards, toward the land, inland.
h)/per, h)e/per: see h)/, h)e/.
h(=|per: see o(/sper.
h)peropeu/s, h=os, and h)peropeuth/s, deceiver, seducer, Od. 11.364 †. Il. 3.39 and Il. 13.769.
h)peropeu/w: talk with intent to deceive, cajole, seduce.
h)pio/-dwros: kindly giving, bountiful, Il. 6.251†.
h)/pios: mild; of persons, remedies, Il. 4.218, counsels, Il. 4.361.
h)pu/ta (for h)pu/ths, h)pu/w): loudcalling, loud-voiced, Il. 7.384†.
*)hputi/dhs: son of Epytus, Periphas, a Trojan, Il. 17.324†.
h)=ra (vh=ra): only with fe/rein, favor, gratify, humor, qu=mw=|, ‘the impulse,’ Il. 14.132; also w. e)pi/, mhtri\ fi/lh| e)pi\ vh=ra fe/rwn, Il. 1.572, 578.
*(hra=klei/dhs: son of Heracles.—(1) Tlepolemus, Il. 2.653.—(2) Thessalus, Il. 2.679.

*(hra=kle/hs, gen. *(hra=klh=os: Heracles, son of Zeus and Alcmēna, Il. 19.98; his celebrated labors, Il. 8.362, Od. 11.623, Od. 21.26; he destroys the Troy of Laomedon, and conquers Pylos, Il. 20.145, Il. 5.642, Il. 11.689 ff., cf. Il. 5.392, 397; his death, and his shade, Il. 18.117, Od. 11.601. Heracles was celebrated in song as a national hero before the time of Homer, Od. 11.602, 267. Epithets, qei=os, qrasume/mnwn, kratero/frwn, kartero/qu=mos.
*(hra=klh/eios: of Heracles, only in the periphrasis bi/h *(hra=klhei/h (see bi/h).
h)/rare: a)rari/skw.
h)/rato: see a)/rnumai.
h)ra=to: see a=)ra/w.

*(/hrh: Hera, daughter of Cronus and Rhea, sister and spouse of Zeus, see Il. 14.201 ff. The perpetual jarring of Zeus and Hera in Olympus, described with humor in the Iliad, but as too serious to be trivial, Il. 1.568, Il. 15.14 ff. Hera is the friend of the Greeks and enemy of the Trojans. Her children, Ares, Hephaestus, Hebe, Eilithyia; favorite haunts, Argos, Mycēnae, Sparta, Il. 4.51 f. Epithets, *)argei/h, *bow=pis po/- tnia, pre/sba qea=/, *dio\s kudrh\ para/koitis, h)u/komos, leukw/lenos, xru=so/qronos, xru=sope/di=los, besides many uncomplimentary titles applied to her by Zeus.
h)rh/rei: see a)rari/skw.
h)rh/reisto: see e)rei/dw.
h)=ri: at early morn.
h)ri - ge/neia: early born, epith. of h)w/s. As subst.=Eos, child of dawn, Od. 22.197.
h)/rike: see e)rei/kw.
h)/rion: sepulchral mound, Il. 23.126†.
h)/ripe: see e)rei/pw.
h)/ruge: see e)reu/gomai.
h)rw=: see a=)ra/w.
h)rw/hsan: see e)rwe/w.

h(/rws, gen. h(/rwos and h(/rw^os, dat. h(/rw^i and h(/rw|, acc. h(/rw(a): hero, warrior; a title of honor for the free and brave; alone as subst., Il. 1.4, Il. 10.179; in address, Il. 20.104, Il. 10.416; w. *danaoi/, *)axaioi/, likewise with single names, Il. 4.200, Od. 2.15, Il. 21.163; joined w. qera/pontes *)/arhos, Il. 2.110; ge/rwn, Od. 7.155. Never =demigod.
h(=sai: see h(=mai.
h(/sato: see h(/domai.
h(/sein: see i(/hmi.
h)=sqa: see ei)mi/.
h)/skein: see a)ske/w.
h(=so: see h(=mai.
h(/sswn, h(=sson, onos: inferior.— Neut. as adv., less.
h(/stai: see h)=mai.
h)/sthn: see ei)mi/.
h(suxi/h: peace, quiet, Od. 18.22†.
h(su/xios: in quiet, Il. 21.598†.
h)|sxumme/nos: see ai)sxu=/nw.
h)/te, h)/ te: or, Il. 19.148; than, Od. 16.216; usu. in correlation, h)/te.. h)/te, whether.. or, either.. or (sive.. sive).
h)=te, h)= te: see h(=.
h)|tia/asqe, h)|tio/wnto: see ai)tia/omai.

h)/toi (h)= toi): verily, to be sure, particle of asseveration (see h)=), and antithesis, not always to be translated; in correlation h)/toi.. au)ta/r differs from me\n.. de/ only in so far as disyllabic and initial words must necessarily have more weight than monosyllabic and postpositive ones. As au)ta/r, q. v., often correlates to me/n, so h)/toi may be followed by de/, Il. 1.68, and often. Freq. a)ll' h)/toi, also h)/toi me/n, Il. 1.140, 211, Il. 16.451.
h)=tor, oros: heart, Il. 2.490, Il. 10.93; always fig., as typical of life, or thought, or feeling; e)n de/ te/ oi( kradi/h| ste/nei a)/lkimon h)=tor, Il. 20.169.
h)u-ge/neios (ge/neion): strong-bearded; epith. of the lion, Il. 15.275, Od. 4.456.
hu)/da=: see au)da/w.
h)u/-komos (ko/mh): fair-haired, epith. of goddesses and women. (Il. and Od. 12.389).
h)u/s: see e)u/s.
h)/use: see au)/w.
h)u/te: as, like, as when, Il. 4.277, Il. 1.359, Il. 2.87.

*(/hfaistos: Hephaestus (Vulcanus), the son of Zeus and Hera, the god of fire and of arts which need the aid of fire: in the Iliad married to Charis, Il. 18.382 ff., but in the Odyssey to Aphrodīte, Od. 8.266 ff. His works are the houses of the gods on Olympus, the armor of Achilles, the sceptre and aegis of Zeus, etc. Epithets, a)mfiguh/eis, kullopodi=/wn, xalkeu/s, klutote/xnhs, kluto/ergos, kluto/mhtis, polu/frwn, peri/klutos, polu/mhtis. The name *(/hfaistos is used by personification for the element which he represents, Il. 2.426, cf. Il. 9.468.
h(=fi (svh=fi)=h(=|, see o(/s, e(o/s.
h)xh/ (vhxh/): resounding, echoing noise, roar; of voices (compared to the waves), wind, Il. 2.209, Il. 16.769; freq. h)xh=| qespesi/h|, Od. 3.150.
h)xh/eis, essa, en (vhxh/): sounding, echoing, roaring, Od. 4.72, Il. 1.157.
h)/xqeto: see (1) a)/xqomai.—(2) e)/xqomai.
h(=|xi: where.
h)w=qen (h)w/s): in the morning, Il. 11.555, Od. 1.372; to-morrow morning, Il. 18.136, Il. 19.320, Od. 1.372.
h)w=qi: always with pro/ (q. v.), early in the morning, Il. 11.50.

h)w/s, h)ou=s, h)oi=, h)w=: dawn, morning, Il. 21.111; for day, Il. 24.31; east, Od. 9.26 .— *)hw/s, Eos (Aurora), consort of Tithōnus, cf., however, Od. 5.121, Od. 15.250. Mother of Memnon, Od. 4.188; her abode, Od. 12.3, Il. 11.1, Il. 19.1, Od. 22.197. Epithets, h)rige/neia, r(ododa/ktulos, di=a, e)u/qronos, kroko/peplos, xru=so/qronos.

div1.head: *q
div1.entryFree: qaa/ssw, inf. -e/men, ipf. qa/asse: sit. (Il. and Od. 3.336.)
qairo/s: hinge, pl., Il. 12.459†. (See cuts from Egyptian originals; also under e)piblh/s, No. 35.)
qala/mh: bed, hole, of an animal, Od. 5.432†.
qalamh-po/los (pe/lomai): chambermaid. (Od.)

qa/lamos: the rear portion of the house, hence any room, chamber therein; e. g. women's chamber, Od. 4.121; room for weapons, Od. 19.17; store-room, Od. 2.337; bedchamber, Il. 3.423 .—qa/lamo/nde, to the chamber. (See table III., at end of volume.)
qa/lassa: the sea.
qala/ssios: of the sea; qala/ssia ve/rga, ‘business on the sea,’ navigation, fishing, Il. 2.614, Od. 5.67.
qa/lea, pl.: good cheer, Il. 22.504†.
qale/qw: parallel form of qa/llw, y, 191; fig., Od. 6.63 ; a)loifh=|, ‘teeming,’ ‘loaded’ with fat, Il. 9.467, Il. 23.32.
qa/leia: fem. adj., dai/s, bounteous, plentiful repast.
*qa/leia (‘Bloomer’): a Nereid, Il. 18.39†.

qalero/s (qa/llw): swelling, blooming; with reference to growth, mhrw/, xai/th, ‘lusty,’ ‘thick,’ Il. 15.113, Il. 17.439; the freshness of youth, para/koitis, ga/mos, *g 53, Od. 6.66; ‘rich’ fat, Od. 8.476;
‘big,’ ‘bursting,’ tear, sobs, Il. 2.266, Od. 10.457; the ‘full,’ ‘swelling’ voice, Od. 4.705.
qali/h: abundance, prosperity; pl., good cheer, Od. 11.603.
qallo/s: collectively, twigs for fodder, Od. 17.224†.
qa/los: scion, only metaph., Il. 22.87, Od. 6.157.
qalpia/w (qa/lpos): be warm, part., Od. 19.319†.
*qa/lpios: son of Eurytus, a leader of the Epeians, Il. 2.620†.
qa/lpw: warm, warm up. (Od.)
qalpwrh/: warming, met., comfort.
qalu=/sia, pl. (qa/llw): offering of first fruits, harvest offering, Il. 9.534†.
*qalu=sia/dhs: son of Thalysius, Echepōlus, Il. 4.458†.
qa/ma: frequently, often.
qambe/w (root qap), aor. qa/mbhsa: be astonished or wonder at, gaze upon with wonder, Od. 2.155, Il. 24.483.
qa/mbos, eus: wonder, astonishment.
qame/es, qameiai/ (qa/ma), dat. qame/si, qameiai=s, acc. qame/as: frequent, thick; stauroi\ puknoi\ kai\ qame/es, ‘thick set and numerous,’ Od. 14.12.
qami/zw: come or go or do frequently, resort to; w. part. ou)/ ti komizo/meno/s ge qa/mizen = ou) qa/ma e)komi/zeto.
qa/mnos: thicket, bush; of the leaves and branches of an olive-tree, Od. 23.190.
*qa/muris: Thamyris, a Thracian bard vanquished and blinded by the Muses, Il. 2.595†.
qa/natos: death; qa/nato/nde, to death, Il. 16.693.—Personified, Death, twinbrother of Sleep, Il. 14.231.
qane/ein: see qnh/skw.
qa/omai (1), aor. opt. 3 pl. qhsai/ato: admire, Od. 18.191†.
qa/omai (2), inf. qh=sqai, aor. qh/sato: suck, Il. 24.58; milk, Od. 4.89.
qap- or taf-, perf. w. pres. signif. te/qhpa, part. -pw/s, o/tes, o/tas, plup. e)teqh/pea, aor. 2 part. tafw/n: wonder, be amazed at, be dazed, Il. 4.243.
qa/ptw, aor. qa/yan, pass. plup. e)te/qapto: inter, bury.
qarsale/os (qa/rsos), comp. -ew/teron: courageous, daring, bold; in bad sense, Od. 17.449.—Adv., qarsale/ws.
qarse/w (qa/rsos), aor. qa/rshse, perf. teqarsh/ka=si: be bold, confident, full of courage, aor., take courage, Il. 1.92, Od. 3.76; w. acc. of specification, Od. 8.197.
qa/rsos, eos: courage, confidence, boldness, audacity.
qa/rsunos: confident, relying upon (tini/), Il. 13.823.
qarsu=/nw, ipf. iter. qarsu=/neske, aor. qa/rsu=na: encourage.
qa/sswn: see taxu/s.
qau=ma: a wonder, marvel; qau=ma vide/sqai, *e 725, Od. 6.306; wonder, amazement, qau=ma/ m' e)/xei, Od. 10.326.
qauma/zw, ipf. iter. qauma/zeskon, fut. qauma/ssetai, aor. subj. qauma/swsi: wonder, admire.
qaumai/nw, fut. part. qaumane/ontes= qauma/zw, Od. 8.108†.
*qaumaki/h: a town in Magnesia, under the rule of Philoctētes, Il. 2.716†.
qea=/, qea=s, dat. pl. qeai=s, qeh=|s, qeh=|sin: goddess.
qe/aina = qea=/, only pl.
*qea=nw/: Theāno, daughter of Cisseus, and wife of Antēnor, a priestess of Athēna in Troy, Il. 6.302.
qe/eion and qh/ion (Att. qei=on): sulphur, used for fumigation and purification, hence called kakw=n a)/kos, Od. 22.481; ‘sulphurous fumes,’ Od. 12.417.
qeeio/w (Att. qeio/w): fumigate with sulphur, mid., Od. 23.50.
qei=en: see ti/qhmi.
qeilo/pedon: drying - place, a sunny spot in the vineyard where grapes were dried, Od. 7.123†.
qei=men, qei=nai: see ti/qhmi.
qei/nw, inf. qeine/men(ai), subj. qei/nh|, aor. e)/qeine, qei=ne, part. qei/na=s, pass. pres. part. qeino/menos: strike.
qei/omen: see ti/qhmi.

qei=os (qeo/s): of the gods, god - like, sacred; of anything belonging or related to, given or sent by, the gods, ge/nos (the Chimaera), Il. 6.180 ; o)/neiros, Il. 2.22; also of things consecrated to them or under their protection, xoro/s, Od. 8.264; kh/ru=c, Il. 4.192; a)oido/s, Od. 1.336; then of persons, qei=oi basilh=es, Od. 4.691; and even of things excellent in a high degree, poto/n, Od. 2.341; do/mos, Od. 4.43.
qei/w: see (1) qe/w.—(2) ti/qhmi.

qe/lgw, ipf. qe/lge, iter. qe/lgeske, fut.
qe/lcw, aor. e)/qelca, pass. pres. opt. qe/lgoito, aor. 3 pl. e)/qelxqen: charm, enchant; Hermes with his magic wand, a)ndrw=n o)/mmata qe/lgei, ‘charms’ their eyes, ‘entrances,’ puts them to sleep, Il. 24.343, Od. 5.47; so Poseidon casts a blindness upon Alcathous, qe/lca=s o)/sse faeina/, Il. 13.435; usually in a bad sense, of ‘bewitching,’ ‘beguiling,’ no/on, qu=mo/n, Il. 12.255, Il. 15.322; e)pe/essin, yeu/dessi, do/lw|, g 264, Il. 21.276, 604; of love, pass., Od. 18.612; rarely in good sense, Od. 17.514, 521.

qelkth/rion (qe/lgw): any means of charming or winning, spell, charm; attributed to the girdle of Aphrodīte, e)/nqa te/ oi( qelkth/ria pa/nta te/tukto, Il. 14.215; of songs, qelkth/ria brotw=n (obj. gen.), Od. 1.337; and of the Trojan Horse, a winsome offering to the gods, Od. 8.509.
qe/meqla and qemei/lia (ti/qhmi), pl.: foundations, base; ‘roots,’ ‘bed,’ stoma/xoio, o)fqalmoi=o, *r 47, Il. 14.493.
qe/men(ai): see ti/qhmi.

qe/mis, qe/mistos (ti/qhmi): old (established) law, right by custom or usage; h(\ qe/mis e)sti/n, ‘as is right’; h(\ qe/mis a)nqrw/pwn pe/lei, ‘the old way’ of mankind, Il. 9.134.—Pl., qe/mistes, ordinances, decrees, prerogatives; *dio/s, Od. 16.403, cf. Il. 1.238 ; kri=/nein, Il. 16.387; telei=n, as ‘dues,’ ‘tribute,’ Il. 9.156, 298.—Personified, Themis, Od. 2.68, Il. 20.4, Il. 15.87, 93.
qemo/w: only aor., qe/mwse, caused, w. inf., Od. 9.486 and 542.

-qen: a suffix forming an ablatival genitive; of place, *troi/hqen, oi)/koqen, a)/lloqen, ‘from Troy,’ ‘from home,’ ‘from elsewhere,’ and with prepositions, a)po\ *troi/hqen, Od. 9.38; e)c a(lo/qen, Il. 21.335; less often of persons, *dio/qen, qeo/qen, ‘from Zeus,’ ‘from a god.’
qe/nar, aros: flat of the hand, Il. 5.339†.
qe/o: see ti/qhmi.
qeo/ - dmhtos (de/mw): god - built, Il. 8.519†.
qeo-eidh/s, e/s (vei=dos): god-like, beautiful as the gods.
qeo-ei/kelos (vei/kelos): like the gods, god-like, of persons.
qeo/qen: from a god, from God, Od. 16.447†.
*qeoklu/menos: a seer in Ithaca, Od. 15.256, Od. 20.350.
qeo - prope/w: prophesy, only part.
qeo-propi/h and qeopro/pion (Il.): prophecy, oracle.
qeo-pro/pos: one who reveals and interprets the will of the gods, seer, prophet; as adj., Il. 13.70.

qeo/s, gen. and dat. pl. qeo/fin: god (or goddess); of individual divinities, and collectively, the deity, God, su\n qew=|, a)/neu qeou=, etc. Forms of the pl. are often to be read with synizesis, e. g. qeoi=sin, Od. 14.251.
qeoudh/s (qeo/s, dve/os): god-fearing, pious. (Od.)
qerapeu/w (qera/pwn): be servant to, serve, defer to, ipf., Od. 13.265†.
qera/pwn, ontos: attendant, comrade at arms (esquire, not servant), cf. Od. 11.255, Il. 2.110, Od. 4.23.
qere/w: see qe/rw.
qermai/nw, aor. subj. qermh/nh|: warm, heat; pass., get hot, Od. 9.376.
qermo/s: warm, hot.
qe/rmw, imp. qe/rmete:=qermai/nw, pass., Il. 23.381.
qe/ros, eus: warm season, summer (opp. o)pw/rh, late summer), Od. 12.76.
*qersi/loxos: (1) a Trojan, Il. 17.216. —(2) a Paeonian, slain by Achilles, Il. 21.209.
*qersi=/ths: Thersītes, the ugliest Greek before Troy, and a brawler (as his name indicates), Il. 2.212 ff.

qe/rw, pass. pres. inf. qe/resqai, aor. e)qe/rhn, subj. qere/w, mid. fut. part. qerso/menos: warm, be warm, warm oneself; puro/s, ‘by the fire,’ Od. 17.23; ‘burn,’ puro/s, ‘with fire,’ Il. 6.331, Il. 11.667.
qe/s: see ti/qhmi.
qe/skelos (qeo/s): supernatural, fig., wondrous; e)/rga, Od. 11.374, 610.—Adv., qe/skelon, wonderfully, Il. 23.107.
qesmo/s (ti/qhmi): site, place, Il. 23.296†.
*qe/speia: a town in Boeotia, Il. 2.498†.

qespe/sios (qeo/s, root sep, e)/spete): divinely uttered or uttering (qespesi/h|, ‘by divine decree,’ Il. 2.367), divine; a)oidh/, Il. 2.600; *seirh=nes, ‘heavenlysinging,’ Od. 12.158 ; bhlo/s, ‘of heaven,’ Il. 1.591; then of anything prodigious, vast, wondrous, mighty, a storm, clamor, panic, etc.—Adv., qespesi/ws, Il. 15.637.
qespi-dah/s, e/s (dai/ Od. 24.1): prodigiously or fiercely blazing, pu=r. (Il. and Od. 4.418).
qe/spis, ios (cf. qespe/sios): inspired, divine; a)oidh/, a)oido/s, Od. 1.328, q 498, Od. 17.385.
*qesprwtoi/: the Thesprotians, a tribe dwelling about Dodōna in Epīrus, Od. 16.427; their king Pheidon, Od. 14.316. (Od.)
*qessalo/s: a son of Heracles, father of Pheidippus and Antiphus, Il. 2.679†.
*qestori/dhs: son of Thestor.—(1) Calchas, the seer, Il. 1.69.—(2) Alcmāon, Il. 12.394.
*qe/stwr: (1) the father of Calchas. —(2) father of Alcmāon.—(3) son of Enops, slain by Patroclus, Il. 16.401†.
qe/s-fatos (qeo/s, fhmi/): declared or decreed by God, Il. 8.477, Od. 4.561; divine (miraculous), a=/h/r, Od. 7.143; as subst., qe/sfaton, decree of heaven, fate, oracle.

*qe/tis: Thetis, a Nereid, married to Peleus, and the mother of Achilles, Il. 18.431 ff., Il. 24.62, cf. Il. 1.502 ff., 397 ff. Epithets, a(losu/dnh, a)rguro/peza, h)u/komos, kalliplo/kamos, tanu/peplos.

qe/w, qei/w, inf. qei/ein, ipf. e)/qee, qe/e, e)/qei, iter. qe/eskon, fut. 2 sing. qeu/seai, inf. qeu/sesqai: run; often the part. joined to other verbs, h)=lqe qe/wn, etc.; said of ships, the potter's wheel, Il. 18.601; a vein, Il. 13.547; and otherwise figuratively.
qew/teros: divine, for the gods, i. e. rather than for men, of the two entrances (cf. qhlu/teros), pu/lai, Od. 13.111†.

*qh=bai, w=n, and *qh/bh: Thebes or Thebē—(1) the city in Boeotia, founded by Cadmus and fortified by Amphīon and Zethus, epithets e(pta/pulos, e)uste/fanos, poluh/ratos.—(2) Egyptian Thebes, on the Nile, called e(kato/mpulai, *i 381, Od. 4.126.—(3) a city in the Troad, at the foot of Mt. Placus, the residence of king Eetion, Il. 1.366, Il. 6.397.
*qh/ba=sde: to Thebes, Il. 23.679.
*qhbai=os: (1) a Theban.—(2) name of the father of Eniopeus, Il. 8.120.
qh/gw, mid. aor. imp. qhca/sqw: whet, sharpen, mid., something of one's own, Il. 2.382.

qhe/omai (Att. qea/omai), opt. 2 sing. qhoi=o, ipf. qhei=to, e)qheu/meqa, qheu=nto, aor. 2 sing. qhh/sao, opt. qhh/saio: gaze at, behold with admiration or delight; joined with qambei=n, qauma/zein, *y 728, Od. 8.265.
qh/h|s: see ti/qhmi.
qhhth/r (qhe/omai): beholder, i. e. fancier; to/cwn, Od. 21.397†.
qh/ion: see qe/eion.
qh/leas: see qh=lus.
qhle/w =qa/llw, w. gen. of fulness, Od. 5.73†.

qh=lus, qh/leia, qh=lu (also w. two endings): female; a)u=th/, i. e. of women's voices, Od. 6.122 ; e)e/rsh, with the thought of ‘nourishing,’ Od. 5.467; comp., qhlu/teros, weaker (of the two sexes), weak, Il. 8.520, Od. 8.324.
qhmw=n, wnos: heap, Od. 5.368†.
qh/n: doubtless, surely now, enclitic particle, much like dh/ or dh/pou in prose; combined, h)= qhn, ou)/ qhn (dh/), ou) me/n qhn, e)pei/ qhn, kai\ ga/r qhn, Od. 3.352, p 91, Il. 21.568.
qhoi=o: see qhe/omai.
qh/r, qhro/s: wild beast, Od. 5.473.
qhreuth/s (qhreu/w): hunts(man), hunting-dog, only with a)ndra/sin and ku/nessin. (Il.)
qhreu/w (qh/r): hunt, part., Od. 19.465†.
qh/rh (qh/r): hunting, chase, game.
qhrhth/r, h=ros, and qhrh/twr, oros (qhra/w): hunter; also as adj., Il. 12.170, Il. 21.252; in Od. 21.397 the better reading is qhhth/r.
qhri/on: wild animal, beast; me/ga qhri/on, of a stag, Od. 10.171.
qh/s, qhto/s: hired laborer, day laborer, pl., Od. 4.644†.
qhsai/ato: see qa/oma Od. 9.1.
qh/sato: see qa/oma Od. 9.2.
*qhseu/s: Theseus, national hero of Athens and Attica, Il. 1.265.
qh=sqai: see qa/oma Od. 9.2.
qhteu/w (qh/s), inf. qhteue/men, aor. qhteu/samen: be a day laborer, work for hire.
-qi (cf. Lat. -bi): a suffix denoting the place in which, e. g. a)gro/qi, a)/lloqi. Of time in h)w=qi.
qi=/s, qi=no/s: heap, Od. 12.45; then of the sandy shore, strand.
*qi/sbh: a town in Boeotia, Il. 2.502†.
qla/w, aor. e)/qlase, qla/sse: crush, bruise.
qli=/bw: press, squeeze; only mid. fut., qli=/yetai w)/mous, ‘will rub his shoulders,’ Od. 17.221†.

qnh/skw, ipf. qnh=skon, fut. inf. qane/esqai, aor. e)/qanon, qa/non, inf. qane/ein, perf. te/qnhka, 3 pl. teqna=si, opt. teqnai/hn, imp. te/qnaqi, -a/tw, inf. teqna/men(ai), part. teqnhw/s, teqnhkui=a, teqnhw=tos and teqnho/tos, dat. teqnew=ti: die, be killed, perf. be dead.
qnhto/s: mortal; subst., qnhtoi/, opp. a=/qa/natoi.

*qo/a=s: (1) son of Andraemon, king of Pleuron and Calydon in Aetolia, Il. 2.638, Il. 4.527.—(2) king in Lemnos, son of Dion&ymacr;sus and Ariadne, Il. 14.230.—(3) a Trojan, slain by Menelāus, Il. 16.311.
*qo/h: a Nereid, Il. 18.40†.
qoina/w: only aor. pass. inf., qoinhqh=nai, to be entertained at the feast, Od. 4.36†.
qo/los, oio: rotunda, a building of circular form, with vaulted roof, in the court-vard of Odysseus's palace. (See plate III., k.)

qoo/s (qe/w): swift, quick; of night, ‘swift - descending,’ because night in the countries of the Mediterranean follows the setting of the sun more speedily than with us (cf. Od. 2.388); qoai\ nh=soi, islands ‘swiftly flitting by’ and sinking in the horizon, Od. 15.299.— Adv., qow=s.
qoo/w, aor e)qo/wsa: make pointed, bring to a point, Od. 9.327†.
qo/re: see qrw/skw.
qou=ros and qou=ris, idos (qrw/skw): impetuous, rushing.
qo/wkos: see qw=kos.

*qo/wn: (1) a Phaeacian, Od. 8.113.—(2) son of Phaenops, a Trojan, slain by Diomed, Il. 5.152.—(3) a Trojan slain by Odysseus, Il. 11.422.—(4) a Trojan, comrade of Asius, slain by Antilochus, Il. 12.140, Il. 13.545.
*qo/wsa: a nymph, the daughter of Phorcys, and mother of Polyphēmus.
*qow/ths: the herald of Menestheus, Il. 12.342.
*qra/sios: a Paeonian, slain by Achilles, Il. 21.210.
qra/sos =qa/rsos, Il. 14.416†.
*qrasu/dhmos: see *qrasu/mhlos.
qrasu-ka/rdios: stout-hearted. (Il.)
qrasu-me/mnwn, onos: bravely steadfast (if from mi/mnw), epith. of Heracles, Il. 5.639 and Od. 11.267.
*qrasumh/dhs: a son of Nestor, Il. 16.321, Il. 10.255.
*qrasu/mhlos: charioteer of Sarpēdon, Il. 16.463†.
qrasu/s, ei=a, u/: bold, daring, confident.
qre/caskon: see tre/xw.

qre/ptra (=qrepth/ria, tre/fw): return for rearing; ou)de\ tokeu=sin qre/ptra fi/lois a)pe/dwken, ‘nor did he recompense his parents for their tender care’ (since his life was cut short), Il. 4.478 and Il. 17.302.
qre/ya: see tre/fw.
*qrhi/kios: Thracian; po/ntos, the northern part of the Aegēan, Il. 23.230 ; *sa/mos, Samothrace, Il. 13.13.
*qrh=ic, ikos, *qrh=|c: inhabitant of Thrace, Thracian; allies of the Trojans.

*qrh/|kh: Thrace, a region of northern Greece, beyond the Penēus, traversed by the river Axius, and inhabited by the Ciconians and Paeonians, Il. 2.845, Il. 20.485, Il. 11.222 .—*qrh/|khqen, from Thrace.—*qrh/|khnde: to Thrace.
*qrhne/w: chant or sing a dirge, Od. 24.61 ; a)oidh/n, ‘were raising the funeral song,’ Il. 24.722.
qrh=nos: dirge, Il. 24.721.
qrh=nus, uos: footstool, either as in cut No. 105, from an Assyrian original, attached to the chair, or as usual standing free; also for the feet of rowers, or of the helmsman, in a ship, Il. 15.729.
*qrh=|c: see *qrh=|ic.
qrigko/s: coping, cornice, pl., battlements, Od. 17.267. (Od.)
qrigko/w: only aor. e)qri/gkwsen, crowned the top of the wall, to make it impassable, with bramble - bushes, Od. 14.10†.
*qri=naki/h: a fabulous island, the pasture of the kine of Helius, Od. 12.135; identified by the ancients with Sicily.
qri/c, trixo/s, dat. pl. qrici/: hair, hairs, of animals as well as men; hence of wool, Il. 3.273; and bristles, Il. 19.254.
qro/non, pl. qro/na: flowers, in woven work, Il. 22.441†.
*qro/nion: a town of the Locrians, Il. 2.533†.

qro/nos: arm-chair, with high back and foot - stool; cushions were laid upon the seat, and over both seat and
back rugs were spread. (See cut, under a)/mpuc. Cf. also Nos. 105, 106, where two chairs, from Assyrian and Greek originals, are represented.)
qro/os: speech, tongue, Il. 4.437†.
qru=li/ssw, aor. pass. qru=li/xqh: crush, Il. 23.396†.
qru/on: rush, collectively, rushes, Il. 21.351†.
*qru/on and *qruo/essa (‘Rushton’): a town in Elis, on the Alphēus, Il. 2.592, Il. 11.711.
qrw/skw, ipf. qrw=skon, aor. e)/qoron, qo/ron, part. qorw/n: spring, leap up, freq. in hostile sense with e)pi/ or e)n, *q 252, Il. 5.161; also fig., of arrows, plants, lots, etc.
qrwsmo/s (qrw/skw): pedi/oio, rise or elevation of the plain of the Scamander, Il. 10.160. (Il.)
quga/thr, gen. qu=gate/ros and qugatro/s: daughter.
que/essin: see qu/os.

qu/ella (qu=/w): blast, gust, squall; puro\s o)looi=o, from volcanic islands, Od. 12.68, 202, 219; figuratively assumed as the agency causing the sudden disappearance of lost persons (cf. a(/rpuia), Od. 20.63, Od. 4.515.
*que/sths: Thyestes, the brother of Atreus, and father of Aegisthus, Od. 4.517, Il. 2.107.
*questia/dhs: son of Thyestes, Aegisthus, Od. 4.518.
quh/eis (qu/os): smoking with incense, fragrant.
quhlh/ (qu/w): the part of the victim to be burned, sacrificial offering, pl., Il. 9.220†.
qu=m-algh/s, es (a)/lgos): heart-grieving, distressing.
qu=m-a=rh/s, e/s: pleasing to the heart, dear, welcome.
*qumbrai=os: a Trojan, slain by Diomed, Il. 11.320†.
*qu/mbrh: a region or a plain bordering on the Thymbrius, a branch of the Scamander, Il. 10.430†.
qum-hgere/w (a)gei/rw): collect or rally the life in one, recover, Od. 7.283†.
qu=m-hdh/s, e/s (h(=dos): delighting the heart, agreeable, Od. 16.389†.
qum-hrh/s, e/s=qu=ma=rh/s, ‘to suit the feelings,’ Od. 10.362†.
qumo - bo/ros (bibrw/skw): heartgnawing, e)/ris. (Il.)
qu=mo-dakh/s, e/s (da/knw): heart-stinging, cutting, Od. 8.185†.
*qumoi/ths: a Trojan chief, Il. 3.146†.
qu=mo - le/wn, ontos: lion - hearted, Il. 5.639.
qu=mo - rai+sth/s, es (r(ai/w): life - destroying. (Il.)

qu=mo/s (qu=/w): heart, soul, life, the seat of emotion, reason, and of the vital principle itself; an extremely common and highly characteristic word in Homer, often employed where no equivalent is called for in modern speech. Of life, qu=mo
 a)fele/sqai, o)le/sai, qu=mo
 a)popnei/ein, e)gei/rein, qu=mo
 a)po\ mele/wn du=nai do/mon *=)/aidos ei)/sw, Il. 7.131; emotion, xo/los e)/mpese qu=mw=|, qu=mo
 o)ri=/nein, e)k qu=mou= file/ein, qu=mw=| xai/rein, a)po\ qu=mou= | ma=llon e)moi\ e)/seai, ‘further from my heart,’ Il. 1.562; desire, appetite, plh/sasqai, te/rpein qu=mo/n, qu=mo\s a)nw/gei, ke/letai, kata\ qu=mo/n, ‘to one's wish,’ Il. 1.136; thoughts, disposition, qu=mo
 pei/qein, fra/zesqai qu=mw=|, e(/na qu=mo
 e)/xein, e)n qumw=| bale/sqai, ‘lay to heart’; kata\ fre/na kai\ kata\ qu=mo/n, ‘in mind and soul.’
qumo-fqo/ros (fqei/rw): life-destroying, deadly; sh/mata, ‘of fatal import,’ Il. 6.169 ; fa/rmaka, Od. 2.329; ‘inhuman,’ Od. 19.323; ‘heart - wasting,’ a)/xos, ka/matos, d 716, Od. 10.363.
qu=/nw (qu=/w), ipf. qu=non: rush along, charge. (Il. and Od. 24.449.)
quo/eis, en (qu/os): odorous, Il. 15.153†.
qu/on: a tree with fragrant wood, arbor-vitae, Od. 5.60†.
qu/os, eos: pl., burnt-offerings.
quo-sko/os: prophet, drawing omens from the smoke of burnt-offerings, Il. 24.221, Od. 21.145.
quo/w (qu/os)=qu=/w, only pass. perf. part., tequwme/non, fragrant, Il. 14.172†.
qu/raze: to the door, forth, out, Il. 5.694, Od. 5.410.
qura-wro/s (root vor, o(ra/w): doorwatching, of watch-dogs, Il. 22.69†.
qureo/s (qu/rh): door-stone, placed by Polyphēmus at the mouth of his den, Od. 9.240.
qu/retra, pl.: wings of a door, door, Il. 2.415; au)lh=s, near to the sto/ma lau/rhs, Od. 22.137 (see plate III., o).

qu/rh: door, gate, folding - doors, entrance, Od. 13.370 ; e)pi\ qu/rh|si, ‘at the
court’ (cf. ‘Sublime Porte,’ of the Sultan, and Xenophon's basile/ws qu/rai).
qu/rhqi: out of doors, out of the sea, Od. 14.352 (cf. qu/raze, Od. 5.410).
qu/rhfi =qu/rhqi.
qusano/eis, essa (qu/sanos): tasselled, many-tasselled, of the aegis. (Il.)
qu/sanos: pl., tufts, tassels, fringe. (Il.)
qu/sqla (qu/w), pl.: the thyrsi, wands and other sacred implements used in the worship of Dion&ymacr;sus, Il. 6.134†. (See cuts.)
qu=/w: rage; of men, and of winds, waves, torrents, ‘surging,’ Il. 21.234 ; da/pedon d' a(/pan ai(/mati qu=en, ‘reeked,’ ‘swam’ with blood, Od. 11.420.
qu/w, part. qu/onta, but ipf. qu=e, aor. e)/qu=sa: offer as burnt offering, Od. 14.446, Od. 15.260. (See cut.)
qu-w/dhs (qu/os): fragrant. (Od.)
qwh/ (ti/qhmi): penalty, Od. 2.192, Il. 13.669.
qw=kos and qo/wkos (Att. qa=kos) seat, Od. 2.14; assembly, Od. 2.26 .—qw=ko/nde, to the assembly.
*qw=n: Thon, a noble Egyptian, Od. 4.228†.
qwrhkth/s (qwrh/ssw): cuirassed, wellcuirassed. (Il.)

qw/rhc, hkos: breast - plate, cuirass, corselet, Il. 11.19 ff. It was usually of bronze, consisting of two plates, gu/ala. (See adjacent cut, also cut No. 33.) The cuirass fitted closely to the body, and was cut square off at the waist; the shoulder - pieces (see cut) were drawn down by small chains and fastened to buttons in front; the metal plates were united by clasps (see cut No. 19); the upper part of the thighs was protected by the mi/trh, worn over the apron, zw=ma, of leather or felt, and by its metal flaps, pte/ruges (Nos. 12, 33, 79), or plates (Nos. 3 and 33); over the qw/rhc, mi/trh, and zw=ma was bound the zwsth/r (No. 3), below which projected the lower end of the xitw/n (Nos. 3, 19, 33; cf. linoqw/rhc and xitw/n).
qwrh/ssw, aor. qw/rhce, subj. qwrh/comen, mid. fut. qwrh/comai, pass. ipf. 3 du. qwrh/ssesqon, aor. qwrh/xqhsan: arm with cuirass, mid., arm oneself for battle.
qw/s, qwo/s: jackal. (Il.)

div1.head: *i
div1.entryFree: i)/a, i)h=s: see i)/os.
i)a/: see i)o/s.

i)ai/nw, aor. i<*>hna, pass. i<*>a/nqh (i= when with augment): warm, soften by warming, Od. 12.175; met., warm, melt, move the heart to compassion, cheer, etc., Od. 15.379; often thus in pass., qu=mo/s, kh=r, Il. 23.598, Od. 22.59; me/twpon i)a/nqh, ‘brightened,’ Il. 15.103; also w. acc. of specification, qu=mo/n, fre/nas, y 47, Od. 24.382; w. dat., Od. 19.537.
*)/iaira: a Nereid, Il. 18.42†.

i)a/llw, aor. i)/hla, inf. i)h=lai: send, mostly implying quick motion toward some definite point; freq. e)p' o)nei/ata xei=ras i)a/llein, ‘apply’ the hands to viands, Il. 9.91, etc.; e(ta/rois e)pi\ (adv.) xei=ras i)/allen, ‘flung out’ his arms to them, Od. 9.288 ; o)isto\n a)po\ neurh=fin i)/allen | *(/ektoros a)ntikru=/, Il. 8.300; e)pi\ (adv.) desmo\n i)/hlon, ‘whip’ on a knot, Od. 8.443, cf. 497; met., a)ti=mi=/h|sin i)a/llein, ‘assail’ as with missiles, Od. 13.142.
*)ia/lmenos: a son of Ares, leader of Boeotians, Il. 2.512, Il. 9.82.
*)ia/nassa, *)ia/neira: Nereids, Il. 18.47†.
i)a/nqh: see i)ai/nw.
i=)a=/omai, ipf. i=)a=to, fut. i=)h/setai, aor. i=)hoa/mhn: heal, cure, Il. 12.2, Od. 9.525.
*)ia=/ones: Ionians, Il. 13.685†.
*=)ia/petos: a Titan, Il. 8.479†.
i)a/ptw: only mh\ klai/ousa kata\ (adv.) xro/a ka=lo\n i)a/pth|(s), harm by smiting, Od. 2.376, Od. 4.749.
*)ia/rdanos: the river Iardanus.— (1) in Crete, Od. 3.292.—(2) in Elis, near Pheiae, Il. 7.135.
i)/a=si: see ei)=mi.
*=)iasi/dhs: son of Iasus.—(1) Amphīon, Od. 11.283.—(2) Dmetor, Od. 17.443.
*=)iasi/wn: a mortal beloved by Demeter, and slain by the thunderbolt of Zeus, Od. 5.125†.
*=)/iason *)/argos: Iasian Argos, meaning the whole of the Peloponnēsus, the origin of the epithet being unknown, Od. 18.246†.
*=)/iasos: (1) son of Sphelus, a leader of the Athenians, slain by Aenēas, Il. 15.332.—(2) the father of Amphīon.— (3) the father of Dmetor.
i)au/w (cf. a)/vesa), ipf. i)/auon, iter. i)au/eskon, aor. inf. i)au=sai: sleep, rest, lie; polla=\s me\n a)u/pnous nu/ktas i)/auon, Il. 9.325, 470, Od. 19.340.
i)axh/ (viaxh/): loud, sharp cry, shriek; of men in battle, Il. 4.456; the shades in the nether world, Od. 11.43; hunters, Il. 15.275.

i)a/xw (via/xw), ipf. i<*>axon (i= when with augment): cry loud and sharply, shriek, scream; of applause, the cry of battle, of wounded men, Il. 23.766, Il. 4.506, Il. 5.343, etc.; of Circe, threatened with Odysseus's sword, Od. 10.323; of a child, Il. 6.468; transferred to inanimate objects, the ‘twanging’ of the bow-string, Il. 4.125; the ‘blare’ of the trumpet, Il. 18.219; ‘hissing’ of hot iron in water, Od. 9.392; ‘crackling’ of fire, Il. 23.216; but the Eng. words do not involve a personification like the Greek.
*)iawlko/s: Iolcus, a town in Thessaly on the Pagasaean gulf, Od. 11.256, Il. 2.712.
i)gnu/h (go/nu): hollow of the knee, Il. 13.212†.
*=)idai=os: of Mt. Ida, Idaean, epith. of the mountains belonging to the range, Il. 8.170, Il. 20.189; also of Zeus, whose grove and altar were upon Gargaron, Il. 16.605, Il. 24.291.
*=)/idaios: Idaeus.—(1) a herald of the Trojans, charioteer to Priam.—(2) a Trojan, the son of Dares, Il. 5.11.
i)de/ =h)de/, and.
i)/de, i)de/ein, i)/deske: see ei)/dw (I.).
i)de/w: see ei)/dw (II.).

*=)/idh: Ida, a mountain range, rich in springs, ravines, forest, and game, extending from Phrygia, through Mysia, toward the Hellespont, and subsiding into the plain near Troy, Il. 2.821, Il. 11.183; its summit, *ga/rgaron.—*=)/idhqen, from Ida.
i)/dhai: see ei)/dw (I.).
*=)/idhs: a famous archer, the father of Cleopatra, Il. 9.558†.
i)/dios: private, opp. dh/mios, Od. 3.82 and Od. 4.314.
i=)di/w =i(dro/w, only ipf., Od. 20.204†.
i)/dmen(ai): see ei)/dw (II.).
i)dno/w, pass. aor. i)dnw/qh, part. -qei/s: bend back ward, double up, pass. as mid., Il. 2.266, Od. 8.375.
i)doi/ato: see ei)/dw (I.).
*=)idomeneu/s: Idomeneus, son of Deucalion, grandson of Minos, king in Crete, Il. 4.265, Il. 12.117, Il. 2.645; his son Arsilochus, Od. 13.259; comrade-at-arms, Meriones, Il. 23.113.
i)drei/h (vidr.): knowledge, skill. (Il.)
i)/dris (vidr.): knowing, skilled, skilful. w. inf., Od. 7.108. (Od.)
i(dro/w (i(drw/s), part. i(drw/onta, etc., fem. pl. i(drw=sai, fut. i(drw/sei, aor. i(/drwsa: sweat.
i(dru<*>/w (root e(d), aor. i(/dru=sa, pass. i(dru/nqhn: cause or bid <*>o be seated, Il. 2.191; pass., take seats, be seated, Il. 3.78.
i(drw/s, dat. -w=|, acc. -w= (svidr.): sweat.
i)dui=a: see ei)/dw (II.).
i)/dw, i)/dwmi: see ei)/dw (I.).
i)/e, i)/en: see ei)=mi.
i(/ei: see i(/hmi.
i)ei/h: see ei)=mi.
i(/emai: see i(/hmi.
i)/entai, i)/esqe: more correct reading, i(/entai, i(/esqe, see i(/hmi.
i(ereu/s, i=(reu/s, h=os: priest, in charge of the sacrifices to some special god, also soothsayer, Il. 11.23.

i(ereu/w, i=(reu/w, ipf. iter. i=(reu/eskon, fut. inf. i(ereu/sein, aor. i(e/reusa, pass. plup. i(e/reuto, mid. aor. inf. i=(reu/sasqai: sacrifice, esp. by killing the victim, offer, then, in general, slaughter, Il. 6.174 ; cei/nw|, ‘in honor of the guest,’ Od. 14.414; mid., subjective, Od. 19.198.
i(erh<*>ion: victim, animal for sacrifice or slaughter, Od. 14.94.
i(ero/n, i=(ro/n, neut. of i(ero/s as subst.: sacrifice, victim, Od. 1.61, Il. 1.147.

i<*>ero/s, i=(ro/s: (1) strong, powerful; i=)/s, me/nos, fula/kwn te/los, pulawroi/, strato/s, Od. 2.409, Od. 7.167, Il. 10.56, Il. 24.681, Od. 24.81; i)xqu/s, ‘lively,’ Il. 16.407.—(2) sacred, hallowed.
i(za/nw (i(/zw): sit; trans., cause or bid to be seated, Il. 23.258.
i(/zw (root e(d), ipf. i(=zon, iter. i(/zeske: take a seat, sit down, sit still, rest; boulh/n, ‘hold a council,’ ‘session,’ Il. 2.53; mid., like act., of an ambuscade, Il. 18.522.
i)/hla, i)h=lai: see i)a/llw.
*)ihlu=so/s: a town in Rhodes, Il. 2.656†.

i(/hmi, i(/hsi, 3 pl. i(ei=si, inf. i<*>e/menai, part. i(e/ntes, i<*>ei=sai, imp. i(/ei, ipf. i(/ei, 3 pl. i(/en, fut. h(/sw, aor. h(=ka, e(/hka, 3 pl. h(=kan and e(/san, subj. h(=|sin, opt. ei(/hn, inf. ei(=nai, mid. pres. i(/etai, imp. i(/esqe, part. i<*>emenos, ipf. i=(/eto, i(/ento, aor. 3 pl. e(/nto: let go, i. e. set in motion of any sort.—I. act., send, a)/ggelo/n tini, Il. 18.182; put to anything, as harness, Il. 16.152; throw, let fly, meta\ (adv.) d' i=)o\n e(/hken, ‘in among them,’ Il. 1.48; so ‘let fall’ anything, as tears, a sword from the hand, ‘let down’ the hair, ‘let on’ water, Il. 12.25, and of the river itself ‘rolling’ its waters (thus, intrans., Od. 11.239, Od. 7.130); metaph., of ‘dismissing,’ i. e. by satisfying, a desire, e)/ron, Il. 13.638; ‘inspiring’ one with force, Il. 5.125; ‘laying’ misfortune on one, Il. 10.71. The applications of the word are very numerous, but always distinct if the fundamental signification be held in mind. The ground-meaning, as may be seen from the examples, usually gets a specific turn from the context, esp. by means of adverbs (e)n, e)c, kata/, meta/, etc.).—II. mid., set oneself in motion at something (tino/s), i(e/menos potamoi=o r(oa=/wn, ‘giving thyself a direction’ toward Oceanus, Od. 10.529; so ‘press on,’ ‘hasten,’ Il. 13.707, Il. 12.274; met., with and without qu=mw=|, ‘strive after’ (tino/s), ‘be eager,’ Il. 23.371 ; qu=mo/s, Il. 8.301; freq. phrase, e)pei\ po/sios kai\ e)dhtu/os e)c e)/ron e(/nto, had dismissed ‘from themselves,’ Il. 1.469, Od. 1.150.
i)h/nate: see i)ai/nw.
i=)h/sasqe: see i=)a=/omai.
i)/h|si: see ei)=mi.
*)ihsoni/dhs: son of Iēson (Jason), Euneus, Il. 7.468, 471, Il. 23.747.
*)ih/swn: Iēson (Jason), the leader of the Argonauts, Od. 12.72
i=)hth/r, h=ros,=i=)htro/s.
i=)htro/s (i)a=/omai): healer, surgeon, physician; with a)nh/r, Il. 11.514.
i)qai - ge/nhs (i)qu/s): born in lawful wedlock, legitimate, Od. 14.203†.
*)iqaime/nhs: a Lycian, Il. 16.586†.

*)iqa/kh: Ithaca.—(1) the native island of Odysseus, with Mts. Neritus, Neius, and Corax, and the harbor Reithrum. Epithets, a)mfi/alos, eu)dei/elos, e)uktime/nh, kranah/, paipalo/essa, trhxei=a.—(2) the city, at the foot of Mt. Neius, Od. 3.81, cf. Od. 16.322 .—*)iqa/khnde, to Ithaca.—*)iqakh/sios: inhabitant of Ithaca, Ithacan.
*)/iqakos: the eponymous hero of the island of Ithaca, Od. 17.207†.
i)/qi, imp. of ei)=mi: come! go! employed as an interjection, freq. with a)/ge.
i)/qma, atos: step, gait, pl., Il. 5.778†.
i=)qu/ntata: see i)qu/s.

i=)qu=/nw (i)qu/s), aor. i=)/qu=na, subj. i)qu=/nomen. make straight, straighten, e)pi\ sta/qmhn, ‘to the line,’ Od. 5.245; pass., i(/ppw d' i)qu=nqh/thn, ‘placed themselves in line’ with the pole of the chariot, Il. 16.475; guide a ship, chariot, etc., and, of missiles, aim, direct, Il. 5.290, Il. 17.632, mid., ‘his arrow,’ Od. 22.8.
i)qu-pti=/wn, wnos (pe/tomai): straightflying, meli/h, Il. 21.169†.

i=)qu/s, ei=a, u/: straight; te/trapto pro\s i)qu/ oi(, ‘straight opposite him,’ Il. 14.403; usually metaph., straight, right, just, Il. 23.580; sup., i)qu/ntata, most fairly, Il. 18.508.—As adv., i=)qu/s, i<*>)qu/, straight at, straight for, tino/s, Il. 5.849; also with prepositions, and abs., Il. 20.99, Od. 3.10 ; i=)qu\s fe/rein, ma/xesqai, fronei=n, ‘turn the mind straight on,’ ‘be bent on battle,’ Il. 13.135, cf. Il. 11.95.
i=)qu/s, u/os: straight course, a)n' i)qu/n, ‘straight up,’ ‘straight on,’ Il. 21.303, Od. 8.377; hence ‘attack,’ ‘tendency,’ ‘disposition,’ Il. 6.69, Od. 4.434, Od. 16.304.
i=)qu/w, aor. i=)qu=sa: go straight forward, advance, attack, of warriors, a lion, Il. 12.48; w. gen., neo/s, Il. 15.693; w. inf., ‘strive,’ Od. 11.591.
*)iqw/mh: a town in Thessaly, Il. 2.729†.

i(ka=/nw (i=(/kw), mid. i(ka=/nomai: come to, arrive at, reach, w. acc. of person or thing attained to, less often with prep., Il. 1.431; freq. of supplication, gou/naq' i(ka=/nw, Od. 5.449; met., ‘come upon,’ ‘come home to,’ u(/pnos, qe/sfata, *k 96, Od. 9.507, etc. Often with perf. signif., ‘am come to,’ Il. 9.197, Od. 6.119.
*=)ika/rios: Icarius, the brother of Tyndareus, and father of Penelope, Od. 1.276, 329, Od. 4.797.
*=)ika/rios po/ntos: the Icarian Sea, S. W. of Asia Minor, Il. 2.145†.
i)/kelos (vik.), like, resembling.
*(iketa=oni/dhs: son of Hicetāon, Melanippus, Il. 15.546†.
*(iketa=/wn: (1) a son of Laomedon, and brother of Priam, Il. 3.147, Il. 20.238.— (2) the father of Melanippus, Il. 15.576.
i(keteu/w (i(ke/ths), aor. i(ke/teusa: ap- proach as suppliant, supplicate, tina/, also w. praep. (Od. and Il. 16.574).
i(ke/ths (i=(/kw): suppliant, for protection of any sort, but esp. one in search of purification from homicide (cf. Tlepolemus, Lycophron, Patroclus), Od. 9.269, Il. 21.75.
i(keth/sios: of suppliants, protector of suppliants, epith. of Zeus, Od. 13.213†.
i(/khai: see i(kne/omai.
*)ikma/lios: a joiner in Ithaca, Od. 19.57†.
i)kma/s, a/dos: moisture, Il. 17.392†.
i)/kmenos: fair wind (ou)=ros), a wind ‘that follows fast’ (secundus). (Od.)

i(kne/omai (i(/kw), part. i(kneu/menai, ipf. i(kneu/mesqa, fut. i(/comai, aor. i<*>ko/mhn, 2 sing. i<*>keu (i= when with augment): come to, arrive at, reach, w. acc., also with praep.; ‘return,’ when the context gives this sense, Od. 23.151; esp. ‘approach as suppliant,’ ‘supplicate,’ Il. 14.260, Il. 22.123, Od. 9.267; met., poqh/, ka/matos, se/bas, ti/ se fre/nas i=(/keto pe/nqos; Il. 1.362.
i)/kria, i)krio/fin, pl.: deck-beams, deck, which in the Homeric ship was partial, only fore and aft (see plate IV., at end of volume); also ribs of a ship. (See cut No. 32.)

i=(/kw, subj. i=(/kwmi, ipf. i(=ke, aor. i(=con: come (to), reach; i(/kw is the stem-form answering to i(ka=/nw and i(kne/omai, and has the same applications and constructions as those verbs; pinuth\ fre/nas i=(/kei, ‘informs,’ Od. 20.228.
i=)lado/n (vi/lh): adv., in troops, Il. 2.93†.
i(/la=os: appeased, hence propitious, gracious, kind. (Il.)
i=(la/skomai and i=(la=/omai (Il. 2.550), ipf. i=(la/skonto, aor. subj. (or fut.) i=(la/ssomai, i=(laso/mesqa, part. i=(lassa/menoi: reconcile to oneself, appease, propitiate.
*=)ilh/ios (vi=l.): of Ilus, pedi/on, so named, according to the scholiast, from the tomb of Ilus, Il. 21.558†.
i=(/lhmi, imp. i(/lhqi, perf. subj. i=(lh/khsi, opt. i=(lh/koi; be propitious, gracious, Od. 3.380. (Od.)
*=)ilio/qen (vi=l.): from Ilium.
*=)ilio/qi (vi=l.): always with pro/, before Ilium.

*=)/ilios (vi=/lios) and *=)/ilion (Il. 15.71): Ilium, a name for Troy derived from
that of its founder Ilus; epithets, ai)peinh/, ai)pu/, e)rateinh/, eu)tei/xeos, h)nemo/essa, i(erh/, o)fruo/essa. In wider signification, for the region about Troy, Il. 1.71, Od. 19.182. In Il. 15.66, Il. 21.104, Il. 22.6, the true form of the gen. is *)ili/oo, as the scansion shows (cf. *ai)/olos).
*=)ilio/fi =*=)ili/ou, Il. 21.295.
i)lla/s, a/dos (ei)/lw): pl., twisted cords, Il. 13.572†.
*)=ilos: Ilus.—(1) son of Tros, and father of Laomedon, Il. 11.166, Il. 20.232; his tomb, Il. 10.415, Il. 11.372.—(2) son of Mermeros of Ephyra, Od. 1.259.
i=)lu=/s, u=os: mud, slime, Il. 21.318†.

i<*>ma=/s, antos: leather strap or thong. —(1) in connection with the chariot, (a) straps in which the chariot - box was hung, or perhaps more likely the network of plaited straps enclosing the body of the chariot, Il. 5.727; (b) the reins, Il. 23.324, 363; (c) the halter, Il. 8.544.—(2) the chin-strap of a helmet, Il. 3.371.—(3) the cestus of boxers, see pugma/xoi.—(4) the leash or latchstring by which doors were fastened. See adjacent cut, in four divisions: above, the closed, below the unfastened door; on the left, as seen from the inner side, on the right as seen from the outside. To close the door from the outside, the string, hanging loosely in fig. 1, was pulled until it drew the bolt from the position of fig. 2 to that of fig. 3, when it was made fast by a knot to the ring, korw/nh, e, fig. 4. To open from the outside, the string was first untied, and then the klhi/s, not unlike a hook (fig. 4, f), was introduced through the key-hole, c, and by means of a crook (g, fig. 3) at the end of it the bolt was pushed back from the position of fig. 3 to that of fig. 2, and the door opened, Od. 1.442.— (5) for a bed - cord, Od. 23.201.—(6) the magic girdle of Aphrodīte, Il. 14.214, 219. —(7) a thong to make a drill revolve, Od. 9.385. (See cut No. 121.)
i(ma/sqlh: lash, whip.
i(ma/ssw, aor. i(/mase, subj. i(ma/ssw: lash, scourge, beat, Il. 5.589, Il. 2.782, Il. 15.17.
*)imbrasi/dhs: son of Imbrasus, Piroüs, Il. 4.520†.
*)/imbrios: (1) inhabitant of Imbros, Imbrian, Il. 21.43.—(2) the son of Mentor, son-in-law of Priam, slain by Teucer, Il. 13.171, 197.
*)/imbros: Imbros, an island on the coast of Thrace, with capital city of the same name, Il. 14.281, Il. 13.33.
i=(mei/rw (i=(/meros), mid. i=(mei/retai, i(meiro/menos, aor. opt. i=(mei/raito, subj. i=(mei/retai: long for, yearn for, tino/s, and w. inf., Od. 10.431, Il. 14.163.
i)/men(ai): see ei)=mi.
i=(mero/eis, essa, en (i=(/meros): passionate, fond, lovely; go/os, e)/rga ga/moio, a)oidh/, Od. 10.398, *e 429, Od. 1.421.—Adv., i=(mero/en kiqa/rize, charmingly, Il. 18.570.
i=(/meros: longing, passion, love; freq, w. obj. gen.; w. two genitives, patro\s i=(/meros go/oio, ‘yearning after tears, to weep for his father,’ Il. 24.507, Od. 4.113.
i=(merto/s (i=(mei/rw): lovely, Il. 2.751†.
i)/mmenai: see ei)=mi.

i(/na: (1) adv., where; this meaning being the primary one, is to be assumed in preference to signif. (2), when the sense admits, e. g. Il. 24.382. Apparently demonstrative, there, in Il. 10.127.—(2) conj., in order that, that; rarely with ke/, Od. 12.156.
i)nda/llomai (root vid): be seen, appear, w. part., Il. 17.213 ; w(/s moi i)nda/lletai h)=tor, impers., ‘as floats before me in recollection’ (h)=tor like kata\ qu=mo/n), Od. 19.224.
i)/nesi: see i=)/s.
i=)ni/on (vi=n.): bone of the back of the head. (Il.)
*)/inw: Ino, see *leukoqe/a=.
i)/calos: doubtful word, spry, epith. of the wild goat, Il. 4.105†.
*)ici=o/nios: a)/loxos *)ici=oni/h, wife of Ixīon, Il. 14.317†.
i(=con: see i=(/kw.
i)cu<*>s, dat. i)cui=: waist. (Od.)
i)o-dnefh/s, e/s (vi/on, dno/fos): violetdark, dark-hued, ei)=ros. (Od.)
i=)o - do/kos (i=)o/s, de/xomai): arrowreceiving, quiver.
i)o - eidh/s, e/s (vi/on, vei=dos): violetcolored, deep blue, epith. of the sea.
i)o/eis, essa (vi/on) = i)oeidh/s, of iron, Il. 23.850†.
i)o/-mwros (viom.): doubtful word, a disparaging epithet applied to the Greeks, *)argei=oi i)o/mwroi, boasters. (Il.)
i)/on (vi/on): collectively, violets, Od. 5.72†.
i)onqa/s, a/dos (vionq.): shaggy, Od. 14.50†.
i=)o/s, pl. i=)oi/ (i=)a/, Il. 20.68): arrow.
i)/os, i)/a, i)/on (=ei(=s, mi/a, e(/n), gen. i)h=s, dat. i)w=|, i)h=|: one; as subst. th\n i)/an, ‘one portion.’ (Il. and Od. 14.435.)
i)o/ths, htos: will, mostly qew=n i)o/thti, Od. 7.214, etc.; mnhsth/rwn i)o/thti, ‘according to their wish,’ Od. 18.234.
i)/oulos (ou)=los): first growth of beard, down, Od. 11.319†.
i=)o-xe/aira (xe/w): pouring arrows, archeress, epith. of Artemis, both as adj. and subst.
i(ppa/zomai: drive one's horses, Il. 23.426†.
*(ippasi/dhs: son of Hippasus.—(1) Apisāon, Il. 17.348.—(2) Hypsēnor, Il. 13.411.—(3) Charops, Il. 11.426.—(4) Socus, Il. 11.431.
i(ppeu/s, h=os, pl. i(pph=es: chariotman, whether as warrior fighting from the chariot, or as competitor in a chariot-race, Il. 4.297, Il. 23.262.
i(pp-hla/sios (e)lau/nw): for driving chariots; i(pphlasi/h o(do/s, Il. 7.340 and 439.
i(pp - hla/ta (e)lau/nw), for -a/ths: driver of steeds, chariot-fighter, knight.
i(pp-h/latos: passable with chariots, adapted to driving horses. (Od.)
*(ipp-hmolgoi/ (a)me/lgw): the Hippemolgi, ‘mare-milkers,’ a Scythian tribe, Il. 13.5.
i(ppio-xa/rmhs (xa/rmh): fighter from a chariot, Il. 24.257, Od. 11.259.
i(ppo/-botos (bo/skw): horse-nourishing, horse - breeding, esp. as epith. of Argos, Il. 2.287.
*(ippoda/ma=s: a Trojan, slain by Achilles, Il. 20.401.
*(ippoda/meia: Hippodamīa.—(1) a daughter of Anchīses, Il. 13.429.—(2) an attendant of Penelope, Od. 18.182.—(3) the wife of Pirithoüs, Il. 2.742.
i(ppo/ - damos (dama/zw): horse-taming, epith. of the Trojans, and of individual heroes. (Il. and Od. 3.17, 181.)
*(ippo/damos: a Trojan, slain by Odysseus, Il. 11.335†.
i(ppo-da/seia (dasu/s, ei=a): with thick horse-hair plume, epith. of the helmet. (Il. and Od. 22.111, 145.)
i(ppo/-dromos: course for chariots, Il. 23.330.
i(ppo/qen: from the (wooden) horse, Od. 8.515, Od. 11.531.
*(ippo/qoos: (1) a son of Priam, Il. 24.251.—(2) a leader of the Pelasgians, slain by Ajax, Il. 17.289.
i(ppo - ke/leuqos: making way with the chariot, swift-driving, epith. of Patroclus. (Il.)
i(ppo/ - komos (ko/mh): decked with horse-hair.
i(ppo-korusth/s (koru/ssw): chariotequipped, chariot-fighter, epith. of the Maeonians and Paeonians, and of individual heroes, Il. 2.1, Il. 24.677.
*(ippoko/wn: a cousin of Rhesus, Il. 10.518†.
*(ippo/loxos: (1) son of Antimachus, slain by Agamemnon, Il. 11.122.— (2) a Lycian, son of Bellerophon, the father of Glaucus, Il. 6.206.
i(ppo/ - maxos: fighting from horses (chariots), Il. 10.431†.
*(ippo/maxos: a Trojan, the son of Antimachus, slain by Leonteus, Il. 12.189†.
*(ippo/noos: a Greek, slain by Hector, Il. 11.303†.
i(ppo/-polos (poleu/w): horse-managing, horse-training, Thracians, Il. 13.4 and Il. 14.227.

i(/ppos: horse or mare; a)/rsenes i(/ppoi, ‘stallions,’ Od. 13.81 ; qh/lees i(/ppoi, i(/ppoi qh/leiai, *e 269, Il. 11.681; the Homeric Greeks did not ride horseback, but employed chariots; hence i(/ppoi,
oftener i(/ppw, span, chariot, alone or w. a(/rma, Il. 12.120; freq. i(/ppoisin kai\ o)/xesfin, Il. 12.114, 119; e)c or a)f' i(/ppwn a)pobh=nai, *g 265, Il. 5.13; of chariotmen as opposed to infantry, Od. 14.267, Il. 2.554, Il. 16.167, Il. 18.153.
i(pposu/nh: horsemanship, i. e. chariot-fighting. (Il. and Od. 24.40.)
i(ppo/ta, for -o/ths: horseman, knight, esp. as epith. of Nestor, Il. 2.336, 628.
*(ippota/dhs: son of Hippotes, Aeolus, Il. 10.36†.
*(ippoti/wn: an Ascanian, slain by Meriones, Il. 13.792, Il. 14.514.
i(/pp-ouris, ios (ou)ra=/): with horsetail plume, epith. of the helmet. (Il. and Od. 22.124.)
i)/ptomai, fut. i)/yetai, aor. 2 sing. i)/yao: smite, chastise, afflict; said of gods and kings, Il. 1.454, Il. 2.193.
i=(reu/s: see i(ereu/s.
i=(reu/sasqai: see i(ereu/w.
*=(irh/: a town in Messēne, under the sway of Agamemnon, Il. 9.150, 292.
i=)/rhc, hkos: hawk or falcon; typical of swiftness, Il. 15.237.

i)=ris (vi=ris), dat. pl. i=)/rissin: rainbow, Il. 11.27, Il. 17.547.—Personified, *)=iris, idos, acc. *)=irin, voc. *)=iri, Iris, messenger of the gods in the Iliad. To men she usually appears under the assumed form of some mortal.
i=(ro/n, i=(ro/s: see i(ero/n, i(ero/s.
*)=iros (vi=ris): Irus, a nickname of Arnaeus the beggar, given to him by the suitors of Penelope, because he went on errands, Od. 18.5 follg.

i=)/s (vi=/s, cf. vis), acc. i)=na, pl. i)=nes, dat. i=)/nesi: (1) sinew, collectively, Il. 17.522, elsewhere pl.—(2) strength, force, literally and fig.; freq. with gen. as periphrasis for the person, kraterh\ i=)\s *)odush=os, i. e. the mighty strong Odysseus himself, Il. 23.720 and Il. 21.356.
i=)sa/zw (vi=sos), part. i=)sa/zousa, mid. aor. iter. i)sa/sketo: make equal, balance, Il. 12.435; mid., deem oneself equal, vie with, Il. 24.607.
i)/san: see (1) ei)=mi.—(2) ei)/dw (Il.).
*=)/isandros: Isander, son of Bellerophon, slain by Ares, Il. 6.197, 203.
i)/sa=si: see ei)/dw (Il.).
i=)sa/sketo: see i=)sa/zw.
i)/sqi: see ei)/dw (II.).
i)/sqmion: necklace, Od. 18.300†. (See cuts Nos. 2, 40, 41 and 93.)
i)/ske: defective ipf., perhaps from the same root as e)/spete, said, spoke, Od. 19.203, Od. 22.31.
*)/ismaros: a city of the Ciconians, Od. 9.40.
i=)so/-qeos (vi=sos): equal to the gods, godlike; always i=)so/qeos fw=s. (Il., and of Telemachus, Od. 1.324, Od. 20.124.)
i=)so/-moros (vi=sos): of equal lot, a peer, Il. 15.209†.
i=)so/-pedon (vi=sos): level ground, Il. 13.142†.

i)=sos (vi=sos, Att. i)/sos), i=)/sh, i)=son: equal in size, weight, or number, also like; freq. i=)/sh as subst., mh/ ti/s moi a)tembo/menos ki/oi i=)/shs, of an equal share in the feast, Od. 9.42, Il. 11.705, Il. 12.423; also i)=sa as subst, ‘reparation,’ Od. 2.203. —Adv., i)=son, i)=sa, equally, on equal terms, Il. 9.616; also kata\ vi=sa, e)pi\ vi=sa, ‘equally balanced,’ ‘undecided, Il. 11.336, Il. 12.436, Il. 15.413.
*)=isos: a natural son of Priam, slain by Agamemnon, Il. 11.101†.
i=)so-fari/zw (vi=sos, fe/rw): deem oneself equal, vie with, rival, in anything (ti\), Il. 6.101, Il. 9.390. (Il.)
i=)so - fo/ros: bearing alike, equally strong, Od. 18.373†.
i=)so/w (vi=sos), mid. aor. opt. i=)swsai/mhn: mid., compare oneself, Od. 7.212†.

i(/sthmi, i(sta=si, imp. i(/sth, inf. i(sta/menai, ipf. iter. i(/staske, 3 pl. i(/stasan, fut. inf. sth/sein, aor. 1 e)/sthsa, sth=sa, aor. 2 e)/sthn, sth=n, 3 pl. e)/sthsan, e)/stan, sta/n, iter. sta/ske, subj. sth/h|s, sth/h|, 1 pl. ste/wmen, stei/omen, perf. e(/sthka, du. e(/staton, 2 pl. e(/sthte, 3 pl. e(sta=si, subj. e(sth/kh|, imp. e(/staqi, e(/state, inf. e(sta/men(ai), part. e(stao/tos, etc., also e(stew=ta, etc., plup. 1 pl. e(/stamen.—Mid. (and pass.), i(/stamai, imp. i(/staso, ipf. i(/stato, fut. sth/somai, aor. 1 sth/santo, sth/sasqai, -sa/menos, aor. pass. e)sta/qh: I. trans. (pres., ipf., fut., and aor. 1 act.), set in place, set on foot, cause to stand, rise, or stop; of marshalling soldiers, sti/xas, la=o/n, *b 525, Il. 6.433; causing clouds, waves, to rise, Od. 12.405, Il. 21.313; bringing horses to a standstill, ships to anchor, Il. 5.368, Od. 3.182; metaph., ‘excite,’ ‘rouse,’ battle, strife, Od. 11.314, Od. 16.292; weigh, Il. 19.247, Il. 22.350, Il. 24.232.— Mid. aor. 1 is causative, set up or set on foot for oneself, or something of one's own, krhth=ra, i(sto/n, met., ma/xhn, *z
528, Il. 1.480, Od. 9.54.—II. intrans. (pass., fut. mid., aor. 2 and perf. and plup. act.), place oneself, come to a stand, rise, perf. and plup., stand; ku=ma i(/statai, Il. 21.240; o)fqalmoi\ w(sei\ ke/ra= e(/stasan, ‘were fixed,’ Od. 19.211 ; sth= d' o)rqo/s, o)rqai\ tri/xes e)/stan, Il. 24.359; met., nei=kos i(/statai, e(/bdomos e(sth/kei mei/s, ‘had set in,’ Il. 19.117 ; mh\n i(sta/menos, ‘beginning of the month,’ Od. 14.162, Od. 19.307; of spring, Od. 19.519; aor. pass., o( d' e)sta/qh h)u/te pe/trh, Od. 17.463.
*(isti/aia: a city in Euboea, Il. 2.537†.
i(sti=/h (Att. e(sti/a=): hearth. (Od.)
i(sti/on (i(sto/s): sail. (See cut, from an ancient coin bearing the inscription *n*i*k*o*m*h*d*i*w*n. *d*i*s. *n*e*w*k*o*r*w*n.)
i(sto-do/kh (de/xomai): mast - receiver, mast-crutch, a saw-horse shaped support on the after-deck to receive the mast when lowered, Il. 1.434†. (Plate IV.)

i(sto-pe/dh: mast-stay, mast-block, a thwart or transverse beam with a depression into which the mast fitted, which was by this means, as well as by the e)pi/tonoi, prevented from falling forward, Od. 12.51. (See cut, letter b.)

i=(sto/s (i(/sthmi): anything that stands. —(1) mast, in the middle of the ship, held in place by the meso/dmh, i(stope/dh, pro/tonoi, e)pi/tonoi. During stay in port the mast was unstepped and laid back upon the i(stodo/kh (cf. preceding cut, and Nos. 60, 84).—(2) weaver's beam, loom. The frame of the loom was not placed, as in modern handlooms, in a horizontal position, but stood upright, as appears in the cut, representing an ancient Egyptian loom. The threads of the warp hung perpendicularly down, and were drawn tight by weights at their lower ends. To set up the beam and so begin the web is (i(sto\n) sth/sasqai. In weaving, the weaver passed from one side to the other before the loom (e)poi/xesqai), as he carried the shuttle (kanw/n), on which was wound the thread of the woof, through the warp, and then drove the woof home with a blow of the kerki/s.— (3) warp, and in general, web, woven stuff.
i)/stw: see ei)/dw (II.).
i)/stwr, oros (root vid): one who knows, judge, Il. 18.501, Il. 21.486.
i)sxale/os (i)sxno/s): dry, withered, Od. 19.233†.

i)sxana/w, i)sxa/nw (i)/sxw), ipf. iter. i)sxana/askon: hold, restrain, detain, Il. 17.747, Od. 15.346; intrans., w. gen., or inf., hold to, crave, desire, Il. 17.572, Il. 23.300, Od. 8.288; mid., restrain oneself, delay, Il. 12.38, Il. 19.234, Od. 7.161.
i)sxi/on (cf. i)cu=/s): hip-joint, Il. 5.306; then the parts about the hips, loins, flanks.

i)/sxw (sise/xw, root sex, e)/xw), inf. i)sxe/menai, mid. ipf. i)/sxeto: hold in the simplest sense, then hold back, check, restrain, tino/s, ‘from’ something, Il. 5.90; mid., restrain oneself, stop, desist from (tino/s), Od. 22.367, Od. 24.54.
i)te/h (vite/h): willow, Il. 21.350 and Od. 10.510.
i)/thn: see ei)=mi.
*)/itulos: Itylus (in the tragic poets Itus), son of Aēdon, slain by her through mistake, and lamented in her plaintive notes, of which the name is an imitation, Od. 19.522†.
*=)itumoneu/s: son of Hypirochus in Elis, slain by Nestor, Il. 11.672†.
i)/tus (vi/tus): felloe of a wheel. (Il.)
i)/tw: see ei)=mi.
*)/itwn: a town in Thessaly, Il. 2.696†.
i=)ugmo/s: cry of joy, jubilant outcry, Il. 18.572†.
i)u/zw: cry out, scream with intent to scare something away, Od. 15.162 and Il. 17.66.
*=)ifeu/s (vif.): a Trojan, slain by Patroclus, Il. 16.417†.
*)ifqi=/mh: daughter of Icarius, the sister of Penelope and wife of Eumēlus, Od. 4.797†.
i)/fqi=mos: doubtful word, mighty, strong, goodly, the latter interpretation to suit the epith. as applied to women, a)/loxos, quga/thr, *phrw/, Il. 5.415, o 364, Od. 11.287.
i)=fi (vi=/s): with might, a)na/ssein, etc.; by violence, kta/menos, Il. 3.375.
*=)ifia/nassa: Iphianassa, daughter of Agamemnon, Il. 9.145 and 287.
*=)ifida/ma=s: son of Antēnor and Theāno, Il. 11.21 ff.
*=)ifiklh/eios: of Iphiclus, bi/h *=)ifiklhei/h, i. e. the mighty Iphiclus himself (see bi/h), Od. 11.290, 296.
*=)/ifiklos: son of Phylacus, father of Podarces and Protesilāüs, Il. 2.705, Il. 13.698, Il. 23.636, Od. 11.289 ff.
*=)ifime/deia: wife of Alōeus, and mother of Otus and Ephialtes, Od. 11.305.
*)ifi/noos: son of Dexius, slain by Glaucus, Il. 7.14†.
i=)/fios: strong, fat, goodly, only i=)/fia mh=la.
*)=ifis: from Scyros, a slave of Patroclus, Il. 9.667†.
*=)ifiti/dhs: son of Iphitus, Archeptolemus, Il. 8.128†.
*=)ifiti/wn: son of Otrynteus, slain by Achilles, Il. 20.382.

*=)/ifitos (vif.): Iphitus.—(1) son of Eurytus, an Argonaut, guest-friend of Odysseus, slain by Heracles, Od. 21.14-37. —(2) son of Nautolus, an Argonaut, from Phocis, father of Schedius and Epistrophus, Il. 2.518, Il. 17.306.—(3) father of Archeptolemus.
i)xqua/w, ipf. iter. i)xqua/askon: catch fish, fish, Od. 12.95 and Od. 4.368.
i)xquo/eis, only -o/enti, -o/enta: abounding in fish, fishy.
i)xqu=/s, u/os, acc. pl. i)xqu/as, i)xqu=s: fish.
i)/xnion =i)/xnos.
i)/xnos, eos: foot-step, track, trace, Od. 17.317†.
i=)xw/r, acc. i)xw=: ichor, attributed to the gods in place of blood, see Il. 5.339342.
i=)/y, i=)po/s: worm that eats into horn or wood, borer, Od. 21.395.
i)/yao, i)/yetai: see i)/ptomai.
i)wgh/: shelter; bore/w, ‘from’ the wind, Od. 14.533†. Cf. e)piwgai/.
i)wh/: sound of a voice, Il. 10.139; tone of a lyre, Od. 17.261; whistling of the wind, Il. 4.276, Il. 11.308.
i)wkh/, acc. i)w=ka (diw/kw): pursuit, attack, battle - tumult. Personified, Il. 5.740. (Il.)
i)wxmo/s =i)wkh/, Il. 8.89 and 158.

div1.head: *k
div1.entryFree: ka/bbale: see kataba/llw.
ka/g: see kata/.
*kabhso/qen: from Cabēsus, a city in Thrace, or, according to others, in Asia Minor, Il. 13.363†.
ka/gxanos: dry, Il. 21.364, Od. 18.308.
kagxala/w, 3 pl. kagxalo/wsi, part. kagxalo/wn: laugh aloud or exultingly.
ka/d: see kata/.
kaddraqe/thn: see katadarqa/nw.
kaddu=sai: see katadu/w.
*kadmei=oi, *kadmei/wnes: the Cadmeians, Thebans, Il. 4.391, 385.
*ka/dmos: Cadmus, the founder of Thebes, father of Ino, Od. 5.333†.
*ka/eira, fem. of *ka/r: of Caria, Carian, Il. 4.142†.
kah/menai: see kai/w.

kaq - aire/w, fut. kaqairh/sousi, aor. kaqei/lomen, subj. kaqe/lh|si, part. kaqelou=sa: take down, i(sti/a, zugo\n a)po\ passalo/fi, i 149, Il. 24.268; of closing the eyes of the dead, Il. 11.453, Od. 24.296; fig., moi=ra qana/toio, bring low, overcome, Od. 2.100, Od. 3.238.

kaqai/rw (kaqaro/s), aor. (e))ka/qhra, imp. ka/qhron, inf. -h=rai, part. -h/rantes: cleanse, clean; ‘make fair,’ Od. 18.192; w. acc., wash off or away, Il. 14.171, Od. 6.93; with two accusatives, Il. 16.667.
kaq-a/llomai: rush down, of a storm, Il. 11.298†.
kaq-a/pac: once for all, Od. 21.349†.
kaq - a/ptomai, -a/ptesqai, -o/menos, ipf. kaqa/pteto: only fig., accost, address, and in unfavorable sense, upbraid, chide, reprove, Od. 18.415, Il. 15.127, Od. 2.240, Od. 3.345.
kaqaro/s: clean, fair, clear; of an open space, Il. 8.491; fig., of an honorable death, Od. 22.462.

kaq-e/zomai, subj. kaqezw/mesqa, part. -o/menos, ipf. kaqe/zeto: sit down; of a public session, Od. 1.372 ; pro/xnu kaqezome/nh, ‘kneeling down,’ Il. 9.570; of a bird, ‘perched,’ Od. 19.520; ‘staying,’ Od. 6.295.
kaqe/hka: see kaqi/hmi.
kaqei/ato: see ka/qhmai.
kaq-ei=sa (ei(=sa): cause or bid to sit down, Il. 18.389; set, place, establish, Od. 4.524, Il. 14.204.
kaqe/cei: see kate/xw.
kaq-eu/dw, imp. kaqeu=de: lie down to sleep, sleep. (Od. and Il. 1.611.)
ka/q-hmai, imp. ka/qhso, ipf. kaqh=sto, 3 pl. kaqei/ato: sit, esp. of sitting quiet or inactive, ‘remaining’ anywhere, Il. 24.403, Il. 2.191, Il. 1.565, Od. 3.186.
ka/qhra: see kaqai/rw.
kaq-idru/w: bid to sit down, Od. 20.257†.
kaq-i/zw, ipf. kaqi=zon, aor. 3 pl. ka/qisan, imp. ka/qison, part. kaqi/ssa=s, ka- qi/sa=sa: intrans., sit; trans., cause to sit, place, convoke, Od. 2.69.
kaq-i/hmi, imp. kaqi=/ete, aor. kaqe/hka, 1 pl. ka/qemen, 3 pl. ka/qesan: let go down, let down; of lowering sails, Od. 9.72; pouring wine down the throat, Il. 24.642.
kaq-ikne/omai, aor. kaqi=ko/mhn: reach, touch, Od. 1.342, Il. 14.104.
kaq-i/sthmi, imp. kaqi/sta=, aor. 1 imp. kata/sthson, inf. -sth=sai: set down; nh=a, ‘bring to anchor,’ Od. 12.185; so of bringing one to his destination, Od. 13.274.
kaq-ora/w, mid. part. kaqorw/menos: look down upon, Il. 11.337, Il. 13.4.
kaq - u/perqe(n): from above, above, over; whether the word expressly denotes ‘northward’ is doubtful, Il. 24.545, Od. 3.170, Od. 15.404.

kai/: and, also, too, even; the purely copulative use needs no illustration, but the word is idiomatically employed in many ways that call for insight and feeling rather than translation; (*ne/stwr) a)no/rouse, ligu\s *puli/wn a)gorhth/s, | tou= kai\ a)po\ glw/sshs me/litos gluki/wn r(e/en au)dh/, ‘even from whose tongue, etc.’ (comparing gluki/wn with ligu/s), Il. 1.249; this comparing kai/ may appear in both members of the statement, do/te dh\ kai\ to/nde gene/sqai | pai=d' e)mo/n, w(s kai\ e)gw/ per, a)riprepe/a *trw/essi, Il. 6.476; kai/ introducing an apodosis institutes a comparison between dependent clause and main clause, Il. 1.478 . kai/ appears in Greek often where we employ a disjunctive word, e(/na kai\ du/o, ‘one or two,’ Il. 2.346. Combined w. other particles, kai\ ei), ei) kai/ (see ei)), kai\ de/ (de/ the connective), kai\ dh/, kai\ mh/n, kai/ r(a, kai/ te, kai\.. pe/r (see pe/r), etc. kai/ sometimes suffers elision, k' e)/ti, Il. 23.526; freq. in crasis, xh(mei=s (kai\ h(mei=s), ka=)gw/, etc.
*kainei/dhs: son of Caeneus, Corōnus, Il. 2.746†.
*kaineu/s: a king of the Lapithae, Il. 1.264†.

kai/numai, ipf. e)kai/nuto, perf. 2 sing. ke/kassai, 3 ke/kastai, inf. keka/sqai, plup. (e))ke/kasto: excel, w. acc., e)kai/nuto fu=l' a)nqrw/pwn | nh=a kubernh=sai, Od. 3.282; e)gxei/h| d' e)ke/kasto *pane/llhnas kai\ *)axaiou/s, Il. 2.530; mostly w. dat. of the thing and prep. governing the person, e)n *danaoi=si, meta\ dmwh=|si, pa=san
e)p' ai)=an, Od. 4.725, t 82, Od. 24.509; gen. of person, Il. 24.546 ; e)pi/ with dat. of thing, Il. 20.35.
kai/rios (kairo/s): in the right place, a fatal place for a wound, Il. 8.84, Il. 4.185. (Il.)

kairose/wn or kairosse/wn: gen. pl. fem. from an adj. kairo/eis, with many loops (kai=roi) or thrums to which the threads of the warp were attached; k. o)qone/wn, from the fine-woven linen, Od. 7.107†.

kai/w, inf. kaie/men, ipf. kai=on, aor. e)/kha, opt. 3 sing. kh/ai, 3 pl. kh/aien, subj. 1 pl. kh/omen, inf. kh=ai, imp. kh=on, part. kh/antes, pass. pres. kai/etai, ipf. 2 sing. kai/eo, aor. (e))ka/h, inf. kah/menai, mid. aor. kh/anto, part. kha/menos: burn, consume, mid., for oneself, Il. 9.88, 234, Od. 16.2; pass., burn, burn up.
ka/k: see kata/.
kaki/zomai: play the coward, Il. 24.214†.
kakkei=ai, -h=ai: see katakai/w.
kakkei/ontes: see katakei/w.
kako-ei/mwn, onos (vei=ma): ill-clad, Od. 18.41.
kako - ergi/h (ve/rgon): ill - doing, Od. 22.374†.
kako-ergo/s: evil - doing, rascally, Od. 18.54†.
*kako - i=/lios (vi=/lios): sad Ilium, Ilium of evil name, Od. 19.260, 597, Od. 23.19.
kako-mh/xanos (mhxanh/): contriving evil, malicious, Od. 16.418.
kako/ - ceinos: having sorry guests, comp., Od. 20.376†.
kako - rrafi/h (r(a/ptw): evil device, maliciousness, Od. 12.26.

kako/s, comp. kakw/teros, kaki/wn, sup. ka/kistos: bad, opp. a)gaqo/s, e)sqlo/s. The variety of applications is as great as that of the opp. words, hence ‘cowardly,’ ‘ugly,’ ‘poor,’ ‘vile,’ ‘sorry,’ ‘useless,’ ‘destructive,’ ‘miserable,’ ‘unlucky,’ ‘ill - boding,’ etc. Not often of persons morally bad, Od. 11.384. As subst., kako/n, kaka/, evil, pest, ills of all sorts, Il. 5.831, Od. 12.118, Od. 11.482.— Adv., kakw=s.
kako/ths, htos: evil, wickedness, cowardice; also ‘hardship,’ ‘misery,’ Od. 17.318, and esp. the ills suffered in war or battle, e. g. Il. 11.382.
kako - fradh/s, e/s (fra/zomai): illjudging, perverse, Il. 23.483†.

kako/w, imp. ka/kou, aor. e)ka/kwsa: bring to evil or trouble, maltreat, disfigure, Od. 6.137 ; kekakwme/noi, ‘in a sad plight,’ Il. 11.689 ; mhde\ ge/ronta ka/kou kekakwme/non, ‘afflict the afflicted,’ Od. 4.754.
ka/ktane: see kataktei/nw.
kakw/teros: see kako/s.

kala/mh (cf. ka/lamos, calamus): reed, stalk, Il. 19.222 (straw as opp. to kernel); fig., as relic of former bloom, ‘by looking on the poor husk that remains I fancy thou canst perceive’ what I once was, Od. 14.214.
kalau=roy, opos: shepherd's staff, Il. 23.845†.

kale/w, kale/ei and kalei=, etc., inf. kalh/menai, part. kaleu=ntes, ipf. (e))ka/lei, iter. kale/eskon, aor. (e))ka/lessa, part. kale/(s)sa=s, pass. kale/ontai, ipf. kaleu=nto, iter. kale/sketo, perf. ke/klhmai, plup. 3 pl. keklh/ato, fut. perf. 2 sing. keklh/sh|, mid. aor. (e))kale/ssato, kale/santo: call by name, call together, summon, invite, mid., to or for oneself; w. cognate acc., tina\ e)pw/numon or e)pi/klhsin kalei=n, call a person ‘by a name,’ Il. 9.562, Il. 18.487; freq. pass., esp. perf., ‘be called,’ ‘pass for,’ often only a poetic amplification of ei)=nai, ai)\ ga\r e)moi\ toio/sde po/sis keklhme/nos ei)/h, Od. 6.244; often of inviting to dinner, see Od. 11.185-187; mid., Il. 24.193, Od. 21.380.
*kalh/sios: companion of Axylus, slain by Diomed, Il. 6.18†.
*kalhtori/dhs: son of Calētor, Aphareus, Il. 13.541†.
kalh/twr, oros: crier, Il. 24.577†.
*kalh/twr: (1) son of Clytius, cousin of Hector, slain by Ajax, Il. 15.419.— (2) the father of Aphareus.
kallei/pw: see katalei/pw.
*kallia/nassa and *kallia/neira: Nereids, Il. 18.46, 44†.
*kalli/aros: a town in Locris, Il. 2.531†.
kalli/-gunaic, only acc. kalligu/naika: with beautiful women, epith. of Hellas, Achaea, Sparta.
kalli/-zwnos: with beautiful girdles. (See cut No. 44.)
kalli/-qric, kalli/trixos: of horses, with beautiful manes; sheep, fairfleeced.
*kallikolw/nh: Fair-mount, near Ilium, Il. 20.53, 151.
kalli/-komos (ko/mh): with beautiful hair, cf. h)u/komos.
kalli-krh/demnos (krh/demnon): with beautiful head-bands, pl., Od. 4.623†.
ka/llimos =ka=lo/s. (Od.)
ka/llion: see ka=lo/s.
kalli-pa/rh|os (pareia=/): faircheeked.
ka/llipe, -pe/ein: see katalei/pw.
kalli-plo/kamos: with beautiful locks of hair, cf. e)uplokami=/s. (See cut No. 44.)
kalli-re/eqros: beautifully-flowing. (Od.)
kalli/-rroos: beautifully - flowing, fair-flowing.
ka/llistos: see ka=lo/s.
kalli/-sfuros (sfura=/): fair-ankled.
ka/llif) =ka/llipe, see katalei/pw.
kalli/-xoros: with beautiful dancing-lawns, Od. 11.581†.
ka/llos, eos: beauty; ka/llos a)mbro/sion, apparently conceived as an unguent, Od. 18.192.

ka=lo/s, comp. kalli/wn, ka/llion, nom. pl. kalli/ones, sup. ka/llistos: beautiful, fair; sometimes figuratively, limh/n, a)/nemos, z 263, Od. 14.253; met., fine, well, proper, only neut. in Homer, ka=lo\n ei)pei=n, ka=la\ a)goreu/ein, ka=lo/n e)sti/ tini.—Adv., ka=lo/n, ka=la/, kalw=s, *q 400, Od. 2.63.
ka/los (Att. ka/lws): pl., ropes, halyards; passing through a hole at the top of the mast, then made fast at the bottom, and serving to hoist and lower the yard. (See cut.)
ka/lpis: water - jar, urn, Od. 7.20†. (See cut, from a picture on an ancient vase.)
*kalu/dnai nh=soi: the Calydnian islands, near Cos, Il. 2.677†.
*kaludw/n: Calydon, a city in Aetolia, Il. 9.530, Il. 13.217, Il. 2.640.
ka/lumma (kalu/ptw): veil, Il. 24.93†. (See cuts Nos. 2, 44, 62, 70.)
ka/luc, ukos: pl., women's ornaments, perhaps cup-shaped ear-rings, Il. 18.401†. (See cut No. 8.)
kalu/ptrh: veil. (Cf. cut, and Nos. 2, 44, 70.)

kalu/ptw, fut. -yw, aor. (e))ka/luya, pass. perf. part. kekalumme/nos, plup. keka/lupto, aor. part. kalufqei/s, mid. aor. kalu/yato: cover, veil, hide, mid., oneself or some part of oneself; tini/, ‘with’ something, but sometimes w. acc. of the thing used to cover with, to/sshn oi( a)/sin kaqu/perqe kalu/yw, *f 321, Il. 5.315; fig., of darkness, sorrow, war, death, Il. 17.243, Il. 11.250, Od. 24.315; mid., Od. 8.92, Od. 10.179.

*kaluyw/ (the ‘Concealer,’ Occulina): Calypso, a goddess, daughter of Atlas, dwelling in the isle of Ogygia, where she detains Odysseus for seven years, until commanded by Zeus to dismiss him, Od. 5.28, Od. 7.259, 265; epithets, dolo/essa, deinh\ qeo/s, e)uplo/kamos, au)dh/essa, h)u/komos, nu/mfh po/tnia.
*ka/lxa=s, antos: Calchas, the son of Thestor, renowned seer of the Greeks before Troy, Il. 1.69 -72, Il. 2.300. (Il.)
ka/m: see kata/.
ka/mac, akos: vine-pole, vine-prop, pl., Il. 18.563†.
ka/matos (ka/mnw): fatigue, weariness, toil; ‘fruit of our labor,’ Od. 14.417.
ka/mbale: see kataba/llw.
ka/me: see ka/mnw.
*ka/meiros: a town on the west coast of Rhodes, Il. 2.656†.
kami=nw/, ou=s: grhi\ kami=noi= vi=sos, like an old oven-woman, bake-woman (of a clattering tongue, as in Eng. ‘fish-woman’), Od. 18.27†.
kammi=/ca=s: see katami=/gnu=mi.
kam - moni/h (katame/nw): steadfastness, endurance (meaning the victory won thereby), Il. 22.257, Il. 23.661.
ka/m-moros (kata/moros): ‘given over to fate,’ hence, ill-starred, hapless.

ka/mnw, fut. kamei=tai, aor. 2. e)/kamon, ka/me, subj. ka/mh|si, perf. ke/kmhka, part. kekmhw/s, -hw=ta, -ho/tas, mid. aor. e)ka/monto, kamo/mesqa: I. intr., grow weary, frequently w. acc. of specification, gui=a, w)=mon, xei=ra, also w. thing as subj., po/des, o)/sse, Od. 12.232; w. part., Il. 4.244, Il. 7.5; euphem., kamo/ntes, the dead, those who have finished their toil, Od. 11.476.— II. trans. (aor. act.), wrought with toil, mi/trh, th\n xalkh=es ka/mon a)/ndres, Il. 4.187; also with teu/xwn; aor. mid., ‘won by toil,’ Il. 18.341; ‘worked up for oneself,’ ‘tilled,’ Od. 9.130.
ka/mptw, fut. inf. -yein, aor. e)/kamya: bend, Il. 4.486; ‘into a lyre,’ Il. 24.274; freq. go/nu, with weariness.
kampu/los (ka/mptw): bent, curved.
kanaxe/w: only aor., rang, Od. 19.469†.
kanaxh/: ringing of bronze, rattling of a mule-wagon, Od. 6.82; ‘gnashing’ of teeth, Il. 19.365.
kanaxi/zw: only ipf., rattled, Il. 12.36; re-echoed, Od. 10.399.
ka/neon, ka/neion: tray, basket, for bread and meat, and for sacrificial barley, Od. 1.147, Od. 17.343.
kanneu/sa=s: see kataneu/w.

kanw/n, o/nos: (1) shuttle or spool, by which the thread of the woof was drawn through the thread of the warp, Il. 23.761.—(2) handle on the interior of a shield, grasped by the left hand, Il. 8.193, Il. 13.407. (Il.) (See cuts Nos. 12, 16, 79; rudely represented in the adjacent cut.)
ka/p: see kata/.
*kapaneu/s: Capaneus, one of the Seven against Thebes, the father of Sthenelus, Il. 5.319.
*kapanhia/dhs and *kapanh/ios, ui(o/s: son of Capaneus, Sthenelus, Il. 5.109, 108.
ka/petos: ditch, grave, Il. 18.564, Il. 24.797. (Il.)
ka/ph, pl. dat. ka/ph|si: crib, manger, Od. 4.40, Il. 8.434.
kapni/zw (kapno/s): only aor., lighted fires, Il. 2.399†.
kapno/s: smoke; in Od. 12.202 of a cloud of spray from violently agitated water.
ka/ppeson: see katapi/ptw.
ka/prios (ka/pros): wild boar, with and without su=s, *m 42, Il. 17.282.
ka/pros: wild boar, boar, Il. 19.197.
*ka/pus: Capys, son of Assaracus, and father of Anchīses, Il. 20.239†.
