le/pw, aor. e)/leyen: peel, strip off; fu/lla, Il. 1.236†.
*le/sbos: Lesbos, the island opposite the gulf of Adramyttium, Od. 3.169, Il. 24.544 . —*lesbo/qen, from Lesbos, Il. 9.664 . — *lesbi/s, i/dos: Lesbian woman, Il. 9.129, 271.
le/sxh: inn, tavern, Od. 18.329†.
leugale/os (cf. lugro/s, loigo/s): mournful, miserable.—Adv., leugale/ws, Il. 13.732.
leukai/nw: make white, with foam, Od. 12.172†.
*leuka/s: pe/trh, ‘White rock,’ at the entrance of the nether world, on the border of Oceanus, Od. 24.11†.
leu/k-aspis, idos: with white shield, white-shielded, Il. 22.294†.
*leukoqe/h: Leucothea, a sea-goddess, once Ino, the daughter of Cadmus, Od. 5.334, 461.

leuko/s: clear, i. e. transparent or full of light, as water, the surface of water, or the radiance of the sky, Od. 5.70, Od. 10.94, Od. 6.45; then white, as snow, milk, bones, barley, Il. 10.437, Od. 9.246, Od. 1.161, Il. 20.496.
*leu=kos: a companion of Odysseus, Il. 4.491†.
leuk - w/lenos (w)le/nh, elbow, forearm): white - armed; epithet of goddesses and women according to the metrical convenience of their names; a)mfi/polos, dmwai/, s 198, Od. 19.60.
leuro/s: level, Od. 7.123†.
leu/ssw (cf. leuko/s, lux), ipf. leu=sse: see, behold.
lexe-poi/hs (le/xos, poi/h): with grassy bed (of a river); grassy (of towns), Il. 4.383, Il. 2.697.

le/xos, eos (root lex, le/gw): bed, bedstead, also pl. in both senses; typical in connubial relations, le/xos a)ntia=n, porsu=/nein, *a 31, Od. 3.403; funeralcouch, bier, Od. 24.44, Od. 23.165 ; le/xosde, to the bed, Il. 3.447.
le/wn, ontos, dat. pl. lei/ousi and le/ousi: lion; fig., where we should expect ‘lioness,’ Il. 21.483.

lh/gw, inf. lhge/menai, ipf. lh=g), fut. lh/cw, aor. 3 pl. lh=can: leave off, cease, w. gen. or w. part., Il. 6.107, Il. 21.224; trans., abate, me/nos, Il. 13.424; xei=ras fo/noio, ‘stay’ my hands from slaughter, Od. 22.63.
*lh/dh: Leda, the wife of Tyndareus, mother by Zeus of Helen, Castor, and Polydeuces, and of Clytaemnestra by Tyndareus, Od. 11.298, 300.
lhqa/nw: cause to forget, tino/s, Od. 7.221†.
lh/qh: forgetfulness, oblivion, Il. 2.33†.
*lh=qos: son of Teutamus, and father of Hippothous, Il. 2.843, Il. 17.288.
lh/qw: see lanqa/nw.
lhia/s, a/dos: captive, Il. 20.193†.
lhi - bo/teira (lh/ion, bo/skw): cropeating, crop-destroying, Od. 18.29†.
lhi/zomai, fut. lhi/ssomai, aor. lhi/ssato: carry off as booty.
lh/ion: crop, grain still standing in the field, field of grain.
lhi/s, i/dos: booty, prey.
lhisth/r, h=ros (lhi/zomai): buccaneer, rover, pl. (Od.)
lhisto/s: to be plundered or taken by plundering, see e(leto/s.
lhi/stwr, oros = lhisth/r, Il. 15.427†.
lhi=tis, idos: booty - bringing, giver of booty, epith. of Athēna, Il. 10.460†.
*lh/itos: son of Alectryon, a leader of the Boeotians, Il. 2.494, Il. 13.91, Il. 17.601, Il. 6.35.
lh/kuqos: oil-flask, Od. 6.79 and 215.

*lh=mnos: Lemnos, the island west of the Troad, with probably in Homer's time a city of the same name, Il. 14.230, 281; called h)gaqe/h, as sacred to Hephaestus (also to the Cabīri) on account of its volcano, Moschylus; now Stalimene [(e))s th\(n) *lh=mnon].
lh/sw: see lanqa/nw.
*lhtw/: Leto (Latona), mother of Apollo and Artemis, Od. 11.580, Il. 1.9; epith., e)riku=dh/s, h)u/komos, kallipa/rh|os.

lia/zomai, part. liazo/menon, ipf. lia/zeto, aor. pass. (e))lia/sqhn: turn aside, withdraw; ku=ma, ‘parted,’ Il. 24.96 ; ei)/dwlon, ‘vanished,’ Od. 4.838; also sink down, droop; proti\ gai/h| ptera/, *u 420, Il. 23.879.
*libu/h: Libya, west of Egypt, Od. 4.85, Od. 14.295.
li/ga (ligu/s): adv., clear, loudly, a)ei/dein, kwku/ein.
ligai/nw (ligu/s): cry with clear, loud voice, Il. 11.685†.
li/ggw, aor. li/gce: twang, Il. 4.125†.
li/gdhn: adv., grazing; ba/llein xei=ra, Od. 22.278†.
lige/ws: see ligu/s.
ligu-pnei/wn, ontos: loudly blowing, whistling, Od. 4.567†.
liguro/s (ligu/s): clear-toned, whistling, piping; a)oidh/, ma/stic, pnoiai/, Od. 12.44, *l 532, Il. 5.526.

ligu/s, ligei=a, ligu/: clear and loud of tone, said of singers, the harp, an orator, ‘clear-voiced,’ ‘clear-toned,’ Od. 24.62, Il. 9.186, Il. 1.248; of the wind, ‘piping,’ ‘whistling,’ Od. 3.176, Il. 13.334.—Adv., lige/ws, a)goreu/ein, fu=sa=n, klai/ein, Il. 3.214, *y 218, Od. 10.201.
ligu/-fqoggos: loud-voiced, clearvoiced.
ligu/-fwnos: with loud, clear note, of a falcon, Il. 19.350†.
li/zw: see li/ggw.

li=/hn: too, excessively, greatly, very; mh/ ti li/hn prokali/zeo, provoke me not ‘too far,’ Od. 18.20 ; ou)de/ ti li=/hn ou(/tw nw/numo/s e)sti, not so very unrenowned, Od. 13.238, cf. Od. 15.405; often kai\ li/hn at the beginning of a statement, ‘most certainly,’ ‘ay, by all means,’ etc.
li/qac, akos: stony, hard, Od. 5.415†.
liqa/s, a/dos, dat. pl. liqa/dessi = li/qos. (Od.)
li/qeos: of stone.
li/qos, usually m.: stone, rock; fig. as symbol of firmness, or of harshness, Od. 19.494, Il. 4.510.
likma/w (likmo/s), part. gen. plur. likmw/ntwn: winnow, Il. 5.500†.
likmhth/r, h=ros: winnower, who threw the grain with his winnowingshovel against the wind, thus separating it from the chaff, Il. 13.590†.
likrifi/s: adv., sideways, to one side, Il. 14.463 and Od. 19.451.
*liku/mnios: brother of Alcmēna, slain by Tlepolemus, Il. 2.663†.
*li/laia: a town in Phocis, at the source of the Cephissus, Il. 2.523†.

lilai/omai, ipf. lilai/eto: d<*>sure, be desirous of or eager for, tino/s, Od. 13.31; freq. w. inf.; with the inf. omitted, Od. 11.223; metaph., of the lance, lilaiome/nh xroo\s a)=sai. Cf. leli/hmai.
limh/n, e/nos (cf. lei/bw, li/mnh): harbor; pl. also in signif. of inlets, bays, Il. 23.745, Od. 13.96, Od. 4.846.
li/mnh (cf. lei/bw, limh/n): lake, pond, even of a swamp or a marsh, Il. 21.317; also of the sea, Od. 3.1.
*limnw/reia (‘Harbor Ward’): a Nereid, Il. 18.41†.
li=mo/s: hunger, famine.
*li/ndos: a town in Rhodes. Il. 2.656†.
lino - qw/rhc: with linen cuirass, Il. 2.529. (As represented in adjoining cut, No. 79; cf. also No. 12.)

li/non: flax, then anything made of it, thread, yarn, esp. fishing - line, Il. 16.408; of a fisher's net, Il. 5.487; linen cloth, linen, Il. 9.681; fig., of the thread of destiny, Il. 20.128, Il. 24.210, Od. 7.198. (See cuts under h)laka/th.)
li/nos: lay of Linus, the Linus-song, an ancient popular melody, Il. 18.570†.
li/pa: adv., always li/p' e)lai/w|, richly with olive oil; but if the word is really an old dat., then with olive oil, e)lai/w| being adj.
liparo - krh/demnos: with shining head-band, Il. 18.382†.
liparo - plo/kamos: with shining locks or braids, Il. 19.126†.
liparo/s (li/pa): sleek, shining with ointment, Od. 15.332; shining (nitidus), Il. 2.44; then fig., rich, comfortable, qe/mistes, gh=ras, *i 156, Od. 11.136.—Adv., liparw=s, fig., Od. 4.210.
lipo/w: be sleek, v. l., Od. 19.72†.
li/s (1), acc. li=n: lion, Il. 11.239, 480.
li/s (2) (lisso/s): smooth, sheer, pe/trh, Od. 12.64 and 79.

li=/s (3), dat. li=ti/, acc. li=ta: linen cloth, used as cover for a seat, Od. 10.353; or for a chariot when not in use, Il. 8.441; also as shroud for the dead, Il. 18.352; and to cover a cinerary urn, Il. 23.254.

li/ssomai (lith/), ipf. (e))(l)li/sseto, iter. lisse/sketo, aor. 1 e)llisa/mhn, imp. li/sai, aor. 2 e)lito/mhn, inf. lite/sqai: pray, beseech with prayer; abs., Il. 22.91, Od. 2.68, and tina\ eu)xh=|si, eu)xwlh=|si lith=si/ te, *zhno/s, ‘in the name of Zeus’; pro/s, u(pe/r tinos, gou/nwn (labw/n, a(ya/menos), etc.; foll. by inf., sometimes o(/pws or i(/na, Od. 3.19, 237, Od. 8.344; with two accusatives, Od. 2.210, cf. Od. 4.347.
lisso/s: smooth, sheer, pe/trh. (Od.)
listreu/w (li/stron): dig about, Od. 24.227†.
li/stron: hoe or scraper, used in cleaning the floor of a hall, Od. 22.455†.
li=ta: see li=/ Od. 18.3.
litaneu/w (lith/), ipf. e)llita/neue, lita/neue, fut. litaneu/somen, aor. e)llita/neusa: pray, implore, abs., and w. acc., Od. 7.145, Il. 9.581.
li=ti/: see li=/ Od. 18.3.
lo/): see lou/w.
lobo/s: lobe of the ear, pl. Il. 14.182†.
lo/gos (le/gw): tale, story, as entertaining recital, with enumeration of details, pl., Il. 15.393 and Od. 1.56.
lo/e, loe/ssai, loessa/menos: see lou/w.
loetro/n (lovetro/n, lou/w): bathing, bath, pl., *)wkeanoi<*>=o, ‘in Ocean,’ Od. 5.275.
loetro - xoo/s (xe/w): pouring (containing) water for the bath, tri/pos, tripod with water - kettle, Il. 18.346, Od. 8.435; subst., bath-maid, Od. 20.297.
loe/w: see lou/w.
loibh/ (lei/bw): libation.
loi/gios (loigo/s): destructive, ruinous, deadly; as subst., Il. 21.533, Il. 23.310. (Il.)
loigo/s: destruction, ruin, death, by sickness (pestilence) or war. (Il.)
loimo/s: pestilence, Il. 1.61 and 97.
loi=sqos (loipo/s): last, Il. 23.536†.
*lokroi/: the Locrians, a tribe occupying one of the divisions of Hellas, and dwelling on the Eurīpus, on both sides of Mt. Cnemis, Il. 2.527, 535, Il. 13.686.
lopo/s (le/pw): peel, skin, Od. 19.233†.

lou/w, loe/w (cf. lavo), ipf. lou=on, lo/) (lo/ve), aor. lou=s(en), subj. lou/sh|, imp. lo/eson, lou/sate, inf. loe/(s)sai, part. loe/sa=sa, mid. pres. inf. lou/esqai, lou=sqai, fut. loe/ssomai, aor. loe/ssato, lou/santo, etc., pass. perf. part. leloume/nos: bathe, wash, mid., bathe, get washed. Il. 6.508; fig., of the rising of Sirius, leloume/nos *)wkeanoi=o, ‘after his bath in Ocean,’ Il. 5.6.
lofih/ (lo/fos): the bristly ridge or comb of a wild boar's back, Od. 19.446†.

lo/fos: (1) crest or plume of a helmet, usually of horse - hair, Il. 5.743. (See adjoining cuts, and Nos. 3, 11, 12, 16, 17, 35, 73, 116, 122.)—(2) back of the neck of animals or of men, Il. 23.508, Il. 10.573.—(3) hill, ridge. (Od.)
loxa/w (lo/xos), aor. inf. loxh=sai, mid. fut. loxh/somai, aor. part. loxhsa/menos: act. and mid., lie in ambush, lie in wait for, waylay, tina/, Od. 13.425.
lo/xmh (root lex): lair of a wild beast, thicket, jungle, Od. 19.439†.

lo/xos (root lex): place of ambush, act of lying in wait; said of the Trojan horse, Il. 18.513, Od. 4.277; also of the party forming the ambuscade, Il. 8.522; and of any armed company, Od. 20.49 ; lo/xos ge/rontos, ‘means of entrapping’ the old man of the sea, Od. 4.395 .— lo/xonde: upon an ambuscade, into the ambush, Il. 1.227, Od. 14.217.
lu/gos: willow-twig, osier, withe.

lugro/s (cf. leugale/os): sad, mournful, miserable; in apparently active sense, fa/rmaka, sh/mata, etc., Od. 4.230, Il. 6.168; also fig., and in derogatory sense, ‘sorry,’ ei(/mata, Od. 16.457; so of persons, Il. 13.119.—Adv., lugrw=s.
lu/qen: see lu/w.
lu/qron: properly pollution, then gore (or blood mixed with dust), with and without ai(=ma.
luka/ - ba=s, antos (root luk, lux, bai/nw): year, Od. 14.161 and Od. 19.306.
*lu/kastos: a town in the southern part of Crete, Il. 2.647.
*luka=/wn: (1) a Lycian, the father of Pandarus, Il. 5.197, 95.—(2) son of Priam and Laothoe, slain by Achilles, Il. 21.144 ff.
luke/h: wolf-skin, Il. 10.459†.
lukh - genh/s, e/os (root luk, lux): light-born, epith. of Apollo as sun-god, Il. 4.101, 119.

*luki/h: Lycia.—(1) a division of Asia Minor, Il. 2.877.—(2) a district on the river Aesēpus, its chief town Zeleia, Il. 2.824, Il. 5.173 .—*luki/hqen, from
Lycia, Il. 5.105 .—*luki/hnde, to Lycia, Il. 6.168.
*lu/kioi: the Lycians, inhabitants of Lycia (1). Led by Glaucus and by Sarpēdon, Il. 7.13, Il. 5.647, Il. 14.426, Il. 16.490.
*lukomh/dhs: son of Creon in Boeotia, Il. 17.346, Il. 19.240.

*luko/orgos (*lukov.): Lycurgus.— (1) son of Dryas, king of the Edonians in Thrace, banishes from his land the worship of Dion&ymacr;sus (Bacchus), Il. 6.134. —(2) an Arcadian, slays Arithous, Il. 7.142-148.
lu/kos (vlu/kos): wolf; symbol of bloodthirstiness, Il. 4.471, Il. 11.72.
*lukofo/nths: a Trojan, slain by Teucer, Il. 8.275.
*luko/frwn: son of Mastor, from Cythēra, a companion of Ajax, Il. 15.430.
*lu/ktos: a city in Crete, east of Cnosus, Il. 2.647, Il. 17.611.
*lu/kwn: a Trojan, slain by Peneleüs, Il. 16.335, 337.
lu=ma, pl. lu=/mata: anything washed away, defilement, Il. 14.171; in symbolical and ritualistic sense, offerings of purification, Il. 1.314.
lupro/s: sorry, poor, Od. 13.243†.
*lurnh(s)so/s: Lyrnessus, a town in Mysia, under the sway of Hypoplacian Thebes, Il. 2.690, Il. 19.60, Il. 20.92, 191.
*lu/sandros: a Trojan, slain by Ajax, Il. 11.491†.
lu=si-melh/s, e/s (lu/w, me/los): relaxing the limbs, u(/pnos, Od. 20.57 (with a play upon the word in v. 56).
lu/sis, ios (lu/w): loosing, ransoming, Il. 24.655 ; qana/tou, ‘deliverance’ from death, Od. 9.421.
lu/ssa: martial rage. (Il.)
lusshth/r, h=ros: one who rages, raging, w. ku/wn, Il. 8.299†.
lussw/dhs (ei)=dos): raging, Il. 13.53†.
lu/xnos: light, lamp, Od. 19.34†.

lu=/w, ipf. e)/luon, lu/e, fut. lu=/sw, aor. e)/lu=sa, lu=sen, mid. aor. e)lu=/sao, inf. lu=/sasqai, aor. 2, w. pass. signif., lu/to, lu/nto, pass. perf. le/lumai, opt. lelu=to, aor. lu/qh, 3 pl. lu/qen: I. act., loose, loosen, set free, of undoing garments, ropes, Il. 4.215, Od. 11.245, Od. 2.415; unharnessing horses, Od. 4.35; of freeing from bonds or captivity (said of the captor), Il. 1.20; pass., of anything giving way, coming apart, Il. 2.135, Od. 22.186; fig., in senses answering to those enumerated, tina\ kako/thtos, ‘deliver’ from misery; a)gorh/n, ‘dismiss’; so lu/to d' a)gw/n; and with reference to emotion, or fainting, death, lu/to gou/nata kai\ fi/lon h)=tor, ‘gave way,’ ‘sank,’ ‘quaked’ (sometimes the act., Od. 20.118); of sleep ‘relaxing’ the limbs, or ‘dissolving’ cares, Od. 4.794, Il. 23.62; of ‘undoing’ (destroying) cities, Il. 2.118.—III. mid., loose or undo oneself, Od. 9.463, or something of one's own, get loosed or released, ransom; lu=so/menos qu/gatra, said of the father, Il. 1.13; cf. the act., v. 20.
lwba/omai (lw/bh), aor. imp. lwbh/sasqe, opt. lwbh/saio: maltreat, outrage; w. cognate acc. and obj. tina\ lw/bhn, do despite, Il. 13.623.
lwbeu/w: mock, Od. 23.15 and 26.
lw/bh: outrage, insult; soi\ lw/bh, ‘shame upon thee,’ if, etc., Il. 18.180; of a person, ‘object of ignominy,’ Il. 3.42.
lwbhth/r, h=ros: one who outrages or insults, slanderer, scoundrel, Il. 2.275, Il. 11.385. (Il.)
lwbhto/s: maltreated, outraged, Il. 24.531†.
lw/ph (le/pw): mantle, Od. 13.224†.
lwtou=nta (lwto/s), either a part., or adj., for lwto/enta: full of lotus, ‘clovery,’ pedi/a, Il. 12.283†.

lwto/s: lotus.—(1) a species of clover, Od. 4.603, Il. 14.348.—(2) the tree and fruit enjoyed by the Lotus-eaters, Od. 9.91 ff. Said to be a plant with fruit the size of olives, in taste resembling dates, still prized in Tunis and Tripoli under the name of Jujube.
*lwtofa/goi: the Lotus-eaters, Od. 9.84 ff.
lwfa/w, fut. lwfh/sei, aor. opt. lwfh/seie: rest from, cease from, retire, Od. 9.460, Il. 21.292.

div1.head: *m
div1.entryFree: m): usually for me/, sometimes for moi/, *z 165, Od. 10.19, etc.
ma/: by, in oaths, w. acc. of the divinity or of the witness invoked; mostly neg., w. ou), Il. 1.86; sometimes, w. nai/, affirmative, Il. 1.234.
*ma/gnhtes: a Thessalian tribe, sprung from Aeolus, Il. 2.756.
mazo/s: nipple, pap, then mother's breast.
mai=a (cf. mh/thr): voc., used esp. in addressing the old nurse, ‘good mother,’ ‘aunty,’ Od. 20.129, Od. 23.11.
*maia/s, a/dos: Maia, daughter of Atlas, and mother of Hermes, Od. 14.435†.
*mai/andros: the Maeander, the river of many windings that flows into the sea near Milētus, Il. 2.869†.
*maimali/dhs: son of Maemalus, Pisander, Il. 16.194†.
maima/w, maimw/wsi, part. maimw/wsa, aor. mai/mhsa: strive or desire madly, rage; fig., ai)xmh/, Il. 5.661.
maina/s, a/dos (mai/nomai): madwoman, Il. 22.460†.
mai/nomai, ipf. mai/neto: be mad, rave, rage, Il. 6.132, Od. 18.406; often of the frenzy of battle, Il. 5.185, Od. 11.537; fig., of the hand, weapons, fire, Il. 16.75, Il. 8.111, Il. 15.606.
mai/omai, inf. mai/esqai, part. maiome/nh: seek for, explore, Od. 14.356, Od. 13.367 ; ma/ssetai, ‘will find’ a wife for me (ge\ ma/ssetai, Aristarchus' reading for vulg. game/ssetai), Il. 9.394.
*mai=ra: (1) a Nereid, Il. 18.48.—(2) an attendant of Artemis, mother of Locrus, Od. 11.326.
*mai/wn: son of Haemon in Thebes, Il. 4.394, 398.
ma/kar, aros, sup. maka/rtatos: blessed, blest, of gods, Il. 1.339, and without qeoi/, Od. 10.299; of men, blissful, happy, through wealth or otherwise, Od. 11.483, Od. 1.217.
*ma/kar: son of Aeolus, ruling in Lesbos, Il. 24.544†.
makari/zw: pronounce happy. (Od.)
makedno/s (cf. makro/s): tall, Od. 7.106†.
ma/kella: mattock, Il. 21.259†.

makro/s, comp. makro/teros and ma=sson, sup. makro/tatos: long, tall, of space and of time (ke/leuqos, h)/mata), and of things that are high or deep (ou)/rea, de/ndra, frei/ata, Il. 21.197); freq. adv., makro/n, makra/, far, afar, boa=n, a)u=tei=n; makra\ biba=/s, ‘with long strides.’
makw/n: see mhka/omai.

ma/la, comp. ma=llon, sup. ma/lista: (1) positive, ma/la, very, quite, right, modifying adjectives and other adverbs, and sometimes placed after its word, h)=ri ma/l), Il. 9.360; occasionally with substantives, ma/la xrew/, *i 197, Od. 18.370; also with verbs (ma/la polemi/zein, ‘with might and main’), and esp. to strengthen an assertion as a whole, certainly, verily, Il. 3.204. ma/la admits of much variety in translating in connection with its several usages.—(2) comp., ma=llon, more, all the more, Od. 5.284; ‘more willingly,’ ‘more gladly,’ Il. 5.231, Od. 1.351.—(3) sup., ma/lista, most, especially, far, by far, with adjectives forming a superlative, Il. 6.433; and even with superlatives themselves, Il. 2.57 f., Il. 24.334.
malako/s, comp. malakw/teros: soft, and metaph., mild, gentle; qa/natos, u(/pnos, Il. 10.2, s 202, Il. 22.373.—Adv., malakw=s.
*ma/leia: Malea, southern promontory of the Peloponnesus, Od. 9.80, Od. 19.187, Od. 3.287.
malero/s: powerful, destroying, epith. of fire. (Il.)
malqako/s = malako/s, fig. effeminate, cowardly, Il. 17.588†.
ma/lista, ma=llon: see ma/la.
ma=/n (= mh/n): verily, truly, indeed; a)/grei ma=/n, ‘come now!’ h)= ma=/n, ou) ma=/n, mh\ ma=/n, Il. 5.765, Il. 2.370, *d 512, Il. 8.512.
manqa/nw, only aor. ma/qon, e)/mmaqes: learn, come to know, ti\, and w. inf., Il. 6.444.
manteu/omai (ma/ntis), ipf. manteu/eto, fut. manteu/somai: declare oracles, divine, prophesy, Od. 2.170.
manth/ion: oracle, prophecy, pl., Od. 12.272†.
*mantine/h: a city in Arcadia, Il. 2.607†.
*ma/ntios: son of Melampus, and brother of Antiphates, Od. 15.242, 249.

ma/ntis, ios (ma/nthos, Od. 10.493): seer, prophet, expounder of omens, which were drawn from the flight of birds, from dreams, and from sacrifices. Seers celebrated by Homer are Tiresias, Calchas, Melampus, Theoclymenus.
mantosu/nh: the art or gift of divination, prophecy; pl., Il. 2.832.
ma/omai: see mai/omai.
*maraqw/n (ma/raqon, ‘fennel’): a village in Attica, Od. 7.80†.
marai/nomai, ipf. e)marai/neto, aor. e)mara/nqh: of fire, die gradually away. (Il.)
margai/nw (ma/rgos): rage madly or wildly, Il. 5.882†.
ma/rgos: mad, raving, raging. (Od.)
*ma/ris: a Lycian, son of Amisodarus, Il. 16.319.
marmai/rw: sparkle, flash, glitter.
marma/reos: flashing, glittering. (Il.)
ma/rmaros: doubtful word, crushing; pe/tros, Il. 16.735; as subst., block of stone, Il. 12.380, Od. 9.499.
marmarugh/ (marmaru/ssw = marmai/rw): the quick twinkling of dancers' feet, pl., Od. 8.265†.
ma/rnamai, opt. marnoi/meqa, inf. ma/rnasqai, ipf. e)marna/sqhn: fight; also contend, wrangle, Il. 1.257.
*ma/rphssa: daughter of Euēnus, and wife of Idas, who recovered her after she had been carried off by Apollo, Il. 9.557 ff.

ma/rptw, ipf. e)/marpte, ma/rpte, fut. ma/ryw, aor. e)/marya: seize, lay hold of, overtake; of reaching or touching with the feet, Il. 14.228; inflicting a stroke (kerauno/s), Il. 8.405, 419; fig., of sleep, age, Od. 20.56, Od. 24.390.
marturi/h: testimony, pl., Od. 11.325†.
ma/rturos: witness.
*ma/rwn: son of Euanthes, priest of Apollo in Ismarus, Od. 9.197†.
*ma=/shs: a town in Argolis, near Hermione, Il. 2.562†.
ma/ssetai: see mai/omai.
ma=sson: see makro/s.
ma/stac, akos (masta/zw, chew): mouth; a mouthful of food, Il. 9.324.
masti=/zw: use the ma/sti=c, lash, whip.
ma/sti=c, i=gos, and ma/stis, dat. ma/sti=, acc. ma/sti=ga, ma/stin: whip, scourge; fig., *dio\s ma/sti=gi, *m 37, Il. 13.812.
masti=/w = masti=/zw, mid., Il. 20.171.
*mastori/dhs: son of Mastor.—(1) Halitherses in Ithaca, Od. 2.158, Od. 24.452.— (2) Lycophron, Il. 15.438, 430.
mata/w (ma/thn), aor. e)ma/thsen, subj. du. math/seton: do in vain, fail, Il. 16.474; then be idle, delay, linger.
mateu/w, fut. mateu/somen: seek, Il. 14.110†.
mati/h (ma/thn): fruitless toil, Od. 10.79†.
ma/xaira: dagger, knife for sacrificing, broad and short in shape. (Il.) (See the cut, and No. 109.)

*maxa=/wn: Machāon, one of the sons of Asclepius, ruler in Tricca and Ithōme in Thessaly, distinguished in the art of healing, Il. 11.512, 613, *d 200, Il. 2.732; wounded by Hector, Il. 11.506, 598, 651.
maxeio/menos, maxeou/menon: see ma/xomai.

ma/xh: flight, battle, combat; ma/xhn ma/xesqai, ti/qesqai, sth/sasqai, o)rnu/men, e)gei/rein, o)tru=/nein, a)rtu=/nein, sumfe/resqai: of single combat, Il. 7.263 and Il. 11.255; for the field of battle, Il. 5.355.
maxh/mwn: warlike, Il. 12.247†.
maxhth/s: fighter, warrior.
maxhto/s: that may be vanquished, Od. 12.119†.
maxlosu/nh (ma/xlos): lust, indulgence, Il. 24.30†.

ma/xomai, maxe/omai, opt. maxe/oito, -oi/ato (Il. 1.272, 344), part. maxeio/menos, maxeou/menos, ipf. (e))maxo/mhn, iter. ma-
xe/sketo, fut. maxh/somai, maxe/ssomai, maxei=tai, maxe/ontai, aor. inf. maxh/sasqai, maxe/sasqai: fight, contend, usually in war, including single combat, but sometimes of friendly contest, Il. 23.621; and of wrangling, quarrelling with words, etc., Il. 1.304, Il. 5.875, Il. 9.32.
ma/y, mayidi/ws: rashly (temere), in vain, Il. 2.120; wantonly, Il. 5.759, Od. 3.138, cf. Il. 17.120, Il. 13.627, Il. 2.214.
*mega/dhs: son of Megas, Perimus, Il. 16.695†.
mega/ - qu=mos: great - hearted, highhearted, high-spirited, epith. of nations, Athēna, a bull.

megai/rw (me/gas), aor. me/ghre, subj. megh/rh|s: properly, to regard something as too great, grudge, begrudge, hence, refuse, object; with acc.; also part. gen., Il. 13.563; and foll. by inf., Od. 3.55.
mega-kh/ths, es (kh=tos): with great gulf or hollow; delfi=/n, ‘voracious,’ Il. 21.22 ; nhu=s, ‘wide-bellied,’ Il. 8.222 ; po/ntos, ‘wide-yawning,’ Od. 3.158.
megal-h/twr (h)=tor): great - hearted, proud.
megali/zomai: exalt oneself, be proud. (Il. and Od. 23.174.)
mega/lws: see me/gas.
megalwsti/: me/gas megalwsti/, ‘great in his (thy) greatness,’ of a stately form prostrate upon the earth, Il. 16.776, Il. 18.26, Od. 24.40.
*megape/nqhs (‘Mournful,’ from the deserted father): Megapenthes, son of Menelāus by a slave, Od. 15.100, 103, Od. 4.11.
*mega/rh: Megara, daughter of Creon in Thebes, wife of Heracles, Od. 11.269†.

me/garon (me/gas): properly large room.—(1) the men's dining-hall, the chief room of the Homeric house. The roof was supported by columns, the light entered through the doors, the smoke escaped by an opening overhead and through loop - holes (o)pai=a) just under the roof. The cut, combined from different ancient representations, is designed to show the back part of the me/garon in the house of Odysseus, cf. plate III. for groundplan.—(2) the women's apartment, behind the one just described, see plate III. G. Pl., Od. 19.16.—(3) the housekeeper's apartment in the upper story (u(perw/ion), Od. 2.94.—(4) a sleeping-apartment, Od. 11.374.—(5) in wider signif., in pl., house, Il. 1.396.

me/gas, mega/lh, me/ga, comp. mei/zwn, sup. me/gistos: great, large, of persons, tall (ka=lo/s te me/gas te, ka=lh/ te mega/lh te, *f 108, Od. 15.418); of things with reference to any kind of dimension, and also to power, loudness, etc., a)/nemos,
i)axh/, o)rumagdo/s; in unfavorable sense, me/ga e)/rgon (facinus), so me/ga e)/pos, me/ga fronei=n, ei)pei=n, ‘be proud,’ ‘boast,’ Od. 3.261, Od. 22.288.—Adv., mega/lws, also me/ga, mega/la, greatly, exceedingly, aloud, etc.
me/geqos, eos: stature, height; see me/gas, third definition.
*me/ghs: son of Phyleus and of the sister of Odysseus, chief of the inhabitants of Dulichium and the Echinades, Il. 5.69, Il. 13.692, Il. 15.520, 535, *b 627, Il. 19.239.
me/gistos: see me/gas.
mede/wn: ruling, bearing sway, only of Zeus. (Il.)
*medew/n: a town in Boeotia, Il. 2.501†.
me/domai, fut. medh/somai: be mindful of, bethink oneself of; do/rpoio, koi/tou, a)lkh=s, *s 245, Il. 4.418; also devise, kaka/ tini, *d 21, Il. 8.458.
me/dwn, ontos (me/domai): a(lo/s, ruler of the sea, Od. 1.72; pl., h(gh/tores h)de\ me/dontes, counsellors.

*me/dwn: (1) son of Oī¨leus, stepbrother of Ajax, from Phylace, chief of the warriors from Methōne in Phthia, Il. 13.693, 695 ff., Il. 2.727; slain by Aenēas, Il. 15.332.—(2) a Lycian, Il. 17.216.—(3) a herald in Ithaca, Od. 4.677, Od. 17.172, Od. 22.357, 361, Od. 24.439.
meq-aire/w: only aor. iter. meqe/leske, would reach after and catch, i. e. ‘on the fly,’ Od. 8.376.
meq-a/llomai: only aor. part., meta/lmenos, springing after or upon a person or thing, overtaking. (Il.)
meqei/w: see meqi/hmi.
meqe/leske: see meqaire/w.
meqe/men: see meqi/hmi.

meq - e/pw, ipf. me/qepe, aor. 2 part. metaspw/n, mid. metaspo/menos: move after, follow after, follow up; trans., w. two accusatives, i(/ppous *tu=dei/dhn, turn the steeds after Tydīdes, Il. 5.329; of ‘visiting’ a place, Od. 1.175; mid., Il. 13.567.
me/q-hmai: only part., meqh/menos, sitting among, Od. 1.118†.
meq-hmosu/nh: remissness, Il. 13.108 and 121.
meq-h/mwn (meqi/hmi): remiss, careless.

meq - i/hmi, meqi/eis, meqi/ei (-iei=s, iei=), inf. meqi=e/men(ai), subj. meqih=|si (-i/h|si), ipf. meqi/eis, meqi/ei (-i/hs, -i/h), 3 pl. me/qien, meqi=/esan, fut. meqh/sw, aor. meqe/hka, meqh=ken, subj. meqei/w, meqei/h|, meqh/h|, meqw=men, inf. meqe/men, meqei=nai: let go after or among.—(1) trans., of letting a person go away, or go free, Od. 15.212, Il. 10.449; letting a thing go (e)s potamo/n), Od. 5.460; give up, give over, Il. 3.414, Il. 14.364, and w. inf., Il. 17.418; metaph., in the above senses, meqe/men xo/lon, ‘dismiss,’ Il. 15.138 ; ei)/ me meqei/h r(i=gos, Od. 5.471. —(2) intrans., relax effort, be remiss, abs., Il. 6.523, Od. 4.372; w. gen., desist from, neglect, cease, Od. 21.377, Il. 11.841; w. part. or inf., Od. 24.48, Il. 13.234.
meq-i/sthmi, fut. metasth/sw, mid. ipf. meqi/stato: substitute, i. e. exchange, Od. 4.612; mid., stand over among, ‘retire’ among, Il. 5.514.
meq - omi=le/w: associate with, have dealings with, ipf., Il. 1.269†.
meq - orma/omai: only aor. part., meqormhqei/s, starting after, ‘making a dash after.’
me/qu, uos (cf. ‘mead’): strong drink, wine.
mequ/w (me/qu): be drunken, fig., soaked, Od. 17.390.
meida/w (root smi), meidia/w, part. meidio/wn, -o/wsa, aor. mei/dhsa: smile.
mei/zwn: see me/gas.
mei/lani: see me/las.
mei/lia: soothing gifts, gifts of reconciliation, Il. 9.147 and 289.
mei/ligma, atos (meili/ssw): that which soothes, meili/gmata qumou=, things to appease the appetite, tid - bits, Od. 10.217†.
mei/linos: see me/linos.
meili/ssw, inf. meilisse/men, mid. imp. meili/sseo: appease the dead with fire (puro/s, cf. constr. w. lagxa/nein), Il. 7.410; mid., ‘extenuate,’ Od. 3.96 (‘try to make it pleasant’ for me).
meilixi/h: mildness, i. e. ‘feebleness,’ pole/moio, Il. 15.741†.
meili/xios and mei/lixos: mild, pleasant, gentle, winsome, Od. 8.172.

mei/romai (root mer, mor), ipf. 2 sing. mei/reo, perf. e)/mmore, pass. plup. ei(/marto: cause to be divided, receive as a portion, ipf. w. acc., Il. 9.616; perf. w. gen., share, Il. 1.278, Il. 15.189, Od. 5.335; pass., ei(/marto, it was ordained, decreed by fate, Il. 21.281, Od. 5.312, Od. 24.34.
mei/s, mh/n, mhno/s: month, Il. 19.117.
mei/wn: see mi=kro/s.
melag - xroih/s, e/s: dark - skinned, swarthy, ‘bronzed,’ Od. 16.175†.

me/laqron, melaqro/fi: beam, crossbeam of a house, supporting rafters and roof; these beams passed through the wall and projected externally, hence e)pi\ prou)/xonti mela/qrw|, Od. 19.544; then roof (tectum), and in wider sense dwelling, mansion, Il. 9.640.
melai/nw (me/la=s): only mid., become dark, grow dark, of blood-stains, and of the glebe under the plough, Il. 5.354 and Il. 6.548.

*mela/mpous: Melampus, son of Amythāon, a famous seer in Pylus. Undertaking to fetch from Phylace in Thessaly the cattle of Iphiclus, and thus to win the hand of Pero for his brother Bias, he was taken captive, as he had himself predicted, and held prisoner for one year, when in consequence of good counsel given by him he was set free by Iphiclus, gained his end, and settled in Argos, Od. 11.287 ff., Od. 15.225 ff.
mela/n-detos (de/w): black - bound or mounted, i. e. with dark hilt or scabbard, Il. 15.713†.
*melaneu/s: father of Amphimedon in Ithaca, Od. 24.103.
*melanqeu/s or *mela/nqios: Melanthius, son of Dolius, goat-herd on the estate of Odysseus, of insolent disposition, Od. 17.212, Od. 20.173, Od. 21.181, Od. 22.135 ff., 182.
*mela/nqios: (1) see *melanqeu/s.— (2) a Trojan, slain by Eurypylus, Il. 6.36.
*melanqw/: Melantho, sister of Melanthius (1), and of the same stripe, Od. 18.321, Od. 19.65.

*mela/nippos: (1) an Achaean chief, Il. 19.240.—(2) a Trojan, son of Hicetāon, slain by Antiochus, Il. 15.547-582.—(3) a Trojan, slain by Teucer, Il. 8.276.—(4) a Trojan, slain by Patroclus, Il. 16.695.
melano/-xroos and melano/-xrws, oos: dark-skinned, black, Od. 19.246 and Il. 13.589.
mela/n-udros: of dark water, krh/nh.
mela/nw: grow black, darken, Il. 7.64† (v. l. melanei=).

me/la=s, me/laina, me/lan, dat. mei/lani, comp. mela/nteros: dark, black, in the general and extensive meaning of these words, opp. leuko/s, Il. 3.103; said of dust, steel, blood, wine, water, grapes, ships, clouds, evening, night, death.—As subst., me/lan druo/s, i. e. the ‘heart-wood,’ which is always the darkest, Od. 14.12.
*me/la=s: son of Portheus, Il. 14.117†.
me/ldomai (root smeld): melt; le/bhs kni=/shn meldo/menos, ‘filled with melting fat,’ Il. 21.363†.

*mele/agros (w(=| me/lei a)/gra): Meleāger, son of Oeneus and Althaea, husband of Cleopatra, the slayer of the Calydonian boar. A quarrel arose between the Curētes of Pleuron and the Aetolians for the head and skin of the boar. The Aetolians had the upper hand until Meleāger withdrew from the struggle in consequence of the curses of his mother. But he was afterwards induced by his wife to enter the conflict again, and he drove the Curētes vanquished into Acarnania, Il. 9.543 ff., Il. 2.642.
mele/dhma, atos (me/lw): care, anxiety, only pl.
meledw/n, w=nos (me/lw) = mele/dhma, Od. 19.517† (v. l. meledw=nai).
me/lei: see me/lw.
melei+sti/ (me/los): adv., limb - meal, limb by limb, Il. 24.409, Od. 9.291, Od. 18.339.
me/leos: fruitless, idle, unrewarded, neut. as adv., in vain, Il. 16.336.
me/li, itos: honey; used even as a drink, mixed with wine; burned upon the funeral-pyre, Il. 23.170, Od. 24.68; mixed with milk in drink-offerings, meli/krhton. Figuratively, Il. 1.249, Il. 18.109.
*meli/boia: a town in Magnesia, Il. 2.717†.
meli/ - ghrus: honey - toned, sweetvoiced, Od. 12.187†.
meli/h: the ash-tree, Il. 13.178, Il. 16.767; then of the shaft of the lance, lance, freq. w. *phlia/s, ‘from Mt. Pelion’; other epithets, eu)/xalkos, xalkoglw/xi=n.
meli-hdh/s, e/s: honey-sweet; fig., u(/pnos, no/stos, qu=mo/s.
meli/ - krhton (kera/nnu=mi): honeymixture, honey - drink, a potion compounded of milk and honey for libation to the shades of the nether world, Od. 10.519, Od. 11.27.
me/linos, mei/linos (meli/h): ashen. (Il.)
me/lissa (me/li): bee.
*meli/th: a Nereid, Il. 18.42†.
meli/ - frwn: honey - minded, honeylike, sweet.

me/llw, ipf. e)/mellon, me/lle: be going or about to do something, foll. by fut. inf., sometimes pres., rarely aor., *y
773; me/llw never means to intend, although intention is of course sometimes implied, th=| ga\r e)/melle dieci/menai pedi/onde, ‘for by that gate he was going to pass out,’ Il. 6.393; by destiny as it were, of something that was or was not meant to happen, *ku/klwy, ou)k a)/r' e)/melles a)na/lkidos a)ndro\s e(tai/rous | e)/dmenai, ‘you were not going to eat the comrades of a man unable to defend himself after all,’ i. e. he was no coward whose companions you undertook to eat, and therefore it was not meant that you should eat them with impunity, Od. 9.475, and often similarly. Virtually the same is the usage that calls for must in paraphrasing, ou(/tw pou *dii\ me/llei u(permene/i+ fi/lon ei)=nai, such methinks ‘must’ be the will of Zeus; ta\ de\ me/llet' a)koue/men, ye ‘must’ have heard, Il. 2.116, Il. 14.125, Od. 4.94, Od. 1.232 ; me/llei me/n pou/ tis kai\ fi/lteron a)/llon o)le/ssai, ‘may well’ have lost, Il. 24.46.
me/los, eos: limb, member, only pl.

me/lpw: act., celebrate with dance and song, Il. 1.474; mid., play (and sing), formi/zwn, on the lyre, Od. 4.17, Od. 13.27; dance and sing, e)n xorw=|, Il. 16.182; fig., me/lpesqai *)/arhi, Il. 7.241.

me/lw, me/lei, me/lousi, imp. mele/tw, melo/ntwn, inf. mele/men, ipf. e)/mele, me/le, fut. melh/sei, inf. melhse/men, perf. me/mhlen, subj. memh/lh|, part. memhlw/s, plup. memh/lei, mid. pres. imp. mele/sqw, fut. melh/setai, perf. me/mbletai, plup. me/mbleto: be an object of care or interest; pa=si do/loisi | a)nqrw/poisi me/lw, i. e. my wiles give me a world - wide ‘renown,’ Od. 9.20; cf. *)argw\ pa=si me/lousa, i. e. the Argo ‘all - renowned,’ Od. 12.70; mostly only the 3d pers., me/lei moi/ tis or ti\, ‘I care for,’ ‘am concerned with’ or ‘in’ somebody or something, he, she, or it ‘interests me,’ ‘rests’ or ‘weighs upon my mind’; melh/sousi/ moi i(/ppoi, ‘I will take care of the horses,’ Il. 5.228 ; a)nh\r w(=| to/ssa me/mhlen, who has so many ‘responsibilities,’ Il. 2.25; perf. part. memhlw/s, ‘interested’ or ‘engaged in,’ ‘intent on,’ tino/s, *e 708, Il. 13.297; mid., Il. 1.523, Il. 19.343, Il. 21.516, Od. 22.12.

me/maa, perf. w. pres. signif., du. me/maton, pl. me/mamen, me/mate, mema/a=si, imp. mema/tw, part. mema<*>w/s, memaui=a, memaw=tos, mema=o/tes, mema=o/te, plup. me/masan: be eagerly desirous, press on hotly, go impetuously at; e)pi/ tini, *q 327, Il. 22.326, abs. Il. 21.174; foll. by inf., even the fut., Il. 2.544, Od. 24.395; freq. the part., as adj. (or adv.), hotly desirous or eager.
memakui=a: see mhka/omai.
me/mblwka: see blw/skw.
me/mbletai, me/mbleto: see me/lw.
memhkw/s: see mhka/omai.
me/mhla: see me/lw.
memne/w|to, memnw/meqa: see mimnh/skw.
*me/mnwn: Memnon, son of Eos and Tithōnus, came to the aid of Priam after the death of Hector, and slew Antilochus, Od. 11.522, cf. Od. 4.188.

me/mona, me/monas, me/monen, perf. w. pres. signif.: have in mind, be minded, be impelled or prompted, w. inf., sometimes the fut., Il. 7.36, Od. 15.521 ; me/monen d' o(/ ge i)=sa qeoi=si (cf. frone/ein i)=sa), ‘vies with the gods,’ Il. 21.315 ; di<*>xqa kradi/h me/mone, ‘yearns with a twofold wish,’ in hesitation, Il. 16.435.
me/mu=ka: see mu=ka/omai.

me/n (mh/n): (1) the same as mh/n, in truth, indeed, certainly, Il. 7.89, Il. 1.267, Od. 3.351; sometimes might be written mh/n, as the scansion shows, Il. 7.389, Il. 22.482; freq. to emphasize a pronoun or another particle, and of course not always translatable, tou= me/n, h)= me/n, kai\ me/n, ou) me/n, ou)de\ me\n ou)de/, z 13, Il. 2.703. —(2) in correlation, me/n without losing the force above described calls attention to what follows, the following statement being introduced by de/, au)ta/r, or some other adversative word. me/n in correlation may sometimes be translated to be sure (quidem), although, but oftener does not admit of translation. It should be remembered that me/n is never a connective, that it always looks forward, never backward. Its combinations with other particles are various.

meneai/nw, inf. meneaine/men, ipf. meneai/nomen, aor. meneh/namen: cagerly desire, w. inf., sometimes fut., Il. 21.176 and Od. 21.125; also be angered, strive, contend, Il. 16.491, Od. 1.20, Il. 19.58.
mene-dh/ios (me/nw): withstanding the enemy, steadfast, brave, Il. 12.247 and Il. 13.228.

*mene/la=os: Menelāus, son of Atreus and brother of Agamemnon, the successful suitor of Helen. King in Lacedaemon, a brave and spirited warrior, but not of the warlike temperament that distinguishes others of the Greeks before Troy above him, Il. 17.18 ff. After the war he wanders eight years before reaching home, Od. 4.82 ff. Epithets, a)rh/ios, a)rhi/filos, diotrefh/s, dourikleito/s, kuda/limos, canqo/s.
mene-pto/lemos (me/nw): steadfast in battle. (Il.)
*menesqeu/s: Menestheus, son of Peteos, leader of the Athenians, renowned as a chariot-fighter, Il. 2.552, Il. 12.331, Il. 13.195, Il. 15.331.
*mene/sqhs: a Greek, slain by Hector, Il. 5.609†.
*mene/sqios: (1) son of Areïthous, slain by Paris, Il. 7.9.—(2) a Myrmidon, son of Spercheius, Il. 16.173.
mene-xa/rmhs and mene/-xarmos (me/nw, xa/rmh): steadfast or stanch in battle. (Il.)
meno-eikh/s, es (me/nos, vei/kw): suiting the spirit, i. e. grateful, satisfying; usually said with reference to quantity, plenty of, so pl. menoeike/<*>, Od. 14.232; and w. polla/, Il. 9.227.

menoina/w, menoine/w, menoinw/w, subj. menoina=/a|, menoinh/h|si, aor. 1 e)menoi/nhsa: have in mind, ponder (Il. 12.59), intend, devise; fresi/, meta\ fresi/, e)ni\ qu=mw=|, o(do/n, no/ston, kaka/ tini, Od. 11.532.
*menoitia/dhs: son of Menoetius, Patroclus, Il. 16.554, Il. 18.93, Il. 9.211.
*menoi/tios: Menoetius, son of Actor and father of Patroclus, an Argonaut, Il. 11.765, Il. 16.14, Il. 23.85 ff.

me/nos, eos: impulse, will, spirit, might, courage, martial fury, rage (noble or otherwise), pl. me/nea pnei/ontes, ‘breathing might,’ Il. 2.536. A very characteristic Homeric word, with a wide range of application; joined w. qu=mo/s, a)lkh/, qa/rsos, yu=xh/, xei=res, gui=a, and w. gen. of names as periphrases for the person, Il. 14.418, Od. 7.167; said of things as well as men and animals, wind, fire, the sun, etc.
*me/nths: (1) leader of the Ciconians, Il. 17.73.—(2) son of Anchialus, king of the Taphians, under whose form Athena visits Telemachus, Od. 1.105, 180.
me/ntoi: indeed, to be sure, however; see me/n and toi/.

*me/ntwr: Mentor.—(1) an Ithacan, the son of Alcimus, a near friend of Odysseus, to whom Odysseus intrusts the oversight of his household during his absence. Under the form of Mentor, Athēna guides Telemachus on his travels in search of his father, and helps him to baffle the suitors; in other words she makes herself his mentor, Od. 2.225, 243, Od. 3.22, 340, Od. 22.206, 208, Od. 24.446.—(2) father of Imbrius, under whose form Apollo incites Hector to battle, Il. 13.171.

me/nw and mi/mnw, ipf. iter. me/neskon, fut. mene/w, aor. e)/meina, mei=na: remain, wait, and trans., await, withsland, Od. 16.367, Il. 6.126; foll. by inf., Il. 15.599 ; ei)so/ke, Il. 9.45; freq. of standing one's ground in battle or elsewhere, Il. 11.317, Od. 10.83; also w. obj., do/ru, e)/gxos, etc.
*me/nwn: a Trojan, slain by Leonteus, Il. 12.193†.
*mermeri/dhs: son of Mermesus, Ilus, Od. 1.259†.
me/rmeros: memorable, signal; me/rmera e)/rga, also me/rmera as subst. (Il.)
*me/rmeros: a Mysian, slain by Antilochus, Il. 14.513†.

mermhri/zw, aor. mermh/rica: ponder, wonder, reflect, trans., think over, Od. 1.427; freq. w. di/xa, dia/ndixa, of a mind hesitating between two resolves, Il. 1.189, Od. 16.73; foll. by h)/ (h)\.. h)=), also w(s, o(/pws, and by inf., Od. 24.235; ‘imagine,’ Od. 16.256, 261.
me/rmi=s, i=qos: cord, Od. 10.23†.
me/roy, opos: probably mortal, me/ropes a)/nqrwpoi, mero/pessi brotoi=sin, *s 288, Il. 2.285.
*me/roy: a seer and ruler in Percōte on the Hellespont, father of Adrastus and Amphīus, Il. 2.831, Il. 11.329.
me/romai: see mei/romai.
mesai-po/lios (me/sos, polio/s): halfgray, grizzled, Il. 13.361†.
*mesau/lios: a servant of Eumaeus, Od. 14.449, 455.
meshgu/(s), messhgu=/(s): in the middle, Il. 11.573, Il. 23.521; meantime, Od. 7.195; elsewhere w. gen., between, betwixt, Il. 6.4, Od. 22.341.
mesh/eis (me/sos): middling, Il. 12.269†.
*me/sqlhs: son of Talaemenes, leader of the Maeonians, Il. 2.864, Il. 17.216.

meso/dmh (de/mw): properly something mid-built.—(1) mast-block, represented in the cut (see a) as a metal shoe in which the mast was firmly fastened so as to be turned back ward on the pivot (c) to a horizontal position, until it rested upon the i(stodo/kh, Od. 2.424. See also plate IV., where the meso/dmh is somewhat differently represented as a threesided trough or mast-box.—(2) meso/dmai, small spaces or niches, opening into the me/garon of the house, and enclosed on three sides, behind by the outside wall, and on either side by the low walls which served as foundations of the columns, Od. 19.37. (See plate III., g, and cut No. 83.)

me/sos, me/ssos: in the middle of; me/ssh| a(li/, in mid-sea, Od. 4.844 ; h(/menoi e)n me/ssoisi, ‘in the midst of them,’ Od. 4.281; of time, me/son h)=mar; as subst., me/son, the middle; e)s me/son tiqe/nai, ‘offer for competition,’ as prize, Il. 23.794 ; e)s me/son a)mfote/rois dika/zein, ‘impartially,’ Il. 23.574; as adv., me/son, in the middle, Il. 12.167, Od. 14.300.
me/ssatos (sup. to me/sos): in the very middle, Il. 8.223 and Il. 11.6.
me/ss-aulos: mid-court, court, farmyard, Il. 17.112; cattle-yard, Il. 11.548.
*me/ssh: a harbor-town near Taenarum in Laconia, Il. 2.582†.
messhgu/s: see meshgu/s.
*messhi/s: a spring in Thessalian Hellas, Il. 6.457†.
*messh/nh: a district about Pherae in what was afterward Messenia, Od. 21.15.
*messh/nioi: the Messenians, inhabitants of Messēne, Od. 21.18.
messo - pagh/s, e/s (ph/gnu=mi): fixed up to the middle; e)/qhken e)/gxos, drove the spear half its length firm into the bank, Il. 21.172 (v. l. messopale/s, ‘vibrating to the middle’).
me/sfa (=Att. me/xri): till, until, w. gen., Il. 8.508†.

meta/: amid, among, after.—I. adv. (here belong all instances of ‘tmesis’), meta\ d' i)o
 e(/hken, let fly an arrow among them (the ships), Il. 1.48, Od. 18.2 ; prw=tos e)gw/, meta\ d' u)/mmes, afterward, Od. 21.231, and so of time, Od. 15.400: denoting change of position, meta\ d' a)/stra bebh/kei, ‘had passed over the meridian’; meta\ d' e)tra/pet), ‘turned around’; meta\ nw=ta balw/n, Od. 12.312, *a 199, Il. 8.94. The relation of the adv. may be specified by a case of a subst., thus showing the transition to the true prepositional use, meta\ kai\ to/de toi=si gene/sqw, ‘let this be added to those and be among them,’ Od. 5.224.—II. prep., (1) w. gen., along with; met' a)/llwn le/co e(tai/rwn, ma/xesqai meta/ tinos, ‘in league with,’ Od. 10.320, Il. 13.700.—(2) w. dat., amid, among, between, in; meta\ xersi
 e)/xein, ‘in the hands,’ Il. 11.184, Od. 3.281 ; meta\ ge/nussi, possi/, ‘between,’ Il. 11.416, Il. 19.110 ; meta\ pnoih=|s a)ne/moio pe/tesqai, i. e. as fast as the winds, Od. 2.148 ; *ou)=tin e)gw\ pu/maton e)/domai meta\ oi(=s e(ta/roisin, the last ‘among’ his mates, the position of honor in being eaten, Od. 9.369.—(3) w. acc., denoting motion, among, towards, to, after, met' *ai)qioph=as e)/bh, meta\ mw=lon *)/arhos, sfai=ran e)/rriye met) a)mfi/polon, bh=nai meta/ tina, Il. 1.423, Il. 7.147, z 115, Il. 5.152, and sometimes of course in a hostile sense; so fig., ba/llein tina\ met' e)/ridas, ‘plunge in,’ ‘involve in,’ Il. 2.376; sometimes only position, without motion, is denoted, Il. 2.143; of succession, after, next to, whether locally or of rank and worth, meta\ kti/lon e(/speto mh=la, Il. 13.492; ka/llistos a)nh meta\ *phlei/wna, Il. 2.674; then of time, purpose, conformity, or adaptation, meta\ *pa/troklo/n ge qano/nta, ‘after the death of P.’; plei=n meta\ xalko/n, ‘after,’ i. e. to get bronze; meta\ so
 kh=r, ‘after,’ i. e. to suit thy heart, Il. 24.575, Od. 1.184, *o
52, Il. 18.552, Od. 2.406, Il. 11.227 .—me/ta = me/testi, Od. 21.93.
meta - bai/nw, aor. imp. meta/bhqi: pass over to a new subject, Od. 8.492†.
meta - bouleu/w: only aor. metebou/leusan, have changed their purpose (cf. metafra/zomai), Od. 5.286†.
met-a/ggelos: messenger between two parties (internuntius, internuntia). Also written as two words, Il. 15.144 and Il. 23.199.
meta-dai/numai, fut. metadai/setai, aor. subj. metadai/somai: feast with, have a share in the feast, i=(rw=n, Il. 23.207.
meta-dh/mios (dh=mos): among the people, in the community, Od. 13.46; at home, Od. 8.293.
meta-do/rpios (do/rpos): during supper, Od. 4.194† (cf. 213, 218).
meta-droma/dhn: adv., running after, Il. 5.80†.
meta-i+/zw: sit among, Il. 16.362†.
met-a=i+/ssw, aor. part. meta=i+/ca=s: dart or spring after.
meta-kia/qw, only ipf. meteki/aqon: go after, pursue, pass over to, traverse, Il. 11.714.
meta - klai/w, fut. inf. metaklau/sesqai: weep afterward, lament hereafter, Il. 11.764†.
meta - kli=/nw: only pass. aor. part. pole/moio metaklinqe/ntos, should the tide of battle turn the other way, Il. 11.509†.
meta - lh/gw, aor. opt. metallh/ceie, part. -llh/canti: cease from. (Il.)

metalla/w, metallw=, -a=|s, -a=|, imp. meta/lla=, aor. meta/llhsan, inf. -h=sai: search after, investigate, inquire about, question; ti\ or tina/, also tina/ ti or a)mfi/ tini, Od. 17.554; coupled w. verbs of similar meaning, Il. 1.550, Od. 3.69, Od. 23.99, Od. 7.243.
metallh/gw: see metalh/gw.
meta/lmenos: see meqa/llomai.
meta-ma/zios: between the paps, mazoi/, Il. 5.19†.

meta-mi=/gnu=mi and meta-mi/sgw, fut. metami=/comen: mix among, intersperse, place in the midst, Od. 18.310; ‘we will merge thy possessions with those of Odysseus’ (for subsequent division among us), Od. 22.221.
metamw/nios: vain, fruitless, only neut. pl. (v. l. metamw/lia).
meta-na/sths (nai/w): new-comer, interloper, immigrant. (Il.)
meta-ni/ssomai: pass over (the meridian), of the sun, only w. boulu=to/nde.
metacu/: between, Il. 1.156†.
meta-pau/omai: cease or rest between whiles, Il. 17.373.
meta-pauswlh/: pause between, rest, respite, Il. 19.201†.
meta-preph/s, e/s (pre/pw): conspicuous among, tisi/n, Il. 18.370†.
meta-pre/pw: be conspicuous or prominent among, tisi/n.
meta-seu/omai, ipf. metesseu/onto, aor. mete/ssuto: rush or hurry after, tina/, Il. 23.389.
metaspo/menos, metaspw/n: see meqe/pw.
me/tassai (meta/): of lambs, ‘middlings,’ i. e. yearlings, summer - lambs, those born in the second of the three bearings of the year, Od. 9.221, see Od. 4.86.
metasseu/omai: see metaseu/omai.
meta-ste/nw: lament afterwards, rue, Od. 4.261†.
meta-stoixi=/ (stoi=xos): in a line, in a row, side by side, Il. 23.358 and 757.

meta-stre/fw, fut. metastre/yeis, aor. subj. -yh|, opt. -yeie, pass. aor. part. metastrefqei/s: turn about or away, change, fig., h)=tor e)k xo/lou, no/on, *k 107, Il. 15.52; ‘cause a reverse of fortune,’ Od. 2.67; intr., Il. 15.203; so the aor. pass., Il. 11.447, 595.
meta-ti/qhmi, aor. mete/qhken: cause among, Od. 18.402†.
meta - tre/pomai: turn oneself towards, met., regard, consider, tino/s, always w. neg.
meta - tropali/zomai (tre/pw): turn about to look behind (in flight), Il. 20.190†.
met-auda/w, ipf. methu/dwn, methu/da=: speak among, e)/pea tisi/. See au)da/w.
meta/-fhmi, ipf. mete/fh: speak among or to, tisi/, also w. acc., Il. 2.795. See fhmi/.
meta - fra/zomai, fut. metafraso/mesqa: consider afterward or by and by, Il. 1.140†.
meta/-frenon (fre/nes): the part behind the diaphragm, upper part of the back; also pl., Il. 12.428.
meta-fwne/w (fwnh/): speak among, make one's voice heard among, Od. 10.67 (sc. toi=si).
mete/a=si: see me/teim Od. 9.1.

me/t-eimi (1) (ei)mi/), subj. metei/w, mete/w,
inf. metei=nai, mete/mmenai, fut. mete/ssomai: be among (tisi/n), intervene, Il. 2.386.
me/t-eimi (2) (ei)=mi), me/teisin, mid. aor. part. meteisa/menos: go among, go after, go or march forth; po/lemo/nde, Il. 13.298.
met-ei=pon, mete/eipon: spoke among or to, tisi/. See ei)=pon.
meteisa/menos: see me/teim Od. 9.2.
metei/w, mete/mmenai: see me/teim Od. 9.1.
met-e/peita: afterward.

met-e/rxomai, part. meterxo/menos, fut. meteleu/somai, aor. 2 opt. mete/lqoi, imp. me/telqe, part. metelqw/n: come or go among (tisi/), to, or after (tina/ or ti\); of seeking or pursuing, Il. 6.280, Il. 21.422 ; patro\s kle/os, Od. 3.83; of ‘attending to’ or ‘caring for’ something, e)/rga, e)/rga ga/moio, p 314, Od. 5.429.
mete/ssuto: see metaseu/omai.
mete/w: see me/teim Od. 9.1.
met - h/oros (a)ei/rw, the later mete/wros): raised aloft, into the air, Il. 8.26, Il. 23.369.
met-oi/xomai, imp. metoi/xeo, part. metoixo/menos, ipf. metw/|xeto: go away with or after, in friendly or hostile sense, Od. 19.24, Od. 8.47, Il. 5.148.
met-okla/zw: keep changing the position (from one knee to the other), Il. 13.281†.
met - o/pisqe(n): behind, in the rear, toward the west, Od. 13.241; afterwards, Od. 11.382; w. gen., Od. 9.539.
met - oxli/zw, aor. opt. metoxli/sseie: pry or push back or away.
metre/w, aor. part. metrh/santes: measure, fig. pe/lagos, of traversing its extent, Od. 3.179†.

me/tron: measure, measuring-rod, Il. 12.422; then of any vessel and its contents, Il. 7.471 ; o(/rmou me/tron, of the proper point for mooring, Od. 13.101 ; me/tra keleu/qou, periphrasis for ke/leuqos, ke/leuqa; fig., h(/bhs, ‘full measure,’ ‘prime.’
met - w/pion: on the forehead, Il. 11.95 and Il. 16.739.
me/t-wpon (w)/y): forehead, also front of a helmet, Il. 16.70.
meu=: see e)gw/.
me/xri(s): as far as, tino/s. te/o me/xris; how long? Il. 24.128.

mh/: not, lest.—(1) adv., not, differing from ou)k in expressing a negation subjectively. mh/ is the regular neg. particle with the inf., in conditions and cond. rel. clauses, in prohibitions and exhortations, in wishes, and in final clauses introduced by i(/na, w(s, etc. mh/ se para\ nhusi/ kixei/w, ‘let me not catch thee near the ships!’ Il. 1.26 ; i)/stw nu=n *zeu\s.. mh\ me\n toi=s i(/ppoisin a)nh\r e)poxh/setai a)/llos (mh/, and not ou), because the statement is in sense dependent on i)/stw, though grammatically the ind. is allowed to stand instead of being changed to the inf.), Il. 10.330, cf. Il. 15.41.—(2) conj., that not, lest (n e), introducing final clauses and object clauses after verbs of fearing, a)po/stixe, mh/ ti noh/sh| | *(/hrh, ‘in order that Hera may not take note of anything,’ Il. 1.522 ; dei/dw mh\ dh\ pa/nta qea=\ nhmerte/a vei=pen, ‘lest all the goddess said was true,’ Od. 5.300 .—mh/ is combined variously with other particles, mh\ dh/, mh\ ma=/n, mh/ pou, mh/ pote, mh/ pws, etc. It is joined to interrogative words only when the question expects a negative answer, h)= mh/ (num), Od. 9.405, 406, Od. 6.200.

mhde/: but not. and not, nor, not even, not at all; mhde/ always introduces an additional negation, after some negative idea has already been expressed or implied. It is never a correlative word; if more than one mhde/ occurs at the beginning of successive clauses, the first mhde/ refers to some previous negative idea just as much as the second one or the third one does; mhde/ tis.. oi)=os mema/tw ma/xesqai, mhd' a)naxwrei/tw, Il. 4.303; here the first mhde/ means and not, nor, the direct quotation being regarded as a continuation of what precedes in the indirect form. Usually mhde/ at the beginning of a sentence means not even or not at all. For the difference between mhde/ and ou)de/, see mh/. See also ou)de/, fin.
mhde/n: nothing, Il. 18.500†.
*mhdesika/sth: a natural daughter of Priam, wife of Imbrius, Il. 13.173†.
mh/domai, fut. mh/seai, aor. mh/sao, (e))mh/sato: take counsel for oneself, Il. 2.360; devise (tini/ ti), esp. in bad sense; decide upon (ti\), Od. 3.160.
mh=dos (1), eos: only pl., mh/dea, plans, counsels.
mh=dos (2), eos: pl., privy parts. (Od.)
*mhqw/nh: a city in Magnesia, the home of Philoctētes, Il. 2.716.

mhka/omai, aor. part. makw/n, perf., w. pres. signif., memhkw/s, memakui=ai, ipf., formed on perf. stem., (e))me/mhkon: of sheep, bleat; of wounded animals, or game hard-pressed, cry, shriek, Il. 10.362; once of a man, Od. 18.98.
mhka/s, a/dos (mhka/omai): bleating (of goats).
mhk-e/ti: no longer, no more.
*mhkisteu/s: (1) son of Talaus, brother of Adrastus, and father of Euryalus, Il. 2.566, Il. 23.678.—(2) son of Echius, companion of Antilochus, slain by Polydamas, Il. 15.339, Il. 8.333, Il. 13.422.
*mhkisthi+a/dhs: son of Mecisteus, Euryalus, Il. 6.28.
mh/kistos: tallest; as adv., mh/kista, finally, Od. 5.299.
mh=kos: length, lofty stature, Od. 20.71.
mh/kwn, wnos: poppy, Il. 8.306†.
mhle/h (mh=lon): apple-tree. (Od.)
mhlo-both/r, h=ros: shepherd, pl., Il. 18.529†.
mh=lon (1): apple (mālum).
mh=lon (2): sheep or goat, Od. 12.301, Od. 14.305; mostly pl., mh=la, small cattle, flocks.
mh=loy, opos: probably shining, Od. 7.104†.

mh/n: asseverative particle, indeed, in truth, verily, cf. ma=/n and me/n (2). mh/n regularly stands in combination with another particle (kai\ mh/n, h)= mh/n, ou) mh/n), or with an imperative like a)/ge, Il. 1.302.
mh/n, mhno/s: see mei/s.
mh/nh: moon, Il. 23.455 and Il. 19.374.
mhniqmo/s (mhni/w): wrath. (*p)
mh/ni=ma, atos: cause of wrath.
mh=nis, ios: wrath, i. e. enduring anger, usually of gods, Il. 1.75, Od. 3.135; but also of the wrath of Achilles.
mhni/w, aor. part. mhni=/sa=s: be wroth, abs., and w. dat. of pers., also causal gen. of thing. mh/ni=en, Il. 2.769.
*mh/|ones: the Maeonians, i. e. the Lydians, Il. 2.864, Il. 10.431.
*mh|oni/h: Maeonia, ancient name of Lydia, Il. 3.401.
*mh|oni/s, i/dos: Maeonian woman, Il. 4.142.
mh/pote, mh/pou, mh/pw, mh/pws: see mh/ and pote/, pou/, pw/, pw/s.
mh=ra: see mhri/on.
mh/rinqos (mhru/w): cord. (*y)
mhri/on: only pl., mhri/a and mh=ra, pieces of meat from the thighs (mhroi/) of victims, thigh - pieces, which were burned upon the altar, wrapped in a double layer of fat, Il. 1.40, Od. 3.456.
*mhrio/nhs: Meriones or Merion, the son of Molus, a Cretan, charioteer of Idomeneus, Il. 13.246, 249, 528, 566, 650, Il. 10.270, Il. 7.166, *c 514, Il. 16.342, 603.

mhro/s: ham, upper part of the thigh; mhrw\ plh/ssesqai, to ‘smite the thighs,’ a gesture indicative of surprise or other excitement, Il. 12.162, Il. 16.125; of victims, mhrou\s e)ce/tamon, i. e. cut out the mhri/a from the mhroi/, *a 460, Od. 12.360.
mhru/omai, aor. mhru=/santo: draw up, furl by brailing up; i(sti/a, Od. 12.170†. (See cut No. 5, an Egyptian representation of a Phoenician ship.)

mh/stwr, wros (mh/domai): counsellor, deviser; u(/patos mh/stwr, Zeus, Il. 8.22 ; qeo/fin m. a)ta/lantos, of heroes with reference to their wisdom, Od. 3.110, 409; w. ref. to prowess, a)u=th=s, fo/boio, ‘raiser’ of the battle-cry, ‘author’ of flight, Il. 4.328, Il. 6.97.
*mh/stwr: a son of Priam, Il. 24.257†.
mh/te (mh/ te): regularly correlative, mh/te.. mh/te, neither.. nor, (not) either.. or, dividing a single neg. statement. mh/te.. te, Il. 13.230. For the difference between mh/te and ou)/te, see mh/.
mh/thr, mhte/ros and mhtro/s: mother; epithets, po/tnia, ai)doi/h, kednh/; fig., mh/thr mh/lwn, qhrw=n, of regions abounding in sheep, game, etc., Il. 2.696, Od. 15.226.
mh/ti: see mh/tis.
mh/ti=: see mh=tis.

mhtia/w (mh=tis), 3 pl. mhtio/wsi, part. mhtio/wsa, mhtio/wntes, mid. pres. mhtia/asqe, ipf. mhtio/wnto: deliberate, conclude, devise, abs., and w. acc., boula=/s, no/ston, kaka/ tini, *u 153, Od. 6.14; mid., debate with oneself, consider, Il. 22.174, Il. 12.17.
mhti/eta (mhti/omai), nom., for -ths: counselling, ‘all-wise,’ epith. of Zeus.
mhtio/eis, pl. -enta (mh=tis): full of device, helpful, fa/rmaka, Od. 4.227†.
mhti/omai (mh=tis), fut. mhti/somai, aor. subj. mhti/somai, opt. mhti=sai/mhn, inf. mhti=/sasqai: devise, perpetrate upon, tini/ ti, and tina/ ti, Od. 18.27.
mhtio/wsa, mhtio/wsi: see mhtia/w.

mh=tis, ios, dat. mh/ti=: counsel, wis-
dom, Il. 2.169, Od. 23.125; concretely, plan, device, mh=tin u(fai/nein, tektai/nesqai, *h 324, Od. 4.678.

mh/tis, mh/ti (mh/ tis, mh/ ti): no one, not anything, adv., mh/ti, not at all, by no means; for the difference between mh/tis and ou)/tis, see mh/. In Od. 9.410, ei) me\n dh\ mh/tis se bia/zetai, mh/tis shows that the other Cyclōpes understood Polyphēmus to say ou)/tis in v. 408 instead of *ou)=tis (he said ‘Noman,’ but they thought he said no man).
mhtro-pa/twr: mother's father, maternal grandfather, Il. 11.224†.
mhtruih/: step-mother. (Il.)
mhtrw/ios: of a mother, maternal, dw=ma, Od. 19.410†.
mh/trws, wos: maternal uncle. (Il.)
mhxana/w, mhxana/omai (mhxanh/), part. mhxano/wntas, ind. 3 pl. mhxano/wntai, opt. mhxano/w|to, ipf. mhxano/wnto: contrive, set at work, perpetrate, freq. in unfavorable sense.
mh=xos, eos: help, remedy.
*mh/|wn: see *mh/|ones.
mi/a: see ei(=s.
miai/nw, aor. subj. mih/nh|, pass. pres. inf. miai/nesqai, ipf. e)miai/neto, aor. 3 pl. e)mi/anqen: dye, stain, soil. (Il.)
miai-fo/nos: blood - stained, epith. of Ares. (Il.)
miaro/s: stained (with blood), Il. 24.420†.
miga/zomai = mi=/gnumai, part., Od. 8.271†.
mi/gda: promiscuously, together, Il. 8.437, Od. 24.77.

mi=/gnu=mi and mi/sgw, inf. misge/menai, aor. inf. mi=cai, mid. ipf. iter. misge/sketo, e)misge/skonto, fut. mi=/cesqai, misgh/sesqai, aor. 2 e)/mi=kto, mi=kto, pass. perf. part. memi=gme/nos, e)me/mi=kto, aor. 3 pl. e)/mi=xqen, aor. 2 e)mi/ghn, mi/gh, 3 pl. mi/gen: I. act., mix, mingle; oi)=non kai\ u(/dwr, Od. 1.110; pass., a(/lessi memi=gme/non ei)=dar, Od. 11.123; fa/rmaka, Od. 4.230; met., of bringing together, or one thing in contact with another, xei=ras te me/nos te (manus conserere), Il. 15.510 ; a)/ndras kako/thti kai\ a)/lgesi, Od. 20.203; glw=ss' e)me/mi=kto, Il. 4.438, cf. Od. 19.175.—II. mid., mingle, come in contact with something, Il. 2.475, Od. 5.517, Il. 10.457; freq. of intercourse, have relations with, friendly or hostile, Od. 24.314, Il. 5.143, and esp. of sexual union, in various phrases; h(\n e)mi/ghs, ‘that you had’ (cognate acc.), Il. 15.33.
*mi/deia: a town in Boeotia on Lake Copāis, Il. 2.507†.
mi=kto: see mi=/gnu=mi.
*mi/lhtos: Milētus.—(1) an Ionian city in Caria, Il. 2.868.—(2) in Crete, mother-city of the foregoing, Il. 2.647.
milto-pa/rh|os (mi/ltos, ‘vermilion’): red-cheeked, epith. of ships painted red, Il. 2.637, Od. 9.125.
*mi/ma=s: a promontory in Asia Minor, opposite Chios, Od. 3.172†.
mimna/zw (mi/mnw): remain, Il. 2.392 and Il. 10.549.

mimnh/skw and mna/omai, act. pres. imp. mi/mnhsk), fut. mnh/sw, aor. e)/mnhsas, subj. mnh/sh|, part. mnh/sa=sa, mid. mimnh/skomai, part. mnwome/nw, ipf. mnw/onto, fut. mnh/somai, aor. e)mnh/sato, mnh/santo, imp. mnh=sai, perf. me/mnhmai, me/mnhai and me/mnh|, subj. memnw/meqa, opt. memnh/|mhn, memne/w|to, fut. perf. memnh/somai, inf. -esqai, pass. aor. inf. mnhsqh=nai: act., remind, tina/ (tinos), Od. 12.38, Il. 1.407; mid., call to mind, remember, and in words, mention, tino/s, also tina/ or ti\, peri/ tinos, Od. 7.192; fu/gade, ‘think on flight,’ Il. 16.697; the perf. has pres. signif., ‘remember,’ implying solicitude, mindfulness, Od. 18.267.
mi/mnw: see me/nw.
mi/n: enclitic personal pronoun, acc. sing., him, her, it; it is sing., as always, in Od. 17.268, Od. 10.212, Il. 12.585 ; au)to/n min together form a reflexive, Od. 4.244, not elsewhere.
*minu/eios, *minuh/ios: Minyeian, belonging to the ancient stock of the Minyae in Orchomenus, Od. 11.284 and Il. 2.511.
*minuh/ios: a river in Elis, Il. 11.722.
minu/qw, ipf. iter. minu/qeskon: trans., lessen, diminish, Il. 15.492, Od. 14.17; intr., decrease, fall or waste away, Od. 4.467, Od. 12.46.
mi/nunqa: for a little, a little while.
minunqa/dios, comp. -diw/teros: lasting but a little while, brief, Il. 22.54, Il. 15.612.
minuri/zw, ipf. minu/rizon: whimper, whine, moan, Il. 5.889 and Od. 4.719.
*mi=/nws: Minos, son of Zeus and Eurōpa, father of Deucalion and Ariadne, ruler of Crete, and after his death a ruler in the nether world, Od. 11.322, 568 ff.
misg - a/gkeia (a)/gkos): meeting of mountain glens, basin, Il. 4.453†.
misgw: see mi=/gnu=mi.
mi=se/w, aor. mi/shse: hate, ‘the thought was abominable to him that, etc.,’ Il. 17.272†.
misqo/s: pay, wages, also pl.
mistu/llw: cut in bits or small pieces, preparatory to roasting the meat on spits, Il. 1.465.
mi/tos: thread of the warp, warp, Il. 23.762†. (See cuts Nos. 59, 123.)

mi/trh: a band or girdle round the waist and abdomen, below the stato\s qw/rhc, the exterior of metal plates, the interior lined with wool (see cut No. 33), shorter than the zw=ma, which covered it, while over both and the qw/rhc passed the zwsth/r. (See cut No. 3.)
mi=xqei/s: see mi=/gnu=mi.
mna/omai (1): see mimnh/skw.

mna/omai (2), 2 sing. mna=/a=|, mnw=ntai, inf. mna=/asqai, mna=sqai, part. mnw/menos, ipf. mnw/meqa, mnw/onto, iter. mna=/sketo: woo, court, win by wooing; gunai<*>=ka, a)/koitin, da/marta, Od. 24.125; abs., Od. 16.77, Od. 19.529.
mnh=ma, atos (mimnh/skw): memorial.
mnhmosu/nh (mnh/mwn): remembrance, w. gene/sqw, a periphr. for a pass. of me/mnhmai, Il. 8.181†.
mnh/mwn (mimnh/skw): mindful, remembering, ‘bent on,’ tino/s, Od. 8.163.
mnh=sai, mnhsa/sketo: see mimnh/skw.
*mnh=sos: a. Paeonian, slain by Achilles, Il. 21.210†.
mnhsteu/w (mnhsto/s), aor. part. mnhsteu/santes: woo, Od. 4.684 and Od. 18.277.
mnhsth/r, h=ros (mna/oma Od. 9.2): only pl., suitors, of whom Penelope had 108, and they had 10 servants, Od. 16.247.
mnh=stis (mimnh/skw): remembrance, Od. 13.280†.
mnhsto/s, only fem. mnhsth/: wooed and won, wedded, a)/loxos. Opp. pallaki/s, dourikth/th, etc., Il. 6.246, Od. 1.36.
mnhstu/s, uos: wooing, courting. (Od.)
mnwo/menos, mnw/menos, mnw/onto: see mimnh/skw.

moge/w (mo/gos), aor. (e))mo/ghsa: toil, labor, suffer, in the last sense often w. acc., a)/lgea, polla/, b 343, Il. 23.607; freq. the part. w. another verb, ‘hardly,’ Od. 11.636 ; e)c e)/rgwn moge/ontes, ‘weary after their work,’ Od. 24.388.
mo/gi=s: with toil, scarcely.
mo/gos: toil, Il. 4.27†.
mogos - to/kos (ti/ktw): travail - producing, epith. of the Eilithyiae. (Il.)
mo/qos: tumult of battle, of warchariots (i(/ppion). (Il.)

moi=ra (mei/romai): part, portion, share, in booty, of the feast, etc., Il. 10.252, Il. 15.195, Od. 4.97 ; ou)d' ai)dou=s moi=ran, ‘not a particle,’ Od. 13.171; significant of a proper share, hence e)n moi/rh, kata\ (para\) moi=ran, ‘properly,’ ‘duly,’ ‘rightly,’ etc.; then of one's lot, fortune, fate, doom; moi=ra bio/toio, qana/tou, *d 170, Od. 2.100; w. acc. and inf., ei) moi=ra (sc. e)sti/) damh=nai pa/ntas o(mw=s, Il. 17.421.—Personified, *moi=ra, Fate; pl., Il. 24.49, cf. Od. 7.197.
moirh-genh/s, voc. -e/s: child of destiny, Fortune's child, Il. 3.182†.
moix-a/gria (moixo/s, a)/grh): the fine imposed upon one taken in adultery, Od. 8.332†.
molei=n: see blw/skw.
mo/libos: lead, Il. 11.237†.
*moli=/wn: (1) son of Molione, the wife of Actor, dual *moli=/one, see *)aktori/wne.—(2) a Trojan, companion of Thymbraeus, slain by Odysseus, Il. 11.322.
molobro/s: glutton, gormandizer, Od. 17.219 and Od. 18.26.
*mo/los: father of Meriones, Il. 10.269, Il. 13.249.
molou=sa, molw/n: see blw/skw.
molph/ (me/lpw): play, entertainment with music and dancing, Od. 6.101, Il. 1.472; music, singing and dancing, Il. 18.572.
molu/bdaina: lead attached to a fishing-line, sinker, Il. 24.80†.
mono/w, mouno/w, aor. mou/nwse, pass. part. monwqei/s, mounwqe/nta: make lone or single, so propagate a race that there shall always be but one solitary heir, Od. 16.117; pass. part., left alone.
mo/rimos (mo/ros) = mo/rsimos, Il. 20.302†.
moro/eis, essa, en: doubtful word, mulberry-colored, dark-hued.

mo/ros (mei/romai, cf. mors): lot, fate, doom; u(pe\r mo/ron, *f 517, Od. 1.34; esp. in bad sense, kako/s, ai)no\s mo/ros,
Il. 18.465; hence death (abstract noun answering to the adj. broto/s).
mo/rsimos (mo/ros): fated, ordained by fate, w. inf., Il. 19.417, Il. 5.674; of persons, destined to death, doomed, Il. 22.13; to marriage, Od. 16.392 ; mo/rsimon h)=mar, ‘day of death,’ Il. 15.613.
*mo/rus: a Mysian, the son of Hippotion, slain by Meriones, Il. 13.792, Il. 14.514.
moru/ssw: only pass. perf. part., memorugme/na (-xme/na), stained, Od. 13.435†.
morfh/: form, fig., grace; e)pe/wn, l 367, Od. 8.170. (Od.)
mo/rfnos: a species of eagle, swampeagle, Il. 24.316†.
mo/sxos: as adj. w. lu/goisi, young, tender, pliant, Il. 11.105†.

*mou/lios: (1) an Epeian, slain by Nestor, Il. 11.739.—(2) a Trojan, slain by Patroclus, Il. 16.696.—(3) a Trojan, slain by Achilles, Il. 20.472.—(4) a native of Dulichium, herald of Amphinomus, Od. 18.423.
mou/nac: singly. (Od.)
mou=nos (Att. mo/nos): alone, ‘single,’ ‘desolate,’ ‘forsaken,’ Od. 2.365, Od. 10.157.

*mou=sa, pl. *mou=sai: Muse, the Muses, nine in number, daughters of Zeus and Mnemosyne, Od. 8.488, Il. 2.598, Od. 24.60; they sing for the gods, and inspire the bard, Il. 1.604, Il. 1.1, Od. 1.1, Il. 2.484.
moxqe/w (mo/xqos), fut. inf. moxqh/sein: toil, suffer, ‘be worn with suffering,’ Il. 10.106†.
moxqi/zw = moxqe/w, Il. 2.723†.
moxle/w: pry or heave up (with levers. moxloi/), Il. 12.259†.
moxlo/s: lever, crow, hand-spike (not roller), Od. 5.261; in i, of a stake.
*mu/gdwn: a king of Phrygia, Il. 3.186†.
mu=dale/os: wet, dripping (with blood), Il. 11.54†.
*mu/dwn: (1) son of Atymnius, charioteer of Pylaemenes, slain by Antilochus, Il. 5.580.—(2) a Paeonian, slain by Achilles, Il. 21.209.
mu=elo/eis, essa, en (mu=elo/s): full of marrow, marrowy, Od. 9.293†.
mu=elo/s: marrow; fig., of nourishing food, mu=elo\s a)ndrw=n, Od. 2.290.

mu=qe/omai (mu=qos), 2 sing. mu=qe/ai and mu=qei=ai, ipf. iter. mu=qe/skonto, fut. mu=qh/somai, aor. mu=qhsa/mhn: speak or talk of, describe, explain, relate, strictly with reference to the subject-matter of discourse (see mu=qos), e(/kasta, pa/nta kata\ qu=mo/n, nhmerte/a, mh=nin *)apo/llwnos, Od. 13.191, Il. 9.645, *z 382, Il. 1.74; w. pred. adj., po/lin polu/xru=son, ‘spoke of it as rich in gold,’ Il. 18.289.
mu=qo-logeu/w: relate. (Od.)

mu=qos: speech with reference to the subject - matter, like the later lo/gos, hence to be paraphrased in Eng. by various more specific words, ‘conversation,’ ‘recital,’ ‘subject,’ ‘request,’ ‘counsel,’ ‘command,’ etc., Od. 4.214, 597, o 196, Il. 1.545.
mui=a: fly, house-fly or horse-fly; as symbol of audacity, Il. 17.570. (Il.)
*muka/lh: Mycale, a promontory in Asia Minor, opposite Samos, Il. 2.869†.
*mukalhsso/s: a town in Boeotia, Il. 2.498†.

mu=ka/omai, part. mu=kw/menai, aor. 2 mu/kon, mu/ke, perf. part. memu=kw/s, plup. e)memu=/kei: low, bellow, of cattle; of the river - god Scamander, memu=kw\s h)u/te tau=ros, Il. 21.237; then of things, as of gates ‘groaning,’ a shield ‘resounding,’ Il. 12.460, Il. 20.260.
mu=khqmo/s: lowing, bellowing, Il. 18.575 and Od. 12.265.
*mukh/nh: Mycēne, daughter of Inachus, Od. 2.120; eponymous heroine of the city *mukh/nh or *mukh=nai, Mycēnae, the residence of Agamemnon.— *mukh/nhqen, from Mycēnae.—*mukhnai=os, of Mycēnae.
mu/kon: see mu=ka/omai.
mu/lac, akos: mill-stone, then of any large round stone, pl., Il. 12.161†.
mu/lh: mill, hand-mill. (Od.) (Probably similar to the Roman hand mills found in Switzerland, and represented in the cut.)
mulh/-fatos (fe/nw): crushed in a mill, ground, Od. 2.355†.
mulo-eidh/s, e/s (ei)=dos): like a millstone, Il. 7.270†.
mu=/nh: excuse, pl., Od. 21.111†.
*mu/nhs: son of Evēnus, slain by Achilles, Il. 2.692 and Il. 19.296.
muri=kh: tamarisk. (Il.)
muri=/kinos: of tamarisk, o)/zos, ‘tamarisk-shoot,’ Il. 6.39†.
*muri=/nh: an Amazon, whose funeralmound was called ‘Thorn - hill,’ *bati/eia, Il. 2.814†.
mu=ri/os: countless, ‘myriad,’ often in pl., ma/la mu=ri/oi, ‘infinite in number,’ Od. 15.556, etc.; mu=ri/on, w. gen., ‘a vast quantity,’ Il. 21.320.
*murmido/nes: the Myrmidons, a Thracian tribe in Phthiōtis, the followers of Achilles; their chief centres were Phthia and Hellas, Il. 16.269, Il. 2.684, Il. 1.180, Od. 11.495.
mu=/romai, ipf. mu=/ronq): flow, dissolve in tears, weep, lament.
*mu/rsinos: a village in Elis, later to\ *murtou/ntion, Il. 2.616†.

*mu=soi/: (1) a tribe on the Danube, Il. 13.5.—(2) kindred with the foregoing, the Mysians of Asia Minor, occupying territory from the river Aesēpus to Mt. Olympus, Il. 2.858, Il. 10.430, Il. 14.512, Il. 24.278.
muxmo/s (mu/zw): moaning, Od. 24.416†.
muxoi/tatos, sup. formed from the locative of muxo/s: inmost (in the men's hall), farthest away (from the rest and from the entrance), Od. 21.146†.
muxo/nde: to the inmost part, Od. 22.270†.
muxo/s: inmost or farthest part, corner, of house, hall, harbor, cave, etc. Freq. muxw=| w. gen., ‘in the farthest corner,’ Il. 6.152, Od. 3.263.
mu/w, aor. 3 pl. mu/san, perf. me/mu=ken: close, said of the eyes, wounds, Il. 24.637, 420. (Il.)
mu=w/n, w=nos: mass of muscle, muscles, Il. 16.315, 324. (Il.)
mw=los: toil and moil of battle, freq. w. *)/arhos, *h 147, Il. 17.397.
mw=lu: moly, an herb given by Hermes to Odysseus to afford protection against the spells of Circe, Od. 10.305†, described v. 304.
mwma/omai, fut. mwmh/sontai: censure, reproach, Il. 3.412†.
mwmeu/w = mwma/omai, Od. 6.274†.
mw=mos: blame, censure; mw=mon a)na/yai, ‘set a brand of shame upon us,’ Od. 2.86†.
mw=nuc, uxos: according to the ancients, single-hoofed, solid-hoofed (mo/nos, o)/nuc), epith. of horses (as opp. to the cloven-footed cattle). (Il. and Od. 15.46.)

div1.head: *n
div1.entryFree: n: nu= e)felkustiko/n, or nu euphonic, affixed to the pl. case - ending -si, to ei)/kosi, -fi, no/sfi, ke/, and to forms of the verb ending in -e and -i of the 3d person.
nai/ (cf. nae): yea, verily, always affirmative; w. ma/, Il. 1.234.

naieta/w (nai/w), part. naieta/wn, -a/wsa, ipf. iter. naieta/askon: dwell, inhabit, Il. 3.387; and of localities, be situated, be inhabited, often w. eu)=, so of houses, etc., ‘comfortable,’ Il. 2.648, Od. 2.400; significant of the very existence of a place, Od. 1.404; trans., Il. 2.539, Il. 17.172, Od. 9.21.

nai/w, inf. naie/men, ipf. iter. nai/eskon, aor. na/ssa, pass. aor. na/sqh, mid. pres. part. (eu)=) naio/menos: dwell, inhabit, be situated, Il. 2.626; the aor. is causative, kai/ ke/ oi( *)/argei+ na/ssa po/lin, ‘would have assigned him a town to dwell in,’ Od. 4.174; pass., na/sqh, settled in, Il. 14.119.
na/ph: forest glen, woody dell, Il. 8.558 and Il. 16.300.
narka/w: only aor., na/rkhse, was palsied, Il. 8.328†.
na/sqh, na/ssa: see nai/w.
na/ssw: only aor. e)/nace, stamped down; gai=an, Od. 21.122†.
*na/sths: son of Nomion, leader of the Carians, slain by Achilles, Il. 2.867 ff.
*nauboli/dhs: son of Naubolus.— (1) Iphitus, Il. 2.518.—(2) a Phaeacian, Od. 8.116.
nau/-loxos (root lex): for ships to lie in, ‘safe for ships,’ of harbors, Od. 4.846 and Od. 10.141.
nau=s: see nhu=s.
*nausi/qoos: a son of Poseidon, the father of Alcinous, colonizes the Phaeacians in Scheria, Od. 7.56 ff.
*nausika/a=: Nausicaa, the Phaeacian princess, daughter of Alcinous and Arēte, Od. 6.17 ff., Od. 7.12, Od. 8.457, 464.
nausi-kleito/s: renowned for ships, Od. 6.22†.
nausi - kluto/s = nausikleito/s, pl., epith. of the Phaeacians and the Phoenicians, Od. 15.415.
*nauteu/s: a Phaeacian, Od. 8.112†.
nau/ths: seaman, sailor, only pl.
nautili/h: seamanship, Od. 8.253†.
nauti/llomai: sail, Od. 4.672 and Od. 14.246.
nau=fi(n): see nhu=s.
na/w, nai/w (sna/vw), ipf. nai=on (v. l. na=on): flow; o)rw=|, ‘ran over’ with whey, Od. 9.222.
*ne/aira: a nymph, the mother of Lampetie and Phaethūsa by Helius, Od. 12.133†.
nearo/s (ne/os): youthful, Il. 2.289†.
ne/atos, nei/atos (ne/os): newest, but always of position, extremest, last, lowest, Il. 6.295, Od. 15.108; apparently, ‘topmost,’ Il. 14.466.
nebro/s: fawn; as symbol of timorousness, Il. 4.243.
ne/es, ne/essi: see nhu=s.
ne/hai: see ne/omai.
neh-genh/s, e/s: new-born, Od. 4.336 and Od. 17.127.
ne-hkh/s, e/s (a)kh/): freshly whetted, Il. 13.391 and Il. 16.484.
ne/ - hlus (h)/luqon): newly come, Il. 10.434 and 558.
nehni/hs (Att. nea=ni/a=s): young (man), youth, always w. a)nh/r. (Od.)
neh=nis, idos: maiden.
nei=ai: see ne/omai.
nei/atos: see ne/atos.

neike/w, neikei/w (nei=kos), neikw=si, subj. neikei/h|(si), inf. neikei/ein, part. neikei/wn, ipf. nei/keion, iter. neikei/eske, fut. neike/sw, aor. (e))nei/ke(s)sa: strive, quarrel; e)/ridas kai\ nei/kea a)llh/lois, ‘contend in railing and strife,’ Il. 20.252; upbraid, reprove, opp. ai)nei=n, Il. 10.249, Il. 24.29; ma/la, ‘angrily’; a)/nthn, ‘outright,’ Od. 17.239.

nei=kos, eos: contention, strife, quarrel, esp. in words; dispute, dissension, often pl.; at law, Il. 18.497, Od. 12.440; also of war and battle, pole/moio, fu=lo/pidos, e)/ridos, Il. 13.271, *r 384, Il. 20.140; reproof, taunt, Il. 9.448, Il. 7.95.
nei=ma: see ne/mw.
neio/qen (ne/os): from below; e)k kradi/hs, ‘from the depths of his heart,’ Il. 10.10†.
neio/qi (ne/os): below; li/mnhs, ‘down in the depths of the sea,’ Il. 21.317†.
neio/s (ne/os): sc. gh=, new land, fallow land, newly ploughed after having lain fallow; thrice ploughed, after such rest, in Il. 18.541, Od. 5.137.
nei=tai: see ne/omai.
nei/fw: see ni=/fw.
neka/s, a/dos (ne/ku=s): heap of slain, Il. 5.886†.
nekro/s: dead body, corpse; with teqnhw=ta, Od. 12.10; also nekrw=n katateqnhw/twn, see kataqnh/skw. Said of the inhabitants of the nether world, the dead, Il. 23.51, Od. 11.34.

ne/ktar, aros: nectar, the drink of the gods, as ambrosia is their food, Il. 1.598, Il. 4.3, applied as a preservative against decay, Il. 19.38. Why the lexicons say that ne/ktar means wine when the Cyclops speak of a ‘sample of nectar and ambrosia,’ we do not know, Od. 9.359.
nekta/reos: nectar-like, fragrant as nectar. (Il.)
ne/ku=s, uos = nekro/s.
neme/qomai = ne/momai, feed, Il. 11.635†.

nemesa/w, nemessa/w (ne/mesis), fut. nemesh/sw, aor. neme/shsa, mid. fut. nemesh/somai, pass. aor. 3 pl. neme/sshqen: be indignant or justly angry with one (at anything), tini/ (ti), take it ill, Od. 6.286, Il. 23.494; also w. part., or ou(/neka, f 169, Od. 23.213; mid., like active, also shrink from, be ashamed, w. inf., Od. 4.158.

nemeshto/s, nemesshto/s: causing indignation, reprehensible, wrong, usually
neut. as pred., Il. 3.310; w. neg., ‘no wonder,’ Il. 9.523, Od. 22.59, to be dreaded, Il. 11.649.
nemesi/zomai (ne/mesis), ipf. nemesi/zeto: be angry with one (for something), tini/ (ti), Il. 5.757; be ashamed, foll. by acc. and inf., Il. 17.254; dread, fear, qeou/s, Od. 1.263.

ne/mesis, dat. neme/ssi= (-ei), (ne/mw, ‘dispensation’): just indignation, anger, censure; ou) ne/mesis, ‘no wonder,’ Il. 3.156 ; e)n fresi\ qe/sqe ai)dw= kai\ ne/mesin, self-respect and a ‘regard for men's indignant blame,’ Il. 13.122, Il. 6.351.
nemessa/w, nemesshto/s: see nemesa/w, nemeshto/s.
neme/ssei, neme/ssi=: see ne/mesis.
ne/mos, eos (ne/mesqai, cf. nemus): wood-pasture, glade, Il. 11.480†.

ne/mw, aor. e)/neima, nei=men, imp. nei=mon: I. act., dispense, divide, assign, moi/ra=s, kre/a, etc.; tini/ ti, *g 274, Od. 6.188; then pasture or tend flocks, Od. 9.233; pass., be consumed (cf. the mid.), puri/, Il. 2.780.—II. mid., have to oneself, possess, enjoy, patrw/ia, te/menos, u 336, Il. 12.313; inhabit, Od. 2.167; then feed (upon), esp. of flocks and herds, graze, Il. 5.777, Od. 13.407, Od. 9.449.
ne/niptai: see ni/zw.
neo-ardh/s, e/s (a)/rdw): freshly watered, Il. 21.346†.
neo/ - dartos (de/rw): newly - flayed. (Od.)
neo-qhlh/s, e/s (qa/llw): fresh-sprouting, Il. 14.347†.
neoi/h: youthfulness, youthful thoughtlessness, Il. 23.604†.

ne/omai, neu=mai, nei=ai, nei=tai, subj. 2 sing. ne/hai, inf. nei=sqai, ipf. neo/mhn, ne/onto<*> pres., usually w. fut. signif., go or come somewhere (as specified), esp. return, abs., Od. 2.238, Od. 11.114, Od. 12.188.
ne/on: see ne/os.
neo-penqh/s, e/s: new to sorrow, Od. 11.39†.
neo/-plutos (plu=/nw): newly washed, Od. 6.64†
neo/-pristos (pri/w): fresh - sawn, Od. 8.404†
*neopto/lemos: Neoptolemus, the son of Achilles, reared in Scyros, conducts the Myrmidons home from Troy, and weds Hermione, the daughter of Menelāus, Il. 19.327, Od. 3.189, Od. 4.5, Od. 11.520.
ne/os, comp. new/teros: new, fresh, young; opp. palaio/s, d 720, Od. 8.58; as subst., Od. 19.433, Il. 9.36, Od. 8.202; adv., ne/on, just now, lately, Od. 16.181, 199.
neo/s: see nhu=s.
neo/ - smhktos (sma/w): freshly polished, Il. 13.342†.
neosso/s (ne/os): young (bird), fledgling. (Il.)
neo/-teuktos (teu/xw): newly wrought, Il. 21.592†.
neo-teuxh/s, e/s (teu/xw): newly made, Il. 5.194†.
neo/ths, htos (ne/os): youth. (Il.)
ne-ou/tatos (ou)ta/w): lately wounded. (Il.)
ne/-podes (ne/w): ‘swim-footed,’ webfooted, Od. 4.404†. According to a modern interpretation (and an Alexandrian usage) the word=nepotes, ‘offspring.’
ne/rqe(n) (e)/nerqen, e)/neros): below, under, w. gen., Od. 11.302.
*nesto/reos: of Nestor.
*nestori/dai, the sons of Nestor, Antilochus and Thrasymēdes, Il. 16.317.
*nestori/dhs: son of Nestor.—(1) Antilochus, Il. 6.33, Il. 15.589, Il. 23.353.—(2) Pisistratus, Od. 3.482, Od. 4.71, 155, etc.

*ne/stwr: Nestor, the aged king of Pylos, son of Neleus and Chloris, was ruling over the 3d generation of men when he joined the expedition against Troy, Il. 1.247 ff. His youthful exploits, Il. 4.319, Il. 11.669 ff., Il. 1.262 ff., Il. 23.630 ff. In the Odyssey he is at home again in Pylos, Od. 3.17, cf. 412 ff.
neu=mai: see ne/omai.
neurh/: sinew, only as bow-string.
neu=ron: sinew, tendon; as bowstring, Il. 4.122; also for a cord to bind the arrow-head to the shaft, Il. 4.151.
neusta/zw (neu/w): keep nodding, nod kefalh=|, bending down the head, Od. 18.154 ; o)/frusi, of giving a sign, Od. 12.194.

neu/w (cf. nuo), fut. neu/sw, aor. neusa: nod, often of giving assent or a promise, Il. 8.246; freq. said of the helmet and its plume, Il. 3.337, Od. 22.124 ; kefala=/s, ‘let their heads hang down,’ Od. 18.237.
nefe/lh: cloud; fig., of death, grief, Il. 20.417, Il. 17.591, Od. 24.315.
nefel - hgere/ta (a)gei/rw), nom. for -ths: cloud - gathering, the cloud-compeller, Zeus.
ne/fos, eos: cloud, often in pl., Il. 15.688; fig., ne/fos qana/toio, *p 350, Od. 4.180; also of dense numbers, *trw/wn, pole/moio, *p 66, Il. 17.243.
ne/w (1) (sne/vw), ipf. e)/nneon: swim.
ne/w (2) (cf. neo), mid. aor. nh/santo: spin, Od. 7.198†.
nh-: inseparable neg. prefix.
nh=a, nha/de: see nhu=s.
nhga/teos: doubtful word, new-made, Il. 2.43 and Il. 14.185.
nh/gretos (nh-, e)gei/rw): sound, deep sleep; neut., as adv., eu(/dein, without waking. (Od.)
nh/duia (nhdu/s), pl.: bowels, Il. 17.524†.
nh/dumos: doubtful word, epith. of sleep. sweet, balmy.
nhdu/s, u/os: belly, stomach; ‘womb,’ Il. 24.496.
nh=es, nh/essi: see nhu=s.
nhe/w (Att. ne/w), ipf. nh/eon, nh/ei, aor. nh/hsa, mid. aor. inf. nhh/sasqai, imp. -a/sqw: heap or pile up; also load, fill with cargo; nh=as, Il. 9.359; mid., one's own ship, Il. 9.137, 279.
*nhia/s, a/dos: Naiad, water-nymph, pl. (Od.)
*nh/ion: Mt. Neium, in Ithaca, Od. 1.186†.
nh/ios (nhu=s): for ships; do/ru nh/ion, ship-timber, also without do/ru, *n 391, Il. 16.484.
*nhi/s, i/dos=*nhia/s. (Il.)
nh=is, idos (nh-, root vid): unknowing, unpractised in; tino/s, Od. 8.79; abs., inexperienced, Il. 7.198.
nh - kerdh/s, e/s (ke/rdos): profitless, useless.
nhkouste/w (a)kou/w), aor. nhkou/sthsa: fail to hearken, disobey, w. gen., Il. 20.14†.

nhleh/s, nhlh/s (nh-, e)/leos): pitiless, ruthless, relentless; of persons, and often fig., qu=mo/s, h)=tor, desmo/s, nhlee\s h)=mar, ‘day of death’; u(/pnos, of a sleep productive of disastrous consequences, Od. 12.372.
*nhlei/dhs =*nhlhia/dhs, Il. 23.652.
nh/leitis, idos (nh-, a)litai/nw): guiltless, innocent. V. l. nhli=tei=s. (Od.)

*nhleu/s: Neleus, son of Poseidon and Tyro, husband of Chloris, and father of Pero and Nestor, Od. 11.254, 281, Od. 15.233; driven from Iolcus in Thessaly by his brother Pelias, he wanders to Messenia and founds Pylos, Od. 3.4; all of his sons except Nestor were slain in a war with Heracles, Il. 11.692.
*nhlhia/dhs: son of Neleus, Nestor.
*nhlh/ios: of Neleus, Neleian.
nhlh/s: see nhleh/s.
nhli=th/s, nhlitei=s: see nh/leitis.
nh=ma, atos (ne/ Od. 24.2): that which is spun, yarn. (Od.)
nhmerth/s, e/s (a(marta/nw): unerring, infallible; freq., nhmerte/s, nhmerte/a ei)pei=n, truthfully, truly, Od. 3.19, Od. 4.314.— Adv., nhmerte/ws, e 98, Od. 19.296.
*nhmerth/s: a Nereid, Il. 18.46†.
nhnemi/h (nh/nemos): windless calm, Il. 5.523; as adj. (or appositive), w. galh/nh, e 392, Od. 12.169.
nh/nemos (nh-, a)/nemos): windless, breathless; ai)qh/r, Il. 8.556†.
nho/s (nai/w): dwelling of a god, temple, fane. (For an idea of the interior of the cella of a temple, cf. cut under bwmo/s, with statue of Aphrodite and altar.)
nho/s: see nhu=s.
nh-penqh/s, e/s (pe/nqos): ‘without sorrow,’ soothing sorrow; fa/rmakon, an Egyptian magic drug,’ Od. 4.221†.
nhpia/a=s: see nhpie/h.
nhpiaxeu/w: play like a child, part., Il. 22.502†.
nhpi/axos =nh/pios. (Il.)
nhpie/h (nh/pios), acc. pl. nhpia/a=s: infancy, childhood, helplessness of childhood, Il. 9.491; pl., childish thoughts.
