nh/pios: epith. of little children or young animals, ‘infant,’ ‘helpless,’ nh/pia te/kna, Il. 9.440, *b 311, Il. 11.113; often fig., indicating the blind unconsciousness on the part of men that suggests an analogy between the relation of men to higher powers and that of infants to adults, ‘helpless,’ ‘unwitting,’ and sometimes disparagingly, ‘simple,’ ‘childish,’ Il. 11.561, Il. 22.445.
nh/-poinos (poinh/): without compensation, unavenged; adv., nh/poinon, with impunity, Od. 1.160.
nhpu/tios = nh/pios. (Il.)
*nhrhi/s, i/dos: Nereid, i. e. daughter of Nereus, who is himself not named by Homer, but is only called a(/lios ge/rwn, Il. 11.538; pl., Il. 18.38, 49, 52.

*nh/rikos: originally a promontory
on the coast of Acarnania, later converted into the island of Leucas; subjugated by Laertes, Od. 24.377†.
*nh/riton: Mt. Neritum, in Ithaca, Od. 13.351, Il. 2.632, Od. 9.22.
*nh/ritos: an Ithacan, Od. 17.207†.
nh/ritos: see ei)kosinh/ritos.
*nhsai/h: a Nereid, Il. 18.40†.
nh=sos (ne/ Od. 24.1): island.
nh=stis, ios (nh-, e)/dw): not eating, without food, fasting.
nhto/s (ne/w, nhe/w): piled up, Od. 2.338†.

nhu=s (ne/ Od. 24.1), gen. nho/s and neo/s, dat. nhi/, acc. nh=a and ne/a, pl. nh=es, ne/es, gen. nhw=n, new=n, nau=fin, dat. nhusi/, nh/essi, ne/essin, nau=fin, acc. nh=as, ne/as: ship, vessel. The parts of a ship, as named in Homer (see cut under e)/dafos), are as follows: of the hull, tro/pis, prw/|rh, pru/mnh, e)phgkeni/des, phda/lion, oi)h/ia, i(sto/s, i(stope/dh, i(stodo/kh, zuga/, klhi=des, tropo/s. Of the rigging, i(sti/a, pei/smata, po/des, e)pi/tonos, pro/tonos. Oar, e)retmo/s, kw/ph. Homer mentions ships of burden, forti/des, Od. 9.323; otherwise ships of war are meant. Pl., nh=es, the ships, often in the Iliad of the camp of the Greeks, which included nh=es and klisi/ai, Il. 2.688. (See plate IV., at end of volume.)—nh=a/de, to the ship, Od. 13.19.
nh/xw (snh/xw) and nh/xomai, inf. nhxe/menai, part. nhxo/menos, ipf. nh=xon, fut. nh/comai: swim. (Od.)

ni/zw, imp. ni/z(e), ipf. ni/zon, fut. ni/yw, aor. ni/ya, mid. ipf. ni/zeto, aor. niya/mhn, pass. perf. ne/niptai: wash, wash off, mid., oneself or a part of oneself; w. two accusatives, ni/yai tina\ po/das, Od. 19.376; mid., xro/a a(/lmhn, ‘the brine from his person,’ Od. 6.224 ; a(lo/s, ‘with water from the sea,’ Od. 2.261; pass., Il. 24.419.

ni=ka/w, ipf. (e))ni=/kwn, iter. ni=ka/skomen, fut. ni=kh/sw, aor. (e))ni=/khsa, pass. aor. part. ni=khqei/s: be victorious or victor, and trans., conquer, vanquish, in games, battle, or legal dispute (w. cognate acc., Od. 11.545), of ‘surpassing’ or ‘excelling’ in anything (tini/), and of things, ‘prevail,’ Il. 1.576, Od. 10.46.
ni=/kh: victory, in battle or before the tribunal, Od. 11.544.

*nio/bh: Niobe, daughter of Tantalus and wife of Amphīon, king of Thebes. Her six sons were slain by the arrows of Apollo, and her six daughters by the arrows of Artemis, because she had presumed to compare her children with those of Leto. Niobe in grief was changed into stone, a legend that connects itself with a natural conformation in the rock of Mt. Sipylus, which resembles a woman in a sitting posture, Il. 24.602, 606.
ni/ptw: see ni/zw.
*ni=reu/s: Nireus, son of Charopus and Aglaïa, of Syme, the handsomest of the Greeks before Troy, next to Achilles, Il. 2.671 ff.
*ni=sa: a village on Mt. Helicon in Boeotia, Il. 2.508†.
*ni=sos: son of Arētus, father of Amphinomus of Dulichium, Od. 16.395, Od. 18.127, 413.
ni/ssomai, fut. ni=/somai, ipf. ni/ssonto = ne/omai.
*ni=/su=ros: a small island, one of the Sporades, Il. 2.676†.
nifa/s, a/dos (sn.): snow-flake, snow, mostly pl.; w. xio/nos, Il. 12.278. (Il.)
nifeto/s (sn.): snow-storm, snows, Il. 10.7 and Od. 4.566.
nifo/eis, essa, en (sn.): snowy, snowclad, epith. of mountains.
ni=/fw (sn.), inf. ni=fe/men: snow, Il. 12.280†. (V. l. neife/men.)
ni/ya, niya/menos: see ni/zw.

noe/w (no/os), imp. no/ei, fut. noh/sw, aor. (e))no/hsa, mid. noh/sato: think, be thoughtful or sensible, have in mind, intend, be (aor. become) aware, perceive; ou(/tw nu=n kai\ e)gw\ noe/w, ‘I think so too,’ Od. 4.148 ; tou=to/ g' e)nai/simon ou)k e)no/hsen, ‘that was not a right thought of hers,’ Od. 7.299 ; noh=sai a(/ma pro/ssw kai\ o)pi/ssw, ‘to direct his mind forward and backward,’ ‘take thought at once of the present and the future,’ Il. 1.343 ; mhtri\ e)gw\ para/fhmi, kai\ au)th=| per noeou/sh|, ‘though she has a good mind of her own,’ Il. 1.577 ; kai\ ma=llon noe/w fresi\ ti=mh/sasqai, ‘I mean to prize thee still more,’ Il. 22.235; freq. o)cu\ noh=sai, of ‘keenly noting’ an occurrence, often w. part., Il. 2.391, Il. 3.21, 30; common transitional phrase, a)/ll(o) e)no/hsen, ‘had another idea,’ ‘thought again,’ ‘passed to a new plan.’ Mid., ‘thought to,’ w. inf., only Il. 10.501. Cf. no/os.

no/hma, atos (noe/w): thought, idea,
plan, mind (more concrete than no/os), Od. 20.82; as symbol of swiftness, ne/es w)kei)ai w(s ei) ptero\n h)e\ no/hma, Od. 7.36.
noh/mwn, onos: thoughtful, discreet. (Od.)
*noh/mwn: (1) a Lycian, slain by Odysseus, Il. 5.678.—(2) son of Phronius in Ithaca, Od. 4.630, Od. 2.386.—(3) a Pylian, Il. 23.612.
nomeu/s, h=os (ne/mw): shepherd; w. a)/ndres, Il. 17.65.
nomeu/w, ipf. e)no/meue: pasture, mh=la. (Od.)
*nomi=/wn: father of Nastes and Amphimacus of Caria, Il. 2.871†.
nomo/s (ne/mw): pasture; fig., e)pe/wn, ‘range,’ Il. 20.249.

no/os: mind, understanding, thought; ou) ga/r tis no/on a)/llon a)mei/nona tou=de noh/sei, | oi(=on e)gw\ noe/w, a better ‘view’ than mine,’ Il. 9.104. The word is somewhat flexible in its application, but needs no special illustration. Cf. noe/w.
no/sos: see nou=sos.

noste/w (no/stos), fut. nosth/sw, aor. no/sthsa: return, often with the implication of a happy escape, Il. 10.247, Il. 17.239, kei=se/ me nosth/santa, ‘when I came there on my way home,’ Od. 4.619, Od. 15.119.

no/stos (ne/omai): return, return home; no/stou gai/hs *faih/kwn, a reaching the land of the Phaeacians (gai/hs, obj. gen.), without the notion of ‘returning,’ except in so far as a man who had been swimming as long as Odysseus had to swim would feel as if he had got back somewhere when he touched dry land, Od. 5.344.
nosfi/zomai, aor. nosfisa/mhn, pass. aor. part. nosfisqei/s: depart from (tino/s), hold aloof from, ‘disregard,’ Il. 2.81, Il. 24.222; w. acc., abandon. (Od.)
noti/h: moisture, pl., rain, showers, Il. 8.307†.
no/tios: moist, wet: neut. as subst., water of a harbor, Od. 4.785.
*no/tos: south (west) wind, bringing rain, Il. 2.145, Od. 3.295 ; a)rgesth/s, Il. 11.306, Il. 21.334; pro\s *no/tou, from the South, Od. 13.111.
nou=s: see no/os.
nou=sos: sickness, illness, disease.

nu/(n): now, enclitic particle, perhaps sometimes temporal, but as a rule differing from the temporal nu=n as the logical and temporal uses of ‘now’ differ in Eng. The context in each case must decide whether the word admits of paraphrasing or not. Often ti/ nu; and ou)/ nu.
nukteri/s, i/dos (nu/c): bat, Od. 12.433 and Od. 24.6.
nu/mfh, voc. nu/mfa (cf. nubo): bride, lady; after as well as at the time of marriage, Il. 9.560, Od. 11.447, Il. 3.130, Od. 4.743.

*nu/mfh: nymph, goddess of secondary rank, as the Naiads, mountain nymphs, etc., Il. 6.420, Od. 6.123; offerings were made to them, Od. 17.211, Od. 12.318; Calypso and Circe are termed nymphs, Od. 5.153, Od. 10.543.
nu/mfios (nu/mfh): newly-married, Od. 7.65 and Il. 23.223.

nu=n: now, freq. nu=n dh/, nu=n au)=, and esp. nu=n de/, ‘as it is,’ ‘as it was,’ contrasting the real state of the case with a supposed one, Il. 1.417. In the uses that are not strictly temporal nu=n differs from nu/n only in form (quantity), not in meaning, Il. 10.175.
nu/c, nukto/s, acc. nu/kta, nu/xq): night, fig., of death, Il. 5.310.—Personified, *nu/c, Night, Il. 14.259.
nuc/s: daughter-in-law or sister-inlaw, Il. 3.49.
*nu=sh/ion: Nysaeum, the region about Nysa, where the god Dion&ymacr;sus was reared, Il. 6.133†.
nu/ssa: turning-post (meta), in the hippodrome, Il. 23.332; elsewhere, starting-point or line.
nu/ssw, part. nu/sswn, -ontes, pass. pres. part. nussome/nwn: prick, pierce (Il. and Od. 14.485.)
nw=: see nw=i.
nwqh/s, e/s: lazy, sluggish, Il. 11.559†.
nw=i (cf. nos), nom. dual, gen. and dat. nw=in, acc. nw=i and nw=: we two, both of us.
nwi/teros: of us two, of us both, Il. 15.39 and Od. 12.185.
nwleme/s: continually, unceasingly, Il. 14.58; usually with ai)ei/.
nwleme/ws: unceasingly, firmly, Il. 4.428.

nwma/w (ne/mw), aor. nw/mhsa: deal out, distribute, Il. 1.471, Od. 3.340; handle, wield, control; e)/gxos, skh=ptron, po/da nho/s, Il. 5.594, *g 218, Od. 10.32; ply the limbs, po/das kai\ gou/nata, Il. 10.358; met., ‘revolve’ (versare), no/on, ke/rdea, n 255, Od. 18.216.
nw/numos and nw/numnos (nh-, o)/noma): nameless, inglorious.
nw=roy, opos: epithet of xalko/s, shining, glittering. (Il. and Od. 24.467, 500.)
nw=ton: back, of meat, back - piece, chine, Il. 9.207, pl., Il. 7.321; fig., eu)re/a nw=ta qala/sshs.
nwxeli/h: sloth, sluggishness, Il. 19.411†.

div1.head: *c
div1.entryFree: cai/nw (cf. ce/w): comb or card wool, Od. 22.423†.
canqo/s: reddish - yellow, blond or auburn (flavus); of horses, sorrel or cream-colored, Il. 11.680.

*ca/nqos: Xanthus.—(1) son of Phaenops, a Trojan, slain by Diomed, Il. 5.152.—(2) name of one of the horses of Achilles (see canqo/s), Il. 16.149.—(3) name of one of Hector's horses, Il. 8.185. —(4) another name of the river Scamander, and, personified, the rivergod, Il. 20.40, 74, Il. 21.146.—(5) a river in Lycia, flowing from Mt. Taurus into the Mediterranean, Il. 2.877.

ceinh/ion: token of guest-friendship, or hospitality, a present given in honor of this relation, Il. 10.269, Il. 6.218, or entertainment, Il. 18.408; ironically, Od. 9.370; as adj., w. dw=ra, Od. 24.273.

cei/nios and ce/nios: pertaining to hospitality or guest - friendship, *zeu/s, protector of guests (strangers), Il. 13.625, Od. 9.271 ; tra/peza, hospitable board, Od. 14.158; neut. as subst. = zeinh/ion, pl., sc. dw=ra.
ceino - do/kos (de/xomai): guest-receiving, hospitable; as subst., host, Od. 18.64.

cei=nos: strange, foreign, Il. 24.302, Od. 7.32 ; cei=ne pa/ter, ‘sir stranger’; stranger, guest, guest - friend; the relation of guest - friend existed from the time when zeinh/ia were exchanged as tokens and pledges; hence patrw/ios cei=nos, ‘hereditary friend,’ Il. 6.215.
ceinosu/nh: hospitality, Od. 21.35†.
ceni/h: hospitality, entertainment as guest, guest-friendship. (Od.)
ce/nios: see cei/nios.
cero/s: dry; cero\n h)pei/roio, ‘dry land,’ Od. 5.402†.
ce/sse: see ce/w.
cesto/s (ce/w): scraped, hewn smooth, polished; of wood, stone, horn, etc.
ce/w, aor. e)/cese, ce/sse: scrape, hew smooth, polish; a)po\ (adv.) d' e)/cese xei=ra, ‘cut clean off,’ Il. 5.81.
chrai/nw: only pass. aor., e)chra/nqh, was dried up. (Il.)

ci/fos, eos: sword. The ci/fos had a two-edged blade, joined to the hilt (kw/ph) by bands of dark metal (mela/ndeton). It was worn in a sheath (kouleo/n), suspended by a baldric (telamw/n) that passed over the shoulder. (See cut on preceding page.)
cu/lon (cu=/w): mostly pl., wood, not standing, but cut; sing., trunk of a tree, Il. 23.327.
cu/loxos: thicket, jungle.

cum- and cun-: the former is used in compounds of ba/llw and pa=s, the latter in comp. w. a)gei/rw, a)/gnu=mi, a)/gw, de/w, e)lau/nw, e)/sesqai, e)/xw, i)e/nai, i(e/nai, and in cu/nesis and cunoxh/. See under sum-, sun-.
cun-eei/kosi: twenty together, Od. 14.98†.
cune/hke, cune/hx): see suni/hmi.
cunh/ios (cu=no/s): common, as common property.
cuni/ei, cu/nion: see suni/hmi.
cunio/ntos, cu/nisan: see su/neimi.
cu=no/s (= koino/s): common; *)enu=a/lios, ‘even - handed,’ ‘shifting,’ Il. 18.309.
curo/n (cu=/w): razor; proverb ‘on the razor's edge,’ see a)kmh/, Il. 10.173†.
custo/n (cu=/w): the polished shaft of a spear, spear; nau/maxon, ‘ship-pike,’ Il. 15.388, 677.
cu=/w (cf. ce/w), ipf. cu=on, aor. e)/cu=se: shave, scrape smooth, smooth, Il. 14.179.

div1.head: *o
div1.entryFree:
o(, h(, to/, epic forms, gen. toi=o, du. toi=in, pl. toi/, tai/, gen. ta=/wn, dat. toi=si, th=s(i): (1) as demonstrative pronoun, that, those, often merely an emphatic he, she, it, pl. they, them; ou)de\ palaiw=n (gunaikw=n), | ta=/wn ai(\ pa/ros h)=san, ‘those ancient,’ Od. 2.119; the emphatic after-position being common when the word is adjectival, cf. Il. 5.320, 332; the pron. is often foll. by a name in apposition, au)ta o(\ mh/nie.. *)axilleu/s, ‘he, namely Achilles,’ Il. 1.488 ; h(\ d' e(/speto *palla\s *)aqh/nh, Od. 1.125; freq. o(\ me
.. o(\ de/, to\ me
.. to\ de/, etc., the one.. the other, this.. that, etc. The word should be accented when used as a demonstrative.—(2) as definite article, the, a use denied by some to Homer, but the sense imperatively demands the later weakened force in many passages, and does not admit the stronger, *ai)/a=s d' o( me/gas, Il. 16.358; ai)e
 a)poktei/nwn to
 o)pi/staton, Il. 8.342; ta/ t) e)o/nta ta/ t) e)sso/mena, Il. 1.70, and oftenest w. adjectives.—(3) as relative pronoun, who, which, esp., but not exclusively, the forms beginning with t. The masc. sing. as rel. occurs, Il. 16.835, Il. 21.59, 230, Od. 1.254, Od. 2.262, Od. 4.777; patro\s, o(/ s' e)/trefe tutqo
 e)o/nta, Od. 11.67. te/ is often appended to the word when used relatively, tai/ te, o(/ te, Od. 12.40.—For o(/ ge, see o(/ge.
o(/: neuter, see o(/s.
o)/ar, aros, dat. pl. w)/ressin: wife. (Il.)
o)ari/zw, inf. o)arize/mei ai, ipf. o)a/rize: converse familiarly, chat. (Il.)
o)aristh/s (o)ari/zw): bosom friend, Od. 19.179†.
o)belo/s: spit. (See cuts under pempw/bolon.)
o)brimo-ergo/s (ve/rgon): worker of grave or monstrous deeds, Il. 5.403 and Il. 22.418.
o)brimo-pa/trh: daughter of a mighty father, Atnēna.
o)/brimos (bri=/qw): heavy, ponderous; a)/xqos, qureo/n, Od. 9.233, 241; then of persons, stout, mighty, Il. 15.112, Il. 19.408.
o)gdo/atos and o)/gdoos: eighth.
o)gdw/konta: eighty.

o(/ge, h(/ge, to/ge (o(/ ge, etc.): the demonstr. o(/, h(/, to/ intensified, and yet often employed where we should not only expect no emphasis, but not even any pronoun at all, as in the second of two alternatives, Il. 3.409, Il. 12.240, Od. 2.327 . o(/ ge serves, however, to keep before the mind a person once mentioned (and perhaps returned to after an interruption), thus usually the very opp. of o(\ de/, which introduces a new person in antithesis.
o)/gkion (o)/gkos): basket or box to hold arrow - heads or other things of iron, Od. 21.61†.
o)/gkos: barb of an arrow, pl. (Il.)
o)/gmos (a)/gw): furrow, also swath made by the mower or reaper, Il. 18.552, 557.
*)ogxhsto/s: Onchestus, a town on Lake Copāis in Boeotia, with a grove of Poseidon, Il. 2.506.
o)/gxnh: pear-tree, pear. (Od.)
o(dai=os (o(do/s): belonging to a journey, pl. o(dai=a, freight, cargo, Od. 8.163 and Od. 15.445.
o)da/c (da/knw): adv., with the teeth, biting; la/zesqai, e(lei=n, gai=an, ou)=das, ‘bite the dust,’ Il. 22.17 ; o)da\c e)n xei/lesi fu/nto, ‘bit their lips,’ in vexation, Od. 1.381.

o(/de, h(/de, to/de, pl. dat. toi=sde and toi/sdes(s)i: demonstr. pron., this here, ‘he, she, it here,’ pointing out a person or thing that is either actually (locally) present, or is a subject of present consideration or interest; hence the word is often ‘deictic,’ i. e. appropriately accompanied by a gesture, kai/ pote/ tis ei)/ph|sin.. *(/ektoros h(/de gunh/, see, ‘this’ is the wife of Hector, Il. 6.460 ; nhu=s moi h(/d' e(/sthken e)p) a)grou=, is stationed ‘here,’ just outside the town, Od. 1.185 ; h(mei=s oi(/de, ‘we here,’ Od. 1.76; freq. referring to what follows, Il. 1.41, Od. 15.211; and sometimes anticipating a relative, Il. 2.346.
o(deu/w (o(do/s): travel, go Il. 11.569†.
*)odi/os: (1) leader of the Halizonians, slain by Agamemnon, Il. 2.856, Il. 5.39.—(2) a herald of the Greeks, Il. 9.170.
o(di=/ths (o(do/s): traveller, wayfarer; w. a)/nqrwpos, *p 263, Od. 13.123.
o)dmh/ (root o)d): smell, fragrance.
o(doi-po/rion: reward for the journey, Od. 15.506†.
o(doi/ - poros: travelling, as subst., wayfarer, Il. 24.375†.
o(do/s, ou)do/s: way, path, road, journey, Od. 17.196; even by sea, Od. 2.273 ; pro\ o(dou= gene/sqai, ‘progress on one's way,’ Il. 4.382.
o)dou/s, o)do/ntos: tooth.
o)du/nh: pain, sometimes of the mind; sing., *(hra=klh=os, ‘for Heracles,’ Il. 15.25; elsewhere pl.
o)dunh/-fatos (fe/nw): pain-killing, relieving pain. (Il.)
o)du=/romai, aor. part. o)du=ra/menos: grieve, lament; abs., or w. causal gen., or trans., tina/ or ti\, a 243, Od. 5.153.
*)odush/ios: of Odysseus, Od. 18.353.

*)odusseu/s, *)oduseu/s, gen. *)odussh=os, *)odush=os, *)oduseu=s, Od. 24.398; dat. *)odush=i, *)odusei=, acc. *)odussh=a, *)odusse/a, *)odush=, Od. 19.136: Odysseus (Ulysses, Ulixes), son of Laertes and Ctimene, resident in the island of Ithaca and king of the Cephallenians, who inhabited Ithaca, Same, Zacynthus, Aegilops, Crocyleia, and a strip of the opposite mainland. Odysseus is the hero of the Odyssey, but figures very prominently in the Iliad also. He inherited his craft from his maternal grandfather Autolycus, see Od. 19.394 ff. Homer indicates the origin of Odysseus' name in Od. 19.406 ff., and plays upon the name also in Od. 1.62.
o)du/ssomai, aor. w)du/sao, -ato, o)du/santo, part. o)dussa/menos, perf. o)dw/dustai: be incensed with, hate, tini/, mostly of gods; w. reciprocal meaning, Od. 19.407; pass., Od. 5.423.
o)dw/dei: see o)/zw.
o)dw/dustai: see o)du/ssomai.
o)/essi: see o)/is.
o)/zos: shoot, twig; fig., *)arhos, ‘scion of Ares,’ Il. 2.540, 745.
o)/zw (root o)d), plup. o)dw/dei: be fragrant or redolent; o)dmh\ o)dw/dei, ‘was exhaled,’ Od. 5.60 and Od. 9.210.

o(/qen (o(/s): whence; with pers. ante
cedent when place or source is meant, Od. 3.319.
o(/q(i) (o(/s): where, there where; o(/qi per, ‘even where,’ Od. 14.532.
o)/qomai, o)/qetai, ipf. o)/qet(o): always w. neg., not to heed, trouble oneself or care about, tino/s, also abs., and w. inf. or part., Il. 5.403.
o)qo/nh: only pl., fine linen, linen garments, Il. 18.595.
*)oqruoneu/s: an ally of the Trojans from Cabēsus, Il. 13.363, 370, 374, 772.
oi(=: see ou(=.
oi(=a: see oi(=os.
oi)/gnu=mi, aor. w)/|ice, w)=|ce, w)/ican, part. oi)/ca=sa, pass. ipf. w)i/gnunto: open doors or gates, broach wine, Od. 3.392.
oi)=da, oi)=das, oi)=de: see ei)/dw, II.
oi)da/nw (oi)de/w): cause to swell, met., no/on (with rage), Il. 9.554; pass., also met., swell, Il. 9.646.
oi)de/w, ipf. w)/dee: swell, be swollen, Od. 5.455†.
*oi)dipo/dhs: Oedipus, king of Thebes, son of Laius and Epicaste, and father of Eteocles, Polynīces, and Antigone, Il. 23.679, Od. 11.271.
oi)=dma, atos: swell of the sea, billow, Il. 21.234 and Il. 23.230.
oi)e/ths (o)ve/ths, ve/tos): of equal age, pl., Il. 2.765†.
o)izu=ro/s, comp. -w/teros, sup. -w/tatos: full of woe, wretched, Il. 17.446, Od. 5.105.
o)izu=/s, u/os (oi)/, ‘alas!’): woe, misery.
o)izu/w, ipf. o)i/zue, o)izu/omen, aor. part. o)izu=/sa=s: suffer woe, be miserable, suffer; kaka/, Il. 14.89.
oi)h/ion: tiller, then helm, rudder, Od. 9.483; usually pl., because a Homeric ship had two rudders or steering-oars, Od. 12.218. (See foll. cuts and No. 60.)
oi)/hc, hkos: pl., yoke-rings, through which the reins passed, Il. 24.269†. (Cf. cuts Nos. 45 h, 10, 78 f.)
oi)/kade (old acc. voi=ka): adv., homeward, home.
oi)keu/s, h=os (voi=kos): inmate of a house, then servant, mostly pl., Od. 4.245, Od. 14.4.
oi)ke/w (voi=kos), ipf. w)/|keon, w)/|kei, pass. pres. opt. oi)ke/oito, aor. 3 pl., w)/|khqen: dwell, inhabit; aor. pass., ‘were settled,’ ‘came to dwell,’ Il. 2.668.
oi)ki/on, pl. oi)ki/a (voi=kos, dim. in form only): only pl., abode, habitation; of the nest of a bird, bees, etc., Il. 12.167, 221, Il. 16.261.
*oi)klei/hs: Oecles, son of Antiphates and father of Amphiarāus, Od. 15.244.
oi)ko/qen: from the house, from home, ‘from one's own store’ or ‘possessions,’ Il. 7.364.
oi)/koqi and oi)/koi: at home.
oi)=ko/nde: home, homeward, into the house, to the women's apartment, Od. 1.360, Od. 21.354.

oi)=kos (voi=kos, cf. vicus): house as home, including the family, and other inmates and belongings, Od. 2.45, 48; said of the tent of Achilles, the cave of Polyphemus, Il. 24.471, 572; the women's apartment, Od. 1.356, cf. 360.
oi)ktei/rw (oi)=ktos), aor. w)/|kteire: pity. (Il.)
oi)/ktistos: see oi)ktro/s.
oi)=ktos (oi)/, ‘alas!’): exclamation of pity, pity, compassion.
oi)ktro/s (oi)=ktos), comp. -o/teros, sup. -o/tatos and oi)/ktistos: pitiable, pitiful, miserable; adv., oi)ktra/, oi)/ktista, pitifully, most miserably, Od. 10.409, Od. 22.472.
oi)k-wfeli/h (voi=kos, o)fe/llw): bettering one's estate, thrift, Od. 14.223†.
*)oi=leu/s: Oīleus.—(1) king of Locris, father of the lesser Ajax and of Medon, Il. 13.697, Il. 15.333, Il. 2.727, see *ai)/a=s. —(1) charioteer of Biēnor, slain by Agamemnon, Il. 11.93.
*)oi=lia/dhs: son of Oīleus, Ajax, Il. 12.365, Il. 13.712, Il. 14.446, Il. 16.330, Il. 23.759.
oi)=ma, atos (oi)/sw, fe/rw): spring, swoop. (Il.) oi)ma/w (oi)=ma), aor. oi)/mhse: dart upon, swoop after, Il. 22.308, 140, Od. 24.538.
oi)/mh: song, lay. (Od.)
oi)=mos: course, stripe, band, pl., Il. 11.24†.
oi)mwgh/ (oi)mw/zw): cry of grief, lamentation.
oi)mw/zw (oi)/moi, ‘woe me!’), aor. w)/|mwca, part. oi)mw/ca=s: cry out in grief (or pain), lament, e)leeina/, smerdale/on, me/ga.
*oi)nei/dhs: son of Oeneus, Tydeus, Il. 5.813, Il. 10.497.

*oi)neu/s (voin.): Oeneus, son of Portheus, king of Calydon in Aetolia, the husband of Althaea, and father of Tydeus and Meleāger, a guest-friend of Bellerophon. The Calydonian boar was sent upon his territory through the anger of Artemis, Il. 2.641, Il. 6.216, Il. 9.535, Il. 14.117.
oi)ni/zomai (voi=nos), ipf. oi)ni/zonto: supply oneself with wine. (Il.)
oi)no-barei/wn (baru/s), part.: heavy with wine. (Od.)
oi)no - barh/s, voc. -e/s=foregoing, ‘wine-bibber,’ Il. 1.225†.
*oi)no/maos: (1) an Aetolian, slain by Hector, Il. 5.706.—(2) a Trojan, Il. 12.140, Il. 13.506.
oi)no/ - pedos (pe/don): consisting of wine-land, wine-yielding; subst., oi)no/pedon, vineyard, Il. 9.579.
*oi)nopi/dhs: son of Oenops, Helenus, Il. 5.707†.
oi)no-plhqh/s: abounding in wine, Od. 15.406†.
oi)no-pota/zw: quaff wine.
oi)no - poth/r, h=ros: wine - drinker, Od. 8.456†.

oi)=nos (voi=nos, cf. vinum): wine. It was regularly mixed with water before drinking, see krhth/r, a)mfiforeu/s, a)sko/s, pi/qos, pro/xoos, ne/mein. Epithets, ai)=qoy, e)ruqro/s, melihdh/s, meli/- frwn, h(du/s, h(du/potos, eu)h/nwr. gerou/sios oi)=nos, typical of the dignity of the council of elders. Places famed for the quality of wine produced were Epidaurus, Phrygia, Pedasus, Arne, Histiaea, Lemnos, Thrace, Pramne, and the land of the Ciconians.
oi)no-xoe/w and oi)noxoeu/w, ipf. w)|noxo/ei (oi)noxo/ei), e)w|noxo/ei, aor. inf. oi)noxoh=sai: be cup-bearer, pour wine, nectar, Il. 4.3.
oi)no-xo/os (xe/w): wine-pourer, cupbearer.
oi)=noy, opos: winy, wine-colored, epithet of the sea and of cattle, Od. 13.32.
*oi)=noy: an Ithacan, the father of Liōdes, Od. 21.144†.
oi)no/w: only pass. aor. part., oi)nwqe/ntes, overcome by wine, drunken, Od. 16.292 and Od. 19.11.
oi)/ca=sa: see oi)/gnu=mi.
oi(=o: see o(/ Od. 18.2.
oi)o/qen: adv., used for an emphatic doubling, oi)o/qen oi)=os, all alone (cf. ai)no/qen ai)nw=s). (Il.)
oi)/omai: see o)i=/w.
oi)o-po/los (pe/lomai): lonely.
oi)=os: alone; mi/) oi)/h, du/) oi)/w, du/o oi)/ous, Od. 3.424; oi)=os a)/neuqe or a)po/ tinos, *x 39, Od. 9.192; ‘alone of its kind,’ i. e. best, Il. 24.499.

oi(=os, oi(/h, oi(=on: relative word, (such) as, of what sort (qualis), with antecedent toi=os expressed or implied. It may be causal in effect, also exclamatory, ai(/matos ei)=s a)gaqoi=o, fi/lon te/kos, oi(=) a)goreu/eis, ‘such words you speak,’ = o(/ti toi=a, Od. 4.611; oi(=on dh/ nu qeou\s brotoi\ ai)tio/wntai, ‘how mortals do, etc.!’ Od. 1.32; foll. by inf., as implying capability, oi(=os e)kei=nos e)/hn bouleue/men, ‘such a man was he to plan,’ Od. 14.491; freq. the neut. oi(=on, oi(=a, as adv., as, how, what (sort), etc. oi(=a te in comparisons, oi(=on dh/ exclamatory and causal, Od. 9.128, Od. 11.429.
oi)o/s and o)/ios: see o)/is.
oi)o-xi/twn, wnos: with tunic only, Od. 14.489†.
oi)o/w (oi)=os), pass. aor. oi)w/qh: leave alone, abandon. (Il.)
o)/is (o)/vis, cf. ovis), gen. o)/ios, oi)o/s, acc. o)/in, pl. o)/ies (oi)/ies, Od. 9.425), gen. o)i/wn, oi)w=n, dat. oi)/esi, o)i/essi, o)/essi, acc. o)/i=s: sheep; with a)rneio/s, a)/rshn, qh/leia.
o)i=/sato: see o)i=/w.
oi)/sete: see fe/rw.
oi)=sqa: see ei)/dw, II.
o)isqei/s: see o)i=/w.

o)isteu/w (o)isto/s), aor. imp. o)i/steuson, part. o)isteu/sa=s: discharge an arrow, shoot arrows; to/cw|, Od. 12.84. (The foll. cuts, from Assyrian reliefs, illustrate the manner of drawing the bow and holding the arrow. See also cut under pw=ma.)

o)isto/s (oi)/sw, fe/rw): arrow. Made of wood, or a reed, with barbed metal point, the lower end feathered and notched (glufi/des), or with projections, enabling the fingers to take a firm hold on the arrow in drawing. Poisoned arrows are mentioned only exceptionally, Od. 1.261, Il. 4.213.
oi)=stros: gadfly, Od. 22.300†.
oi)su/inos: of willow, willow, Od. 5.256†.
oi)/sw: see fe/rw.
oi)=tos: fate, mostly in bad sense, and usually with kako/s. Without kako/s, Il. 9.563, *w 388, Od. 8.489, 578.
*oi)/tulos: a town on the coast of Laconia, Il. 2.585†.
*oi)xali/h: a town on the river Peneius, the home of Eurytus, Il. 2.730 .— *oi)xali/hqen: from Oechalia, Il. 2.596 .— *oi)xalieu/s: the Oechalian, Eurytus, Il. 2.596, Od. 8.224.
oi)xne/w (oi)/xomai), oi)xneu=sin, ipf. iter. oi)/xneskon: go or come (frequently), Il. 5.790, Il. 15.640, Od. 3.322.

oi)/xomai, ipf. w)|xo/mhn: go, depart, and freq. w. perf. signif., h)/dh.. oi)/xetai ei)s a(/la di=an, is gone, Il. 15.223, Il. 5.472; so the part., *)odussh=os po/qos oi)xome/noio, the ‘absent,’ perhaps the ‘departed’ Odysseus, Od. 14.144. The verb is common with a supplementary part., the more specific part of the predication being contained in this participle, w)/|xet' a)popta/menos, ‘sped on wings away,’ flew away, Il. 2.71.

o)i=/w, oi)/w, o)i=/omai, oi)/omai, opt. oi)/oito, ipf. w)i=/eto, aor. o)i=/sato, pass. aor. w)i/sqhn, part. o)isqei/s: verb of subjective view or opinion, think, believe, fancy, regularly foll. by inf.; often iron. or in litotes, o)i=/w, methinks, Od. 8.180, Il. 13.263; likewise parenthetically (opinor), Od. 16.309; sometimes to be paraphrased, ‘suspect,’ or when the reference is to the future, ‘expect’; implying apprehension, Od. 19.390 . go/on d' w)i=/eto qu=mo/s, was ‘bent on,’ or ‘engrossed with’ lamentation, Od. 10.248; once impers., like dokei=, Od. 19.312.
oi)wnisth/s: (bird) seer; as adj., Il. 13.70.
oi)wno - po/los (pole/w): versed in omens drawn from birds, seer, pl., Il. 1.69 and Il. 6.76.
oi)wno/s (cf. avis): bird of prey, bird of omen; ei(=s oi)wno\s a)/ristos, a)mu=/nesqai peri\ pa/trhs, Il. 13.243. (Said by Hector. A fine example of an early protest for free-thought.)
o)kne/w, o)knei/w, ipf. w)/kneon: shrink from doing something, hesitate through some sort of dread, Il. 5.255 and Il. 20.155.
o)/knos: shrinking, hesitancy through dread. (Il.)
o)kria/w (o)/kris, a)/kros): only pass. ipf. o)krio/wnto, met., were becoming incensed, furious, Od. 18.33†.
o)krio/eis, essa, en (o)/kris, a)/kros): having sharp points, jagged, rugged.
o)kruo/eis, essa, en (kru/os): chilling, horrible, Il. 9.64 and Il. 6.344.

o)kta/-knhmos (krh/mh): eight-spoked, of wheels, Il. 5.723†. (See cut, from a
painting on a Panathenaic amphora found at Volsci.)
o)ktw/: eight.
o)ktw-kai-de/katos: eighteenth.
o)lbio-dai/mwn: blessed by the deity, Il. 3.182†.
o)/lbios (o)/lbos): happy, blessed, esp with riches, Od. 18.138; (dw=ra) o)/lbia poih/seian, ‘may they bless’ them, Od. 13.42; pl., o)/lbia, blessings.
o)/lbos: happiness, fortune, riches.
o)le/esqai, o)le/eske: see o)/llu=mi.
o)le/qrios: o)le/qrion h)=mar: day of destruction, Il. 19.294 and 409.
o)/leqros (o)/llu=mi): destruction, ruin, death; ai)pu/s, lugro/s, a)deukh/s, oi)/ktistos.
o)lei=tai: see o)/llu=mi.
o)le/kw, ipf. iter. o)le/kesken, pass. o)le/konto:=o)/llu=mi.
o)le/sai, o)le/sa=s, o)le/ssai, o)le/ssa=s, o)le/sqai: see o)/llu=mi.
o)leth/r, h=oos: destroyer, Il. 18.114†.
o)ligh-pele/w: be weak, faint, swooning, only part.
o)ligh - peli/h: weakness, faintness, Od. 5.468.
o)li/gistos: see o)li/gos.
o)ligo-drane/w: only part., able to do little, feeble. (Il.)

o)li/gos, sup. o)li/gistos: little, small; of a ‘short’ time (o)li/gos xro/nos), a ‘thin’ voice (o)li/gh| o)pi/), a ‘feeblyflowing’ spring (pi=/dakos o)li/ghs), ‘little’fishes (o)li/goi i)xqu/es). Neut. as adv., o)li/gon, a little, also o)li/gou, almost, Od. 14.37. Sup., Il. 19.223, ‘scanty shall be the reaping.’
o)li/zones: see u(poli/zones.
*)olizw/n: a town in Magnesia in Thessaly, Il. 2.717†.
o)lisqa/nw, aor. 2 o)/lisqe: slip, slip and fall, fall. (Il.)

o)/llu=mi, part. o)llu=/s, -u/nta, pl. fem. o)llu=sai, ipf. iter. o)le/eske, fut. o)le/sw, o)le/sseis, aor. w)/lesa, o)/les(s)e, inf. o)le/(s)sai, part. o)le/(s)sa=s, part. o)/lwla, plup. o)lw/lei, mid. pres. part. o)llu/menoi, fut. o)lei=tai, inf. o)le/esqai, aor. 2 w)/leo, o)/lonto, inf. o)le/sqai (see ou)lo/menos): act., lose, destroy, mid., be lost, perish; perf. and plup. mid. in sense, Il. 24.729, Il. 10.187.
o)/lmos: smooth round stone, quoit, Il. 11.147†.
o)loio/s =o)loo/s, *a 342, Il. 22.5.
o)lolugh/: outcry of women's voices, Il. 6.301†.
o)lolu/zw, aor. o)lo/luca: cry out aloud, only of women, either with jubilant voice or in lamentation, Od. 22.408, 411, Od. 4.767.
o)lo/mhn: see o)/llu=mi.
o)looi/ - troxos (vol., cf. volvo): rolling stone, round rock, Il. 13.137†.
o)loo/s (o)llu=mi), comp. -ow/teros, sup. -ow/tatos: destroying, destructive, deadly.
*)oloossw/n: a town on the river Eurōtas in Thessaly, situated on white cliffs, Il. 2.739†.
o)loo/-frwn: destructive-minded, baleful.
o)lofudno/s: doleful, pitiful.

o)lofu=/romai, aor. o)lofu=ra/mhn: lament, mourn, bewail, commiserate; freq. abs., esp. in part., also w. gen. of the person mourned for, Il. 8.33; and trans., tina/, Il. 24.328, k 157, Od. 19.522; w. inf., ‘bewail that thou must be brave before the suitors,’ Od. 22.232.
*)olumpia/s, pl. *)olumpia/des: Olympian, epith. of the Muses, Il. 2.491†.
*)olu/mpios: Olympian, dwelling on Olympus, epith. of the gods and their homes, and as subst.=Zeus, the Olympian.

*)/olumpos, *ou)/lumpos: Olympus, a mountain in Thessaly, not less than nine thousand feet in height, penetrating with snow-capped peaks through the clouds to the sky, and conceived by Homer as the abode of the gods. Epithets, a)ga/nnifos, ai)glh/eis, ai)pus, makro/s, polu/ptuxos.
o)/lu=rai, pl.: a kind of grain similar to barley, Il. 5.196 and Il. 8.564.
o)/lwla: see o)/llu=mi.
o(made/w (o(/mados): only aor. o(ma/dhsan, they raised a din. (Od.)
o(/mados (o(mo/s): din, properly of many voices together. (Il. and Od. 10.556.)
o(malo/s (o(mo/s): even, smooth, Od. 9.327†.
o(m-arte/w (o(mo/s, root a)r), part. o(marte/wn, aor. opt. o(marth/seien, part. o(marth/sa=s: accompany or attend, keep pace with, meet, encounter, Il. 24.438, Od. 13.87, Il. 12.400.
o(marth=|: see a(marth=|.
o)mbrimopa/trh, o)/mbrimos: see o)brim.
o)/mbros (cf. imber): rain, rainstorm; also of a heavy fall of snow, Il. 12.286.
o)mei=tai: see o)/mnu=mi.
o(m-hgerh/s, e/s (o(mo/s, a)gei/rw): assembled together.
o(m-hguri/zomai, aor. inf. o(mhguri/sasqai: assemble, convoke, Od. 16.376†.
o(m-h/guris: assembly, Il. 20.142†.
o(m - hliki/h: equal age, Il. 20.465; for the concrete, person of like age, mate, companion.
o(m - h=lic, ikos: of like age; tino/s, ‘with’ one, Od. 19.358.
o(m - hre/w (root a)r), aor. w(mh/rhse: meet, Od. 16.468†.
o(mi=lado/n: adv., in crowds. (Il.)

o(mi=le/w, ipf. w(mi=/leun, o(mi=/leon, o(mi=/lei, aor. w(mi/lhsa: be in a throng, throng about, associate or go with, tini/, so meta/, e)ni/, para/ tisi, peri/ tina, Il. 16.641, 644; of meeting in battle, engaging, Il. 11.523, Od. 1.265.
o(/mi=los: throng, crowd; in the Iliad freq. of the crowd and tumult of battle, Il. 5.553, Il. 10.499.
o)mi/xlh: mist, cloud; fig., of dust, Il. 13.336. (Il.)
o)/mma, atos (root o)p, cf. oculus): eye, only pl.

o)/mnu=mi, o)mnu/w, imp. o)/mnuqi, o)mnue/tw, ipf. w)/mnue, fut. o)mou=mai, -ei=tai, aor. w)/mosa, o)/mo(s)sa: take oath, swear; o(/rkon (tini/, or pro/s tina), Il. 3.279, Od. 14.331; foll. by inf., also w. acc. of the person or thing in whose name, or by whom or which, the oath is taken, Il. 14.271, Il. 15.40.
o(mo-ga/strios (gasth/r): kasi/gnhtos, own brother, by the same mother. (Il.)
o(mo/qen: from the same place (root), Od. 5.477†.

o(moi=os, o(moi/i=os: like, similar, equal; to
 o(moi=on, ‘his peer,’ Il. 16.53; prov., to
 o(moi=on a)/gei qeo\s w(s to
 o(moi=on, ‘birds of a feather,’ Od. 17.218; as epith. of po/lemos (o(moii=/ou pole/moio), qa/natos, etc., common, impartial, levelling all alike, Od. 24.543.

o(mokle/w and o(mokla/w (o(moklh/), ipf. o(mo/kleon, o(mo/kla=, aor. o(mo/klhsa, iter. o(moklh/saske: shout together, call out to, command sharply; abs., and w. dat., Il. 24.248; w. (acc. and) inf., Od. 24.173, Il. 16.714.
o(mo-klh/ (o(mo/s, kale/w): call of many together, loud, sharp call or command.
o(mo-klhth/r, h=ros: one who shouts or calls loudly and sharply, Il. 12.273 and Il. 23.452.
o)mo/rgnu=mi, ipf. o)mo/rgnu=, mid. w)mo/rgnunto, aor. part. o)morca/menos: wipe, wipe away, mid., one's own tears, etc., Il. 18.124.
o(mo/s (cf. a(/ma): like, common.
o)mo/sa=s: see o)/mnu=mi.
o(mo/se: to the place, together, Il. 12.24 and Il. 13.337.
o(mo-stixa/w (stei/xw): march along with, keep pace with, Il. 15.635†.
o(mo/-ti=mos: like - honored, entitled to equal honor, Il. 15.186†.
o(mou=: in the same place with, together, at once, alike.
o(mo-frone/w: be like-minded, of one mind. (Od.)
o(mo - frosu/nh: harmony of mind, congeniality. (Od.)
o(mo/-frwn: like-minded, harmonious, congenial, Il. 22.263†.
o)mfalo/eis, essa, en: furnished with an o)mfalo/s or o)mfaloi/, bossy, studded, epith. of shield, yoke. (Il.)

o)mfalo/s (cf. umbilicus): navel, Il. 4.525, Il. 21.180; fig., qala/sshs, Od. 1.50; then (1) of a shield, boss, the projection in the centre ending in a button or point; pl., studs, serving as ornaments, Il. 11.34.—(2) of a yoke, knob, or pin, on the centre (see cut No. 45 a), Il. 24.273. The Assyrians had the same (see cut No. 51), while the Egyptians ornamented the ends of the yoke with a ball of brass. (See cut No. 92 on next page.)
o)/mfac, akos: pl., unripe grapes, Od. 7.125†.
o)mfh/: divine or prophetic voice, conveyed by a dream or through omens of birds, etc. See panomfai=os.
o(m-w/numos (o)/noma): having the same name, Il. 16.720†.
o(mw=s (o(mo/s): together, alike, likewise, equally as, just as.
o(/mws (o(mo/s): yet, Il. 12.393†.
o)/nar: dream, vision; opp. u(/par, ‘reality,’ Od. 19.547, Od. 20.90.

o)/neiar, atos (o)ni/nhmi): anything that is helpful, help, relief, refresh-
ment; of a person, Il. 22.433; pl., o)nei/ata, viands, food, and once of goods, treasures, Il. 24.367.
o)neidi/zw (o)/neidos), aor. o)nei/disas, imp. o)nei/dison: reproach, ‘cast in one's teeth,’ tini/ ti, *i 34, Od. 18.380.

o)/neidos, eos: reproach, often pl., o)nei/dea mu=qei=sqai, le/gein, profe/rein, ba/zein, kat' o)nei/dea xeu=ai/ tini, ‘overwhelm one with reproach,’ Od. 22.463; then matter of reproach, disgrace, Il. 16.489.
o)nei/rata: see o)/neiros.
o)nei/reios: e)n o)neirei/h|si pu/lh|sin, at the gates of dreams, Od. 4.809†.

o)/neiros, o)/neiron, pl. o)/neiroi and o)nei/rata: dream; personified, Il. 2.6, Il. 16.22; as a people dwelling hard by the way to the nether world, Od. 24.12; a dreamallegory, Od. 19.562, cf. Od. 4.809†.
o)nh/menos, o)/nhsa: see o)ni/nhmi.
o)/nhsis (o)ni/nhmi): benefit, luck, prosperity, Od. 21.402†.
*)onhtori/dhs: son of Onētor, Phrontis, Od. 3.282.
*)onh/twr: a Trojan, father of Laogonus, Il. 16.604†.
o)/nqos: dung. (*y)

o)ni/nhmi, fut. o)nh/sw, aor. w)/nhsa, o)/nhsa, mid. fut. o)nh/somai, aor. 2 imp. o)/nhso, part. o)nh/menos: act., benefit, help (tina/), mid., derive benefit or advantage from, enjoy, tino/s, Il. 16.31; e)sqlo/s moi dokei= ei)=nai, o)nh/menos, ‘bless him!’ Od. 2.33.
o)/noma, ou)/noma, atos (for o)/-gnoma, gnw=nai, cf. nomen): name; for ‘fame,’ ‘glory,’ Od. 13.248, Od. 24.93.

o)noma/zw, ipf. o)no/mazon, aor. w)no/masa: call or address by name (Il. 22.415, Il. 10.68), name, mention; the phrase e)/pos t' e)/fat) e)/k (adv.) t' o)no/mazen (and ‘familiarly addressed’ him) is always followed either by the name of the person addressed or by some substantial equivalent for the name.

o)/nomai, o)/nosai, o)/nontai, opt. o)/noito, fut. o)no/ssomai, aor. 1 w)nosa/mhn, o)no/sasq(e), -nt(o), part. o)nossa/menos, aor. 2 w)/nato, Il. 17.25: find fault with, scorn, tina/ or ti\, usually w. neg. expressed or implied, Il. 4.539, Il. 17.399; once w. gen., kak<*>thtos, ‘esteem lightly,’ Od. 5.379.
o)nomai/nw (parallel form to o)noma/zw), aor. o)no/mhnas: call by name, name, name over, mention; in the sense of ‘appointing’ or ‘constituting,’ Il. 23.90.
o)noma - klh/dhn: adv., calling the name, by name.
o)noma/-klutos: of famous name, renowned, Il. 22.51†.
o)nomasto/s: to be named, w. neg., of a name not to be uttered for the illomen it contains. (Od.)
o)/nos: ass, Il. 11.558†.
o)no/sasqe, o)nossa/menos, o)no/ssesqai: see o)/nomai.
o)nosto/s (o)/nomai): w. neg., not to be despised, not contemptible, Il. 9.164†.
o)/nuc, uxos: pl., claws, talons, of the eagle.
o)cu-belh/s, e/s (be/los): sharp-pointed, Il. 4.126†.
o)cu-o/eis, -essa, en: sharp-pointed.

o)cu/s, ei=a, u/, sup. o)cu/tatos: sharp, of weapons and other implements, crags, hill-tops, Od. 5.411, Od. 12.74; metaph., of light, pains, sounds, etc., ‘keen,’ ‘piercing,’ Il. 17.372, Od. 11.208; ‘fierce’ Ares, Il. 11.836; neut. as adv., o)cu/ and o)ce/a, met. as above, proi+dei=n, noei=n, boa=n, Od. 5.393, *g 374, Il. 17.89.
o(/o and o(/ou: see o(/ Od. 18.1.

o)pa/zw (cf. e(/pw), fut. o)pa/ssw, aor. w)/pasa, o)/pa(s)sa, mid. pres. part. o)pazo/menos, fut. o)pa/sseai, aor. o)pa/ssato, part. o)passa/menos: I. act., join as companion (guide, escort), tina/ tini (a(/ma, meta/), cause to follow or accompany, Il. 13.416, Od. 15.310, Il. 24.153, 461, Od. 10.204; then of things, bestow, lend, confer; ku=do/s tini, xa/rin kai\ ku=dos e)/rgois, g 57, Od. 15.320, w. inf., Il. 23.151; also follow hard upon, press upon. tina/, Il. 8.341; fig., gh=ras, Il. 4.321; pass., Il. 11.493.—II. mid., take with one (as companion, guide, escort), tina/, Il. 10.238, *t 238, Od. 10.59.

o)pai=os (o)ph/): with an opening; neut. pl. as subst., a)n' o)pai=a (v. l. a)nopai=a, q. v.), through the loop-holes, i. e. between the rafters under the eaves, Od. 1.320†. These spaces were in later times closed, and termed specifically meto/pai. (See cut No. 83.)
o)/-patros: of the same father, Il. 11.257 and Il. 12.371.
o)pa=/wn, onos (cf. e(/pw, o)pa/zw): atte<*>dant, ‘armor-bearer,’ ‘esquire.’ (Il.)
o(/per: see o(/sper.
o(/ph|, o(/pph|: adv. of place or manner, where (whither), as, Od. 10.190, Il. 12.48, Od. 8.45.
o)phde/w (o)phdo/s, o)pa/zw), ipf. o)ph/dei: accompany, attend, follow, tini/ (a(/ma tini/); said of things as well as persons, to/ca, a)reth/, ti=mh/, Il. 5.216, q 237, Il. 17.251.
o)pi/zomai (o)/pis), ipf. o)pi/zeo, w)pi/zeto: have regard to with awe, reverence, dread; *dio\s mh=nin, mhtro\s e)fetmh/n, tina/, Od. 14.283, *s 216, Il. 22.332.
o)/piqen: see o)/pisqen.
o)pipteu/w and o)pipeu/w (root o)p), aor. part. -eu/sa=s: peer after, watch (timorously, or in lurking for one), Il. 4.371, Il. 7.243 ; gunai=kas, ogle, Od. 19.67 (cf. parqenopi=/phs).
o)/pis, acc. o)/pida and o)/pin (root o)p): jealous and vengeful regard, divine vengeance, always w. qew=n exc. Od. 14.82, 88. (Od. and Il. 16.388.)
o)/pisqe(n), o)/piqe(n): from behind, behind, afterward, hereafter; w. gen., Il. 13.536.
o)pi/(s)sw: backward, behind, hereafter, in(to) the future.
o)pi/statos: hindmost, Il. 8.432 and Il. 11.178.
*)opi=/ths: a Greek, slain by Hector, Il. 11.301†.
o(ple/w (= o(pli/zw): only ipf., w(/pleon (o(/pleon), were getting ready, Od. 6.73†.
o(/plh: hoof, pl., Il. 11.536 and Il. 20.501.

o(pli/zw (o(/plon), aor. w(/plisse, imp. w(/plisson, inf. o(pli/sai, mid. aor. o(pli/(s)sato: equip, make ready, as a chariot, a ship for sailing, prepare a meal; mid., equip or arm oneself, prepare for oneself, Od. 14.526, Od. 16.453; aor. pass., o(/plisqen gunai=kes, ‘arrayed themselves’ for the dance, Od. 23.143.
o(/plon: mostly pl., o(/pla, implements, arms (armor), rigging of a ship, Il. 18.409, Od. 3.433, Od. 10.254, Od. 2.390; sing., rope, cable, Od. 21.390, Od. 14.346.
o(/plomai: prepare, inf. (Il.)
*)opo/eis: Opūs, a city in Locris, the home of Menoetius, father of Patroclus, Il. 23.85, Il. 18.326, Il. 2.531.

o(poi=os, o(ppoi=os: indirect interrog., of what sort, Od. 1.171 ; o(poi=) a)/ssa (o(poi=a/ tina), ‘about what sort’ of garments, Od. 19.218; also rel., like oi(=os, correl. to toi=os, *u 250, Od. 17.421.
o)po/s: sap of the wild fig-tree, used for curdling milk, Il. 5.902†.
o)po/s: see o)/y.
o(po/sos, o(po/ssos, o(ppo/sos: how great, how much, how many.
o(po/te, o(ppo/te: whenever, when; w. the same constructions as other rel. words, see a)/n, ke/n.
o(/pou: where. (Od.)
o(ppo/qen: whence. (Od.)
o(/ppoq(i): where.
o(ppo/se: whithersoever, Od. 14.139†.
o(ppo/teros: whichever (of two).
o(ppote/rwqen: from or on which side (of two), Il. 14.59†.
o)ptale/os (o)pto/s): roasted.

o)pta/w (o)pto/s), ipf. o)/ptwn (w)/ptwn),
aor. w)/pthsa, o)/pthsa, pass. aor. inf. o)pthqh=nai: roast on the spit; w. part. gen., krew=n, Od. 15.98.
o)pth/r, h=ros (root o)p): scout, spy, pl., Od. 14.261 and Od. 17.430.
o)pto/s (root pep, pe/ssw): roasted, broiled. (Od.)
o)pui/w, inf. o)puie/men(ai), ipf. w)/puie, o)/puie, pass. part. o)puiome/nh: wed, take to wife; part., married, act. of man, pass. of woman, Od. 6.63, Il. 8.304.
o)/pwpa: see o(ra/w.
o)pwph/ (o)/pwpa): sight, power of vision, Od. 9.512 ; h)/nthsas o)pwph=s, ‘hast met the view,’ ‘thine eyes have seen,’ Od. 3.97.

o)pw/rh (w(/rh): late summer (or early autumn), harvest-tide; the season extended from the rising of Sirius (end of July) to the setting of the Pleiades, thus corresponding nearly to our ‘dogdays,’ teqalui=a, ‘luxuriant,’ ‘exuberant,’ fruit-time, Od. 11.192.
o)pwri=no/s: of late summer; a)sth/r, Sirins, Il. 5.5.

o(/pws, o(/ppws: how, in order that, as.—(1) indirect interrog., ou)de/ ti/ pw sa/fa vi/dmen o(/pws e)/stai ta/de ve/rga, ‘how these things will be,’ Il. 2.250; then implying purpose, fra/zeo nu=n o(/ppws ke po/lin kai\ va/stu saw/seis, ‘how you are to save,’ Il. 16.144; and purely final, li/ssesqai de/ min au)to/s, o(/pws nhmerte/a vei/ph|, ‘that he speak the truth,’ Od. 3.19.—(2) rel., as; e)/rcon o(/pws e)qe/leis, Il. 4.37; qau/mazen d' o( geraio/s, o(/pws i)/den o)/fqalmoi=sin, Od. 3.373; causal, Od. 4.109.

o(ra/w, o(ro/w (root vor), ipf. o(/ra=, o(rw=men, mil. o(rw=mai, 2 sing. o(/rhai, ipf. o(ra=to, o(rw=nto (from root o)p, perf. o)/pwpa, plup. o)pw/pei, mid. fut. o)/yeai, o)/yei, 2 pl. [or aor. imp.] o)/yesqe; from root vid, see ei)/dw I.): act. and mid., see, behold, look on; freq. phrases, (e)n) o)fqalmoi=sin o(ra=n, o(ra=sqai, o(ra=n faos h)eli/oio (= zh=n).
o)/rguia (o/re/gw): distance spanned by the outstretched arms, fathom.

o)re/gnu=mi, o)re/gw, part. o)re/gwn, o)regnu=/s, fut. o)re/cw, aor. w)/reca, mid. pres. inf. o)re/gesqai, aor. w)re/cat(o), o)re/cat(o), perf. 3 pl. o)rwre/xatai, plup. 3 pl. o)rwre/xato: reach, extend, mid., stretch out oneself, or one's own hands, etc., reach for, tino/s, sometimes ti\, Il. 16.314, 322, Il. 23.805; of ‘reaching and giving’ something, Il. 24.102; and metaph., o(ppote/roisi path\r *zeu\s ku=dos o)re/ch|, ‘may bestow,’ Il. 5.33; mid., of trying to hit, ‘lunging’ at one with the spear, Il. 4.307; of horses ‘laying themselves out,’ to exert their speed (perf. and plup.), Il. 16.834; so dra/kontes, ‘outstretched,’ Il. 11.26.
o)rekto/s (o)re/gw): extended, thrust out, Il. 2.543†.
o)re/omai =o)/rnumai, only ipf., o)re/onto, rushed forth, Il. 2.398 and Il. 23.212.
*)ore/sbios: a Boeotian from Hyle, slain by Hector, Il. 5.707†.
o)resi/-trofos: mountain-bred.
o)res-kw=|os (kei=mai): having mountain-lairs, Il. 1.268 and Od. 9.155.
o)re/steros (o)/ros, cf. a)gro/teros): of the mountains, mountain-, dragon, wolves, Il. 22.93, Od. 10.212.

*)ore/sths: Orestes.—(1) the son of Agamemnon, who having been reared at Athens returns to Mycēnae and slays Aegisthus, after the latter had reigned eight years. Clytaemnestra was slain at the same time. (See cut under e(/drh, from a painting on an ancient Greek vase.) The murder of Agamemnon was thus avenged, and the throne restored to its rightful heir, Od. 3.306, Od. 11.461, Od. 1.30, 40, 298, d 546, Il. 9.142, 284.—(2) a Greek slain by Hec. tor, Il. 5.705.—(3) a Trojan, slain by Leonteus, Il. 12.139, 193.
o)restia/s, a/dos: mountain - nymph, pl., Il. 6.420†.
o)/resfi: see o)/ros.
o)rexqe/w: doubtful word, bellow in last agonies, rattle in the throat, Il. 23.30†.
o)/rqai: see o)/rnu=mi.
*)orqai=os: a Trojan, Il. 13.791†.
*)/orqh: a town in Thessaly, Il. 2.739†.
o)/rqios: of the voice, high; adv., o)/rqia, ‘with shrill voice,’ Il. 11.11†.

o)rqo/-krairos (ke/ras), only gen. pl. fem. o)rqokraira=/wn: straight - horned, high - horned; bow=n, m 348, Il. 8.231; then of ships, either with reference to the pointed bow and stern, or perhaps to the yards (kerai/a=).
o)rqo/s: upright, erect.
o)rqo/w, aor. w)/rqwse, pass. aor. part. o)rqwqei/s: raise up straight, pass., rise up. (Il.)

o)ri=/nw (parallel form of o)/rnu=mi), aor.
w)/ri=na, o)/ri=na, pass. ipf. w)ri=/neto, aor. w)ri/nqhn, o)ri/nqh: stir, rouse, arouse, move, wind, waves, etc.; metaph., of anger and other passions, qu=mo/n tini, Il. 24.467, pass. Od. 18.75 ; go/on, kh=r, h)=tor; o)rinqe/ntes kata\ dw=ma, ‘stirred with dismay,’ Od. 22.23.

o(/rkion (o(/rkos): (1) oath, Il. 4.158, elsewhere pl.—(2) pledges of the covenant, hence victims, Il. 3.245, 269.—(3) the covenant or treaty itself; o(/rkia pista\ tamei=n (foedus ferire), because victims were slaughtered as a part of the ceremony, Il. 2.124, Il. 3.73, Od. 24.483.

o(/rkos: (1) that by which one swears, witness of an oath, for the gods the Styx; for men Zeus, Earth, the Ermnyes, etc., Il. 2.755, Il. 15.38, Il. 3.276 ff., Il. 19.258 ff., Od. 14.394; Achilles swears by his sceptre, Il. 1.234.—(2) oath; e(le/sqai tino/s or tini/, ‘take an oath from one,’ Il. 22.119, Od. 4.746 ; o(/rkos qew=n, ‘by the gods,’ cf. Il. 20.313 ; gerou/sios o(/rkos, Il. 22.119; o(/rkw| pistwqh=nai, Od. 15.436.
o(rmaqo/s (o(/rmos): chain, cluster of bats hanging together, Od. 24.8†.

o(rmai/nw (o(rma/w), ipf. w(/rmaine, aor. w(/rmhne: turn over in the mind, debate, ponder; kata\ fre/na kai\ kata\ qu=mo/n, a)na\ qu=mo/n (e)ni\) fresi/n, *k 4, Od. 3.169; foll. by acc., po/lemon, plo/on, xalepa\ a)llh/lois, Od. 3.151; and by o(/pws, h)\.. h)=, etc., Il. 14.20, Il. 21.137.

o(rma/w (o(rmh/), aor. w(/rmhsa, mid. ipf. w(rma=to, aor. w(rmh/sato, subj. o(rmh/swntai, pass. aor. w(rmh/qhn, o(rmhqh/thn: I. act., set in motion, impel, move; po/lemon, tina\ e)s po/lemon, s 376, Il. 6.338; pass. (met.), o(rmhqei\s qeou=, ‘inspired of heaven,’ Od. 8.499; intrans., start, rush; tino/s, ‘at one,’ Il. 4.335; w. inf., Il. 21.265 (cf. Il. 22.194), Il. 13.64.—II. mid., be moved, set out, start, rush, esp. in hostile sense, charge upon; e)/gxei+, cife/essi, Il. 5.855, Il. 17.530; tino/s, ‘at one,’ Il. 14.488; freq. w. inf., and met., h)=tor w(rma=to polemi/zein, Il. 21.572.
*)ormeni/dhs: son of Ormenus.—(1) Amyntor, Il. 9.448.—(2) Ctesius, Od. 15.414.
*)orme/nion: a town in Magnesia, Il. 2.734†.
*)/ormenos: (1) a Trojan slain by Teucer, Il. 8.274.—(2) a Trojan slain by Polypoetes, Il. 12.187.—(3) and (4), see *)ormeni/dhs.
o)/rmenos: see o)/rnu=mi.

o(rmh/: start, impetus, rush, attack, effort; of things as well as persons, ku=/matos, puro/s, e)s o(rmh\n e)/gxeos e)lqei=n, within the ‘cast’ of a spear, Il. 5.118; ‘departure,’ Od. 2.403 ; e)mh\n o(rmh/n, ‘prompting from me,’ Il. 10.123.
o(/rmhma, atos (o(rma/w): pl., met., struggles, i. e. agonies and sorrows, Il. 2.356†.
o(rmi/zw, aor. w(rmi/samen, subj. o(rmi/ssomen: bring to anchor, moor, nh=a.
o(/rmos (1): anchorage, mooring-place.
o(/rmos (2) (root ser, ei)/rw): necklace. (See cut, also Nos. 40, 41.)
*)orneiai/: Orneae, a town in Argolis, Il. 2.571†.
o)/rneon: bird, Il. 13.64†.
o)/rni=s, i=qos, pl. dat. o)rni/qessi: bird, freq. w. specific name added, o)/rni=sin e)oiko/tes ai)gupioi=sin, *h 59, Od. 5.51; then like oi)wno/s, bird of omen, Il. 24.219.

o)/rnu=mi, o)rnu/w, inf. o)rnu/men(ai), ipf. w)/rnuon, fut. o)/rsomen, part. o)/rsousa, aor. w)=rsa, iter. o)/rsaske, aor. 2 w)/rore(n), perf. o)/rwren, subj. o)rw/rh|, plup. o)rw/rei (see also o)/romai), w)rw/rei, mid. o)/rnumai, o)/rnutai, ipf. w)/rnuto, fut. o)rei=tai, aor. w)/reto, w)=rto, o)/ronto, subj. o)/rhtai, opt. o)/roito, imp. o)/rso, o)/rseo, o)/rsen, inf. o)/rqai, part. o)/rmenos, perf. o)rw/retai, subj. o)rw/rhtai: I. trans. (act., exc. perf.), arouse, awake, excite; la=ou/s, ai)=gas, nebro\n e)c eu)nh=s, Il. 15.475, i 154, Il. 22.190; freq. of the mind, Il. 5.105, Od. 4.712; w. inf., Il. 12.142, Od. 23.222 ; go/on,
fo/bon, sqe/nos, Il. 2.451; so of things, a)/nemon, ku=/mata, etc.—II. intrans. (mid., and perf.), rouse oneself, arise, spring up, w. inf., Od. 2.397, part., Od. 8.342; in hostile sense, xalkw=|, Il. 3.349; freq. of ‘beginning’ to do something, Il. 12.279, Od. 8.539 ; ei)so/ke moi fi/la gou/nat' o)rw/rh|, ‘have strength to move.’
o)roqu=/nw, aor. imp. o)ro/qu=non=o)/rnu=mi, e)nau/lous, ‘cause all the river-beds to swell,’ Il. 21.312.
o)/romai (root vor, o(ra/w), o)/rontai, ipf. o)/ronto, plup. o)rw/rei: keep watch or ward, e)pi\ (adv., ‘over’) d' a=)nh\r e)sqlo\s o)rw/rei, Il. 23.112, c 104, Od. 3.471.
o)/ros, ou)=ros, eos, pl. dat. o)/resfi: mountain.
o)ro/s: whey, Od. 9.222 and Od. 17.225.
o)rou/w (o)/rnu=mi), aor. o)/rousa: rush, spring; of persons and things, ai)xmh/, a)/nemoi d' e)k (‘forth’) pa/ntes o)/rousan, e)k klh=ros o)/rousen, Il. 3.325.
o)rofh/ (e)re/fw): roof, ceiling, Od. 22.298†.
o)/rofos (e)re/fw): reeds for thatching, Il. 24.451†.
o(ro/w: see o(ra/w.
o(/rphc, hkos: shoot, sapling, pl., Il. 21.38†.
o)/rs), o)/rseo, o)/rseu, o)/rsa=s, o)/rsaske: see o)/rnu=mi.

*)orsi/loxos: Orsilochus.—(1) son of Alpheius, Il. 5.547,=*)orti/loxos, father of Diocles, Od. 3.489, Od. 15.187, cf. Od. 21.16.—(2) son of Diocles from Pherae, grandson of the foregoing, Il. 5.549.—(3) a Trojan, slain by Teucer, Il. 8.274.—(4) a fabled son of Idomeneus, Od. 13.260.

o)rso - qu/rh (o)/rros): back door, in the side wall of the men's hall (me/garon) of the house of Odysseus, leading into the passage (lau/rh), Od. 22.126, 132, 333. (See cut No. 83, and plate III., h, at end of vol.)
*)orti/loxos: see *)orsi/loxos (1).
*)ortugi/h (o)/rtuc): Ortygia (‘Quailland’), a fabulous place, Od. 15.404, Od. 5.123.
o)rukto/s (o)ru/ssw): dug. (Il.)

o)rumagdo/s: loud noise, din, crash; often of crowds of men, esp. in battle, Od. 24.70, Il. 2.810, Il. 17.740, Od. 9.133; also of trees felled, wood thrown down, a torrent, stones, Il. 16.633, Od. 9.235, Il. 21.256, 313.
o)ru/ssw, inf. o)ru/ssein, aor. o)/ruca: dig, dig up, Od. 10.305.
o)rfaniko/s: bereft, orphaned, father- less; h)=mar, ‘day of orphanhood,’ the day that makes one an orphan, Il. 22.490.
o)rfano/s: bereft, orphaned; o)rfanai/, as ‘orphans,’ Od. 20.68†.
o)rfnai=os (o)/rfnh, e)/rebos): dark, gloomy, murky, nu/c. (Il. and Od. 9.143.)
o)/rxamos (a)/rxw): the first of a row, leader, chief; always w. a)ndrw=n or la=w=n, said of heroes, and of Eumaeus and Philoetius, Od. 14.22, Od. 20.185.
o)/rxatos (o)/rxos): trees planted in rows, orchard. (The resemblance between the Eng. and Greek words is accidental.)
o)rxe/omai, ipf. du. w)rxei/sqhn, 3 pl. w)rxeu=nto, aor. inf. o)rxh/sasqai: dance.
o)rxhqmo/s: dancing, choral dance.
o)rxhsth/r, h=ros, and o)rxhsth/s: dancer.
o)rxhstu/s, u/os, dat. -ui=: dancing, dance.
*)orxomeno/s: Orchomenus.—(1) *minu/eios, Minyian, a very ancient city on Lake Copāis in Boeotia, seat of the treasure - house of Minyas, Il. 2.511, Od. 11.284.—(2) a city in Arcadia, Il. 2.605.
o)/rxos: row of vines, Od. 7.127 and Od. 24.341.
o)/rwre, o)rw/retai: see o)/rnu=mi.
o)rw/rei: see (1) o)/rnu=mi.—(2) o)/romai.
o)rwre/xatai, o)rwre/xato: see o)re/gnu=mi.

o(/s, h(/, o(/ (1), gen. o(/ou (o(/o), Il. 2.325, Od. 1.70, e(/hs, pl. dat. h(=|s(in): demonstrative and relative pronoun.—(1) dem., he, this, that; o(/s (as antecedent to o(/ntina), Il. 6.59 ; o(/, Il. 12.344; and so both forms elsewhere.—(2) rel., who, that, which. The rel. pron. in Homer is either definite or conditional (see a)/n, ke/n), and exhibits in the main the same peculiarities as regards position, agreement (attraction, assimilation), and syntactical construction as in prose. To express purpose it is not foll. by <*> ut. ind. as in Att., but by the su<*>ith or without ke/, or by a potentia <*>tative, Il. 3.287, Od. 15.311, Il. 1.64 .—o(/, con <*>e quod (o(/ti), that, Il. 18.197, Od. 4.206, etc.

o(/s, h(/, o(/n (2) (svo/s, cf. suus), gen. oi(=o (voi=o), dat. h(=fi, Il. 22.107, see e(o/s: poss. pron. of the third person, own, (his) own, (her) own; placed before or after the subst., with or without article, qugate/ra svh/n, ta\ va\ kh=la, *m
280; the word is not always directly reflexive, Od. 1.218, Od. 9.369, etc. Some passages in which o(/s appears to be of the 1st or 2d pers. are doubtful as regards the text.
o(si/h: divine or natural right, ou)x o(si/h, w. inf. (non fas est), ‘it is contrary to divine law.’ (Od.)

o(/sos, o(/ssos: how great, how much, pl. how many, w. to/ssos expressed or implied as antec., (as great) as, (as much) as, pl. (as many) as (quantus, quot); very often the appropriate form of pa=s precedes (or is implied) as antecedent, *trw/wn o(/ssoi a)/ristoi, all the bravest of the Trojans, Il. 12.13, Il. 2.125, Od. 11.388, etc.—Neut. as adv., o(/son, o(/sson, o(/son e)/pi, o(/sson t' e)/pi, as far as, Il. 2.616, Il. 23.251 ; o(/son e)s *skaia=\s pu/la=s, ‘only as far as,’ Il. 9.354; so o(/son te, ‘about,’ Od. 9.322; w. comp. and sup., ‘by how much,’ ‘how far,’ Il. 9.160, Il. 1.516.
o(/sper (o(/per, Il. 7.114), h(/per, o(/per: just who (which), who (which) however, Il. 2.286; adv., h(=|per, just where (whither), just as. See pe/r.
o)/ssa (root vep, cf. vox): rumor.— Personified, *)/ossa, daughter of Zeus, Il. 2.93, Od. 24.413.
*)/ossa: Ossa, a mountain in Thessaly, Od. 11.315.
o(/ssa: see o(/sos.
o(ssa/ki: as often as.
o(ssa/tios: how great, Il. 5.758†.
o)/sse (root o)p, cf. oculus), du.: the (two) eyes, with attributes in du. or pl., and verb in all three numbers.

o)/ssomai (o)/sse), ipf. o)/sseto, o)/ssonto: see, esp. in spirit, ‘with the mind's eye,’ forebode, Od. 20.81, Od. 10.374, Il. 18.224; causative, give to foresee, forebode, threaten, Od. 2.112, Il. 14.17.
o(/ssos: see o(/sos.
o(/ste (o(/ te, Od. 12.40, etc.), h(/te, o(/ te: rel. pron., rarely to be distinguished in translating from the simple word. See te/.
o)ste/on, pl. gen. and dat. o)steo/fin: bone.

o(/stis, h(/tis, o(/ ti (o(/ tti), gen. ou(=tinos, h(=stinos, and o(/t teo, o(/(t)teu, dat. o(/tew|, acc. o(/tina, pl. neut. o(/tina, a(/ssa, gen. o(/tewn, dat. o(te/oisi, acc. o(/tinas: who(so)ever, which(so)ever, what(so)ever, both relative and indirect interrogative; cei=nos o(/d), ou)k oi)=d' o(/stis, ‘unknown to me,’ Od. 8.28. See o(/ti.
o(/ti):=(1) o(/te.—(2) o(/ te, i. e. o(/ti te. Never=o(/ti, which does not suffer elision.
o(/tan:=o(/t' a)/n, see o(/te and a)/n.
o(/ te: see o(/ste.

o(/te: when, since.—(1) temporal, w. the same constructions as other relative words, see a)/n, ke/n. Freq. in similes, w(s d' o(/te, w(s d) o(t) a)/n, and without verb, w(s o(/te, just like; there is nothing peculiar in such a usage.—(2) less often causal, Il. 1.244.
o(te/: regularly found in correlation, o(te\ me\n.. o(te\ de/, now.. now; a)/llote (me/n or de/) may replace one of the terms, now (at one time).. at another, Il. 20.49, Il. 11.566.
o(te/oisi, o(/teu, o(/tew|: see o(/stis.
o(/ti, o(/tti (neut. of o(/stis): (1) conj., that because (quod).—(2) adv., strengthening superlatives, o(/tti ta/xista, as quickly as possible, Il. 4.193.
o(/ ti, o(/ tti: see o(/stis.
o)trale/ws (cf. o)trhro/s): busily, nimbly, quickly.
*)otreu/s: son of Dymas, king of Phrygia, Il. 3.186†.
o)trhro/s (cf. o)trale/ws): busy, nimble, ready.
o)/-trixes (qri/c), pl.: with like hair, like-colored, Il. 2.765†.
*)otruntei/dhs: son of Otrynteus, Iphition, Il. 20.383, 389.
*)otrunteu/s: king of Hydē, Il. 20.384.
o)truntu/s, u/os (o)tru=/nw): encouragement. (Il.)

o)tru=/nw, inf. o)tru=ne/men, ipf. iter. o)tru=/neskon, fut. o)trune/w, aor. w)/tru=na, subj. o)tru=/nh|si, inf. o)tru=nai: urge on, send forth, hasten, speed, encourage, mid., make haste, mostly foll. by inf., in both act. and mid., Od. 10.425; the obj. is usually a person, rarely animals or things, i(/ppous, ku/nas, o)do/n tini, Od. 2.253.
o(/tti: see o(/ti.
o(/ tti: see o(/stis.

ou), ou)xi/, ou)ki/ (q. v.), before vowels ou)k, or, if aspirated, ou)x: not, no, the adv. of objective negation, see mh/. ou) may be used w. the inf. in indirect discourse, Il. 17.174; in a condition, when the neg. applies to a single word or phrase and not to the whole clause,
ei) de/ toi ou) dw/sei, ‘shall fail to grant,’ Il. 24.296 . ou) (like nonne) is found in questions that expect an affirmative answer. ou)/ti, ‘not a whit,’ ‘not at all,’ ‘by no means,’ so ou) pa/mpan, ou) pa/gxu, etc. ou) may be doubled for emphasis, Od. 3.27 f.

ou(= (sv., cf. sui), dat. oi(=, acc. e(/, other forms, gen. eu(=, ei(=o, e(/o, e(/qen, dat. e(oi=, acc. e(e/: (1) simple personal pron. of 3d pers., (of, to) him, her, rarely it, Il. 1.236; in this sense enclitic, except e(e/. —(2) reflexive pron., not enclitic, (of, to) himself, herself (itself), Od. 7.217; usually with au)tw=|, au)th=|, au)to/n, au)th/n, d 38, Il. 14.162.
ou)/asi, ou)/ata: see ou)=s.
ou)=das, eos: ground, earth, floor, Od. 23.46 ; a)/speton ou)=das, see a)/spetos. o)da\c e(lei=n, see o)da/c.—ou)=da/sde, to the ground.

ou)de/: (but not), and not, nor, not even; never a correlative word, but always (except when meaning ‘but not’) adding a new negation after a previous one expressed or implied; if ou)de/ occurs at the beginning of several successive clauses, the first one refers to some previous negation just as much as the 2d or the 3d, *thle/max), ou)d' o)/piqen kako\s e)/sseai ou)d) a)noh/mwn, not even in the future, i. e. even as not in the past, Od. 2.270 . ou)de\ ga\r ou)de/, doubled for emphasis, no, not at all, Il. 5.22, etc. (When the meaning is ‘but not,’ it would be well to write ou) de/ separately, as this usage is essentially different from the other one. See mhde/.)
ou)dei/s, ou)de/n: no one, nothing, in Homer only the neut. as adv., and the dat. masc., to\ o(\n me/nos ou)deni\ ei)/kwn, *x 459, Od. 11.515.
ou)deno/s - wros (w)/ra=): not to be regarded, worthy of no notice, Il. 8.178†.
ou)de/ph|: in no way, by no means.
ou)de/pote: never.
ou)de/pw: not yet, not at all.
ou)dete/rwse: in neither direction, Il. 14.18†.
ou)do/s (1): threshold; fig., gh/raos, ‘threshold of old age,’ a poetic periphrasis for old age itself (of course not meaning the ‘beginning’ of old age), Od. 15.246, 348.
ou)do/s (2): see o(do/s.
ou)=qar, atos: udder; met., a)rou/rhs, of fat land, Il. 9.141.
ou)k: see ou).
*ou)kale/gwn: Ucalegon, a Trojan elder, Il. 3.148†.
ou)k-e/ti: no longer, no more.
ou)ki/:=ou)/k, only kai\ ou)ki/ at the close of a verse and a sentence.
ou)lai/: barley-corns, roasted, mixed with salt and sprinkled between the horns of the victim to be sacrificed, Od. 3.441†.
ou)lamo/s (ei)/lw): a)ndrw=n, dense throng, crowd of men. (Il.)
ou)=le (cf. ou)=lo Od. 18.1): imp. (salve), hail! Od. 24.402†.
ou)lh/: scar. (Od.)
ou)/lios (ou)=lo Od. 18.3): baleful, deadly, Il. 11.62†.
ou)lo-ka/rhnos (ou)=lo Od. 18.2): with thick, curly hair, Od. 19.246†.
ou)lo/menos (o)/llu=mi): accursed, cursed, properly designating that upon which the imprecation o)/loio has been pronounced.
ou)=los (1) (Att. o(/los): whole, Od. 17.343 and Od. 24.118.
ou)=los (2): thick, woolly, woollen; of fabrics and of hair; fig., of the cry of many voices; neut. as adv., ou)=lon, loudly, incessantly, Il. 17.756.
ou)=los (3) (o)loo/s, o)/llu=mi): destructive, murderous, Il. 5.461; baneful Dream, Il. 2.6, 8.

ou)lo/-xutai (ou)lai/, xe/w): sprinkled barley, poured or scattered from baskets, Od. 4.761 ; ou)loxu/ta=s kata/rxesqai, to begin the solemn rites by sprinkling the barley between the horns of the victim, Od. 3.445, Il. 1.458.
*ou)/lumpos: see *)/olumpos.
ou(mo/s =o( e)mo/s, Il. 8.360†.

ou)=n: inferential or resumptive particle, now, then, in Homer regularly found in connection with some other particle, ga\r ou)=n, e)pei\ ou)=n, w(s ou)=n, me\n ou)=n, and as in the 1st or 2d of a pair of correlative clauses, ou)/t' ou)=n.. ou)/te, Od. 1.414; ei)/ g) ou)=n e(/tero/s ge fu/gh|sin, if ‘for that matter,’ etc., Il. 5.258. The various shades of meaning assumed by ou)=n must be learned from the context of the passages in which it occurs.

ou(/neka (ou(= e(/neka): (1) wherefore, (quamobrem), corresponding to tou)/-
neka, Il. 3.403.—(2) because, Il. 1.11, Od. 4.569. —(3) that, like o(/ti. (Od.)
ou)/nesqe: v. l. for o)no/sasqe, see o)/nomai.
ou)/noma: see o)/noma.
ou)/per: not at all.
ou)/ph|: nowhere, in no way.
ou)/poqe: nowhere.
ou)/pote: never.
ou)/pw: not yet, by no means.
ou)/pws: nohow, on no terms.
ou)=ra: see ou)=ron.
ou)rai=os (ou)rh/): of the tail; tri/xes, Il. 23.520†.
ou)rani/wn, wnos: heavenly; as subst., *ou)rani/wnes, the Celestials, i. e. the gods, Il. 5.373, 898.
ou)rano/qen: from heaven; also with e)c and a)po/, *q 19, Il. 21.199.
ou)rano/qi: in the heavens (see pro/), Il. 3.3†.
ou)rano - mh/khs (mh=kos): high as heaven, Od. 5.239†.

ou)rano/s: heaven, i. e. the skies, above and beyond the ai)qh/r, Il. 2.458; and penetrated by the peaks of Mt. Olympus, the home of the gods, hence (qeoi\ a)qanatoi\) toi\ ou)rano\n eu)ru\n e)/xousin, Od. 1.67, etc. The epithets xa/lkeos, sidh/reos, etc., are figurative, Il. 17.425, Od. 15.329.
ou)/rea: see o)/ros.
ou)reu/s, h=os (o)/ros): mule, as mountain animal, cf. h(mi/onos. [For ou)=ro Od. 18.3, in Il. 10.84.] (Il.)
ou)rh/: tail.
ou)ri/axos: butt end of a spear. (Il.) (See cut under a)mfi/guos.)
ou)=ron (cf. o)/rnu=mi): range, stretch; of the extent of a discus - throw (cf. di/skoura), Il. 23.431, and of a furrow's length, as ploughed by mules, Il. 10.351, Od. 8.124.
ou)=ros (1): fair wind (secundus ventus), i)/kmenos, ka/llimos, a)ph/mwn, ligu/s, *dio\s ou)=ros.
ou)=ros (2) (Att. o(/ros): land - mark, boundary. (Il.)
ou)=ros (3) (root vor, o(ra/w): guard, watch, warder; often of Nestor, ou)=ros *)axaiw=n.
ou)=ros (4): see o)/ros.
ou)ro/s (o)ru/ssw): ditch, channel, serving as ways for ships in drawing them down into the sea, Il. 2.153†.
ou)=s, gen. ou)/atos, pl. dat. w)si/n: ear; a)p' ou)/atos, ‘far from the ear,’ i. e. unheard, Il. 18.272, Il. 22.445; of the handles of a tankard, Il. 11.633.

ou)ta/zw, ou)ta/w, ou)/thmi, imp. ou)/tae, ipf. ou)/tazon, aor. ou)/tasa, ou)/thsa, iter. ou)th/saske, aor. 2 ou)=ta, iter. ou)/taske, inf. ou)ta/men(ai), pass. ipf. ou)ta/zonto, perf. ou)/tastai, part. ou)tasme/nos and, with irreg. accent, ou)ta/menos: stab, wound by cutting or thrusting (au)tosxedi/hn, au)tosxedo/n), thus opp. to ba/llein, hit with a missile, Il. 11.659, 826; e(/lkos, ‘inflict’ a wound, Il. 5.361; hence ou)tame/nh w)teilh/, *c 518, Il. 17.86.

ou)/te: negative particle, regularly correlative, ou)/te.. ou)/te, neither.. nor, (not) either.. or, dividing a negation already expressed or implied; but the correlation is often irregular as a different word (te/, kai/, de/) replaces one or the other ou)/te, e. g. Il. 6.450, Od. 8.563, Il. 24.156, Il. 7.433.
ou)th/saske: see ou)ta/zw.
ou)/ti: see ou)/tis.
ou)tidano/s: good-for-nothing, worthless, only of persons.
ou)/tis, ou)/ti: no one, not anything; the neut. as adv., not at all, by no means.
*ou)=tis: Noman, a feigned name assumed by Odysseus to delude the Cyclōpes. (i)
ou)/toi: certainly not.

ou(=tos, au(/th, tou=to: demonstrative pronoun, this, (he), sometimes however to be translated that, as when it anticipates a following relative, Od. 6.201 f. Sometimes deictic and local, ‘here’ like o(/de, Il. 10.82, 341, Il. 11.612. The article, required with ou(=tos in prose, occurs in Homer once, tou=ton to\n a)/nalton, Od. 18.114.
ou(/tw(s): this way, thus, so, adv. answering to the usage of ou(=tos. In wishes, ‘so surely (as),’ Il. 13.825.
ou)/x, ou)xi/: see ou).

o)fei/lw, o)fe/llw, ipf. o)/feilon, w)/fellon, o)/fellon, aor. 2 o)/felon, w)/feles, pass. o)fei/letai, ipf. o)fei/leto: owe, ought; xrei=os o)/feilon, ‘they were owing’ a debt; pass. xrei=os o)fei/letai/ moi, ‘is due’ me, Il. 11.688, 686, Od. 3.367; then of obligation (ipf. and aor. 2), ti=mh/n pe/r moi o)/fellen *)olu/mpios e)gguali/cai, honor at all events ‘he ought to have bestowed’ upon me, Il. 1.353;
hence the use in wishes impossible of realization (past or present), explained in the grammars, ai)/q' o)/feles para\ nhusi\n a)da/kru=tos kai\ a)ph/mwn | h(=sqai, ‘would that thou wert sitting, etc.,’ Il. 1.415.
*)ofele/sths: (1) a Trojan, slain by Teucer, Il. 8.274.—(2) a Paeonian, slain by Achilles, Il. 21.210.
o)fe/llw (1): see o)fei/lw.

o)fe/llw (2), ipf. w)/fellon, o)/felle(n), aor. opt. o)fe/lleien, pass. ipf. o)fe/lleto: augment, increase; oi)=kon, oi)=kos, o)fe/lleto, in riches, Od. 15.21, Od. 14.233 ; mu=qon, ‘multiply words,’ Il. 16.631.
o)/felos, eos: advantage, profit; w. neg., ‘no good,’ Il. 22.513. (Il.)
*)ofe/ltios: (1) a Greek, slain by Hector, Il. 11.302.—(2) a Trojan, slain by Euryalus, Il. 6.20.
o)fqalmo/s (root o)p, cf. oculus): eye; freq., (e)n) o)fqalmoi=sin o(ra=sqai, ‘see with one's eyes’; e)s o)fqalmou\s e)lqei=n, ‘into one's sight,’ Il. 24.204.
o)/fis, ios: snake, serpent, Il. 12.208†.

o)/fra: while, until, in order that.— (1) temporal; once as adv., for a while, some time; o)/fra me/n, Il. 15.547; elsewhere conj., as long as, while, freq. w. correl. to/fra, Il. 4.220; then until, with ref. to the past or the fut., and with the appropriate constructions, Il. 5.557, Il. 1.82.—(2) final conj., in order that, that, Il. 1.147, Od. 1.85, Od. 24.334.
o)fruo/eis, essa, en (o)fru=/s): with beetling brows, beetling, Il. 22.411†.
o)fru=/s, u/os, pl. acc. o)fru=s: brow, Il. 9.620; fig., of a hill, Il. 20.151.
o)/xa (cf. e)/coxa): by far, always o)/x' a)/ristos.
o)/xesfi: see o)/xos.
o)/xet-hgo/s (a)/gw): laying out a ditch, Il. 21.257†.
o)xeu/s, h=os (e)/xw): holder; the chinstrap of a helmet, Il. 3.372; clasps on a belt, Il. 4.132; bolt of a door, Il. 12.121. (See cut No. 29.)

o)xe/w (root vex, cf. veho), ipf. iter. o)xe/eskon, pass. pr. inf. o)xe/esqai, ipf. o)xei=to, mid. fut. o)xh/sontai, aor. o)xh/sato: bear, endure, mo/ron, a=)/thn; fig., nhpia/a=s o)xe/ein, ‘put up with,’ ‘be willing to exhibit,’ Od. 1.297; pass. and mid., be borne, ride, sail, Il. 17.77, Od. 5.54.
*)oxh/sios: an Aetolian, father of Periphas, Il. 5.843.
o)xqe/w, aor. w)/xqhsan: be moved with indignation, grief, anger, be vexed, Il. 1.570, Il. 15.101; usually the part., o)xqh/sa=s.
o)/xqh (e)/xw): bank of a river, the sea, a trench, Il. 15.356; mostly pl., sing., Il. 21.17, 171 f.
o)xle/w (o)xlo/s): only pass., o)xleu=ntai, are swept away, Il. 21.261†.
o)xli/zw (o)xlo/s): only aor. opt., o)xli/sseian, would heave from its place, raise, Il. 12.448, Od. 9.242.
o)/xos (1), eos (root vex, cf. veho), pl. dat. o)xe/essin and o)/xesfin: only pl., car, chariot.
o)/xos (2) (e)/xw): only pl., nhw=n o)/xoi, places of shelter for ships, Od. 5.404†.
o)/y, o)po/s (vo/y, root vep): voice, properly the human voice with its varied expressiveness; then applied to the cicada, lambs, Il. 3.152, Il. 4.435.
o)ye/ (cf. o)/pisqe): late, long afterward, in the evening, Il. 4.161, Il. 21.232, Od. 5.272.
o)yei/w (o)/yomai): only part., o)yei/ontes, desiring to see, Il. 14.37.
o)yi/ - gonos: late - born, born afterward, posterity.
o)/yimos: late, Il. 2.325†.
o)/yis, ios (root o)p): power of sight; o)/yei+ i)dei<*>=n, ‘with one's eyes,’ Il. 20.205, Od. 23.94; appearance, looks, Il. 6.468, Il. 24.632.
o)yi - te/lestos: late - fulfilled, Il. 2.325†.
o)/yomai: see o(ra/w.
o)/yon (e(/yw): properly that which is cooked (boiled), said of anything that is eaten with bread, relish, sauce, of an onion as a relish with wine, Il. 11.630; of meat, Od. 3.480.

div1.head: *p
div1.entryFree: pa/gen, pa/gh: see ph/gnu=mi.
pa/gos (phgnu=mi): pl., cliffs, Od. 5.405 and 411.
pag-xa/lkeos and pa/gxalkos: all of bronze; fig., of a man, Il. 20.102.
pag-xru=/seos: all of gold, Il. 2.448†.
pa/gxu: altogether, entirely; w. ma/la, li=/hn, Il. 14.143, c 367, Od. 4.825.
pa/qe, paqe/ein: see pa/sxw.
paidno/s (pai=s): of childish age, a lad, Od. 21.21 and Od. 24.338.
paido - fo/nos: slayer of one's children, Il. 24.506†.
pai/zw (pai=s), ipf. pai/zomen, aor. imp. pai/sate: play (as a child); of dancing, Od. 8.251; a game at ball, Od. 6.100.
*paih/wn, onos: Paean, the physician of the gods, Il. 5.401, 899; from him the Egyptian physicians traced their descent, Od. 4.232.
paih/wn, onos: paean, song of triumph or thanksgiving (addressed to Apollo), Il. 1.473, Il. 22.391.
*pai/wn, onos: Paeonian, pl. the Paeonians, a tribe in Macedonia and Thrace, on the river Axius, allies of the Trojans, Il. 10.428, Il. 16.287, 291, Il. 21.155.
*paioni/dhs: son of Paeon, Agastrophus, Il. 11.339, 368.
*paioni/h: Paeonia (see *pai/wn), Il. 17.350, Il. 21.154.
paipalo/eis, essa, en: doubtful word, rugged, rough, epith. of mountains and roads.
pai=s or pa/i+s, paido/s, voc. pa/i+: child, boy or girl, hence sometimes son, daughter; as adj., Il. 21.282.
*paiso/s: a town on the Propontis (see *)apaiso/s), Il. 5.612.
paifa/ssw: only part., paifa/ssousa, darting gleams, ‘like lightning,’ Il. 2.450†.
pa/lai: long ago, long, all along.
palai-genh/s, e/s: ancient - born, full of years.
palaio/s, comp. palai/teros a d -o/teros: ancient, old, aged.
palaismosu/nh (palai/w): wrestling, wrestling-match.
palaisth/s (palai/w): wrestler, pl., Od. 8.246†.
palai/-fatos (fhmi/): uttered long ago; qe/sfata, Od. 9.507, Od. 13.172; druo/s, ‘of ancient fable,’ Od. 19.163.
palai/w (pa/lh), fut. palai/seis, aor. e)pa/laisen: wrestle.
pala/mh: palm of the hand, hand.

pala/ssw (cf. pa/llw), fut. inf. palace/men, pass. perf. part. pepalagme/nos, plup. pepa/lakto, also mid., perf. imp. pepa/laxqe, inf. pepala/xqai (or -asqe, -a/sqai): sprinkle, hence stain, defile; ai(/mati, i(drw=|, n 395, Od. 22.402, 184; mid. (perf. w. pres. signif.), ‘select among themselves by lot,’ the lots being shaken in a helmet, Il. 7.171 and Od. 9.331.
pa/lh: wrestling, Il. 23.635 and Od. 8.206.
pali/l-logos (pa/lin, le/gw): gathered together again, Il. 1.126†.
palim-peth/s, e/s (pi=/ptw): neut. as adv., (falling) back again, back, Il. 16.395, Od. 5.27.
palim-pla/zomai (pla/zw), aor. part. palimplagxqei/s: be driven vainly (drifting) back, Od. 13.5, Il. 1.59.
palin-a/gretos (a)gre/w=ai(re/w): to be taken back, revocable, Il. 1.526†.
palin - o/rmenos: rushing back, Il. 11.326†. Better written as two words.
pali/n - orsos (o)/rnu=mi): springing back, recoiling, Il. 3.33†.
pali/n - titos (ti=/nw): paid back, avenged; e)/rga, ‘works of retribution,’ Od. 1.379 and Od. 2.144.
pali/n - tonos (tei/nw): stretched or bending back, ‘elastic,’ epith. of the bow.
palirro/qios (r(o/qos): surging back, refluent, Od. 5.430 and Od. 9.485.
pali=/wcis (i)/wcis, diw/kw): pursuit back again, rally. (Il.)
pallaki/s, i/dos: concubine.
*palla/s, a/dos: Pallas Athena, an epithet explained by the ancients as from pa/llw, i. e. she who ‘brandishes,’ the spear and the aegis.

pa/llw, aor. 1 ph=le, inf. ph=lai, mid. aor. 2 pa/lto, pass. pres. pa/lletai, part. pallo/menos: act. brandish, swing, shake lots (klh/rous), Il. 3.316, 324, and without klh/rous, *h 181, Il. 23.353; mid., brandish or hurl for oneself, cast lot for oneself (or, of several, among one another), Il. 15.191, Il. 24.400 ; e)n a)spi/dos a)/ntugi pa/lto, ‘struck,’ ‘stumbled’ against the rim, Il. 15.645; fig., of the heart, ‘throb,’ ‘palpitate,’ Il. 22.452, 461.
*palmu/s: a Trojan chief, Il. 13.792.
pa/lto: see pa/llw.
palu=/nw, ipf. (e))pa/lu=ne, aor. part. palu=/na=s: strew, sprinkle; a)/lfita, a)lfi/tou a)kth=| ti, Od. 14.429; of snow, Il. 10.7.
pam-me/la=s, aina, an: all black, jet black. (Od.)
*pa/mmwn: a son of Priam, Il. 24.250†.
pa/mpan: altogether, entirely; with neg., not at all, ‘by no means.’
pam - poi/kilos: all variegated, embroidered all over, Il. 6.289 and Od. 15.105.
pa/m-prwtos: very first, first of all; adv., pa/mprwton (Od.), pa/mprwta (Il.)
pamfai/nw (redup. from fai/nw), subj. pamfai/nh|si, ipf. pa/mfainon: shine or gleam brightly; sth/qesi, ‘with white shining breasts’ (bare), Il. 11.100.
pamfano/wn, wsa: variant form of present partic. from pamfai/nw, q. v.
pa/n - agros (a)gre/w=ai(re/w): alltaking, all-catching, Il. 5.487†.
pa/n-aiqos (ai)/qw): all-glowing, burnished, Il. 14.372†.
pan-ai/olos: all-gleaming, glancing. (Il.)
pan - a/palos: all-tender, delicate, Od. 13.223.
pan-a/-potmos: all - hapless, Il. 24.255 and 493.
pan-a/rguros: all of silver, solid silver, Od. 9.203 and Od. 24.275.
pan-af-h=lic, ikos: deprived of all playmates, Il. 22.490†.
*pan-axaioi/: all the Achaeans, ‘the Pan-achaean host.’
pan-a-w/rios (w(/rh): all - untimely, ‘to die an untimely death,’ Il. 24.540†.
pan - dama/twr: all - subduing, Il. 24.5 and Od. 9.373.
*panda/reos: Pandareüs, a friend of Tantalus, father of Aē¨don and other daughters, Od. 19.518, Od. 20.66.
*pa/ndaros: Pandarus, the Lycian archer, who by an arrow-shot violates the truce between Trojans and Greeks, and is afterwards slain by Diomed, Il. 2.827, Il. 4.88, Il. 5.168, 171, 294, 795.
pan - dh/mios: belonging to all the people (the town), public, common, Od. 18.1†.
*pandi=/wn: a Greek, Il. 12.372†.
*pa/ndokos: a Trojan, wounded by Ajax, Il. 11.490†.
*pan-e/llhnes: the Panhellēnes, the united Greeks, Il. 2.530.
pan-h=mar: adv., all day long, Od. 13.31†.
pan - hme/rios: all day long, from morn till eve.
*panqoi/dhs: son of Panthoüs.—(1) Euphorbus, Il. 17.70.—(2) Polydamas, Il. 14.454.
*pa/nqoos: Panthous, son of Othrys, father of Euphorbus and Polydamas, a priest of Apollo at Delphi, afterward a priest and an elder at Troy, Il. 3.146, Il. 17.9, 23, 40, 59, Il. 15.522.
pan-qu=mado/n: all in wrath, in full wrath, Od. 18.33†.
pan-nu/xios and pa/nnuxos: all night long, the night through.
pan-omfai=os (o)mfh/): author of all omens, all-disclosing, Il. 8.250†.
*panopeu/s: (1) a Greek, the father Epeius, Il. 23.665.—(2) a city in Phocis, on the Cephissus, Il. 2.520, Il. 17.307, Od. 11.581.
*pano/ph: a Nereid, Il. 18.45†.
pa/n-ormos: offering moorage at all points, ‘convenient for landing,’ Od. 13.195†.
pan-o/yios (o)/yis): before the eyes of all, Il. 21.397†.
pan-sudi/h| (seu/w): with all haste.
pa/nth| or pa/nth: on all sides, in all directions.
pa/ntoqen: from every side.
pa/ntws: by all means, and w. neg. ‘by no means.’

pan - upe/rtatos: quite the highest,
i. e. above or farther off than the rest, Od. 9.25†.
pan-u/statos: the very last.
pappa/zw: say papa, call one father, Il. 5.408†.
pa/ppas, voc. pa/ppa: papa, father, Od. 6.57†.

paptai/nw, du. paptai/neton, aor. pa/pthne, part. papth/na=s: peer around, look about cautiously, look in quest of something, Il. 13.551, Od. 17.330, Il. 11.546, Il. 4.200 ; deino/n, ‘glancing terribly about him,’ Od. 11.608.
pa/r: (1) an abbreviated form of para/ before certain consonants.—(2) for pa/resti or pa/reisi, Il. 9.43, *a 174, Od. 3.325.

para/, parai/, pa/r: beside, by.—I. adv. (here belong all instances of the so - called ‘tmesis’), written pa/ra (‘anastrophe’) when placed after the verb it modifies, or when the verb is not expressed; e)ti/qei pa/ra pa=san e)dwdh/n, placed food ‘beside’ (we should say ‘before’) him, Od. 5.196 ; pa/r r() a)/kulon ba/len, threw ‘down,’ we should say, Od. 10.242 ; para/ m' h)/pafe dai/mwn, deceived and led me ‘astray’ (cf. our ‘beside oneself’), Od. 14.488. The relation of the adv. may be made more specific by the addition of an appropriate case of a subst. in the same sentence, thus showing the transition to the true prepositional usage, pa\r d' i)/san *)wkeanou= r(oa=/s (acc. of extent of space), Od. 24.11.—II. prep. (1) w. gen., from beside, from; fa/sganon para\ mhrou= e)ru/ssasqai, para/ tinos e)/rxesqai, often ‘from one's house,’ Il. 21.444; then to denote the giver, author, Od. 6.290, Il. 11.795.—(2) w. dat., of rest or position beside, but also where a certain amount of motion is meant, as with verbs of placing, sitting, falling, qei=nai, pesei=n para/ tini, *n 617, Od. 15.285; then of possession, keeping, pa\r keinoi=sin e)mo\n ge/ras, ‘in their hands,’ Od. 11.175.—(3) w. acc., to the side of, unto, along by, beyond, implying motion, though sometimes very faintly, Il. 1.463 ; tu/ye kata\ klhi=da par' au)xe/na, motion implied in the mere act of striking, Il. 21.117 ; bh=nai para\ qi<*>=na, ‘along the shore’; sth=nai para/ tina, ‘come and stand by one’; then the thought of over-passing, over-stepping, transgressing, pa\r du/namin, para\ moi=ran, ‘contrary to right,’ Od. 14.509.—As a prep. also pa/ra is written with anastrophe when standing after its case, unless there is elision, Od. 18.315.—In composition para/ has the meanings above given, but that of winning over (persuading from one side to the other), leading ‘astray,’ ‘amiss’ (also in good sense) by words, etc., is particularly to be noted.
para - bai/nw: only perf. part. parbebaw/s, -w=te, standing by one in the chariot. (Il.)
para - ba/llomai: only part. (fig.) risking, staking, Il. 9.322†.
para-ba/skw, ipf. pare/baske: stand beside one in the chariot (as paraiba/ths, q. v.), Il. 11.104†.
para - blh/dhn: with comparisons, insinuatingly, Il. 4.6.
para-blw/skw, perf. parme/mblwke: go (with help) to the side of, Il. 4.11 and Il. 24.73.
para - blw/y, wpos (parable/pw): looking askance, Il. 9.503†.
para - gi/gnomai: be present at, ipf., Od. 17.173†.
para - darqa/nw, aor. 2 pare/draqon, inf. paradraqe/ein: sleep beside, lie with.
para-de/xomai, aor. parede/cato: receive from, or ‘at the hands of,’ Il. 6.178†.
paradraqe/ein: see paradarqa/nw.
paradrame/thn: see paratre/xw.
para-dra/w, 3 pl. paradrw/wsi: perform in the service of; tini/, Od. 15.324†.
para - du/w, aor. inf. paradu=/menai: slip past, steal past, Il. 23.416†.
par - aei/dw: sing beside or before; tini/, Od. 22.348†.
par-aei/rw: only aor. pass., parhe/rqh, hung down, Il. 16.341†.
parai - ba/ths (bai/nw): one who stands beside the charioteer and fights, ‘chariot-fighter,’ pl., Il. 23.132†.
paraipepi/qh|si, -qw/n: see parapei/qw.
par-ai/sios (ai)=sa): unlucky, adverse, Il. 4.381†.
par-a=i=+/ssw, part. para=i+/ssontos, aor. parh/i=cen: dart by, spring by. (Il.)
paraifa/menos: see para/fhmi.
parai/-fasis: persuasion, encouragement, Il. 11.793 and Il. 15.404.
paraka/bbale: see the foll. word.
para-kata-ba/llw, aor. 2 paraka/bbalon: throw down beside one, ‘lay in one's reach,’ Il. 23.167 and 683.
para/ - keimai, ipf. pare/keito, iter. pareke/sketo: lie by or near, be placed or stand by or before, Od. 21.416, Od. 14.521; met., u(mi=n para/keitai, ‘ye have the choice,’ Od. 22.65.
para - klido/n (kli=/nw): adv., turning to one side, evasively, Od. 4.348 and Od. 17.139.
para-kli=/nw, aor. part. parakli=/na=s: incline to one side, turn aside, Il. 23.424, Od. 20.301.
para - koi/ths: bed - fellow, spouse, husband, Il. 6.430 and Il. 8.156.
para/-koitis, dat. parakoiti=: wife.
para - krema/nnu=mi, aor. part. parakrema/sa=s: let hang by the side or down, Il. 13.597†.
para - le/gomai, aor. parele/cato, subj. parale/comai: lie down to sleep beside, lie with.
para-me/nw, parme/nw, inf. parmene/men, aor. 1 pare/meine: remain with, stay by, hold out. (Il.)
para-mi/mnw:=parame/nw. (Od.)
para - mu=qe/omai (mu=qos), aor. opt. paramuqhsai/mhn: exhort, encourage; tini/, and w. inf. (Il.)
