pro-pro-kuli/ndomai: roll (as suppliant) before, *dio/s, Il. 22.221; ‘wander from place to place,’ Od. 17.525.
pro - re/w, prore/ei, -e/ousi, inf. -e/ein, part. -e/ontos: flow forth, flow on.
pro/ - rrizos (r(i/za): with the roots, ‘root and branch,’ Il. 11.157 and Il. 14.415.

pro/s, proti/, poti/: I. adv., thereto, in addition; pro\s d' a)/ra phda/lion poih/sato, ‘to it,’ ‘for it,’ Od. 5.255 ; poti\ d' au)= kai\ e)gei/romen a)/llous, besides, Il. 10.108; with a specifying case of a subst. in the same clause, poti\ de\ skh=ptron ba/le gai/h| (local gen.), threw it to (‘down,’ we should say) on the ground, Il. 1.245.—II. prep., (1) w. gen., with reference to motion either toward or from some direction, (i=(/keto) h)e\ pro\s h)oi/wn h)\ e(speri/wn a)nqrw/pwn, ‘from,’ Od. 8.29 ; proti\ pto/lios pe/tet' a=)ei/, ‘toward,’ Il. 22.198; as of origin, source, a)kou/ein ti pro/s tinos, Il. 6.525; hence to denote mastery, authority, dida/skesqai pro/s tinos, Il. 11.831; pro\s a)/llhs u(fai/nein, ‘at the command of,’ Il. 6.456 ; pro\s *dio/s ei)si cei=noi, ‘under the protection of,’ Od. 6.207; ‘in the eyes of,’ ‘before,’ ‘by,’ in oaths and entreaties, Il. 1.399, Il. 19.188, Od. 13.324.—(2) w. dat., to, at, on, besides, Od. 10.68.—(3) w. acc., to, toward, at, upon, with verbs of motion, and very freq. w. verbs of saying, so o)mnu/nai pro/s tina, Od. 14.331; of hostile action, ma/xesqai pro\s *trw=as, with, against, Il. 17.471 ; pro\s r(o/on, up stream, Il. 21.303; fig., pro\s dai/mona, Il. 17.98, 104.—Of time, poti\ e(/spera, ‘towards evening,’ Od. 17.191.
pros-a/gw, aor. 2 prosh/gage: bring upon, Od. 17.446†.
pros - a=i=+/ssw, aor. part. prosa=i=/ca=s: spring to, dart to, Od. 22.337, 342, 365.
pros - amu=/nw, aor. inf. prosamu=nai: ward off from one (tini/), bring help or aid to. (Il.)
pros-a/ptw, protia/ptw: attach to, accord, Il. 24.110†.
pros - arhrw/s (a)rari/skw), part.: closely fitted, Il. 5.725†.
pros-auda/w, imp. prosauda=/tw, ipf. proshu/dwn, proshu/da=, du. prosaudh/thn: speak to, address, abs., or w. acc., and freq. w. two accusatives, tina\ e)/pea, Il. 1.201. See au)da/w and au)dh/.
pros-bai/nw, aor. 2 prose/bhn, 3 pl. prose/ban, mid. aor. prosebh/seto: go to, arrive at, step upon.
pros-ba/llw, mid. 2 sing. protiba/lleai: cast upon, strike; *)he/lios a)rou/ra=s, Il. 7.421; mid., met., reprove, Il. 5.879.
pros - de/rkomai, potide/rketai, ipf. prosede/rketo: look upon.
pros - de/xomai, aor. part. potide/gmenos: expect, await, wait.
pros - do/rpios, potido/rpios: for supper, Od. 9.234 and 249.
pros - eile/w, protieile/w (veile/w), inf. protieilei=n: press forward, Il. 10.347†.
pros - ei=pon, protiei=pon (vei=pon), prose/eipon, opt. protiei/poi: speak to, address, accost.
pros - ereu/gomai: belch at; prosereu/getai pe/trhn, ‘breaks foaming against the rock,’ Il. 15.621†.

pro/sqe(n): in front, before, formerly, of place and of time; (the Chimaera), pro/sqe le/wn, o)/piqen de\ dra/kwn, Il. 6.181; oi( pro/sqen, ‘the men of old,’ Il. 9.524; as prep., w. gen., often of place, also to denote protection, like pro/ or u(pe/r, *f 587, Od. 8.524; local and temporal, Il. 2.359.
pro/s-keimai: be attached to (pass. of prosti/qhmi), ipf., Il. 18.379†.
pros-khdh/s, e/s (kh=dos): solicitous, affectionate, Od. 21.35†.
pros - kli=/nw, potikli=/nw, ipf. prose/kli=ne, pass. perf. potike/klitai: lean against, tini/ tu; perf. pass., is placed or stands near. (Od.)
pros - le/gomai, aor. 2 prose/lekto: lie or recline beside, Od. 12.34†.
pros-mu=qe/omai, protimu=qe/omai, aor. inf. protimu=qh/sasqai: speak to, Od. 11.143†.
pros - ni/ssomai, potini/ssomai: go or come in; ei)/s ti, Il. 9.381†.
pros - pela/zw, aor. part. prospela/sa=s: bring in contact with, drive upon, Od. 9.285†.
pros - pi/lnamai: draw near, ipf., Od. 13.95†.
pros - pla/zw, part. prospla/zon: strike upon, reach to, Il. 12.285 and Od. 11.583.
pros - pth/ssw, potipth/ssw, perf. part. potipepthui=ai: sink down towards, tino/s, Od. 13.98†.

pros - ptu/ssomai, potiptu/ssomai, opt. potiptussoi/meqa, fut. prosptu/cetai, aor. prosptu/cato, subj. prosptu/comai: fold to oneself, embrace, receive or greet warmly, Od. 11.451, Od. 8.478, Od. 3.22 ; mu=/qw|, ‘apply oneself’ in entreaty, ‘entreat,’ Od. 2.77.
pro/ssoqen: before him, Il. 23.533†.
pro/ssw: see pro/sw.
pros - stei/xw, aor. 2 prose/stixe: ascend, Od. 20.73†.
pros-ti/qhmi, aor. 1 prose/qhke: place at (the entrance), Od. 9.305†.
prosfa/sqai: see pro/sfhmi.
pro/s - fatos: usually interpreted, freshly slain (fe/nw); according to others, that may be addressed (fhmi/), i. e. with natural, lifelike countenance, Il. 24.757†.
pro/s - fhmi, ipf. (aor.) prose/fhn, mid. inf. prosfa/sqai: speak to, address.
pros - fuh/s, e/s: grown upon, i. e. fastened to, Od. 19.58†. (See cut No. 105.)
pros - fu/w, aor. 2 part. prosfu=/s, -u=sa: aor. 2 intrans., grow to, cling, Od. 12.433 and Il. 24.213.
pros - fwne/w, ipf. prosefw/neon: speak to, address, accost; in Od. 22.69, metefw/nee is the better reading. See fwne/w and fwnh/.
pros - fwnh/eis, potifwnh/eis, essa, en: capable of addressing, endued with speech, Od. 9.456†.
pro/(s)sw: forward, in the future, Il. 16.265, Il. 1.343.
pro/s - wpon (w)/y), pl. pro/swpa and prosw/pata: face, visage, countenance, usually pl.; sing., Il. 18.24.

pro/teros (comp. to pro/): fore, former; po/des, Od. 19.228; usually of time, (oi() pro/teroi, ‘men of former time,’ Il. 4.308 ; th=| prote/rh| (sc. h(me/rh|), Od. 16.50 ; gene/h|, ‘elder,’ Il. 15.166.
prote/rw: forward, further.
pro-teu/xw, pass. perf. inf. protetu/xqai: perf. pass., be past and done, let ‘by-gones by by-gones.’ (Il.)
proti/: see pro/s. For compounds with proti-, see under pros-.
*protia=/wn: a Trojan, the father of Astynous, Il. 15.455†.
protiba/lleai, protieilei=n: see prosba/llw, proseile/w.
protiei/poi: see prosei=pon.
pro-ti/qhmi, 3 pl., proqe/ousin, ipf. 3 pl. pro/tiqen, aor. prou)/qhken: place before, ‘throw before’ dogs, Il. 24.409; fig., ‘permit,’ Il. 1.291.
protimu=qh/sasqai: see prosmu=qe/omai.
proti-o/ssomai, imp. protio/sseo, ipf. -eto: look upon or toward, and, with the eyes of the mind, forbode; ‘recognize thee for what I had foreboded,’ Il. 22.356.
pro/ - tmhsis (te/mnw): parts about the navel, Il. 11.424†.
pro/ - tonos (tei/nw): only pl., forestays of a ship, ropes extending from the mast to the inner portion of the bows, Il. 1.434, Od. 2.425. (See cut under *seirh/n.)
pro-tre/pomai (tre/pw), ipf. protre/ponto, aor. 2 subj. protra/phtai, opt. -oi/mhn, inf. -e/sqai: turn (in flight) to, fig., give oneself to, a)/xei+, Il. 6.336.
pro - tropa/dhn: adv., in headlong flight, Il. 16.304†.
pro - tu/ptw, aor. prou)/tuya: strike forward, intrans., press forward; a)na\ r(i=nas dri=mu\ me/nos, ‘forced itself forward’ (rose quickly in spite of him), Od. 24.319.
prou)/qhke: see proti/qhmi.
prou)/pemye: see prope/mpw.
prou)/xonta, prouxou/sh|: see proe/xw.

pro - fai/nw, ipf. prou)/fainon, mid. ipf. proufai/neto, pass. perf. 3 sing. prope/fantai, aor. part. profanei/s: show forth, reveal, and intrans., shine forth, Od. 9.145; mid., shine forth, be visible, appear; ou)de\ prou)fai/net' i)de/sqai, ‘it was not light enough to see,’ Od. 9.143.
pro/-fasis (fhmi/): pretext; acc. as adv., ostensibly, Il. 19.262 and 302.
pro - ferh/s, e/s, comp. profere/steros, sup. -e/statos: preferred, tino/s, ‘above’ some one, superior in, tini/, Od. 21.134; w. inf., ‘better in drawing,’ Il. 10.352.

pro-fe/rw, subj. profe/rh|si, opt. -ois, imp. -e, part. -wn, mid. pres. profe/rontai, subj. -htai: bear forth or away, proffer, fig., o)nei/dea tini/, Il. 2.251; ‘dis
play,’ me/nos, Il. 10.479; mid., e)/rida/ tini, ‘challenge,’ Od. 8.210; ‘begin’ combat, Il. 3.7.
pro - feu/gw, aor. 2 subj. profu/gh|, opt. 2 sing. profu/goisqa, inf. profugei=n, part. -w/n: flee away, escape, abs., and w. acc.
pro/ - frassa, fem. of pro/frwn: cheerful(ly), serious(ly), in earnest, Od. 10.386.

pro/-frwn, onos (frh/n): adj., regularly used not as attributive but as adverb, cheerful(ly), gracious(ly), kind- (ly), zealous(ly), earnest(ly); ironical, pro/frwn ken dh\ e)/peita *di/a litoi/mhn, ‘in good earnest,’ i. e. I could not do it, Od. 14.406; as adj., qu=mw=| pro/froni, Il. 8.40.—Adv., profrone/ws (Il.).
pro-xe/w, pass. ipf. proxe/onto: pour forth; met., Il. 2.465, etc. (Il.)
pro/-xnu (go/nu): (forward) on the knee, ‘on her knees,’ Il. 9.570; fig., a)pole/sqai, laid ‘low,’ ‘utterly’ destroyed, Il. 21.460.
pro-xoh/ (xe/w): only pl., out-pourings, mouth of a river, stream, Od. 20.65.
pro/-xoos (xe/w): vessel for pouring, pitcher, vase (for the form see cut No. 26). Used for wine, Od. 18.397, and for water in ablutions (see cut No. 76).
prule/es, dat. prule/essi: heavyarmed foot-soldiers (= o(pli<*>=tai), Il. 11.49, Il. 12.77, Il. 15.517, Il. 5.744.
*prumneu/s: a Phaeacian, Od. 8.112†.
pru/mnh: stern of a ship; for prumnh\ nhu/s, see prumno/s.
pru/mnhqen: at the stern; lamba/nein, ‘by the stern-post,’ Il. 15.716†.
prumnh/sia: neut. adj. as subst., sc. pei/smata, stern - cables, by means of which the ship was made fast to the shore; prumnh/sia katadh=sai, a)na/yai, lu=sai, Od. 2.418.

prumno/s, sup. prumno/tatos (Od. 17.463): at the extreme end, usually the lower or hinder part; braxi=/wn, ‘end’ of the arm near the shoulder, Il. 13.532 ; glw=ssa, ‘root’ of the tongue, Il. 5.292; so ke/ras, Il. 13.705; nhu=s prumnh/, at the stern, ‘aft,’ ‘after part,’ cf. pru/mnh, Od. 2.417; do/ru, here apparently the upper end, ‘by the point,’ Il. 17.618; of a stone, prumno\s paxu/s, thick ‘at the base,’ Il. 12.446 ; u=(/lhn prumnh/n, wood ‘at the root,’ Il. 12.149.—Neut. as subst., prum- no\n qe/naros, ‘end of the palm,’ just below the fingers, Il. 5.339.
prumn-wrei/h (o)/ros): foot of a mountain, Il. 14.307†.
*pru/tanis: a Lycian, slain by Odysseus, Il. 5.678†.
prw/|hn (pro/): lately, recently. (Il.)
prwq-h/bhs (prw=tos, h(/bh): in the prime or ‘bloom’ of youth.
prw=i (pro/): early, in the morning; ‘untimely,’ v. l. for prw=ta, Od. 24.28.
prw/iz(a), prwiza/: day before yesterday, Il. 2.303†.
prw/ion, neut. adj. as adv., early in the morning, Il. 15.470†.
prw=n, prw=nos, pl. prw/ones: foreland, headland. (Il.)
*prwreu/s: a Phaeacian, Od. 8.113†.
prw/rh (pro/): fem. adj. as subst., prow, Od. 12.230†.
*prwtesi/la=os: Protesilāus, son of Iphiclus, a leader of the Thessalians, the first Greek to tread on Trojan soil, and the first to fall, Il. 2.698, 706, Il. 15.705, *n 681, Il. 16.286.
*prwteu/s: Proteus, the prophetic old man of the sea, changing himself into many shapes, Od. 4.365, 385.
prw/tistos, sup. to prw=tos: first of all, chiefest.—Adv., prw/tiston, prw/tista (prw/tisq)), Od. 11.168.
prwto/ - gonos: first - born, a)/rnes, ‘firstlings.’ (Il.)
prwto-pagh/s, e/s (ph/gnu=mi): newmade, Il. 5.194 and Il. 24.267.
prwto - plo/os (ple/w): sailing or going to sea for the first time, Od. 8.35†.

prw=tos (sup. from pro/): first, of position, rank, or time, opp. u(/statos, Il. 2.281; e)n prwth| a)gorh=|, ‘front’ of the assembly, Il. 19.50 ; e)ni\ prw/th|si qu/rh|si (cf. pro/qura), ‘at the first entrance,’ Od. 1.255 ; prw=toi for pro/maxoi, Il. 5.536, Od. 18.379; ta\ prw=ta (sc. a)=qla), Il. 23.275.— Adv., prw=ton, prw=ta, to\ prw=ton, ta\ prw=ta, *d 267, Il. 1.6; w. e)peidh/ (cum primum), ‘as soon as.’
prwto-to/kos (ti/ktw): about to bear (‘come in’) for the first time, of a heifer, Il. 17.5†.
*prwtw/: a Nereid, Il. 18.43†.
prw/ones: see prw/n.
ptai/rw, aor. 2 e)/ptaren: sneeze, Od. 17.541†.
pta/menos, pta/to: see pe/tomai.
ptele/h: elm. (Il.)
*pteleo/s: (1) a harbor - town in Thessaly, Il. 2.697.—(2) in Elis, a colony of the Thessalian Pteleus, Il. 2.594.
pte/rnh: heel, Il. 22.397†.

ptero/eis, essa, en: winged, epith. of the feathered arrow; also of targes (laish/ia), because of the fluttering apron attached to them, Il. 5.453 (see cuts Nos. 73 and 79); met., e)/pea ptero/enta, ‘winged words.’
ptero/n (pe/tomai): feather, wing; ptera\ ba/llein, ‘ply,’ tina/ssesqai, *l 454, Od. 2.151; symbol of lightness, swiftness, Il. 19.386, Od. 7.36; fig., of oars, ptera\ nhusi/n, Od. 11.125.
pte/ruc, ugos, pl. dat. pteru/gessin: wing, pinion.
pth/ssw, aor. pth=ce, perf. part. pepthw/s: cower, crouch, perf.; aor. trans. in an interpolated verse, ‘make to cower, ‘terrify,’ Il. 14.40.
ptoie/w: only pass. aor. 3 pl., e)ptoi/hqen, were dismayed, Od. 23.298†.
*ptolemai=os: son of Piraeus, father of Eurymedon, Il. 4.228†.
ptolemi/zw, ptolemisth/s, pto/lemos: see polemi/zw, etc.
ptoli/eqron: town, city, but often in a more restricted sense than po/lis, hence w. gen., *troi/hs i(ero\n ptoli/eqron, *pu/lou ai)pu\ ptoli/eqron, a 2, Od. 3.485.
ptoli - po/rqios, ptoli/porqos (pe/rqw): sacker of cities, epith. of gods and heroes (in the Od. only of Odysseus).
pto/lis: see po/lis.
pto/rqos: sapling, Od. 6.128†.
ptu/gma (ptu/ssw): fold, Il. 5.315†.
ptukto/s (ptu/ssw): folded, Il. 6.169†.
ptu/c, ptuxo/s (ptu/ssw): fold, layer, of the layers of a shield, Il. 18.481 (see cut No. 130); fig., of mountains, cleft, vale, ravine, Il. 11.77, Il. 20.22, Od. 19.432.
ptu/on, gen. ptuo/fin: winnowing shovel or fan, used to throw up grain and chaff against the wind, Il. 13.588†.
ptu/ssw, aor. part. ptu/ca=sa, mid. ipf. e)ptu/ssonto: fold, fold together; pass., ‘were bent,’ Il. 13.134.
ptu=/w: spit forth, part., Il. 23.697†.
ptw/c, ptwko/s (ptw/ssw): timid, epith. of the hare, Il. 22.310; as subst., hare, Il. 17.676.
ptwska/zw, inf. -e/men: crouch in fear, Il. 4.372†.

ptw/ssw (cf. pth/ssw, ptw/c), ipf. ptw=sson: cower, hide; u(po/ tini, ‘before’ one, Il. 7.129; of a beggar, ‘go cringing about,’ kata\ dh=mon, r 227, Od. 18.363; trans., o)/rni=qes ne/fea, ‘flee’ the clouds, Od. 22.304.
ptwxo/s (ptw/ssw): beggar-(man), a)nh/r, f 327, Od. 14.400. (Od.)
*pugmai=oi (pugmh/, ‘Fistlings,’ cf. Tom ‘Thumb,’ ‘Thumbkin): the Pygmies, a fabulous race of dwarfs or manikins, Il. 3.6†.
pug-maxi/h: boxing, Il. 23.653 and 665.
pug-ma/xos: boxer, pl., Od. 8.246†. (Cf. cut.)
pugmh/ (pu/c, cf. pugnus): fist, then boxing, boxing-match, Il. 23.669†.
pugou/sios (pugw/n): a cubit long; e)/nqa kai\ e)/nqa, i. e. a cubit square, Od. 10.517 and Od. 11.25.
pu/elos: feedingtrough, Od. 19.553†.
puqe/sqai: see punqa/nomai.
puqmh/n, e)/nos: bottom of a vase, trunk, butt of a tree, Il. 11.635, Od. 13.122, 372.
pu=/qw, fut. pu=/sei, pass. pres. pu=/qetai: cause to rot, pass., rot, decay.
*pu=qw/, *pu=qw/n, dat. *pu=qoi=, acc. *pu=qw/ and *puqw=na: Pytho, the most ancient name of the oracle of Apollo on Mt. Parnassus near Delphi in Phocis, Il. 2.519, Il. 9.405, Od. 8.80.
*pu=qw=de: to Pytho, Od. 11.581.

puka/zw (pu/ka), opt. puka/zoien, aor. pu/kasa, pass. perf. part. pepukasme/nos: cover closely or thickly, wrap up; tina\ nefe/lh|, Il. 17.551; of a helmet, pu/kase ka/rh, Il. 10.271; sfe/as au)tou/s, ‘crowd’ themselves, Od. 12.225; pass., of chariots ‘overlaid’ with gold, etc., Il. 23.503; met., of grief, tina\ fre/nas, ‘overshadow’ the soul, Il. 8.124.
puki-mhdh/s, e/s (mh=dos): deep-counselled, Od. 1.438†.

pukino/s, pukno/s (pu/ka): close, thick, compact; qw/rhc, a)spi/s, xlai=na, Od. 14.521; with reference to the particles or parts
of anything, ne/fos, fa/lagges, sti/xes; of a bed with several coverings, ‘closely spread,’ Il. 9.621 ; pukina\ ptera/, perhaps to be taken adverbially, of the movements in close succession (see below), Od. 2.151, etc.; of thick foliage, o)/zos, qa/mnos, u=(/lh; ‘closely shut,’ ‘packed,’ qu/rh, xhlo/s, *c 167, Od. 13.68; metaph., ‘strong,’ ‘sore,’ a)/xos, a=)/th, *p 599, Il. 24.480; wise, prudent, sagacious, fre/nes, mh/dea, e)/pos, etc.—Adv., puk(i)no/n, puk(i)na/, pukinw=s, close, fast, rapidly, often; also deeply, wisely.
*pulaime/nhs: king of the Paphlagonians, an ally of the Trojans, father of Harpalion, Il. 2.851, Il. 13.643. He is slain by Menelāus, Il. 5.576, but appears later as still living, Il. 13.658.
*pulai=os: son of Lethus, a chief of the Pelasgians, Il. 2.842†.
pul - a/rths, a=o: gate - closer, doorkeeper of the nether world, w. kratero/s, epith. of Hades, Il. 8.367, Od. 11.277.
*pula/rths: the name of two Trojans, one overcome by Ajax, Il. 11.491; the other by Patroclus, Il. 16.696.
pula-wro/s (root vor, o(ra/w): gatekeeper, pl. (Il.)

pu/lh: gate, gates, always pl., with reference to the two wings. Poetically *)ai/da=o (periphrasis for death), ou)ranou=, *)olu/mpou, *)heli/oio, o)nei/reiai, o)nei/rwn, Od. 4.809, Od. 19.562, *e 646, Od. 14.156.
*pulhgenh/s: see *puloigenh/s.
*pulh/nh: a town in Aetolia, Il. 2.639†.
*pu/lios: of Pylus; *pu/lioi, the Pylians, Il. 7.134, Il. 11.753, Il. 23.633, Od. 15.216.
*puloigenh/s, e/s: born in Pylos, bred in Pylus, Nestor, i(/ppoi, *b 54, Il. 23.303.
*pulo/qen: from Pylos, Od. 16.323†.
*pulo/nde: to Pylos.

*pu/los: Pylos.—(1) a city in Messenian Elis, on the coast opposite the southern extremity of the island of Sphacteria; the home of Neleus and Nestor. Under the epith. ‘sandy’ Pylos the entire region is designated, Il. 2.77, Od. 3.4.—(2) a city in Triphylia of Elis, south of the Alphēus, Il. 11.671 ff. —(3) see pu/los.
pu/los: e)n pu/lw|, Il. 5.397†, explained by those who prefer not to read e)n *pu/lw| as in the gateway, i. e. at the gates of Hades.
*pu/lwn: a Trojan, slain by Polypoetes, Il. 12.187†.

pu/matos: last, of time or place; a)/ntuc a)spi/dos, ‘outermost,’ Il. 6.118, cf. Il. 18.608; ‘root’ of the nose, Il. 13.616.— Adv., pu/maton, pu/mata, joined with u(/staton, u(/stata, *x 203, Od. 4.685.

punqa/nomai, peu/qomai, opt. 3 pl. peuqoi/ato, ipf. punqano/mhn, (e))peu/qeto, fut. peu/somai, aor. 2 (e))puqo/mhn, opt. redup. pepu/qoito, perf. pe/pusmai, pe/pussai, plup. (e))pe/pusto, du. pepu/sqhn: learn by inquiry, ascertain, hear tell of; w. gen. (or e)k) of the person giving the information, also gen. of the person or thing learned about, Od. 13.256, Od. 14.321 ; boh=s, ‘hear,’ Il. 6.465; freq. w. part., ‘hear of all this wrangling on your part,’ Il. 1.257.
pu/c (cf. pu/ka, pukno/s, pugmh/): adv., with the fist, at boxing.
pu/cinos (pu/cos): of box-wood, Il. 24.269†.
pu=r, puro/s: fire; pl. pura/, watchfires, Il. 8.509, 554.
pur - a/grh (a)gre/w = ai(re/w): firetongs, Od. 3.434 and Il. 18.477.
*pu=rai/xmhs: a chief of the Paeonians, an ally of the Trojans, slain by Patroclus, Il. 2.848, Il. 16.287.
purakte/w: only ipf. e)pura/kteon, I brought to a glow, Od. 9.328†.
*pu=/rasos: (1) a Trojan, slain by Ajax, Il. 11.491.—(2) name of a town in Thessaly, Il. 2.695.
purghdo/n: adv., like a tower, ‘in solid masses.’ (Il.)
pu/rgos: tower, turreted wall; fig., of Ajax, pu/rgos *)axaiw=n, Il. 11.556; his shield also is compared to a tower, Il. 7.219, Il. 11.485; of a ‘column,’ ‘compact body’ of troops, Il. 4.334.
purgo/w, aor. pu/rgwsan: surround with towers, fortify, Od. 11.264†.
pureto/s: fever, Il. 22.31†.
purh/ (pu=r): pyre, funeral - pile, Il. 23.110 -177, 192-258; Il. 24.786-799. (Cf. cut No. 103, on following page.)
pu=rhfo/ros: see pu=rofo/ros.
puri-h/khs, es (a)/kh): fire - pointed, with blazing point, Od. 9.387†.
puri/ - kaustos (kai/w): charred, Il. 13.564†.
*pu/ris: a Lycian, slain by Patroclus, Il. 16.416†.
*puriflege/qwn: Pyriphlegethon, a river of the nether world, Od. 10.513†.
pur-kai+h/ (kai/w): place where fire is kindled, funeral-pile. (Il.)
pu/rnon: wheaten loaf. (Od.)
pu=ro/s: wheat, often pl.; mentioned only once as food for men, Od. 20.109, but cf. pu/rnon.
pu=ro-fo/ros and pu=rhfo/ros: wheatbearing, Od. 3.495.
pur-pole/w: tend fires (watch-fires), part., Od. 10.30†.
purso/s (pu=r): torch, beacon, signallight, pl., Il. 18.211†.
pw/: enclitic adv., always w. neg., ou)/ pw, not yet, (n)ever, ou) ga/r pw, mh\ dh/ pw, etc.; also like pw/s, ou)/ (mh/) pw, ‘in no wise,’ ‘by no means.’
pwle/omai (frequentative of pe/lomai), pw/le(ai), part. pwleu/menoi, ipf. pwleu/mhn, -ei=to, iter. pwle/sketo, fut. pwlh/somai: frequent a place, go and come to or among, consort with.
pw=los: foal.
pw=ma, atos: lid, cover, of a chest, a vase, a quiver, Il. 16.221, Od. 2.353, Il. 4.116. (See the quiver of Heracles in cut.)
pw/-pote: ever yet, always after ou), referring to past time.
pw=s: interrog. adv., how? in what way? Also with merely exclamatory effect, Od. 10.337. Combined, pw=s ga/r, pw=s dh/, pw=s t' a)/ra, etc.
pw/s: enclitic indef. adv., somehow, in some way; if in any way, perchance, perhaps; w. neg., by no means.
pwta/omai (pe/tomai), ipf. pwtw=nto: fly, Il. 12.287†.
pw=u, eos, pl. dat. pw/esi: flock, o)i/wn, mh/lwn.

div1.head: *r
div1.entryFree: *r. Many words beginning with r originally began with two consonants, esp. vr or sr (vrh/gnu=mi, sre/w), and the quantitative (metrical) effect of the two letters has been preserved in the frequent doubling of r (e)/rreon). What the initial consonant was cannot always be determined.
r(a/, r(): see a)/ra.
r(a/bdos: rod, wand, esp. the magic wand of Hermes, Circe, Athēna, Il. 24.343, Od. 10.238, Od. 13.429; of a fishing-rod, Od. 12.251; pins, Il. 12.297.
r(adalo/s: see r(odano/s.
*(rada/manqus: Rhadamanthys, son of Zeus and brother of Minos, a ruler in Elvsium, Il. 12.322, Od. 7.323, Od. 4.564.
r(adino/s (vr.): slender, pliant, Il. 23.583†.
r(a<*>a/migc, iggos: pl., drops; fig., koni=/hs, ‘particles’ of dust, Il. 23.502. (Il.)
r(ai/nw, aor. imp. r(a/ssate, pass. ipf. r(ai/nonto, perf. 3 pl. e)rra/datai, plup. e)rra/dato: sprinkle, besprinkle.
r(aisth/r, h=ros (r(ai/w): hammer, Il. 18.477†.

r(ai/w, fut. inf. r(aise/menai, aor. subj. r(ai/sh|, inf. r(ai<*>=sai, pass. pres. opt. r(ai/o-
ito, aor. e)rrai/sqh: shatter, dash (in pieces), pro\s ou)/dei+, Od. 9.459; ‘wreck,’ Od. 6.326, Od. 5.221.
r(a/kos, eos (vr.): ragged garment, tatters. (Od.)
r(apto/s: sewed, patched, Od. 24.228 and 229.
r(a/ptw, ipf. r(a/ptomen, aor. r(a/ye, inf. r(a/yai: sew, stitch, or rivet together, Il. 12.296; met., ‘devise,’ ‘contrive,’ Il. 18.367, Od. 3.118, Od. 16.379, 422.
r(a/ssate: see r(ai/nw.
r(afh/ (r(a/ptw): seam, pl., Od. 22.186†.
r(a/xis, ios: chine, back - piece, cut lengthwise along the spine, Il. 9.208†.
*(re/a=, *(rei/h: Rhea, daughter of Uranus, sister and consort of Cronus, mother of Zeus, Poseidon, Hades, Hera, Demēter, Hestia.
r(e/a, r(ei=a: easily; qeoi\ r(ei=a zw/ontes, i. e. without the effort entailed by care and trouble, Od. 5.122.

r(e/zw (vr., ve/rgon), ipf. iter. r(e/zeskon, fut. r(e/cw, aor. e)/reca, e)/rrece, r(e/ce, subj. r(e/comen, pass. aor. inf. r(exqh=nai, part. r(exqei/s, cf. e)/rdw: do, work, act, me/ga e)/rgon, eu)= or kakw=s tina/, Od. 23.56; ou) kata\ moi=ran e)/recas, Od. 9.352; pass., r(exqe/n de/ te nh/pios e)/gnw, ‘a thing once done,’ Il. 17.32; esp., ‘do’ sacrifice, ‘perform,’ ‘offer,’ ‘sacrifice,’ e(kato/mbhn, qalu=/sia, abs. qew=|, Il. 9. 535, Il. 8.250.
r(e/qos, eos: pl., limbs. (Il.)
r(ei=a: see r(e/a.
*(rei/h: see *(re/a=.
*(rei=qron: name of a harbor in Ithaca, Od. 1.186†.

r(e/pw (vr.): sink in the scale, used figuratively of the balances of fate, r(e/pe d' ai)/simon h)=mar *)axaiw=n (meaning that their fate was sealed, an expression the converse in form, but the counterpart in sense, of our ‘kick the beam’), Il. 8.72, Il. 22.212. (Il.)
r(erupwme/nos: see r(upo/w.
r(exqei/s: see r(e/zw.
r(e/w (sre/vw), ipf. e)/rreon, r(e/e, aor. e)rru/hn, r(u/h: flow, stream; met., of speech, missiles, hair, Il. 1.249, Il. 12.159, Od. 10.393.
r(hgmi=/n, i=nos (vrh/gnu=mi): surf, breakers.

r(h/gnu=mi (vr., cf. frango), 3 pl. r(hgnu=si, ipf. iter. r(h/gnuske, fut. r(h/cw, aor. e)/rrhca, r(h=ce, mid. pres. imp. r(h/gnusqe, aor. (e)r)rh/canto: break, burst, rend in twain, different from a)/gnu=mi. Freq. of breaking the ranks of the enemy in battle, fa/laggas, o(/mi=lon, sti/xas, Il. 6.6, *l 538, Il. 15.615.—Mid., break for oneself, Il. 11.90, Il. 12.90; break intrans., as waves, and fig., ‘let break out,’ ‘let loose,’ e)/rida, Il. 20.55.

r(h=gos, eos (vr.): rug, blanket, probably of wool, opp. li/non, Od. 13.73; often pl., mentioned as covers, cushions, for bed or chairs. (Od. and Il. 9.661, Il. 24.664.) (Cf. the Assyrian and Greek qro/nos with qrh=nus attached.)
r(hqei/s: see ei)/r Od. 24.1.

r(hi/dios (Att. r(a/|dios), comp. r(hi/teros, sup. r(hi/tatos and r(h/istos: easy; w. dat., also foll. by inf.; pers. for impers., r(hi/teroi polemi/zein h)=san *)axaioi/, Il. 18.258.—Adv., r(hidi/ws, sup. r(hi/tata, *d 390, Od. 19.577.
r(hkto/s (vrh/gnu=mi): breakable, penetrable, vulnerable, Il. 13.323†.
*(rh/nh: concubine of Oī¨leus, mother of Medon, Il. 2.728†.
r(hc-hnori/h: might to break hostile ranks of men, Od. 14.217†.

r(hc - h/nwr, oros (vrh/gnu=mi, a)nh/r):
bursting ranks of men, epith. of Achilles.
*(rhch/nwr: son of Nausithous, and brother of Alcinous, Od. 7.63 and 146.
r(h=sis, ios (root ver, ei)/r Od. 24.1): speaking, speech, Od. 21.291†.
*(rh=sos: Rhesus, king of the Thracians, slain by Odysseus and Diomed, Il. 10.474, 519.
r(h/ssw (cf. r(h/gnu=mi): stamp, part., Il. 18.571†.
r(hth/r, h=ros (root ver, ei)/r Od. 24.1): speaker, Il. 9.443†.
r(hto/s: spoken, stipulated, Il. 21.445†.
r(h/trh: stipulation, bargain, Od. 14.393†.
r(i=gedano/s (vri=ge/w): horrible, Il. 19.325†.

r(i=ge/w (vri=gos), fut. inf. r(i=gh/sein, aor. (e)r)ri=/ghsa, perf., w. pres. signif., e)/rri=ga, subj. e)rri=/gh|si, plup. e)rri=/gei: properly, to shudder with cold, but in Homer always met., shudder (at) with fear, be horrified, abs., also w. acc., inf., Il. 3.353; part., Il. 4.279 ; mh/, Od. 23.216.
r(i=/gion (vri=gos), comp.: colder, Od. 17.191; met., more horrible, more terrible, cf. a)/lgion.—Sup., r(i=/gistos, r(i=/gista, Il. 5.873†.
*(ri/gmos: son of Piroüs, from Thrace, an ally of the Trojans, Il. 20.485†.
r(i=gos, eos (cf. frigus): cold, Od. 5.472†.
r(i=go/w, fut. inf. r(i=gwse/men: be cold, Od. 14.481†.
r(i/za: root; fig., of the eye, Od. 9.390.
r(izo/w, aor. e)rri/zwse, pass. perf. e)rri/zwtai: cause to take root, plant, plant out, pass., Od. 7.122; fig., ‘fix firmly,’ Od. 13.163. (Od.)
r(i/mfa (vri=/ptw): swiftly.
r(i=/n: see r(i=/s.

r(i=no/n and r(i=no/s (vr.): skin of men, or hide of animals, then shield of oxhide (with and without bow=n), Il. 4.447, Il. 12.263; reading and sense doubtful in Od. 5.281 (v. l. e)ri=no/n, ‘cloud’?).
r(i=no-to/ros (tore/w): shield-piercing, Il. 21.392†.
r(i/on: peak, crag, headland, Od. 3.295.
r(i=ph/ (vri=/ptw): impulse, flight, rush, of a stone thrown, a spear, wind and fire, Od. 8.192, Il. 16.589, Il. 21.12.
*(ri=/ph: a town in Arcadia, Il. 2.606†.
r(i=pta/zw (frequentative of vri=/ptw): hurl about, part., Il. 14.257†.
r(i=/ptw (vr.), ipf. iter. r(i=/ptaskon, fut. r(i=/yw, aor. e)/rri=yen, r(i=ya: fling, hurl; ti\ meta/ tina, ‘toss into the hands of,’ Il. 3.378.
r(i/s, r(i=no/s (vr.): nose, pl. nostrils.
r(odano/s: waving, swaying, Il. 18.576† (v. l. r(adalo/n).
*(ro/dios: see *(ro/dos.
*(rodi/os: a river in the Troad, rising in Mt. Ida, Il. 12.20†.
r(odo-da/ktulos: rosy-fingered, epith. of Eos, goddess of the dawn.
r(odo/eis, essa, en (vro/don): rosy, ‘fragrant with roses,’ Il. 23.186†.
*(ro/dos: Rhodes, the celebrated island southwest of Asia Minor, Il. 2.654 ff., 667.—*(ro/dios, of Rhodes, pl. *(ro/dioi, the Rhodians, Il. 2.654.
r(oh/ (sre/w): pl., flood, stream, streams.
r(o/qios: plashing, dashing, surging, Od. 5.412†.
r(oibde/w (r(oi=bdos, r(oi=zos), aor. opt. r(oibdh/seien: gulp, suck in, Od. 12.106†.
r(oize/w, aor. r(oi/zhse: whistle, Il. 10.502†.
r(oi=zos (cf. r(oi=bdos, r(oibde/w): whistling, whizzing, of arrows, Il. 16.361; of the shepherd's call, Od. 9.315.
r(oih/: pomegranate, tree and fruit, pl., Od. 7.115 and Od. 11.589.
r(o/os (sre/w): flow, stream, current.
r(o/palon (vre/pw): club, cudgel.
r(oxqe/w, r(oxqei=, ipf. r(o/xqei: roar, of the waves, Od. 12.60 and Od. 5.402.
r(u=/ato: see r(u/omai.
r(udo/n (sre/w): adv., in floods, ‘enormously,’ Od. 15.426†.
r(u/h: see r(e/w.
r(u=mo/s (e)ru/w): pole of a chariot, Il. 6.40, Il. 10.505. (Cf. cut No. 42 for the method of attaching the pole; cf. also Nos. 45, 92.)

r(u<*>/omai (e)ru/w), inf. r(u<*>esqai and r(u=sqai, ipf. r(u=/eto, 3 pl. r(u=/at(o), iter. r(u/skeu, aor. r(usa/mhn, (e)r)ru=/sato, imp. r(u=sai: rescue, save; u(pe/k, u(po/ tinos, ‘out of,’ ‘from,’ Il. 12.107, Il. 17.645; in general, ‘protect,’ ‘cover,’ ‘hide,’ Od. 6.129, Il. 17.224, Il. 12.8; detain, Od. 23.244.
r(upa/w, r(upo/w, part. r(upo/wnta: be dirty, soiled.
r(u/pos, pl. r(u/pa: dirt, Od. 6.93†.
r(u=sai, r(u=/sato, r(u=sqai: see r(u/omai.
r(u=/sion (e)ru/w): pl., booty dragged away, of cattle, Il. 11.674†.
r(usi/ptolis: see e)rusi/ptolis.
r(u/skeu: see r(u/omai.
r(u=so/s (e)ru/w): wrinkled, Il. 9.503†.
r(usta/zw (e)ru/w), ipf. iter. r(usta/zesken: drag about, maltreat, Od. 16.109.
r(ustaktu/s, u/os (r(usta/zw): dragging, maltreatment, Od. 18.224†.

r(u=th/r, h=ros (e)ru/w): (1) one who draws, drawer of a bow, Od. 21.173, Od. 18.262. —(2) guard, Od. 17.187 and 223.—(3) reins drawn tight, taut reins, which in Il. 16.475 are described as having been drawn to one side and entangled by the fall of the parh/oros.
*(ru/tion: a town in Crete, Il. 2.648†.
r(u=to/s (e)ru/w): dragged, hauled, of stones too large to carry, Od. 6.267 and Od. 14.10.
r(wgale/os: torn, ragged.
r(w/c, r(wgo/s (vrh/gnu=mi): pl., clefts, loop-holes or windows in the rear wall of the me/garon, to light the stairway behind them, Od. 22.143. (See cut No. 83.)
r(w/omai (cf. ruo), ipf. (e)r)rw/onto, aor. e)rrw/santo: more quickly; gou/nata, knh=mai, y 3, Il. 18.411; of dancing, marching in armor, horses' manes fluttering, Il. 24.616, Od. 24.69, Il. 23.367.
r(wph/ion (r(w/y): pl., undergrowth.
r(wxmo/s (r(w/c): place gullied out, hollow, Il. 23.420†.
r(w/y, r(wpo/s: pl., twigs, brushwood.

div1.head: *s
div1.entryFree: *sagga/rios: Sangarius, a river flowing through Bithynia and Phrygia, and emptying into the Euxine, Il. 3.187, Il. 16.719.
sai/nw, ipf. sai=non, aor. e)/shne: wag the tail, fawn upon, w. dat. of the tail wagged, Od. 17.302.
sa/kos, eos: the great shield. (See cuts Nos. 9, 16, 17.)
*salami/s: Salamis, the island near Athens, home of Telamonian Ajax, Il. 2.557, Il. 7.199.
*salmwneu/s: son of Aeolus and father of Tyro, Od. 11.236†.
sa/lpigc, ggos: trumpet, Il. 18.219†.
salpi/zw: only aor., sa/lpigcen, fig., resounded, quaked, Il. 21.388†.
*sa/mh: Same, an island near Ithaca, perhaps Cephallenia or a part of Cephallenia, Od. 9.24, Od. 16.249.
*sa/mos: (1)=*sa/mh, Il. 2.634.—(2) *qrhiki/h, Samothrace, an island off the coast of Thrace, Il. 13.12.
sani/s, i/dos: board, plank; pl., esp. the wings of folding - doors, doors; scaffolding, stage, Od. 21.51.
sa/os: only comp., saw/teros, more safe(ly), Il. 1.32†.
sao - frosu/nh: sound sense, discretion; ‘bring into ways of reason,’ Od. 23.13.
sao/ - frwn (Att. sw/frwn): soundminded, discreet, Od. 4.158 and Il. 21.462.

sao/w (sa/os), sw/w, sw/zw, subj. so/h|s, so/h| (so/w|s, so/w|), 3 pl. so/wsi (sa/wsi, sow=si), imp. sa/w, part. sw/zwn, sw/ontes, ipf. sa/w (sa/ou), iter. sw/eskon, fut. saw/sw, inf. sawse/men(ai), aor. (e))sa/wsa, mid. fut. saw/seai, pass. aor. 3 pl. e)sa/wqen, imp. sawqh/tw, inf. sawqh=nai: save, preserve, deliver, mid., oneself, Od. 5.490, Il. 16.363; freq. implying motion, e)k pole/mou, thlo/qen, e)s proxoa=/s, e)pi\ nh=a, Od. 3.231, *r 692, Od. 21.309.
saph/h|: see sh/pw.
sarda/nion: neut. adj. as adv., sardonically, of a bitter, sarcastic smile, Od. 20.302†.
*sarphdw/n: Sarpēdon, son of Zeus, leader of the Lycians, an ally of the Trojans, slain by Patroclus, Il. 2.876, Il. 5.633, 658, *m 392, Il. 16.464, 480 ff., Il. 23.800.
*satnio/eis: a forest stream in Mysia, Il. 6.34, Il. 14.445, Il. 21.87.
*sa/tnios: son of Enops, wounded by Ajax, Il. 14.443†.
saurwth/r, h=ros: a spike at the butt - end of a spear, by means of which it could be stuck in the ground, Il. 10.153†. (See cut No. 4.)
sa/fa (safh/s): clearly, plainly, for certain.
sa/w, saw=sai: see sao/w.
saw/teros: see sa/os.

sbe/nnu=mi, aor. 1 e)/sbesen, sbe/san, inf. sbe/ssai, aor. 2 e)/sbh: aor. 1, trans., quench, extinguish, Il. 23.237; then quell, calm, allay, Il. 9.678, Il. 16.621.—Aor. 2, intrans., of fire, go out, Il. 9.471; of wind, go down, cease, Od. 3.182.
-se =-de, a suffix denoting motion toward, to, kei=se, po/se, kuklo/se, u(yo/se, etc.
seba/zomai (se/bas), aor. seba/ssato: stand in awe of, fear, scruple, Il. 6.167 and 417.
se/bas: awe, reverence, dread; then ‘astonishment,’ ‘wonder,’ Od. 3.123, Od. 4.75.
se/bomai, se/besqe: feel awe, scruple, be ashamed, Il. 4.242†.
se/qen: see su/.
sei=(o), seu=: see su/.
seirh/ (root ser, ei)/r Od. 24.2): cord.

*seirh/n, pl. *seirh=nes, du. *seirh/noiin: pl., the Sirens, two in number, si<*>ging maidens, by their enchanting song luring mariners to destruction, Od. 12.39 ff., 158, 167, 198, Od. 23.326. (The conception of the Sirens as bird-footed and three in number, as seen in the cut, is post-Homeric.)

sei/w, ipf. sei=on, aor. sei=se, part. sei/sa=sa, pass. pres. part. seio/menos, ipf. sei/eto, e)ssei/onto, mid. aor. sei/sato: shake, brandish; sani/das, of no gentle knocking, Il. 9.583 ; zugo/n, of horses as they run, Od. 3.486; pass. often, of spears, a forest, Il. 14.285; mid., ‘moved herself,’ Il. 8.199.
*se/lagos: the father of Amphīus, from Paesus, Il. 5.612†.
se/las, aos: brightness, light, gleam, radiance, of fire, lightning, the eyes in anger, Il. 17.739, Il. 8.76, Il. 19.17.
selh/nh (cf. se/las): moon.
*selhpia/dhs: son of Selepius, Evēnus, Il. 2.693†.
se/li=non: parsley, Il. 2.776 and Od. 5.72.
*sellh/eis: (1) a river in Elis near Ephyra, Il. 2.659, Il. 15.531.—(2) a river in the Troad near Arisbe, Il. 2.839, Il. 12.97.
*selloi/: the Selli, priests of Zeus at Dodōna, Il. 16.234†.

*seme/lh: Semele, daughter of Cad
mus and mother of Dion&ymacr;sus by Zeus, Il. 14.323 and 325.
se/o: see su/.
seu=a: see seu/w.

seu/w, aor. e)/sseua, seu=a, mid. ipf. e)sseu/onto, aor. 1 seu/ato, e)sseu/anto, subj. seu/wntai, aor. 2 e)/ssuo, e)/ssuto, su/to, pass. perf. e)/ssumai, part., w. pres. signif. and irreg. accent, e)ssu/menos: I. act. and mid. aor. 1, set a going rapidly, chase, drive, start; of impulsion by the hand of a god, ‘swung’ him, Il. 20.325; so of chasing persons down-hill, Il. 6.133; driving away animals, Od. 14.35, Il. 3.26; making a stone fly, a head roll, Il. 14.413, Il. 11.147; starting or drawing blood, Il. 5.208.—II. pass. and mid., sometimes even aor. 1, set oneself a going rapidly, rush, hasten, speed; w. inf., seu/ato diw/kein, ‘made haste’ to pursue, Il. 17.463, Il. 23.198; met., qu=mo/s moi e)/ssutai, Il. 10.484; esp. the part. e)ssu/menos, striving, eager, desirous, w. gen., Od. 4.733, w. inf. Od. 4.416.
shka/zw (shko/s), pass. aor. 3 pl. sh/kasqen: pen up, Il. 8.131†.
shko-ko/ros (kore/w): cleaner of pens or folds, Od. 17.224†.
shko/s: pen, fold.

sh=ma, atos: sign, token, mark, by means of which anything is identified, Od. 23.188; of the mark on a lot, Il. 7.189; a spot or star on a horse, Il. 23.455; mark to show the length of a throw, Od. 8.195; a sign from heaven, prodigy, Od. 21.413, Il. 13.244, Il. 22.30; a sepulchre, Il. 2.814, Il. 7.86; characters as a sort of pictorial writing, Il. 6.168.

shmai/nw (sh=ma), ipf. sh/maine, fut. shmane/w, aor. 1 sh/mhne, mid. aor. 1 e)shmh/nato: give the sign, hence, command, dictate, Il. 1.289; w. gen., Il. 14.85 ; e)pi/ tini, Od. 22.427; trans., mark, point out, te/rmata, Il. 23.358; mid., mark for oneself, something of one's own, Il. 7.175.
shma/ntwr, oros (shmai/nw): one who gives the sign, commander, leader, then driver, herder, of horses, cattle, Il. 8.127, Il. 15.325.
sh/meron (Att. th/meron, th=| h(me/ra|): to-day.
sh/pw, perf. se/shpe, pass. aor. subj. saph/h|: pass., and perf., rot, decăy. (Il.)
*sh/samos: a town in Paphlagonia, Il. 2.853†.
*shsto/s: Sestus, a Thracian city on the Hellespont, opposite Ab&ymacr;dus, Il. 2.836†.
sqenaro/s (sqe/nos): strong, Il. 9.505†.
*sqene/la=os: son of Ithaemenes, slain by Patroclus, Il. 16.586†.

*sqe/nelos: Sthenelus.—(1) son of Capaneus, and one of the Epigoni (‘Descendants’) who took Thebes, companion of Diomed, Il. 2.564, Il. 4.367 ff., Il. 23.511, Il. 9.48.—(2) son of Perseus and Andromeda, father of Eurystheus, Il. 19.116, 123.

sqe/nos, eos: strength; in periphrasis like bi/h, is, sqe/nos *=)idomenh=os, i. e. the strong Idomeneus himself, Il. 13.248, Il. 18.486, Il. 23.827; strength of the spirit, valor, Il. 2.451, Il. 14.151; and in general, ‘power,’ ‘might,’ ‘forces’ (army), Il. 14.274.
si/alos: fat hog, with and without su=s.
si=galo/eis, essa, en: shining, glistening, of garments, rugs, reins, room and furniture, Il. 5.226, Od. 6.81, Od. 5.86, Od. 16.449, Od. 18.206.
si=ga/w: only imp. si=/ga=, hush!
si=gh/: silence, only dat. as adv., still, silently.
sidh/reos, sidh/reios: of iron; o)rumagdo/s, ‘of iron weapons,’ Il. 17.424; fig., ou)rano/s, kradi/h, qu=mo/s, ‘hard,’ ‘unwearied,’ etc., Il. 22.357, Il. 24.205, Od. 12.280.
si/dhros: iron; epithets, polio/s, ai)/qwn, i)o/eis, tempered to blue steel; symbol of firmness, inexorableness, Od. 19.494 ; polu/kmhtos, of iron tools or weapons.
*si=doni/hqen: from Sidonia, Il. 6.291†.
*si=do/nios: Sidonian; as subst., Od. 4.84, 618.—*si=doni/h, Sidonia, the district containing the city Sidon, Od. 13.285.
*si=dw/n, w=nos: Sidon, the principal city of the Phoenicians, Od. 15.425.
*sidw/n, o/nos: pl., *sido/nes, the Sidonians, Il. 23.743.
si/zw (cf. ‘sizzle’), ipf. si/z(e): hiss, Od. 9.394†.
*si=kani/h: Sicania, earlier name of Sicily, Od. 24.307†.
*sikelo/s: Sicilian, Od. 24.211, 366, 389; pl., the Sicilians, Od. 20.383.
*sikuw/n: Sicyon, a city on the south shore of the gulf of Corinth, in the realm of Agamemnon, Il. 2.572, Il. 23.299.

*simo/eis: Simois.—(1) a small river
rising in Mt. Ida, and flowing through the Trojan plain into the Scamander, Il. 5.774, 777, Il. 12.22, Il. 4.475, *z 4, Il. 20.52. (See plate V., at end of volume).—(2) the same personified, the god of the river, Il. 21.307.
*simoei/sios: son of the Trojan Anthemion, slain by Ajax, Il. 4.474 ff.
si/nths: ravening. (Il.)
*si/nties (‘Plunderers’): the Sintians, ancient inhabitants of Lemnos, Il. 1.594, Od. 8.294.
*si=/pulos: Sipylus, a branch of the mountain range of Tmolus, near Magnesia, on the borders of Lydia, Il. 24.615†.

*si=/sufos (redup. from sofo/s): Sisyphus, son of Aeolus, father of Glaucus, and founder of Ephyra (Corinth), renowned for craft and wiles, Il. 6.153 ff. He was punished in Hades by rolling the ‘resulting’ stone up-hill, Od. 11.593.
si=te/w, mid. ipf. iter. si=te/skonto: feed, mid., eat, Od. 24.209†.
si=tos: grain, wheat, wheaten bread, Od. 9.9, Od. 1.139; then in general, food, Il. 24.602, Il. 19.306.
si=to - fa/gos: grain - eating, breadeating, Od. 9.191†.
siflo/w, aor. opt. siflw/seien: deform, ruin, Il. 14.142†.
siwpa/w, inf. siwpa=n, aor. opt. siwph/seian, inf. siwph=sai: keep silence, Od. 17.513 and Il. 23.568.
siwph/: silence, only dat. as adv., silently, secretly, Il. 14.310. See a)kh/n.
ska/zw, part. du. ska/zonte, mid. inf. ska/zesqai: limp. (Il.)

*skaiai/: pu/lai, and without pu/lai, Il. 3.263; the Scaean Gate of Troy, the only gate of the city which Homer mentions by name. It appears to have faced the Greek camp, affording a view over the Trojan plain, Il. 3.145, 149, 263, Il. 6.237, 307, 393, Il. 9.354, Il. 11.170, Il. 16.712, *s 453, Il. 22.6, 360.
skaio/s (cf. scaevus): left (hand), Il. 1.501; western, Od. 3.295.
skai/rw: skip, Od. 10.412 ; posi/, ‘with tripping feet,’ Il. 18.572.

*skama/ndrios: (1) of the Scamander; pedi/on, leimw/n, Il. 2.465, 467.—(2) Scamandrius, the real name of Hector's son Astyanax, Il. 6.402.—(3) a Trojan, the son of Strophius, slain by Menelāus, Il. 5.49.
*ska/mandros: Scamander, a river rising in Mt. Ida, called by the gods (ancient name) Xanthus, Il. 14.434, Il. 20.74, Il. 22.147 ff.
*ska/ndeia: name of a harbor in the island of Cythēra, Il. 10.268†.
*ska/rfh: a place in Locris, near Thermopylae, Il. 2.532†.
skafi/s, i/dos (ska/ptw): bowl, pl., Od. 9.223†.
skeda/nnu=mi, aor. (e))ske/dase, imp. ske/dason: scatter, disperse; ai(=ma, shed, Il. 7.330.
ske/dasis, ios: scattering; ske/dasin qei=nai = skeda/sai, Od. 1.116 and Od. 20.225.
ske/llw, aor. 1 opt. skh/leie: parch, Il. 23.191†.
ske/los, eos: prumno/n, upper part of the thigh, Il. 16.314†.
ske/parnon: adze, Od. 5.237 and Od. 9.391.
ske/pas: shelter; a)ne/moio, ‘against the wind,’ Od. 6.210. (Od.)
skepa/w, skepo/wsi: shelter against, keep off, Od. 13.99†.

ske/ptomai, imp. ske/pteo, aor. e)ske/yato, part. skeya/menos: take a view, look about; e)s, meta/ ti, ai)/ ken, at or after something, -to see whether, etc., Il. 17.652; trans., look out for, Il. 16.361.
skhpa/nion = skh=ptron, Il. 13.59 and Il. 24.247.
skhpt - ou=xos (skh=ptron, e)/xw): sceptre - holding, sceptred, epithet of kings; as subst., Il. 14.93.

skh=ptron: staff of a wanderer or mendicant, sceptre of kings, priests, heralds, judges. (See the cut, No. 109, representing Agamemnon.) When a speaker arose to address the assembly, a sceptre was put into his hands by a herald. Fig., as symbol of royal power and dignity, Il. 2.46; see also Od. 2.37, Od. 11.91.
skh/ptw: only mid. pres. part. skhpto/menos, supporting himself, leaning on his staff; ironically of one transfixed with a spear, Il. 14.457.
skhri/ptw, mid. inf. -esqai, part. -o/menos: lean upon, ‘push against,’ Od. 11.595.
skia/zw (skih/), aor. subj. skia/sh|: overshadow, Il. 21.232†.
skia/w (skih/): only pass. ipf. skio/wnto, were darkened. (Od.)

ski/dnamai (= skeda/nnumai), imp. ski/dnasqe, inf. -asqai, inf. ski/dnato, e)ski/dnanto: intrans., disperse, scatter, be diffused, of persons, dust, foam of the sea, a streamlet, Il. 16.375, Il. 11.308, Od. 7.130.
skiero/s: shady, Il. 11.480 and Od. 20.278.
skih/: shadow, shade; also of the nether shades, ghosts of the departed, Od. 10.495, Od. 11.207.
skio/eis, essa, en: affording shade, shady; me/gara, shadowy halls, an epithet appropriate to a large apartment illuminated by flickering fire-lights.
skirta/w (cf. skai/rw), opt. 3 pl. skirtw=|en: skip, gambol, bound along, Il. 20.226 and 228.
skolio/s: crooked; met., ‘perverse,’ ‘unrighteous’ (opp. i=)qu/ntata), Il. 16.387†.
sko/loy, opos: stake for impaling, palisades, Il. 15.344.
sko/pelos: cliff.
skopia/zw (skopih/), inf. -e/men: keep a look-out, watch, spy out, Il. 10.40.
skopo/s (ske/ptomai): watchman, watch, look-out, scout, spy; also of an overseer or person in charge, Il. 23.359, Od. 22.396; mark to shoot at, target, Od. 22.6 ; a)po\ skopou=, see a)po/.
sko/tios: in the dark, in secret, Il. 6.24†.
skoto-mh/nios (sko/tos, mh/n): dark from the absence of moonlight, moonless, nu/c, Od. 14.457†.
sko/tos: darkness, gloom; often in relation to death, Il. 4.461, Il. 5.47.
skudmai/nw, inf. -e/men = sku/zomai, Il. 24.592†.
sku/zomai, imp. sku/zeu, inf. -esqai, part. -o/menos: be wroth, incensed, indignant, tini/.
sku/lac, akos: whelp, puppy. (Od.)
*sku/llh: Scylla, daughter of Crataeis, a monster inhabiting a sea-cave opposite Charybdis, Od. 12.85, 108, 125, 223, 235, Od. 23.328.
sku/mnos: whelp of a lion, pl., Il. 18.319†.
*sku=ros: Scyros.—(1) an island northwest of Chios, with a city of the same name, Od. 11.509, Il. 19.326 .—*sku=ro/qen, from Scyros, Il. 19.332.—(2) a town in Lesser Phrygia, Il. 9.668.
sku=tos, eos: hide, leather, Od. 14.34†.
sku=to-to/mos: leather-cutter, leatherworker, Il. 7.221†.
sku/fos: rude cup, for drinking, Od. 14.112†.
skw/lhc, hkos: earth-worm, Il. 13.654†.
skw=los: pointed stake, Il. 13.564†.
*skw=los: a place in Boeotia, Il. 2.497†.
skw/y, skwpo/s: horned owl, Od. 5.66†.
smarage/w, aor. subj. smaragh/sh|: roar, thunder, re - echo, of the sea, storm, meadow full of cranes. (Il.)
smerdale/os: fearful, terrible, to look upon, dra/kwn, le/wn, etc.—Adv., smerdale/on, smerdale/a, de/dorken, Il. 22.95; elsewhere of sounds.
smerdno/s = smerdale/os, Il. 5.472.— Adv., smerdno/n, boa=n, Il. 15.687, 732.
smh/xw, ipf. e)/smhxe: wipe off, cleanse, Od. 6.226†.
smi=kro/s = mi=kro/s, Il. 17.757.

*sminqeu/s, voc. *sminqeu=: Smintheus, epith. of Apollo, explained by ancient commentators as meaning destroyer of field-mice (smi/nqoi). (The cut, showing a mouse at work, is reproduced from the tetradrachm of Metapontum.)
smu=/xw, aor. inf. smu=cai, pass. pres. opt. smu=/xoito: destroy by fire, <*>onsume, burn down, Il. 9.653 and Il. 22.411.
smw=dic, iggos: bloody wale, weal, Il. 2.267 and Il. 23.716.
so/h|: see sao/w.
soi=o: see so/s.
so/los: mass of cast iron used as a quoit, Il. 23.826, 839, 844.
*so/lumoi: the Solymi, a Lycian tribe, Il. 6.184, 204, Od. 5.283.
so/os (sa/os): safe, sound, see sw=s.
soro/s: funeral-urn, Il. 23.91†.

so/s, sh/, so/n, gen. soi=o: thy, thine, usually without article, with art., Il. 1.185, Il. 6.457; neut. as subst., e)pi\ soi=si, ‘thy possessions,’ Od. 2.369 ; so(s po/qos, sh\ poqh/, longing ‘for thee,’ Il. 19.321, Od. 11.202.
*sou/nion: Sunium, the southernmost promontory of Attica, Od. 3.278†.
sofi/h (sofo/s): skill, accomplishment, Il. 15.412†.
so/w|s: see sao/w.

*spa/rth: Sparta, the principal city of Laconia, residence of Menelāus and Helen. Epith., eu)rei=a, kalligu/naic, Od. 11.460, Od. 13.412, Il. 2.582, Il. 4.52, Od. 1.93, Od. 2.214, 359.—*spa/rthqen, from Sparta, Od. 2.327, Od. 4.10 .—*spa/rthnde, to Sparta, Od. 1.285.
spa/rton (cf. spei=ron): pl., ropes, Il. 2.135†.
spa/w, aor. e)/spasa, spa/se, mid. aor. (e))spa(s)sa/mhn, pass. aor. part. spasqe/ntos: pull up or out, draw forth or away; mid., for oneself, something of one's own, Od. 2.321, Od. 10.166, 439.
spei=o: see e(/pw.
spei=os: see spe/os.
spei=ron (cf. spa/rton, spei/rw): any wrap, garment, shroud, sail, Od. 5.318, Od. 6.269.
spei=sai, spei/sate: see spe/ndw.
*speiw/: a Nereid, Il. 18.40†.

spe/ndw, subj. 2 sing. spe/ndh|sqa, ipf. iter. spe/ndeskon, aor. e)/speisa, spei=san, iter. spei/saske, imp. spei=son: pour a drink-offering, oi)=non, u=(/dati, ‘with water,’ make a libation, *dii/, qeoi=s. Unmixed wine was poured upon the ground or on the altar (Od. 12.363) before drinking. de/pai, ‘with (from) the goblet,’ Il. 23.196, Od. 7.137.
spe/os, spei=os, gen. spei/ous, dat. sph=i, pl. dat. spe/ssi and sph/essi: cave, cavern, grotto; pl., of one with many parts, Od. 16.232.
spe/rma, atos (spei/rw): seed, germ; fig., puro/s, Od. 5.490†.
*sperxeio/s: Spercheius, a river in Thessaly; as river-god the father of Menestheus, Il. 16.174, 176, Il. 23.144.
spe/rxw, mid. opt. 3 pl. sperxoi/at(o): speed, drive fast, intrans. and mid. (freq. the part.), a)/ellai, e)retmoi=s, nau=s, *n 334, Od. 13.22, 115.
spe/sqai: see e(/pw.

speu/dw, inf. speude/men, aor. speu=se, imp. speu/sate, subj. speu/somen, mid. fut. speu/somai: be quick, hasten; speu=se ponhsa/menos ta\ a(\ e)/rga, ‘hastily performed,’ Od. 9.250; ‘struggle for,’ peri/ tinos, Il. 17.121; trans., hurry, ti\, ga/mon, Od. 19.137.
sph=i, sph/essi: see spe/os.
spidh/s, e/s: broad, Il. 11.754† (v. l. a)spide/os).
spila/s, a/dos: pl., reefs. (Od.)
spinqh/r, h=ros: spark, pl., Il. 4.77†.

spla/gxnon: pl., inwards, the nobler parts of the animal, esp. heart, liver, and lungs. While other parts of the victim were burning on the altar, these were roasted and tasted preliminary to the sacrificial banquet, Il. 11.464, Od. 3.9.
spo/ggos: sponge, Il. 18.414, Od. 1.111.
spodih/: ash-heap, Od. 5.488†.
spodo/s: ashes, Od. 9.375†.
spondh/: drink-offering, libation, see spe/ndw. Then a treaty, ratified by libations, pl., Il. 2.341 and Il. 4.159.
spoudh/ (speu/dw): earnest effort; a)po\ spoudh=s, ‘in earnest,’ Il. 7.359 ; a)/ter spoudh=s, ‘without difficulty,’ Od. 21.409 ; spoudh=|, eagerly, quickly; also with difficulty, hardly, Od. 3.297.
stadi/h: see sta/dios.
sta/dios (i(/sthmi): u(smi=/nh, standing fight, close combat; also e)n stadi/h| alone, Il. 7.241, Il. 13.514, Il. 15.283.
sta/zw, aor. sta/ce, imp. sta/con: drop, instil, Il. 19.39, 348, 354.
sta/qmh (i(/sthmi): chalk line; e)pi\ sta/qmhn i=)qu=/nein, straighten or make true ‘to the line,’ phrase used of various mechanical operations, Od. 5.245, Od. 21.121.

staqmo/s (i(/sthmi): any standingplace or thing that stands, hence stall, pen, or fold for animals, also the shepherd's lodge, Il. 2.470, Il. 19.377, Od. 17.20; so post, door-post, Il. 14.167, Od. 4.838; weight for the balance, Il. 12.434 .—staqmo/nde, to the stall, homeward, Od. 9.451.
sta/menai: see i(/sthmi.
stami=nes, dat. stami/nessin: braces in a boat, enabling the ribs to resist the inward pressure of the water, Od. 5.252†. (In plate IV., however, the stami=nes are taken as the same as ribs.)
sta/n: see i(/sthmi.
sta/c(e): see sta/zw.
sta=/s: see i(/sthmi.
stato/s (i(/sthmi): i(/ppos, stalled horse. (Il.)
stauro/s: stake, pale, pl., Il. 24.453 and Od. 14.11.
stafulh/: bunch of grapes.
stafu/lh: plummet; stafu/lh| e)pi\ nw=ton e)i=sai, matched to a hair in height (plumb-equal), Il. 2.765†.
sta/xus, uos: ear of grain, pl., Il. 23.598†.
ste/ar, ste/a=tos: hardened fat, tallow, Od. 21.178 and 183.
stei/bw, ipf. stei=bon: tread, stamp, trample upon, Il. 11.534; of washing clothes by foot-power, Od. 6.92.
stei=la: see ste/llw.
steileih/ (ste/llw): hole in an axhead for the helve, Od. 21.422†.
steileio/n (ste/llw): axe-helve, handle, Od. 5.236†.
stei=nos, eos (steno/s): close or confined space, narrow entrance, narrows, Il. 12.66, Il. 23.419.
stei/nw (steno/s), pass. pres. opt. stei/noito, ipf. stei/nonto: pass., be narrow, too narrow, crowded, dammed, weighed down, Il. 21.220, Od. 9.445, Od. 18.386.
stei/omen: see i(/sthmi.
stei=ra (1) (stereo/s): unfruitful, barren. (Od.)
stei=ra (2): fore part of the keel, stem, cut-water, Il. 1.482, Od. 2.428. (See cut No. 31, e.)
stei/xw (sti/xos, sti/xes), subj. stei/xh|si, ipf. e)/steixe, stei=xon, aor. 2 e)/stixon: march up or forward, go, move; of the sun, climb, Od. 11.17.

ste/llw, opt. ste/lloimi, fut. stele/w, aor. stei=la, mid. aor. stei/lanto; put in order, arrange, make ready, equip, send off, dispatch, mid., subjectively; ste/llesqe, ‘make yourselves ready,’ Il. 23.285; i(sti/a, ‘took in their’ sails, Il. 1.433.

ste/mma, atos (ste/fw): chaplet or fillet of a priest. Chryses takes the fillet from his head and places it upon his sceptre, because he comes as a suppliant, Il. 1.14. (The cut shows the band in two positions—as extended at full length, and as wrapped around the head. In the second representation the ends should hang down by the sides of the head below the ears, Il. 1.28.)
stena/xesx): see stena/xw.
stenaxi/zw, mid. ipf. stenaxi/zeto: sigh, groan, resound with groans, Od. 10.454.
stena/xw (ste/nw), ipf. iter. stena/xeske, mid. ipf. stena/xonto: sigh, groan, act. and mid.; act. also trans., lament, tina/, Il. 19.132; fig. of torrents, and of horses, Il. 16.391, 393.
*ste/ntwr: Stentor, whose voice was as loud as the united cry of 50 men, Il. 5.785†.
ste/nw (steno/s), ipf. e)/stene: sigh, groan, the bursting of pent-up breath and emotion, cf. stei/nw.—Fig. of the sea, Il. 23.230.
stereo/s, comp. sterew/teros: hard, stiff; li/qos, boe/h, Il. 17.493; fig., e)/pea, kradi/h, *m 267, Od. 23.103.—Adv., sterew=s, firmly, obstinately, Il. 23.42.
stere/w, aor. inf. stere/sai: deprive; tina/ tinos, Od. 13.262†.
ste/rnon: breast, chest.
steroph/ (a)steroph/, a)stra/ptw): lightning; then the gleam, sheen of metals, Il. 19.363, Od. 4.72, Od. 14.268.
sterop - hgere/ta: (if from e)gei/rw) waker of lightning, (if from a)gei/rw) gatherer of lightning, lightning-compeller, Il. 16.298†.

steu=mai, steu=tai, ipf. steu=to: denotes the expression of a wish by a gesture, have the appearance, make as if, foll. by inf., regularly the fut., once
aor., ‘pretends to have heard,’ Od. 17.525; diya=/wn, ‘stood as if thirsty,’ Od. 11.584; in general, engage, threaten, promise, tini/, Il. 5.832.

stefa/nh (ste/fw): that which surrounds, encircles anything at the top, as if it were a crown. Hence (1) a woman's head-band, Il. 18.597. (See cuts Nos. 16, 40, 41.)—(2) brim or visor of a helmet, helmet, Il. 11.96, Il. 10.30, Il. 7.12. (See cuts Nos. 12, 79, 80, 81, 86, 116.)—(3) of the edge of a cliff, Il. 13.138.
ste/fanos (ste/fw): crown, ring, Il. 13.736†. See stefa/nh.

stefano/w (ste/fanos), pass. perf. e)stefa/nwtai, plup. -to: put around as a crown; the pass. is to be understood literally, but it may be paraphrased ‘encircles,’ ‘encompasses,’ etc., Od. 10.195, Il. 11.36, Il. 5.739, Il. 15.153 ; ta/ t' ou)rano\s e)stefa/nwtai, ‘with which the heaven is crowned,’ Il. 18.485.
ste/fw (cf. stipo): properly to stuff or set close around, put on as a crown, crown with (cf. stefano/w), Il. 18.205; fig., Od. 8.170.
ste/wmen, sth=| sth/h|: see i(/sthmi.

sth=qos, eos, sth/qesfi: breast; as source of voice and breath, Il. 4.430, Il. 9.610; pl., often fig., as seat of the heart, Il. 14.140, Il. 9.256, Il. 10.95, Il. 1.189; hence of passions, emotions, reason.
sth/lh (ste/llw): pillar, Il. 13.437; esp., grave stone, monument (cf. cut), Il. 16.457, Il. 12.259.
sth/menai: see i(/sthmi.

sthri/zw (stereo/s), aor. (e))sth/rica, mid. aor. inf. sthri/casqai, plup. e)sth/rikto: set or fix firmly, Il. 11.28, Il. 4.443; intrans. and mid., support oneself or stand firmly, Il. 21.242; kako\n kakw=|, ‘was piled upon,’ Il. 16.111.
stibaro/s (stei/bw), comp. stibarw/teros: close-pressed, trodden firm, firm, compact, strong, of limbs, weapons.— Adv., stibarw=s, Il. 12.454.
sti=/bh (stei<*>bw): rime, hoar-frost, Od. 5.467 and Od. 17.25.
sti/lbw (cf. steroph/): only part., glistening, glittering; e)lai/w|, Il. 18.596; fig., ka/llei+, etc., Il. 3.392, Od. 6.237.
stilpno/s: sparkling, Il. 14.351†.
sti/c (Att. sti/xos), assumed nom., gen. stixo/s: row, rank, or file, of warriors, dancers, Il. 18.602 ; e)pi\ sti/xas, ‘in ranks’; kata\ sti/xas, ‘by ranks,’ Il. 2.687, Il. 3.113, 326.
stixa/omai, ipf. e)stixo/wnto: move in ranks, march, advance, of soldiers, herdsmen, ships, Il. 18.577, Il. 2.516.
*stixi/os: an Athenian leader, slain by Hector, Il. 13.195, Il. 15.329, 331.

sto/ma, atos: mouth; a)na\ sto/ma e)/xein, dia\ sto/ma a)/gesqai, phrases relating to utterance, Il. 2.250, Il. 14.91; fig., of the mouth of rivers or harbors, point of a lance, Il. 15.389 ; h)io/nos, ‘opening,’ ‘inlet,’ Il. 14.36.
sto/maxos (sto/ma): throat, gullet. (Il.)
stonaxe/w (stonaxh/), aor. inf. stonaxh=sai: sigh, lament, Il. 18.124†.
stonaxh/ (stena/xw): sighing, groaning, often pl.
stonaxi/zw: see stenaxi/zw.
stono/eis, essa, en: full of, or causing sighs and groans, mournful, grievous, a)oidh/, be/lea, *w 721, Il. 8.159.
sto/nos (ste/nw): sighing, groaning.
store/nnu=mi, strw/nnu=mi, aor. (e))sto/resa, pass. perf. e)/strwmai, plup. e)/strwto: spread, lay (sternere), a bed, couch, carpet; ‘lay,’ ‘calm,’ the waves, Od. 3.158.
*strati/h: a town in Arcadia, Il. 2.606†.
*strati/os: a son of Nestor, Od. 3.413 and 439.

strato/s (strw/nnu=mi), gen. strato/fin: army, host, Od. 2.30. In the Iliad strato/s is the encamped army of the Greeks before Troy, the 1186 ships, with streets throughout the camp, Il. 10.66. The tents or barracks stood parallel with the ships, and opposite the intervals between them, Il. 15.653 ff. At first the camp had no wall, the presence of Achilles rendering such defence needless, but after his withdrawal from warfare, by the advice of
Nestor (Il. 7.436-441), a massive wall was built, with gates and towers, Il. 12.118-123.
strato/omai, ipf. strato/wnto: be encamped, take the field, ‘conduct an expedition.’ (Il.)
strepto/s (stre/fw): twisted, braided; fig., glw=ssa, ‘voluble,’ Il. 20.248 ; fre/nes, qeoi/, to be turned, placable, Il. 15.203, Il. 9.497.
streu/gomai (stra/ggw, cf. stringo): be exhausted drop by drop, be wearied out, inf., Il. 15.512, Od. 12.341.
strefe-di=ne/w (stre/fw, di=ne/w): only pass. aor. 3 pl., strefedi=/nhqen de/ oi( o)/sse, his eyes whirled round and round, everything was in a whirl before his eyes, Il. 16.792†.

stre/fw, aor. stre/ya, iter. stre/yaskon, mid. ipf. e)stre/feto, fut. inf. stre/yesqai, pass. aor. e)stre/fqhn: turn around the other way (more than tre/pw), twist; of a chariot in battle or the race, Il. 23.323; intrans, of ploughing, Il. 18.544, 546; mid. and pass., turn oneself about (to and fro), twist, Il. 24.5, Il. 12.42; ‘twisting myself’ into his wool, Od. 9.435.
stre/yaskon: see stre/fw.
stro/mbos (stre/fw): top, Il. 14.413†.
strouqo/s: sparrow. (Il.)
strofa/ligc, liggos (stre/fw): eddy, whirl, of dust.
*stro/fios: the father of Scamandrius, Il. 5.49†.
stro/fos (stre/fw): cord, rope. (Od.)
strw/nnu=mi: see store/nnu=mi.

strwfa/w (stre/fw), strwfw=si, mid. inf. strwfa=sqai, ipf. strwfa=to: turn constantly; h)la/kata, z 63, Od. 17.97; mid., intrans., keep turning, tarry, dwell (versari), kat' au)tou/s, fighting among them, Il. 13.557.
stugero/s (stuge/w): abominable, hateful, hated.

stuge/w, aor. 2 e)/stugon, aor. 1 opt. stu/caimi: abominate, loathe, hate; kata\ (adv.) d' e)/stugon au)th/n, ‘were disgusted’ at the sight of her, Od. 10.113; aor. 1 is causative, make hateful or horrible, Od. 11.502.
*stu/mfhlos: a town in Arcadia, Il. 2.608†.
*stu/c, *stugo/s (‘River of Hate’): the Styx, a river of the nether world, by which the gods swore their most solemn oaths, Il. 2.755, Od. 10.514, Il. 8.369, Il. 14.271, Il. 15.37.
*stu/ra, pl.: a town in Euboea, Il. 2.539†.

su/, gen. se/o, seu=, sei=o, se/qen, dat. soi/, toi/, tei+/n, acc. se/: thou, thee. Most of the oblique forms are either enclitic or accented; sei=o and soi/ are never enclitic, toi/ is always enclitic; in connection with au)to/s all forms retain their accent. The pron. is frequently strengthened by ge/ or pe/r.
su-bo/sion (bo/sis), pl. subo/si=a (subo/seia): herd of swine, pl., Il. 11.769, Od. 14.101.
su-bw/ths (bo/skw), -ew: swineherd. (Od.)
su/ge: see su/.
sug - kale/w, aor. part. sugkale/sa=s: call together, summon, Il. 2.55 and Il. 10.302.
sug - klone/w, ipf. suneklo/neon: confound, Il. 13.722†.
sug - kure/w, aor. opt. sugku/rseian: hit or strike together, Il. 23.435†.

sug - xe/w, imp. su/gxei, ipf. su/gxei, aor. 1 sune/xeue, inf. sugxeu=ai, mid. aor. 2 su/gxuto: pour together, mix up, ya/maqon, Il. 15.364; mid. intrans, get entangled, h(ni/a, Il. 16.471; met., confuse, confound, bring to naught, no/on, i=)ou/s, ka/maton, o(/rkia, Il. 9.612, Il. 15.366, 473; a)/ndra, ‘break down,’ Od. 8.139.
su=ke/h, su=kh=: fig-tree. (Od.)
su=kon: fig, Od. 7.121†.
su=leu/w: despoil, rob, take advantage of, Il. 5.48, Il. 24.436.
sul-le/gw, aor. part. sulle/ca=s, mid. aor. sulle/cato, fut. sulle/comai: collect, gather up, mid., for oneself.

sum - ba/llw, cumba/llw, sumba/lleton, aor. 2 su/mbalon, du. cumblh/thn, inf. -h/menai, mid. aor. 2 cu/mblhto, -hnto, subj. cumblh=tai, part. -h/menos, fut. sumblh/(s)eai: I. act., throw, bring, or put together; of bringing men to
gether in battle, Il. 3.70; rivers uniting their waters, Il. 5.774; also intrans., like mid., Il. 16.565, Il. 21.578, Od. 21.15.—II. mid., intrans., meet, encounter, abs. and with dat., aor. 2 very freq., Il. 14.39, 27, 231, z 54, Od. 10.105.
*su=/mh: an island between Rhodes and Cnidus in Caria.—Adv., *su=/mhqen, from Syme, Il. 2.671.
sum-ma/rptw, aor. part. summa/rya=s: seize or grasp together, in order to break off, Il. 10.467†.
sum - mhtia/omai, inf. -a/asqai: take counsel together, Il. 10.197†.
sum-mi/sgomai: be mingled with, flow into, Il. 2.753.
su/m - pa=s, cu/mpa=s, a=sa, an: all (together).
sum - ph/gnu=mi, aor. sune/phce: of milk, curdle, Il. 5.902†.
sum - platage/w, aor. sumplata/ghsen: xersi/, smite the hands together, Il. 23.102†.
sum - ferto/s: combined, united, Il. 13.237†.
sum - fe/rw, mid. ipf. sumfero/mesqa, fut. sunoiso/meqa: mid., be borne or come together, meet in battle, Il. 8.400, Il. 11.736. (Il.)
sum-fra/dmwn (fra/zw): counselling together, pl., joint counsellors, Il. 2.372†.
sum - fra/zomai, fut. sumfra/ssomai, aor. sumfra/ssato: take or share counsel with, concert plans with, Il. 9.374, Il. 1.537; with oneself, deliberate, Od. 15.202.

su/n, cu/n, the latter (older) form for metrical convenience, but more freely in compounds: along with, together.— I. adv., together, at once; su
 de\ du/w ma/rya=s, Od. 9.289 (cf. 311, 344); su
 de\ nefe/essi (dat. instr.) ka/luyen | gai=an o(mou= kai\ po/nton, Od. 5.293; h)=lqe *doli/os, su
 d' ui(ei=s, ‘along with him,’ Od. 24.387; of mingling, confusing, breaking up, su
 d' h(/mi=n dai=ta tara/ch|, Il. 1.579 (cf. Il. 8.86); su
 d' o(/rki) e)/xeuan, Il. 4.269; su
 de\ ge/ronti no/os xu/to, Il. 24.358.—II. prep. w. dat., with, in company with, by the aid of; su
 qew=|, su
 qeoi=sin, su
 *)aqh/nh|, su
 soi/, Od. 13.391; of things, with, denoting accompaniment and secondarily instrument, the clothing or armor one wears, the ship one sails with, Il. 3.29, Il. 1.179; met., of quality or characteristic, a)/koitin su
 mega/lh| a)reth=| e)kth/sw, Od. 24.193; of consequence, penalty, su
 de\ mega/lw| a)pe/ti=san, Il. 4.161. su/n sometimes follows its case, Od. 15.410.
sun - a/gnu=mi, cuna/gnu=mi, aor. -e/aca, break or dash to pieces, crunch up, Il. 11.114.
sun-a/gw, cuna/gw, fut. -a/cousi: lead or bring together, collect; fig., e)/rida, *)/arha, join battle, ‘bring about,’ ‘stir up,’ Il. 5.861, Il. 16.764.
sun-aei/rw, mid. aor. subj. sunaei/retai: mid., couple together for oneself, Il. 15.680.
sun - ai/numai, ipf. sunai/nuto: take together, gather up, Il. 21.502†.
sun-aire/w, aor. 2 su/nele, part. sunelw/n: take together, lay hold of at once, Od. 20.95; ‘tore away,’ Il. 16.740.
sun - anta/w and suna/ntomai, part. sunanto/menos, ipf. sunh/nteto, sunante/sqhn, sunanth/thn, aor. subj. sunanth/swntai: meet, encounter.
sun - de/w, cunde/w, aor. -e/dhsa: bind together, bind fast, bind up.
sune/dramon: see suntre/xw.
sun-ee/rgw, aor. sunee/rgaqon: shut in or confine together, bind together, Od. 9.427, Od. 12.424.
sun-ei/kosi, cuneei/kosi: twenty (men) together, Od. 14.98†.
su/n - eimi, cu/neimi (1) (ei)mi/), fut. inf. -e/sesqai: be with, ‘be linked to,’ Od. 7.270†.
su/n-eimi, cu/neimi (2) (ei)=mi), part. cunio/ntes, ipf. 3 pl. cu/nisan, du. suni/thn: go or come together, esp. in hostile ways, meet; peri\ e)/ridos, e)/ridi, ‘in a spirit of strife,’ Il. 20.66.

sun - elau/nw, cunelau/nw, inf. cunelaune/men, aor. sune/lassa, subj. cunela/ssomen, inf. cunela/ssai: drive or bring together, booty, men in battle, Il. 11.677, Od. 18.39, Il. 20.134; intrans., e)/ridi, Il. 22.129.
su/nelon: see sunaire/w.
sun-eoxmo/s (root vex, o)xe/w): junction, Il. 14.465†.
sun-e/ri=qos: fellow-worker, Od. 6.32†.
su/n-esis, cu/nesis (i(/hmi): conflux, Od. 10.515†.
sun-exh/s (e)/xw): neut. as adv., su=nexe/s, continuously, Il. 12.26; w. ai)ei/, Od. 9.74.
sun-e/xw, cune/xw, ipf. su/nexon: hold together, intrans., meet, Il. 4.133, Il. 20.415; an old perf. part. sunoxwko/te means bent together over, Il. 2.218.
sun-hmosu/nh (i(/hmi): only pl., compacts, Il. 22.261†.
sun-h/oros (a)ei/rw): joined with, an accompaniment to, Od. 8.99†.
sun-qesi/h (<*>i/qhmi): only pl., treaty, Il. 2.339; instructions, Il. 5.319.
sun-qe/w, fut. sunqeu/setai: run with, go well, Od. 20.245†.

sun-i/hmi, cuni/hmi, imp. cuni/ei, ipf. 3 pl. cu/nien, aor. cune/hke, imp. cu/nes, mid. aor. cu=/neto, subj. sunw/meqa: let go with.—I. act., send or bring together, esp. in hostile ways, Il. 1.8, Il. 7.210; metaph., mark, attend to, hear (cf. conicere), w. acc., sometimes gen., of person or of thing, Il. 1.273, Il. 2.26.— II. mid., agree, covenant, Il. 13.381; also like act., mark, Od. 4.76.
sun-i/sthmi: only perf. part. pole/moio sunestao/tos, having arisen, Il. 14.96†.
sunoiso/meqa: see sumfe/rw.
sun-ori=/nw: only mid. part., fa/lagges sunori=no/menai, stirring or beginning to move (together), Il. 4.332†.
sun-oxh/, cunoxh/ (e)/xw): pl., meeting, o(dou=, of the forward and the homestretch, Il. 23.330†.
sunoxwko/te: see sune/xw.
sun-ti/qhmi, mid. aor. su/nqeto, imp. su/nqeo, su/nqesqe: put together; mid., metaph. with and without qu=mw=|, heed, take heed to, hear (animo componere), abs. and w. acc., Il. 1.76, Od. 15.27.
su/n-treis: three together, by threes, Od. 9.429†.
sun-tre/xw, aor. 2 sune/dramon: run or rush together, Il. 16.335 and 337.
sunw/meqa: see suni/hmi.
su=rigc, iggos: any tube, hence (1) shepherd's pipe, Pan's - pipe, Il. 10.13, Il. 18.526.—(2) spear-case, Il. 19.387.
*suri/h: a mythical island, far in the West, bevond Ortygia, Od. 15.403†.
sur-rh/gnu=mi: only pass. perf., sune/rrhktai, is broken, fig., kakoi=sin, Od. 8.137†.
su=s, suo/s, pl. dat. susi/, su/essi, acc. su/as, su=s: swine, pig, hog; ka/prios, wild boar, and so without ka/prios, Idomeneus sui+\ ei)/kelos a)lkh/n, Il. 4.253.
su/to: see seu/w.
su - forbo/s (fe/rbw): swineherd; pai=s, tending swine. (Od. and Il. 21.282.)

sfa/zw, aor. e)/sfaca, sfa/ce, pass. pres. part. sfazo/menoi, perf. part. e)sfagme/na: cut the throat, slaughter, always of animals, esp. victims for sacrifice, Il. 1.459, Od. 3.449, 454, Od. 1.92. The blood was caught in a vessel made for the purpose. (See cut under a)mni/on.)
sfai=ra: ball; sfai/rh| pai/zein, ‘play at ball,’ Od. 6.100. (Od.)
sfairhdo/n: like a ball, Il. 13.204†.
sfa/llw (cf. fallo), aor. 1 sfh=le, inf. sfh=lai: make to totter or fall, Od. 17.464, Il. 23.719.
sfarage/omai, ipf. sfarageu=nto: hiss, be full to bursting, Od. 9.390, 440.
sfa/s, sfe/: see sfei=s.
sfedano/n (cf. sfodro/s): neut. adj. as adv., eagerly, impatiently. (Il.)

sfei=s (root sve, cf. sui), gen. sfe/wn, sfei/wn, sfw=n (au)tw=n), dat. sfi/si(n), sf(i/n), acc. sfe/as, sfa/s, sf(e/): personal and reflexive pron. of 3d pers., them(selves). sfe/ and sfi/ are always enclitic, sfw=n and sfei/wn never. sfi/ is probably never reflexive. Rarely of things, Od. 9.70, Od. 10.355.
sfe/las, aos, pl. sfe/la=: footstool, foot-block, Od. 18.394 and Od. 17.231.
sfendo/nh: sling; serves in case of need as a bandage for a wound, Il. 13.600†. (See cut, representing an Assyrian slinger.)

sfe/teros (sfei=s): poss. pron. of 3d
pers., their; strengthened by au)to/s, Od. 1.7; as subst., e)pi\ sfe/tera, Od. 1.274.
sfhko/w (sfh/c), pass. plup. e)sfh/kwnto: compress in a wasp-like shape, bind together, Il. 17.52†.
*sfh=los: son of Bucolus, of Athens, Il. 15.338.
sfh=le: see sfa/llw.
sfh/c, sfhko/s (cf. vespa): wasp or hornet, Il. 12.167 and Il. 16.259.
sfi/, sfi/n: see sfei=s.
sfodrw=s (cf. sfedano/n): strongly, earnestly, eagerly, Od. 12.124†.
sfondu/lios: vertebra of the spine, pl., back-bone, Il. 20.483†.
sfo/s (sfei=s): their; always referring to a pl. subst., Od. 2.237, Il. 18.231.
sfu=ra: hammer, Od. 3.434†.
sfuro/n: ankle.
sfw(e/), gen. and dat. sfwi/n: dual of sfei=s, they two, both of them, Il. 1.8, 338. Both forms are enclitic, and instead of them the pl. forms are freq. employed.
sfw=i, sfw/, gen. and dat. sfw=in, sfw=|n: dual of su/, ye two, you two, you both, Il. 1.336, 574, Il. 11.776, 862. sfw=i and sfw=in are never enclitic.
sfwi/teros: of you two, of you both, Il. 1.216†.

sxedi/h: raft, light boat, Od. 5.234 ff. (An attempt has been made to represent the construction and parts of Odysseus's sxedi/h under a(rmoni/h=: a, the beams forming the e)/dafos, h. b, stami=nes. c, go/mfoi. d, a(rmoni/ai. e, e)phgkeni/des. f, i)/kria. g, i(sto/s.)
sxedi/hn (e)/xw): fem. adj. as adv., near at hand, in hand to hand fight, Il. 5.830†.
*sxedi/os: (1) a Phocian, the son of Iphitus, slain by Hector, Il. 2.517, Il. 17.306. —(2) a Phocian, the son of Perimēdes, slain by Hector, Il. 15.515.
sxedo/qen (e)/xw): from near at hand, close by, near, w. dat. or gen., Il. 16.800, Od. 19.477.
sxedo/n (e)/xw): near, hard by; w. dat. or gen., Od. 9.23, Od. 6.125; of relationship, Od. 10.441; of time, Il. 13.817, Od. 2.284, Od. 6.27.
sxeqe/ein: see e)/xw.
sxei=n, sxe/men, sxe/o: see e)/xw.
*sxeri/h: Scheria, a fabulous country, the home of the Phaeacians, Od. 5.34, Od. 6.8-263.

sxe/tlios (e)/xw), sxetli/h, Il. 3.414: properly, holding out, enduring, then in moral sense, hard, hardened, perverse, cruel; sxe/tlio/s ei)s, *)oduseu=, Od. 12.279 (cf. what follows); similarly, but without serious reproach, Il. 10.164; of things in Od., e)/rga, u(/pnos, i 295, Od. 10.69.
sxe/to: see e)/xw.
sxi/za: split wood; druo/s, oaken billet, Od. 14.425.
sxi/zw (cf. scindo), aor. e)/sxisen: cleave, split, Od. 4.507.
sxoi/ato: see e)/xw.
sxoi=nos: rush, rushes, Od. 5.463†.
*sxoi=nos: a town on a river of the same name in Boeotia, Il. 2.497†.
sxo/menos: see e)/xw.
sw/eskon, sw/zwn: see soa/w.
sw=kos (cf. sw=s, sw/zw): saviour, epith. of Hermes, Il. 20.72†.
*sw=kos: a Trojan, the son of Hippasus, slain by Odysseus, Il. 11.427 f., 440 ff.
sw=ma, atos: dead body, corpse, carcase.
sw=s (sa/os, so/os): safe, sound, unharmed; certain, Il. 13.773, Od. 5.305.
sw/w: see sao/w.

div1.head: *t
div1.entryFree: t) =(1) te/.—(2) toi/ (soi/), Od. 1.60, 347. —(3) toi/ after me/n (me/ntoi).
ta=go/s (ta/ssw): arranger, marshal, leader (v. l. t' a)goi/), Il. 23.160†.
taqei/s, ta/qh: see tei/nw.
tala-ergo/s (tlh=nai, ve/rgon): enduring labor, patient, drudging, epith. of mules.
*talaime/nhs: a leader of the Maeonians, Il. 2.865†.
*talai=+oni/dhs: son of Talaus, Mecisteus, Il. 2.566, Il. 23.678.

ta/lanton (root tal, tlh=nai): (1) scale, pl. scales, balance, Il. 12.433; esp. fig., of the golden scales in which Zeus balances the fates of men, Il. 8.69, Il. 16.658, Il. 19.223.—(2) a definite (unknown) weight, talent, xru=soi=o, *i 122, Od. 4.129.
tala-pei/rios (tlh=nai, pei=ra): enduring trials, much tried. (Od.)
tala-penqh/s, e/s (pe/nqos): bearing sorrow, patient in suffering, Od. 5.222†.
ta/laros (root tal): basket, of wicker-work, for fruit, etc., Il. 18.568; of silver, for wool, Od. 4.125.
ta/las, voc. ta/lan (root tal): foolhardy, wretch, Od. 18.327 and Od. 19.68. Cf. sxe/tlios.
talasi/-frwn (root tal, frh/n): stouthearted; epith. esp. of Odysseus.
tala/ssai: see tlh=nai.
talau/ri=nos (root tal, vri=no/s): lit., enduring the ox - hide shield, tough, doughty, brave; epith. of Ares, with polemisth/s.—Neut. as adv., bravely, Il. 7.239. (Il.)
tala/-frwn = talasi/frwn, Il. 13.300†.
*talqu/bios: Talthybius, a herald of Agamemnon, Il. 1.320, Il. 3.118, Il. 4.192, Il. 7.276, Il. 19.196, 250, 267, Il. 23.897. (Represented in the foll. cut, from a very ancient Greek relief.)
ta)/lla, ta)=lla: see a)/llos.
ta/me, tame/ein: see ta/mnw.
tamesi/ - xrws, oos (ta/mnw, xrw/s): cutting the skin, sharp-cutting. (Il.)
tami/h (fem. of tami/hs): house-keeper, stewardess; with and without gunh/, Od. 1.139, Il. 6.390; a)mfi/polos, Od. 16.152.
tami/hs (ta/mnw): steward, dispenser, Il. 19.44; fig., pole/moio, a)ne/mwn, *d 84, Od. 10.21.

ta/mnw, te/mnw, te/mw, aor. ta/me, inf. tame/ein, mid. aor. inf. tame/sqai, pass. perf. part. tetmhme/non: cut, cut up, off, out, etc., mid. subjectively; of ‘felling’ or ‘lopping’ trees, ‘hewing’ beams, ‘marking off’ an enclosure, ‘furrowing’ the earth with the plough, ‘cutting off’ (intercepting, driving away) cattle, ‘cutting’ the waves in sailing, Il. 9.580, Il. 13.707, Il. 18.528, Il. 21.38, Od. 3.175 ; o(/rkia, ‘conclude’ a treaty, see o(/rkion.
tana - h/khs, es: with long edge or point, sword or spear, axe, Il. 23.118.
tanao/s: long, Il. 16.589†.
tanau/-pous, podos: long-legged, i. e. slender-legged, Od. 9.464†.
tanhlegh/s, gen. e/os: doubtful word, epith. of qa/natos, anciently interpreted prostrating, laying stretched out at length (of a corpse); acc. to some moderns, from a)/lgos, long-lamented.
*ta/ntalos: Tantalus, son of Zeus, and father of Pelops, a king of Sipylus, who revealed the secrets of the gods, and was punished in Hades, Od. 11.582 ff.
tanu- (tei/nw): stem of an adj., used as a prefix, meaning stretched out long or thin.
tanu/ - glwssos: slender - tongued, long-tongued, Od. 5.66†.
tanu - glw/xi=n, i=nos: with slender (sharp) point, Il. 8.297†.
tanu - h/khs, es: with thin edge or point, keen, tapering, Il. 16.768.
tanu/ - peplos: with trailing robes, long-robed.
tanu-pte/ruc, ugos: with wide-stretching wings, Il. 12.237 and Il. 19.350.
tanusi/-pteros: broad-winged, Od. 5.65 and Od. 22.468.
tanustu/s, u/os (tanu/w): stretching or stringing of a bow, Od. 21.112†. (Illustrated in cut No. 34.)
ta/nutai: see tanu/w.
tanu/ - floios: with thin (smooth, tender) bark, Il. 16.767†.
tanu/ - fullos: with long or slender leaves. (Od.)

tanu/w, ta/nu=mi (Att. tei/nw), aor. (e))ta/nu(s)sa, mid. pres. ta/nutai, ipf. tanu/onto, aor. part. tanussa/menos, pass. perf. teta/nustai, plup. teta/nusto, aor. 3 pl. ta/nusqen, part. tanusqei/s: I. act., stretch, strain, extend, as in ‘stringing’ a bow, a lyre, Od. 21.407, 409; ‘holding horses to their speed’ with the reins, Il. 23.324; ‘drawing’ the shuttle to and fro in weaving, Il. 23.761; and in general of ‘arranging’ anything long or broad, spears, spits, tables, Il. 9.213, Od. 15.283, Od. 1.138. Metaph., e)/rida pole/moio, ma/xhn, po/non, e)/ridos pei=rar, *c 389, Il. 13.359.—II. pass. and mid., be stretched or extended, be tight; the cheeks ‘became full’ again, Od. 16.175; of mules, horses ‘stretching out,’ ‘laying themselves out’ to run, Il. 16.375, 475, Od. 6.83; nh=sos teta/nustai, ‘extends,’ Od. 9.116.— Mid., subjectively, Il. 4.112; reflexive, Od. 9.298.
ta/phs, htos: rug, coverlet, laid upon chairs or beds. (See cuts Nos. 69, 105.)
taprw=ta: see prw=tos.
ta/r: see te/ and a)/ra.

tara/ssw (traxu/s), aor t)a/raca, perf. part. tetrhxui=a, plup. tetrh/xei: stir up, trouble, disturb, throw into confusion; po/nton, i(/ppous, dai=ta, Od. 5.291, *q 86, Il. 1.579. The perf. is intrans., be in confusion, stormy, Il. 2.95, Il. 7.346.
tarbe/w, imp. ta/rbei, ipf. ta/rbei, aor. ta/rbhsa: be afraid, dread, intrans. and trans.
ta/rbos, eos: fear, dread.
tarbosu/nh = ta/rbos, Od. 18.342†.
*ta/rnh: a city on Mt. Tmolus, the later Sardis, Il. 5.44†.
tarph/menai, tarph=nai: see te/rpw.
tarso/s (tersai/nw): a surface for drying, crate, Od. 9.219; flat of the foot, Il. 11.377, 388.
*ta/rtaros: Tartarus, a dark abyss, place of imprisonment of the Titans, as far below Hades as the earth is below the heavens, Il. 8.13, 481.
tarfe/es (tre/fw): thick, close together, frequent.—Neut. as adv., tarfe/a, often, thickly, Il. 12.47†.
*ta/rfh: a town in Locris, Il. 2.533†.
ta/rfos, eos (tre/fw): thicket, only dat. pl., e)n ta/rfesin u=(/lhs, Il. 5.555 and Il. 15.606.
tarxu=/w, fut. tarxu=/sousi, aor. subj. tarxu=swsi: solemnly bury. (Il.)
tau/reios: of a bull, of bull- or oxhide. (Il.)
tau=ros: bull, with and without bou=s.
tafh/ios (ta/fos): for burial; fa=ros, winding-sheet, shroud. (Od.)
*ta/fioi: the Taphians, inhabitants of Taphos, notorious for their piracy, Od. 1.105, 181, 419, Od. 14.452, o 427, Od. 16.426.
*ta/fos: Taphos, an island between Lencadia and Acarnania, near Meganisi, Od. 1.417.
ta/fos (1) (qa/ptw): burial; funeralfeast, Od. 3.309.
ta/fos (2) (root qap, tafw/n): astonishment. (Od.)
ta/fros (qa/ptw): ditch, trench.
tafw/n: see qap-.
ta/xa: quickly, soon.
taxe/ws: quickly, speedily, Il. 23.365†.
ta/xista: see taxu/s.
ta/xos, eos: speed. (Il.)
taxu/-pwlos: with swift steeds.

taxu/s, ei=a, u/, comp. qa=/sswn, sup. ta/xistos: quick, swift, fleet.—Adv. comp. qa=sson, sup. ta/xista: quicker, most speedily; o(/ tti ta/xista, ‘with all speed,’ Il. 4.193, Od. 5.112; the comp. is also similarly used for emphasis, Od. 7.152, etc.
taxuth/s, h=tos: swiftness, speed, Il. 23.740 and Od. 17.315.

te/ (cf. que): enclitic conj., and; correl., te/.. te/ (both.. and), also te/.. kai/, and with h)de/. te/ has some uses in Homer of which only traces remain in the later language. Their exact force cannot always be discerned, and the particle itself remams untranslatable. It attaches itself esp. to rel. words (seemingly as if they needed a connective), o(/s te/, oi(=o/s te, o(/sos te, e)/nqa te, i(/na te, e)pei/ te, w(/s te, etc.; thus in Att. (with special meanings), oi(=o/s te, w(/ste. So ti/s te (ti\s), a)/lla te, ga/r te, me/n te, de/ te, a)ta/r te, ou)de/ te. In all these cases with or without a corresponding te/ in the connected clause, Il. 1.81, Il. 19.164. Many Latin words may be compared (for form, not necessarily for sense) with these combinations of te/, namque, atque, quisque, etc.
*tege/h: Tegea, a city in Arcadia, Il. 2.607†.
te/geos: roofed over, Il. 6.248†.
teei=o: see su/.
teqalui=a, te/qhla: see qa/llw.
te/qhpa: see qap-.
te/qnaqi, teqna/menai, teqna=si, teqnew/s, teqnhw/s, teqneiw/s: see qnh/skw.
tequwme/nos: see quo/w.
tei+/n: see su/.

tei/nw (cf. tendo), aor. 1 e)/teina, tei=ne, pass. perf. te/tatai, plup. te/tato, teta/sqhn, aor. ta/qh, pass. taqei/s: stretch, stretch out, extend, draw tight; of a bow, Il. 4.124; reins fastened tightly to the chariot rim (see cut No. 10), Il. 5.322; a sword hung by the baldric, Il. 22.307; a helmet-strap drawn under the chin, Il. 3.372. Metaph., lai/lapa, pass., nu/c, pto/lemos, Il. 16.365, Il. 17.736, Od. 11.19. i(/ppoisi ta/qh dro/mos, ‘was put forth,’ ‘exerted,’ Il. 23.375, 758. Cf. tanu/w.
tei=os: see te/ws.

*teiresi/hs: Tiresias, the blind seer of Thebes. Of all the shades in the nether world Tiresias alone retained his mental faculties unimpaired. Od. 10.524, 537, Od. 11.32, 50, 89, 139, 151, 479, m 267, Od. 23.251, 323.
tei=ros, eos (cf. te/ras, a)sth/r): pl., constellations, Il. 18.485†.

tei/rw (cf. tero), ipf. e)/teire, tei=re, pass. ipf. (e))tei/reto: wear out or away, only met., weary, exhaust, distress, of age, hunger, troubles, Il. 4.315, Il. 15.61, Od. 1.342; freq. the pass., be worn, hard pressed, afflicted, Il. 6.387.
teixesi - plh/ths: stormer of walls or cities, Il. 5.31 and 455.
teixi/zw (tei=xos): only mid. aor., e)teixi/ssanto, built for themselves, Il. 7.449†.
teixio/eis, essa, en: walled, well walled, well fortified, Il. 2.559 and 646.
teixi/on (dimin. from tei=xos): wall belonging to a building, not a city or town, Od. 16.165 and 343.
tei=xos, eos: wall of a city or town, then in general any fortification, rampart; tei=xos e)lau/nein, dei=mai, poih/sasqai, *m 4, Il. 7.436.
tei/ws: see te/ws.
te/ke, teke/ein: see ti/ktw.
tekmai/romai (te/kmwr), aor. tekmh/rato, -nto: set an end, hence decree, appoint, ordain, Il. 6.349, Od. 7.317; portend, predict, Il. 7.70, Od. 11.112, Od. 12.139.
te/kmwr (Att. te/kmar): goal, end; *=)ili/ou, ‘overthrow,’ Il. 7.30, Il. 9.48; then token, pledge, Il. 1.526.
te/knon (ti/ktw): child; freq. in endearing or conciliatory address, Il. 22.84, Od. 2.363. Of animals, young.
te/kon: see ti/ktw.
te/kos, eos = te/knon.
tektai/nomai (te/ktwn), aor. tekth/nato, -aito: build, Il. 5.62; met., contrive, devise, Il. 10.19. (Il.)
*tektoni/dhs: son of Tecton (‘Builder’), Polynāüs, Od. 8.114†.
tektosu/nh: art of the joiner, carpentry, pl., Od. 5.250†.
te/ktwn, onos (cf. pi/ktw, teu/xw): maker, builder, joiner, carpenter.
*te/ktwn: the father of Phereclus, Il. 5.59†.

telamw/n, w=nos (root tal): any belt or strap to bear or support something, hence (1) sword-belt, baldric (see cuts Nos. 86, 109).—(2) shield-strap, Od. 11.610, Il. 14.404 (see cut).—(3) thong attached to the ankles of a dead body, to drag it away, Il. 17.290. (Cf. cut No. 16.)
*telamw/n: Telamon, the son of Aeacus, brother of Peleus, king in Salamis, and father of Ajax and Teucer, Il. 8.283, Il. 13.177, Il. 17.284, 293, Od. 11.553.
*telamwnia/dhs: son of Telamon, Ajax, Il. 13.709.
*telamw/nios: Telamonian, Ajax the greater, as distinguished from Ajax son of Oī¨leus, so with ui(o/s, Il. 11.591. Also of Teucer, Il. 13.170, Il. 15.462.

tele/qw (te/llw): poetic synonym of ei)=nai or gi/gnesqai, nu\c h)/dh tele/qei, ‘it is already night,’ Il. 7.282 ; a)/rnes a)/far keraoi\ tele/qousin, ‘become horned,’ ‘get horns’ straightway, Od. 4.85 ; pan-
toi=si tele/qontes, ‘assuming all sorts of shapes,’ Od. 17.486.
te/leios (te/los): perfect; said of victims that are without spot or blemish, Il. 1.66; the eagle is teleio/tatos petehnw=n, because he brings the surest omen from Zeus, Il. 8.247, Il. 24.315.
telei/w: see tele/w.
teles - fo/ros (= fe/rwn te/los): bringing to perfection or maturity, hence e)niauto/s, a full year. (Od. and Il. 19.32.)

teleuta/w, ipf. teleu/ta=, fut. teleuth/sw, aor. teleu/thsa, mid. fut. teleuth/sesqai, pass. aor. inf. teleuthqh=nai: complete, bring to pass, fulfil; noh/mata, e)e/ldwr, Il. 18.328, Od. 21.200; o(/rkon, in due and solemn form, Il. 14.280; pass. and fut. mid., be fulfilled, come to pass, Il. 15.74, Od. 2.171, Od. 8.510.
teleuth/: end, accomplishment, purpose, Il. 9.625, Od. 1.249.
