tele/w, telei/w, ipf. te/leon, e)te/leion, fut. tele/w, telei=, aor. (e))te/le(s)sa, mid. fut., w. pass. signif., telei=tai, inf. tele/esqai, -ei=sqai, pass. perf. tete/lestai, plup. -to, aor. (e))tele/sqh: bring to an end or to completion, end, complete, accomplish, fulfil; freq. the pass., be fulfilled, come to pass, Od. 2.176, Od. 5.302 ; to\ kai\ tetelesme/non e)/stai, Il. 1.212; but tetelesme/nos also means ‘to be accomplished,’ ‘practicable,’ Il. 14.196, Od. 5.90.— Pay, render (tini/ ti), tribute, gifts, Il. 9.156 f., 598, Od. 2.34.
telh/eis, essa, en: ‘rich in fulfilment,’ perfect, hecatombs.
te/losde = ei)s te/los. (Il.)
te/lson = te/rma.
te/menos, eos (te/mnw, cf. templum): a piece of land marked off and reserved as the king's estate, Od. 11.185; or as the sacred precinct of a god (grove with temple), Od. 8.363.
*teme/sh: a town celebrated for its copper mines, perhaps in Cyprus, Od. 1.184†.
te/mnw, te/mei, temei=: see ta/mnw.
*te/nedos: Tenedos, a small island west of the Troad, Il. 1.38, Il. 11.625, Il. 13.33, Od. 3.159.
*tenqrhdw/n: a leader of the Magnesians from Thessaly, father of Prothoüs, Il. 2.756†.
te/nwn, ontos (tei/nw): du. and pl., muscles.
te/cw, te/comai: see ti/ktw.
te/o, teo/: see ti/s, ti\s.
teoi=o: see su/.
teo/s =so/s.

te/ras, atos and aos (cf. tei=ros, a)sth/r): prodigy, portent, omen, found in some manifestation of nature, such as thunder, lightning, the rainbow. te/ras *dio/s, ‘sent by Zeus,’ Il. 12.209 ; a)nqrw/pwn, ‘for men,’ Il. 11.28; of a monster, the Gorgon, Il. 5.742.
te/retron (tetrai/nw): auger, Od. 5.246 and Od. 23.198.
te/rhn, eina, en (cf. tei/rw): tender, soft, delicate.
te/rma, atos (cf. te/los, terminus): limit, goal; the turning - post in the race, Il. 23.307; a mark to show how far a quoit was thrown, Od. 8.193.
termio/eis, essa, en (te/rmis = pou/s): reaching to the feet; according to others, fringed, tasselled; xitw/n, a)spi/s, t 242, Il. 16.803.
*terpia/dhs: son of Terpis, Phemius, Od. 22.330†.
terpi-ke/raunos: delighting in thunder, epith. of Zeus.

te/rpw, ipf. e)/terpon, te/rpe, mid. fut. te/ryomai, aor. 1 part. terya/menos, aor. 2 red. tetarpo/mhn, subj. tarpw/meqa, red. tetarpw/mesqa, part. tetarpo/menos, pass. aor. e)te/rfqhn, e)ta/rfqhn, aor. 2 e)ta/rphn, 3 pl. e)/terfqen, ta/rfqen, ta/rphsan, subj. trapei/omen: I. act., delight, cheer; tina\ lo/gois, qu=mo\n fo/rmiggi, a)ei/dwn, Il. 15.393, Il. 9.189, Od. 1.107, Od. 17.385; a)kaxhme/non, Il. 19.312.—II. mid. and pass., enjoy oneself, take pleasure in, rejoice; tini/. Also tino/s, enjoy; fig., go/oio, ‘have one's fill’ of lamentation, Il. 23.10, Od. 11.212. The form trapei/omen = terfqw=men occurs Il. 3.441, Il. 14.314, Od. 8.292.
terpwlh/ (te/rpw): delight, rare sport, Od. 18.37†.
tersai/nw, aor. te/rshne: dry, dry up, Il. 16.529†.

te/rsomai, ipf. e)te/rseto, te/rsonto,
aor. 2 inf. tersh=nai, -h/menai: be or become dry; w. gen., dakruo/fin, Od. 5.152.
teryi/-mbrotos (broto/s): delighting mortals, Od. 12.269 and 274.
tessara/-boios (bou=s): worth four cattle, Il. 23.705†.
tessara/konta: forty.
te/ssares: four.
tetagw/n (cf. tango), defective aor. part.: laying hold of, Il. 1.591 and Il. 15.23.
te/tatai: see tei/nw.
teta/rpeto, tetarpw/mesqa, tetarpo/menos: see te/rpw.
te/tartos and te/tratos: fourth.— Adv. (to\)te/tarton, for the fourth time, Il. 16.786, Il. 22.208.
teta/sqhn: see tei/nw.
teteu/cetai, teteu/xetai, teteu/xeton: see teu/xw.
teteuxh=sqai (teuxe/w, teu/xea), inf. perf. pass.: to have armed ourselves, be armed, Od. 22.104†.
te/thka: see th/kw.
teti/hmai, teti/hsqon, part. tetihme/nos, also act. perf. part. tetihw/s: be troubled, sad; tetihme/nos h)=tor, tetiho/ti qu=mw=|, Il. 11.555.
te/tlaqi, tetlai/hn, tetla/men, tetla/menai, tetlhw/s: see tlh=nai.
tetmhme/nos: see ta/mnw.
te/tmon, te/tmh|s: see e)/tetmon.
tetra/ - guos (gu/hs): containing 4 gu/ai, four-acre lot; as subst., a piece of land as large as a man can plough in a day, Od. 18.374.
tetra-qe/lumnos (qe/lumnon): of four layers (of hide), Il. 15.479 and Od. 22.122.
tetrai/nw (cf. tei/rw), aor. te/trhne: pierce with holes, perforate, bore.
tetra/kis: four times, Od. 5.306†.
tetra/oros (a)ei/rw): yoked four abreast, pl., Od. 13.81†.
tetra-plh=|: four-fold, Il. 1.128†.
te/trapto: see tre/pw.
te/tratos: see te/tartos.
tetra - fa/lhros: with four - fold crest, kune/h. (Il.) (See cut under au)lw=pis.)
tetra/ - falos: with four - banded crest, kune/h. (Il.) (See cut No. 116.)
tetra/fato: see tre/pw.
tetraxqa/: in four parts.
te/trhne: see tetrai/nw.
tetrh/xei, tetrhxui=a: see tara/ssw.
tetri=/gei, tetri=gui=a: see tri/zw.
te/trofen: see tre/fw.
te/tta, voc.: a form of familiar address, as of a younger friend to an elder, Father; Diomed to Sthenelus, Il. 4.412†.
te/ttic, i=gos: tettix or cicada, an insect whose note was greatly liked by the ancients, Il. 3.151†.
tetugme/na, tetuxei=n, tetuxe/sqai, te/tucai, tetu/xqai: see teu/xw.
tetu/xhka: see tugxa/nw.
teu=, teu/: see ti/s, ti\s.
*teuqrani/dhs: son of Teuthras, Axylus, Il. 6.13†.
*teu/qra=s: (1) the father of Axylus. —(2) a Greek from Magnesia, slain by Hector, Il. 5.705.
*teu=kros: Teucer, son of Telamon and Hesione, half-brother of Ajax, the best archer before Troy, Il. 12.350, 371 f., Il. 13.170, Il. 6.31, Il. 8.273, 322, Il. 15.484.
*teutami/dhs: son of Teutamias, Lethus, Il. 2.843†.
teu=xos, eos: implement of any kind, regularly pl., arms, armor, also tackling of a ship, Od. 15.218.

teu/xw, fut. -cw, aor. e)/teuca, teu=ce, aor. 2 inf. red. tetukei=n, perf. part. teteuxw/s, mid. fut. inf. teu/cesqai, aor. 2 red. tetu/konto, opt. -oi/meqa, inf. -e/sqai, pass. perf. 2 sing. te/tucai, te/tuktai, 3 pl. teteu/xatai, inf. tetu/xqai, imp. tetu/xqw, tetu/gmhn, (e))te/tuco, -to, 3 pl. (e))teteu/xato, aor. e)tu/xqh, fut. perf. teteu/cetai: I. act., make, cause, of all kinds of handiwork, and metaph., a)/lgea, kh/dea/ tini, *a 110, Od. 1.244; so prepare, dei=pnon, etc.; with two accusatives, make, render, Il. 1.4.—Mid., prepare or have prepared for oneself, Il. 1.467, Il. 19.208.—II. pass. (fut. mid. w. pass. signif., Il. 5.653), be made, wrought, furnished, or ready, very often the
perf. and plup.; also the perf. act. in this sense, Od. 12.423; tetugme/nos, ‘well wrought,’ Il. 16.225, etc.; metaph., no/os tetugme/nos, ‘sound,’ Od. 20.366.—Esp. as synonym of ei)=nai, gene/sqai, be, become, take place, happen; oi(=on e)tu/xqh, poqh\ *danaoi=si te/tuktai, qau=m' e)te/tukto (for e)ge/neto, ge/gone, e)/stin, h)=n), Il. 2.320, Il. 17.690, Od. 9.190, and often.
te/frh: ashes. (Il.)
texna/w, texna/omai, aor. inf. texnh=sai (v. l. texnh=ssai), fut. texnh/somai, aor. texnh/sato, opt. -aito, part. -a/menos: construct with art, contrive, devise. (Od. and Il. 23.415.)
te/xnh (cf. ti/ktw, tekei=n): art, skill, device, craft, cunning, Od. 4.455, 529. (Od. and Il. 3.61.)
texnh/eis, essa, en: full of art or skill, skilful, Od. 8.297. Contracted pl. nom. fem. texnh=ssai (v. l. texnh=sai, from texna/w), Od. 7.110.—Adv., texnhe/ntws, Od. 5.270.
te/w|, te/wn: see ti/s.
te/ws, tei/ws: so long, Il. 24.658; meanwhile, Od. 15.127, Od. 18.190; some time, Od. 15.231; correl. to e(/ws, o)/fra, *u 42, Il. 19.189.
th= (cf. tei/nw): an old imp. used in offering something, here (extend your hand and take)! there! Il. 14.219, Od. 5.346.
th=|, th=: demonstr., here; rel., where, as, Il. 12.118, Od. 4.565, Od. 8.510.
th=|de: see o(/de.
th=qos, eos: oyster, pl. Il. 16.747†.
*thqu/s: Tethys, daughter of Uranus and Gaea, wife of Oceanus, and mother of the river-gods, Il. 14.302. Mother of all the gods according to Il. 14.201.
thkedw/n, o/nos: melting, wasting away, decline, Od. 11.201†.

th/kw, ipf. th=ke, mid. ipf. th/keto, perf., w. pres. signif., te/thka: act., melt; fig., qu=mo/n, ‘consume’ with grief, Od. 19.264.—Mid. and perf., intrans., melt, thaw, Od. 19.207; fig., waste away, pine away, Il. 3.176.
th=le: adv., far, far away; w. gen., far from, Od. 17.250, Il. 22.445; also with a)po/, e)k, g 313, Il. 2.863.
thledapo/s: distant, Il. 21.454; strange, foreign, Il. 22.45.
thleqa/wn (qa/llw), -qo/wsa, defective part.: luxuriant, blooming, of plants, forest, hair; pai=des, Il. 22.423.
thle - kleito/s: far - famed, wide-renowned.
thle-kluto/s = thlekleito/s.

*thle/maxos: Telemachus, the son of Odysseus and Penelope. The name (‘Afar - fighting’) was given to the child because he was born as his father was about to depart for the war of Troy. Telemachus is the principal figure in the first four books of the Odyssey, and his journey in quest of tidings of his father to Pylos and Sparta, under the guidance of Athēna in the form of Mentor, has made the name of his ‘mentor’ proverbial. After the return of Odysseus, Telemachus assists him in taking revenge upon the suitors. He is mentioned in the Iliad only in Il. 2.260, Il. 4.354.
*th/lemos: son of Eurymus, a seer among the Cyclōpes, Od. 9.509.
*thle/pulos: a town of the Laestr&ymacr;gons, Od. 10.82, Od. 23.318.
thle-fanh/s, e/s (fai/nomai): conspicuous far and wide, Od. 24.83†.
*thlefi/dhs: son of Telephus, Eurypylus, Od. 11.519.
thli/kos: of such an age, so old or so young, of the right age.
thlo/qen: from far away.
thlo/qi: far away; w. gen., far from, Il. 1.30.
thlo/se: to a distance, far away.
thlota/tw: adv., sup. to thlou=, most distant, Od. 7.322†.
thlou=: afar; w. gen., far from.
thlu/getos: doubtful word, dearly beloved. Neither the ancient nor the modern guesses as to the etymology of this word are worth recording.
th=mos: then, thereupon, correl. to h)=mos.
th=|per = h(=| per.
*threi/h: a mountain in Mysia, Il. 2.829†.
*thu/geton: Taygetus, a mountain range in Laconia, extending to Cape Taenarum, Od. 6.103†.
thu/sios: vain, fruitless, useless, Od. 3.316 and Od. 15.13.
ti/eskon: see ti/w.
ti/h (ti/ h)=): why then? why pray? ti/h de/; ti/h dh/; a)lla\ ti/h; Il. 15.244, o 326, Il. 20.251.
tiqaibw/ssw: lay up honey, Od. 13.106†.

ti/qhmi, tiqe/w, ti/qhsqa, ti/qhsi and tiqei=, 3 pl. tiqei=si, ipf. (e))ti/qei, ti/qesan, fut. inf. qhse/menai, aor. e)/qhka, qh=ke,
qh=kan, e)/qesan, qe/san, subj. qei/w, qei/h|s (qh/h|s), qe/wmen, qei/omen, opt. qei/hn, qei=men, qei=en, imp. qe/s, inf. qei=nai, qe/menai, mid. pres. part. tiqh/menos, fut. qh/somai, aor. qh/kato, e)/qeto, qe/to, e)/qesqe, qe/sqe, opt. qei=o, qei=to, imp. qe/w, qe/sqe: I. act., put, place, properly local, w. dat. of place or w. prep.; metaph., put into one's mind, inspire, suggest, me/nos tini\ e)n qu=mw=|, qu=mo/n tini, boulh\n e)n sth/qessin, Od. 1.321, Il. 24.49, *r 470, Od. 11.146; similarly of ‘proposing,’ ‘offering’ prizes at games, ‘depositing,’ ‘setting up’ offerings in a temple, ‘determining’ the limit, end, or outcome of anything, Il. 23.263, Od. 12.347, Il. 23.333, Od. 8.465; make, cause (poetic for poiei=n), o)rumagdo\n e)/qhken, Od. 9.235; ke/leuqo/n tini, Il. 12.399; and forming a periphrasis, ske/dasin qei=nai (= skeda/sai), Od. 1.116 ; *)axaioi=s a)/lge) e)/qhken, ‘caused,’ ‘gave rise to’ miseries for the Greeks, Il. 1.2; so w. double acc., tina\ a)/loxon qei=nai, *t 298, Od. 13.163.—II. mid., the above meanings subjectively applied, put or place for oneself, something of one's own, kolew=| a)/or, a)mfi\ w)/moisin e)/ntea, Od. 10.34, 333; met., e)n fresi ti, ‘take to heart,’ ‘consider,’ Od. 4.729 ; e)le/gxea tau=ta ti/qesqe, ‘hold,’ ‘deem this a disgrace to yourselves,’ Od. 21.333; make or prepare for oneself, Il. 9.88, Il. 24.402; w. two accusatives, tina\ qe/sqai gunai=ka, f 72, Il. 9.629.
tiqh/nh (qh=sqai): nurse. (Il.)
ti/qhsqa: see ti/qhmi.
*tiqwno/s: Tithōnus, a son of Laomedon, carried off by the goddess Eos, to be her spouse, Il. 20.237, Il. 11.1, Od. 5.1.

ti/ktw (root tek, cf. te/ktwn, te/xnh), fut. te/ceis, aor. 2 e)/tekon, te/ken, mid. fut. inf. te/cesqai, aor. 2 teko/mhn: give birth to, bear, bring forth, also of the father, beget; the mid., too, is said of either parent, Il. 2.741, 742, Od. 24.293.
ti/llw, ipf. ti/lle, mid. ipf. tille/sqhn, -onto: pluck out, mid., one's own hair; w. acc. of the person mourned for in this way, Il. 24.711.

ti=ma/w, ipf. e)ti=/ma=, ti=/ma=, aor. ti=/mhsa, subj. ti=mh/somen, inf. ti=/mhson, mid. aor. (e))ti=mhsa/mhn, pass. perf. teti=mh/mesqa, inf. -h=sqai: prize, deem worthy of honor, honor, mid. subjective.

ti=mh/ (ti/w): valuation, price, then (1) satisfaction, penalty, punishment; a)/rnusqai, a)poti=/nein, a)/gein, *a 159, Il. 3.286, Od. 22.57.—(2) honor, dignity, prerogative, of gods and kings, Il. 9.498, Od. 5.535, Il. 2.197, Od. 1.117.
ti=mh/eis, essa, en, and ti=mh=s, acc. ti=mh=nta, comp. ti=mhe/steros, sup. ti=mhe/statos: precious, Il. 18.475, Od. 11.327; then honored, Od. 18.161, Il. 9.605.
ti=/mios: honored, Od. 10.38†.

tina/ssw, ipf. e)ti/nasson, ti/nasse, aor. e)tinaca, mid. ipf. tina/sseto, aor. tinaca/sqhn, pass. aor. 3 pl. ti/naxqen: shake, brandish; dou=re, ai)gi/da, a)steroph/n, mid. ptera/, ‘shook their’ wings, Od. 2.151 ; qro/non, ‘overthrow,’ Od. 22.88 ; e)k (adv.) d' e)ti/naxqen o)do/ntes, ‘were dashed’ out, Il. 16.348; ‘plucked her garment,’ Il. 3.385.
ti=/numai, ti=/nutai, -usqon, -ntai, part. ti=nu/menos = ti=/nomai: punish, chastise, tina/, lw/bhn, Od. 24.326.

ti=/nw (ti/w), fut. ti=/sw, aor. e)/ti=sa, inf. ti=sai, mid. fut. ti=/somai, aor. e)ti=sa/mhn, ti=/sato, opt. 3 pl. ti=sai/ato, inf. ti=/sasqai: I. act., pay a debt or a penalty, atone for; in good sense, zwa/gria, ai)/sima pa/nta, a)moibh\n bow=n, Od. 5.407, q 348, Od. 12.382; in bad sense, ti=mh/n tini, qwh/n, Od. 2.193; w. acc. of the thing atoned for, Il. 1.42, Od. 24.352; rarely acc. of the person atoned for, Il. 17.34; ‘reward,’ Od. 14.166.—II. mid., exact satisfaction, make one pay you for something, tina/ ti, tina/ tinos, o 236, Il. 3.366; hence punish.
ti/pte (= ti/ pote), ti/pt), ti/fq): why pray?
*ti=runs, nqos: Tiryns, an ancient city in Argolis, with Cyclopean walls, residence of Perseus and other kings of Argos, Il. 2.559†.

ti/s, ti/, gen. te/o, teu=, pl. gen. te/wn (te/wn, z 119, Od. 13.200): interrog. pron., who? what? e)s ti/, how long? Il. 5.465.— Rarely in indirect questions, Il. 18.192, Od. 15.423, Od. 17.368.—Adv. ti/, why? how?

ti\s, ti\, gen. teu/, teo/, dat. (ou)/) tini, tew/|, tw/, pl. neut. a)/ssa: indef. pron. enclitic, some (any) one, some (any) thing; many a one, (every) one, Od. 19.265, Il. 2.388, 355; appended to adjectives, it makes them less precise, o(ppoi=) a)/ssa ei(/mata, ‘about what sort of clothing,’ Od. 19.218.—Adv., ti\, somewhat, in a degree, but adds force to a negation, ou)/ ti, not at all, by no means; ou)de/ ti, nothing whatever, Od. 3.184.
ti/sis, ios (ti/w): recompense, Od. 2.76; then vengeance, punishment, tino/s, ‘for something,’ e)/k tinos, ‘at the hands of some one.’

titai/nw (tanu/w, tei/nw), ipf. e)ti/taine, aor. 1 part. tith/na=s, mid. ipf. (e))titai/neto: stretch, draw, extend, mid., reflexive and subjective; of drawing the bow, chariot, plough, Il. 8.266, Il. 2.390; stretching out the hands, spreading a table, poising the balance, Il. 13.534, Il. 8.69, Od. 10.354; mid., of exerting one's strength, Od. 11.599; horses, birds, stretching themselves to run or fly, Od. 22.23, Od. 2.149; stringing a bow for oneself, Od. 21.259.
*ti/tanos: a place (mountain or town) in Thessaly, Il. 2.735†.
*titarh/sios: a river (later Eurōpus) of Thessaly, rising in Mt. Olympus and a branch of the Peneius, Il. 2.751†.

*tith=nes: the Titans, sons of Uranus and Gaea. Under the lead of Cronus they took possession of heaven, but were cast down by him into Tartarus. Finally Zeus, aided by Gaea, overpowered Cronus and shut him up with the other Titans, Il. 5.898, Il. 14.279.
ti/tos (ti=/nw): paid for, avenged; ti/ta e)/rga, ‘works of vengeance,’ Il. 24.213 (v. l. a)/ntita).
titrw/skw: see trw/w.
*tituo/s: Tityus, a giant, the son of Gaea, punished in Hades, Od. 11.576 -580, Od. 7.324.

titu/skomai (root tuk, tuxei=n), ipf. titu/sketo: (1) lit., try to hit, hence aim; a)/nta, ‘straight before one,’ Od. 21.48 ; tino/s, ‘at something’; met., of purpose, design, fresi/, *n 558, Od. 8.556.—(2) try to get, hence make ready, prepare; pu=r, i(/ppous u(p' o)/xesfi, ‘couple,’ ‘put to,’ Il. 8.41.
ti/fq): see ti/pte.
ti<*>w, inf. ti=e/men, ipf. ti=on, e)/tie, iter. ti<*>eskon, fut. ti=/sw, aor. e)/ti=sa, mid. ipf. iter. tie/sketo, pass. perf. part. teti=me/nos: value, estimate, then esteem, prize, honor.
tlh/mwn, onos (tlh=nai): enduring, patient, Il. 5.670; then bold, impudent, Il. 21.430. Cf. sxe/tlios.

tlh=nai (root tal), aor. 2 inf., ind. e)/tlhn, tlh=, tlh=men, e)/tlan, opt. tlai/hn, imp. tlh=qi, tlh/tw, tlh=te, aor. 1 e)ta/lassa, subj. tala/ssh|s, fut. tlh/somai, perf., w. pres. signif., te/tlhka, 1 pl. te/tlamen, imp. te/tlaqi, -a/tw, opt. tetlai/h, inf. tetla/men(ai), part. tetlhw/s, -ui=a: endure, suffer, bear up under, submit to, ti\, Il. 18.433; so the part. as adj., tetlho/ti qu=mw=|, with steadfast soul; and with part., Od. 5.362, Od. 20.311; with inf., bring oneself to do something (by overcoming any kind of a scruple), dare, venture, have the heart or the hardihood to do it, Il. 17.166.

*tlhpo/lemos: (1) a son of Hercules and Astyoche, who as a fugitive found safety in Rhodes, and became king there, Il. 2.653, 657, 661, Il. 5.628, 631, 632, 648, 656, 660, 668.—(2) a Lycian, son of Damastor, slain by Patroclus, Il. 16.416.
tlhto/s (tlh=nai): enduring, Il. 24.49†.
tmh/gw (te/mnw): cut; only pass., aor. 3 pl. tma/gen, fig., ‘they separated,’ ‘dispersed,’ Il. 11.146, Il. 16.374.
tmh/dhn (te/mnw): adv., so as to cut or graze, Il. 7.262†.
*tmw=los: Tmolus, a mountain in Lydia, near Sardis, Il. 2.866, Il. 20.385.
to/qi: there, Od. 15.239†.
toi/: pronoun. See (1) o(.—(2) su/.

toi/: enclitic particle of asseveration, certainly, you may be sure, I assure you, let me tell you; toi/ has been called the ‘gnomic’ particle from the frequency of its occurrence in the statement of general truths or maxims, kixa=/nei toi bradu\s w)ku/n, ‘the race is not always to the swift,’ Od. 8.329, Od. 2.276, Il. 2.298, etc. Sometimes it is impossible to decide whether this particle or the ethical dat. (toi/ = soi/) is meant, and probably the two were originally identical.
toi/gar: so then, accordingly, always at the beginning of the clause.

toi=os: of such a kind, such (talis), answering to oi(=os, *s 105, Od. 1.257; to o(poi=os, Od. 21.421; to o(/s, Od. 2.286; to o(/pws, Od. 16.208; with inf., capable, able; with adjs., so really, so very, just, Od. 1.209, cf. Od. 11.135, Od. 2.286.—Adv., toi=on, so, so very.

toio/sde, -h/de, -o/nde: such, like toi=os, but properly deictic, i. e. said with reference to something present or near, that can be pointed out, ‘such as that there,’ Il. 21.509, Od. 15.330. Sometimes implying ‘so good,’ ‘so fine,’ ‘so bad,’ etc., Il. 2.120, Il. 3.157, Od. 20.206; w. inf., Il. 6.463.
toiou=tos, toiau/th, toiou=to(n): of such a kind, such, like toi=os, but a stronger demonstrative; ‘so excellent,’ Il. 2.372, Il. 16.847; ‘so heinous’ things, Il. 23.494, Od. 22.315.
toi/sde(s)si: see o(/de.
toi=xos: wall of a house or court; sides of a ship, Od. 12.420, Il. 15.382.
toka/s, a/dos (ti/ktw): su/es, having just littered, Od. 14.16†.
tokeu/s, h=os: pl., parents; ancestors, Od. 4.596, Od. 7.54.
to/kos: bringing forth, delivery; offspring, young, Il. 15.141, Od. 15.175.
tolma/w (root tal), ipf. to/lmwn, e)to/lma=s, fut. tolmh/sw, aor. to/lmhsa: endure, bear, with part., Od. 24.162; with inf., Od. 24.261; be bold, dare, Il. 5.670, Il. 8.424.
tolmh/eis, essa, en: enduring, steadfast, daring, Od. 17.284, Il. 10.205.
tolupeu/w, fut. -eu/sw, aor. tolu/peusa: wind up as a ball (tolu/ph), hence contrive, do/lous, Od. 19.137, cf. u(fai/nw. Also achieve, finish, Od. 24.95, Il. 24.7.
tomh/ (te/mnw): end left after cutting, stump, stock, Il. 1.235†.
toca/zomai (to/con), opt. 3 pl. tocazoi/ato, fut. toca/ssetai, aor. opt. toca/ssaito: shoot with the bow; tino/s, ‘at something,’ Od. 8.218.
toceuth/s: bowman, archer, pl., Il. 23.850†.
toceu/w = toca/zomai, Il. 23.855†.

to/con (root tuk, tuxei=n), pl. to/ca: bow, freq. the pl. for the sing., as the weapon was made of two horns joined by a centre-piece, see Il. 4.105-111. The bow was strung by slipping the loop at one end of the string (neurh/) over the curved tip (korw/nh) at the end of the bow, see cut No. 34. For the way of shooting, see cuts Nos. 63, 89, 90, 104; and for the bow - case, Nos. 24, 124. The archer was regarded as an inferior sort of warrior, Il. 11.385.—For the art, archery, Il. 2.718, cf. 827.
tocosu/nh: archery, Il. 13.314†.
toco/ths: archer, Il. 11.385†.
toco-fo/ros: bow-bearing, Il. 21.483†.
to/prin: see pri/n.
topro/sqen: see pro/sqen.
toprw=ton: see prw=ton.
tore/w (cf. tei/rw, tetra/inw), aor. 2 e)/tore: bore, pierce, Il. 11.236†.
torno/w, mid. aor. tornw/santo, subj. tornw/setai: round off, mid., for oneself.
to/(s)sos: so great, so much, pl., so many.—Adv., to/(s)son, to/sa, so much, so very.
to(s)so/sde, -h/de, -o/nde = to/sos, but properly deictic, referring to something present or near.—Adv., to(s)so/nde.
to(s)sou=tos, -au/th, -ou=ton = to/sos, but a stronger demonstrative.—Adv., to(s)sou=ton.
tossa/ki, tossa/x): so many times, so often; answering to o(ssa/ki, Il. 21.268.
to/ssos, tossou=ton: see to/sos, tosou=tos.
to/te: at that time, then; freq. in apodosis, in phrases, kai\ to/te dh/, r(a, e)/peita.
tou=: see (1) o(.—(2) ti/s.—(3) ti\s.
tou)/neka = tou= e(/neka, therefore.
tou)/noma = to\ o)/noma.
to/fra: so long, answering to o)/fra, also to e(/ws, o(/te, pri/n, eu)=te. With de/, Il. 4.221. Up to the time (when), Il. 1.509. Meanwhile, Il. 13.83, Od. 12.166.
tra/gos: he-goat, pl., Od. 9.239†.
tra/peza (tetra/pedya, ‘four - foot,’ cf. tri/pos): table; ceni/h, ‘hospitable board,’ Od. 14.158. Guests as a rule, though not always, had each his own table, Od. 1.111.
trapezeu/s, h=os: belonging to the table; ku/nes, ‘table-dogs,’ i. e. fed from the table, cf. ‘lap-dog.’
trapei/omen: see te/rpw.
trape/w (tre/pw): tread, press, Od. 7.125†.
trafe/men, tra/fen: see tre/fw.
trafero/s (tre/fw): solid, firm; as subst., e)pi\ traferh/n te kai\ u(grh/n, cf. ‘terra firma,’ Il. 14.308 and Od. 20.98.
trei=s: three.
tre/mw (cf. tremo): tremble.

tre/pw, fut. tre/yw, aor. e)/treya, tre/ya, aor. 2 e)/trapon, tra/pon, mid. aor. 1 part. treya/menos, aor. 2 (e))trapo/mhn, pass. perf. te/trammai, imp. tetra/fqw, part. tetramme/nos, plup. 3 pl. tetra/faq), aor. inf. trafqh=nai: turn, so as to alter the direction more or less.—I. act., turn, direct; ti\ e)/s ti, pro/s, para/, kata/, a)na/ ti, etc., pass., Il. 14.403; of
guiding or leading one to a place, Od. 4.294, Od. 9.315; turning missiles aside, horses to flight, Il. 5.187, Il. 8.157, and without i(/ppous, Il. 16.657; esp., of turning, ‘routing’ an enemy, Il. 15.261; metaph., no/on, qu=mo/n, Il. 5.676.—With pa/lin, turn about or around, o)/sse, ‘avert’ the eyes, Il. 13.3 ; i(/ppous, Il. 8.432; met., fre/nas tino/s, Il. 6.61.—II. mid., intrans., turn oneself, with direction specified by preposition or adv., as above; metaph., trape/sqai e)pi\ e)/rga, *g 422, Od. 1.422; of motion to and fro (versari), trafqh=nai a)n' *(ella/da, ‘wander up and down’ through Hellas, Od. 15.80; met., change, tre/petai xrw/s, Il. 13.279; tra/peto noo/s, frh/n, kradi/h te/trapto, Il. 17.546, *k 45, Od. 4.260.

tre/fw, aor. 1 e)/qreya, aor. 2 e)/trafon, e)/traf) (tra/f)), du. e)trafe/thn, inf. trafe/men, perf. te/trofe, mid. aor. 1 opt. qre/yaio, pass. aor. 2, 3 pl., tra/fen: trans., make big or thick, make to grow by feeding, nourish, bring up, rear, tend; of curdling milk, Od. 9.246; among the trans. forms the aor. 1 mid. (causative) is to be included, Od. 19.368; said of plants, Il. 17.53; so fig., u=(/lh tre/fei a)/gria, xqw\n fa/rmaka, Il. 11.741.—Intrans. (pass., with aor. 2 and perf. act.), thicken, congeal, grow big, wax, grow up; peri\ xroi\ te/trofen a(/lmh, ‘encrusted,’ Od. 23.237 ; tra/fen h)d' e)ge/nonto, were born and bred, Il. 1.251.
tre/xw, aor. 1 iter. qre/caskon, aor. 2 e)/dramon, dra/me: run; fig., of the auger, Od. 9.386.
tre/w, trei=, inf. trei=n, ipf. tre/e, aor. e)/tre(s)sa: turn to flee, flee in terror, be afraid, fear. (Il.)
trh/rwn, wnos (tre/w): timid, epith. of the dove.
trhto/s (titra/w): bored, pierced with holes, perforated. Mooring stones had a hole through them to receive the cable, bedsteads were perforated for the bed-cord.
*trhxi=/s, i=nos: Trachis, a town in Thessaly near Thermopylae, Il. 2.682†.
*trh=xos: an Aetolian, slain by Hector, Il. 5.706†.
trhxu/s, ei=a, u/: rough, rugged; li/qos, a)kth/, a)tarpo/s, Od. 14.1; also of places, esp. Ithaca, Od. 9.27.
tri/aina (trei=s): the trident (threeforked harpoon), weapon of Poseidon, the symbol of his power, Il. 12.27, Od. 4.506.

tri=/bw (cf. tei/rw), inf. tri=be/menai, aor. e)/tri=ya, inf. tri=yai: rub, hence thresh corn (by treading out with oxen, see cut), Il. 20.496 ; moxlo\n e)n o)fqalmw=|, ‘plunge’ we should say (cf. ‘rubbed in’), Od. 9.333; pass. and fig., wear oneself out, Il. 23.735.
tri/-glhnos (glh/nh): with three eyeballs, of ear - rings with three drops or pearls, Il. 14.183 and Od. 18.297. (See cut, from an ancient Greek coin.)
tri - glw/xi=n, i=nos (glwxi=/n, glw=ssa): threebarbed, arrow, Il. 5.393 and Il. 11.507.
tri/-etes (ve/tos): three years long. (Od.)

tri/zw (cf. strideo, strix), part. tri/zousai, perf. part., w. pres. signif., tetri=gui=a, tetri=gw=tes, plup. tetri=/gei: of birds, twitter, Il. 2.314; of bats, ghosts, squeak, gibber, Od. 24.5, 7, 9; of wrestlers' backs, crack, Il. 23.714.
trih/konta: thirty.
trihko/sioi: three hundred.
*tri/(k)kh: a city in Thessaly, on the Peneius, Il. 2.729, Il. 4.202.
tri/ - llistos (li/ssomai): thriceearnestly prayed for, Il. 8.488†.
tri/-plac, akos: threefold, Il. 18.480†.
tri-plh=|: threefold, thrice over, Il. 1.128†.
tri/-polos (pole/w): thrice turned, i. e. thrice ploughed.

tri/-pos, odos: tripod. In Homer usually a three-footed kettle for warming water, Il. 23.702. Also used to mix wine in, as an ornament, and as a
prize in games, Il. 18.373, Il. 23.264. (The cut is from an ancient relief, representing a Delphic tripod, which was a favorite subject of representation.)
tri/ - ptuxos (ptu/ssw): triple, of three layers, trufa/leia, Il. 11.353†.
tri/s: thrice.
tris-kai/-deka: thirteen.
tris-kai-de/katos: thirteenth.
tri-stoixi=/: in three rows, Il. 10.473†.
tri/-stoixos: in three rows, Od. 12.91†.
tris - xi=/lioi: three thousand, Il. 20.221†.
tri/tatos: third.
*tri=toge/neia: ‘Trito - born,’ Tritogenīa, epith. of Athēna, also alone as name, Il. 8.39, Il. 22.183, Il. 4.515, Od. 3.378. The significance of the first part of the word is unknown.
tri/tos: third; to\ tri/ton, in the third place, for the third time, Il. 3.225.
tri/xa (tri/s): threefold, in three parts; tri/xa nukto\s e)/hn, ‘a third of the night remained,’ ‘'twas in the third watch,’ Od. 12.312. (Od.)
trixa=/i=kes: doubtful word, epith. of *dwrie/es, with waving or flowing plume (qri/c, a=)i=/ssw?), Od. 19.177†.
tri/xes: see qri/c.
trixqa/: in three parts.
*troizh/n, h=nos: Troezen, a town in Argolis, near the shore of the Saronic gulf, Il. 2.561†.
*troi/zhnos: son of Ceas, father of Euphēmus, Il. 2.847†.
*troi/h: (1) the Troad, or the district of which Troy was the principal city, Il. 2.162.—(2) Troy, otherwise called Ilium, Il. 1.129.
*troi/hqe(n): from Troy.
*troi/hnde: to Troy.
trome/w, mid. opt. 3 pl. tromeoi/ato: tremble with fear, quake, fre/nes, Il. 15.627; so the mid., Il. 10.10; trans., fear, dread, Od. 16.446.
tro/mos: trembling, tremor, shudder, Od. 24.49; then fear, terror.
trope/w (tre/pw): turn about, Il. 18.224†.
troph/: pl., h)eli/oio, turning - places (cf. ‘tropics’), where the sun daily turns back his steeds, indicating the extreme west, Od. 15.404†.
tro/pis, ios: keel. (Od.) (See cut under dru/oxos.)

tropo/s: pl., thongs or straps, by means of which oars were loosely attached to the thole - pins (klhi=des), Od. 4.782 and Od. 8.53. (See cut No. 32, d. *a later different arrangement is seen in the following cut, and in No. 38.)
trofe/onto: see trofo/eis.
trofo/eis, essa, en: big, swollen; ku=/mata trofo/enta (v. l. trofe/onto, ‘were swelling’), Od. 3.290†.
trofo/s: nurse. (Od.)
troxa/w: only part., a(/ma troxo/wnta, running about after me, Od. 15.451†.
troxo/s (tre/xw): wheel; potter's wheel, Il. 18.600; a round cake of wax or tallow, Od. 12.173, Od. 21.178.
truga/w, 3 pl. trugo/wsin, opt. trugo/w|en: gather harvest or vintage.
tru/zw (cf. trugw/n, ‘turtle-dove’): coo, fig., gossip, ‘din into one's ears,’ I 311†.
tru=/panon: auger, drill, of the carpenter, turned by a bow and string, Od. 9.385†. (The cut is from an ancient Egyptian representation.)
tru=pa/w, opt. 3 sing. tru=pw=|: bore, Od. 9.384†.
trufa/leia: helmet. (See the cut.)
tru/fos, eos (qru/ptw): fragment, Od. 4.508†.
tru=/xw (tru/w), fut. part. tru/conta: wear out, exhaust, consume, impoverish; oi)=kon, Od. 1.248; pass., Od. 1.288, Od. 10.177.
*trw|ai/, *trwa/s: see *trw|o/s.
trw/gw: gnaw, crop, browse upon, Od. 6.90†.
*trw=es: the Trojans, inhabitants of the Troad.
*trwia/s: see *trw/ios.
*trw/ilos: Troïlus, son of Priam and Hecuba, Il. 24.257†.

*trw/ios: (1) of Tros, belonging to Tros, the son of Erichthonius, Il. 5.222, Il. 23.378.—(2) Trojan, belonging to the Trojans, Il. 13.262.—Fem., *trwia/s, a/dos, lhi/s, gunai=kes, n 263, Il. 9.139; and as subst., without gunai=kes, Il. 18.122.
trw/kths: deceiver, knave, Od. 14.289 and Od. 15.415.
*trw|o/s: (1) of Tros, belonging to Tros, the son of Erichthonius, Il. 23.291. —(2) Trojan, belonging to the Trojans, Il. 5.461.—Subst., *trwai/, *trwa/des, Trojan women, Il. 3.384, Il. 6.442.
trwpa/w (tre/pw), part. trwpw=sa, mid. ipf. trwpw=nto, iter. trwpa/sketo: act., change frequently, vary, Od. 19.521; mid., intrans., turn oneself.
*trw/s: Tros.—(1) son of Erichthonius, father of Ilus, Assaracus, and Ganymēdes, Il. 5.265 ff., Il. 20.230 ff.—(2) son of Alastor, slain by Achilles, Il. 20.463.
trwto/s: vulnerable, Il. 21.568†.
trwxa/w (tre/xw), ipf. trw/xwn: run.
trw/w, trw/ei, aor. subj. trw/sh|, -hte, mid. fut. inf. trw/sesqai: wound; fut. mid. w. pass. signif., Il. 12.66; fig. (like bla/ptw), Od. 21.293.

tugxa/nw, fut. teu/comai, aor. 2 e)/tuxon, tu/xon, subj. tu/xwmi, aor. 1 (e))tu/xhsa, perf. part. tetuxhkw/s: (1) hit the mark, w. gen., Il. 16.609, etc.; freq. the part. tuxw/n, tuxh/sa=s and ba/llw, ou)ta/w, nu/ssw (where the acc. is to be construed not w. the part. but w. the verb), Il. 4.106, Il. 5.582; so fig. w. part. of another verb, be successful in doing something, succeed; ou)k e)tu/xhsen e(li/ca=s, Il. 23.466; abs. (without part.), Il. 8.430; then, come upon, chance upon, hence get, gain, obtain, Od. 21.13, Il. 5.587, Od. 15.158.—(2) happen to be there, be by chance, happen; often nearly equiv. to ei)=nai, *r 748, Od. 10.88; often w. part. which in Eng. becomes the principal verb, tu/xhse ga\r e)rxome/nh nhu=s, ‘was by chance about to sail,’ Od. 14.334; impers., fall to one's share, Il. 11.684.
*tu=dei/dhs: son of Tydeus, Diomēdes, Il. 5.1, 281, Il. 14.380.

*tu=deu/s: Tydeus, son of Oeneus, king of Calydon in Aetolia, and father of Diomed, Il. 5.813, 163, Il. 6.96. While a fugitive at Argos he married the
daughter of Adrastus, and joined Polynīces in the expedition of the Seven against Thebes, Il. 4.376 ff.
tukto/s (teu/xw): well made, well wrought; tukto\n kako/n, ‘a born plague,’ Il. 5.831.
tu/mbos: funeral mound, tomb, grave. The mound was raised over the urn containing the ashes of the deceased.
tumbo-xoe/w (xe/w), aor. inf. tumboxoh=s(ai): heap up a funeral mound, Il. 21.323. The elision is exceptional, hence the v. l. tumboxo/hs, ‘of a mound.’
tumboxo/h: see the foregoing.
*tunda/reos: Tyndareüs, of Sparta, husband of Leda, and father of Clytaemnestra, Castor, and Pollux, Od. 24.199, Od. 11.298 ff.
tu/nh = su/.
tuph/: blow, stroke, pl., Il. 5.887†.

tu/ptw, aor. tu/ya, pass. perf. part. tetumme/nos, aor. 2 e)tu/phn: strike, hit, esp. in hand-to-hand encounter, hence opp. to ba/llein, Il. 11.191, *n 288, Il. 15.495; met., to\n a)/xos kata/ fre/na tu/ye ba- qei=an, ‘struck deep into his soul,’ Il. 19.125; pass., Il. 13.782, Il. 24.421; of rowers, a(/la tu/pton e)retmoi=s, Od. 9.104; ‘trod in’ his (Ajax's) footsteps, Il. 23.754 ; lai/lapi, ‘lashing’ with the tempest, Il. 11.306.
tu=ro/s: cheese.
*tu=rw/: Tyro, daughter of Salmōneus, and mother of Pelias and Neleus by Poseidon, Od. 2.120, Od. 11.235.

tutqo/s: little, small, of persons with reference to age, Il. 6.222, Il. 22.480, Od. 1.435; of things, tutqa\ diatmh=cai, kea/ssai, into small pieces, ‘small,’ Od. 12.174, 388. —Adv., tutqo/n, little, a little; fqe/ggesqai, ‘low,’ Il. 24.170; temporal, Il. 19.335.
tuflo/s: blind, Il. 6.139†.
*tufweu/s, e/os: Typhōeus, a monster, originally symbolical of the volcanic agencies of nature, Il. 2.782 f.
tuxh/sa=s: see tugxa/nw.
*tuxi/os: a Boeotian from Hyle, the maker (teu/xw) of Ajax's shield, Il. 7.220†.
tw=|, tw=: dat. of to/, then, therefore.
tw/s = w(/s, ou(/tws, thus.

div1.head: *u
div1.entryFree: *(ua/des (u(/w): the Hyades, seven stars in the head of the Bull, whose rising marks the beginning of the rainy season, Il. 18.486†.
u(aki/nqinos: hyacinthine; a)/nqos, Od. 6.231 and Od. 23.158.
u(a/kinqos: hyacinth, Il. 14.348†. An entirely different flower from our hyacinth, perhaps the larkspur.
*(ua/mpolis: a town in Phocis, on the Cephissus, Il. 2.521†.
u(bba/llein: see u(poba/llw.
u(bri/zw: be insolent or arrogant; trans., insult, outrage; w. cognate acc., lw/bhn, ‘perpetrate wantonly,’ Od. 20.170.
u(/bris, ios (cf. u(pe/r): insolence, arrogance, wanton violence. (Od. and Il. 1.203, 214.)
u(bristh/s: overbearing, insolent, wantonly violent person. (Od. and Il. 13.633.)
u(gih/s, e/s: healthful, sound, salutary, wholesome, Il. 8.524†.

u(gro/s: liquid, wet, moist; u(/dwr, e)/laion, ga/la, ke/leuqa ‘watery ways,’ i. e. the sea, Od. 3.71 ; a)/nemoi u(gro\n a)e/ntes, blowing ‘rainy,’ Od. 5.478. As subst., u(grh/, ‘the waters,’ opp. traferh/, Il. 14.308.
u(dato - trefh/s, e/s: water-fed, growing by the water, Od. 17.208†.
*(/udh: a town on Mt. Tmolus in Lydia, perhaps the later Sardis, Il. 20.385†.
u(drai/nw, mid. aor. part. u(drhname/nh: mid., wash oneself, bathe. (Od.)
u(dreu/w: draw water, mid., for oneself. (Od.)
u(drhlo/s: watery, well - watered, Od. 9.133†.
u(/dros: water-snake, Il. 2.723†.

u=<*>dwr, atos: water; pl., Od. 13.109;
prov., u(/dwr kai\ gai=a ge/noisqe, as we say ‘become dust and ashes,’ Il. 7.99.
u(eto/s (u(/w): shower, Il. 12.133†.

ui(o/s, gen. ui(ou=, ui(=os, ui(e/os, dat. ui(w=|, ui(=i, ui(e/i, acc. ui(o/n, ui(=a, ui(e/a, du. ui(=e, pl. ui(=es, ui(e/es, dat. ui(oi=si, ui(a/si, acc. ui(=as, ui(e/as, ui(ei=s: son; freq. ui(=es *)axaiw=n for *)axaioi/. The diphthong is sometimes shortened in ui(o/s, ui(o/n, ui(e/, Od. 11.270, 478, Il. 4.473.
ui(wno/s: grandson.
u(lagmo/s: barking, howling, Il. 21.575†.
*=(ulaki/dhs: son of Hylacus or Hylax, a name assumed by Odysseus, Od. 14.204.
u=(lako/mwros: loud - barking, Od. 14.29 and Od. 16.4.
u(lakte/w, ipf. u(la/kteon, u(la/ktei: bark, bay; kradi/h, ‘growled with wrath,’ Od. 20.13, 16.
u(la/w, u(la/omai: bark, bay, bark at, Od. 16.5. (Od.)
u=(/lh (cf. silva): wood, forest; also of cut wood, firewood, Il. 23.50, Od. 9.234. In general of brush, stuff, raw material, Od. 5.257.
*=(/ulh: Hyle, a town in Boeotia, Il. 5.708, Il. 7.221, Il. 2.500.
u=(lh/eis, essa, en: woody, wooded; also as two endings, Od. 1.246, Od. 16.123.
*(/ullos: a branch of the river Hermus in Lydia, Il. 20.392†.
u=(lo-to/mos (te/mnw): wood-cutting, axe, Il. 23.114; as subst., pl., wood-cutters, woodmen, Il. 23.123.
u=(mei=s, u=(me/wn, u=(mei/wn, dat. u=(mi=n, encl. u=(/mi=n, or u(=min, also u)/mmes, dat. u)/mm(in), acc. u)/mme: ye, you, pl. of su/.
u(me/naios: wedding-song, bridal-song, Il. 18.493†.
u=(me/teros: your, yours; w. gen. in apposition, au)tw=n, e(ka/stou, b 138, Il. 17.226.
u)/mme, u)/mmes, u)/mmin: see u=(mei=s.
u(/mnos: strain, melody, Od. 8.429†.
u=(mo/s = u=(me/teros. Forms: u=(mh/, u=(mh=s, u=(mh/n, u=(ma/, Il. 13.815, Il. 5.489, i 284, Od. 1.375.
u(p-a/gw, ipf. u(/pagon: lead under; i(/ppous zugo/n, i. e. yoke, and without zugo/n, Od. 6.63; lead out from under, withdraw, tina\ e)k bele/wn, Il. 11.163.
u(pai/: see u(po/.
u(/paiqa: out from under, sidewise, Il. 15.520 ; tino/s, sidewise away, at one's side, Il. 18.421.
u(p - a=i=+/ssw, fut. u(pa=i=cei, aor. part. u(pa=i=+/ca=s: dart or spring up under or out from under, Il. 21.126, Il. 2.310.
u(p-akou/w, aor. u(pa/kouse, inf. u(pakou=sai: hearken or give ear to, hence reply, Od. 4.283, Od. 10.83.
u(p-aleu/omai, aor. part. u(paleua/menos: avoid, evade, Od. 15.275†.
u(p - a/lucis: escape, Il. 22.270 and Od. 23.287.
u(p - alu/skw, aor. u(pa/luca: avoid, evade, escape from.
u(p - antia/w, aor. part. u(pantia/sa=s: come to meet, i. e. to meet the enemy and defend the man, Il. 6.17†.
u(/par: reality, real appearance as opp. to a dream, Od. 19.547 and Od. 20.90.
u(p-a/rxw, aor. subj. u(pa/rch|: begin, make a beginning, Od. 24.286.
u(p - aspi/dios: under the shield; adv., u(paspi/dia, ‘under shelter of the shield.’ (Il.)
u(/patos: highest, supremest, most high or exalted, usually as epith. of Zeus; also e)n purh=| u(pa/th|, ‘on the top’ of the pyre, Il. 23.165.
u(pe/a=si: see u(/peimi.
u(pe/ddeisan: see u(podei/dw.
u(pe/dekto: see u(pode/xomai.
u(peqerma/nqh: see u(poqermai/nw.

u(p-ei/kw, u(poei/kw (vei/kw), fut. u(poei/cw, aor. 1 u(po/eice, subj. u(poei/comen, mid. fut. u(pei/comai and u(poei/comai: retire, withdraw from (tino/s), yield, make way for (tini/); w. both gen. and dat., tw=| d' e(/drhs u(po/eicen, Od. 16.42; w. acc., xei=ra/s tinos, ‘before one's hands,’ Il. 15.227.
u(/p-eimi, 3 pl. u(pe/a=si, ipf. u(ph=san, be under; pollh=|si, ‘many had sucking foals,’ Il. 11.681.
u(pei/r, u(peire/xw, u(pei/roxos: see u(pe/r, u(per-.
*(upei/roxos: a Trojan, slain by Odysseus, Il. 11.335†.
*(upeiroxi/dhs: son of Hypirochus, Itymoneus, Il. 11.673†.
*(upei/rwn: a Trojan, slain by Diomed, Il. 5.144†.
u(p-e/k, u(pe/c: out from under.
u(p-ek-pro-qe/w: run on before, outrun. Il. 9.506.
u(p-ek-pro-lu/w: only aor., u(pekproe/lu=san, loosed from under the yoke (wagon), Od. 6.88†.
u(p-ek-pro-re/w: flow forth from the depth below, Od. 6.87†.
u(p-ek-pro-feu/gw, aor. 2 -fu/goimi, part. -fugw/n: escape by furtive flight.
u(p-ek-sao/w, aor. u(pecesa/wse: save from under, rescue, Il. 23.292†.
u(p - ek - fe/rw, ipf. u(pece/feron and u(pe/kferon: bear out from under, carry away; apparently intrans., ‘bear forward,’ Od. 3.496.
u(p-ek-feu/gw, aor. 2 u(pece/fugon and u(pe/kfugon, opt. -oi, inf. -e/ein: escape or come safely forth from, w. acc.
u(pemnh/mu=ke: see u(phmu/w.
u(p-e/nerqe(n): beneath, below, underneath; opp. kaqu/perqen, Od. 10.353; w. gen., Il. 2.150, Od. 3.172; ‘in the nether world,’ Il. 3.278.
u(pe/c: see u(pe/k.
u(p-ec-a/gw, aor. 2 opt. u(pecaga/goi: bring safely forth, rescue, bring safe home, Od. 18.147†.
u(p - ec - ale/omai, aor. inf. u(pecale/asqai: avoid, shun, Il. 15.180†.
u(p-ec-ana-du/w: only aor. 2 part., u(pecanadu=/s, emerging from under the sea, Il. 13.352†.

u(pe/r, u(pei/r (cf. super): over, prep. w. gen. and acc., accented u(/per when it follows its case.—(1) w. gen., local, over, above, beyond, across; u(pe\r ou)dou= bh=nai, Od. 17.575; u(pe\r kefalh=s sth=nai/ tini, Il. 2.20; thlou= u(pe\r po/ntou, Od. 13.257. Metaph., for, in defence of, Il. 1.444, Il. 7.449; w. verbs of entreaty, by, for the sake of (per), gouna/zesqai u(pe\r toke/wn, u(pe\r yu=xh=s kai\ gou/nwn, *o 660, Od. 15.261; then like peri/, concerning (de), Il. 6.524.—(2) w. acc., local, over, beyond, a)lalh=sqai u(pei\r a(/la, Od. 3.74; ‘along the surface’ of the hand, Il. 5.339. Metaph., beyond, transcending, against, u(pe\r ai)=san, moi=ran, qeo/n, *r 327, Od. 1.34.
u(per-a=h/s, e/s (a)/hmi): blowing excessively or strongly, Il. 11.297†.
u(per-a/llomai, aor. u(pera=lto, part. u(pera/lmenon: leap or spring over, w. gen. or acc. (Il.)
u(per - bai/nw, aor. 2 u(pe/rbh, 3 pl. u(pe/rbasan, subj. u(perbh/h|: step over, overstep, transgress.

u(per - ba/llw, u(peirba/llw, aor. 2 u(peire/balon, u(pe/rbale: cast beyond; sh/mata, ‘beyond the marks,’ Il. 23.843 ; a)/kron, ‘over the crest of the hill,’ Od. 11.597; rarely w. gen., Il. 23.847. Fig., excel, tina\ douri/, in throwing the spear, Il. 23.637.
u(pe/rbasan: see u(perbai/nw.
u(per-basi/h: transgression, violence.
u(perbh/h|: see u(perbai/nw.
u(pe/r-bios (bi/h): violent, lawless, insolent, wanton; not in bad sense, qu=mo/s, ‘abrupt,’ Od. 15.212.—Adv., u(pe/rbion, insolently.
u(per - deh/s, e/s, acc. u(perde/a= (for -dee/a): having very scanty forces, Il. 17.330†.
*(upe/reia: Hyperīa.—(1) a spring in Pelasgian Argos, Il. 6.457, Il. 2.734.— (2) the former abode of the Phaeacians, near the island of the Cyclōpes, before they removed to Scheria, Od. 6.4.
u(p - erei/pw: only aor. 2 u(ph/ripe, sank under him, Il. 23.691†.
u(p-ere/ptw: eat away; ‘was washing away’ the sand ‘under’ his feet, Il. 21.271†.

u(per-e/xw, u(peire/xw, aor. 2 u(pere/sxe, u(pere/sxeqe, subj. u(pe/rsxh|: trans., hold over or above; tino/s ti, Il. 2.426; for protection, xei=ra/s tini or tino/s, *d 249, Il. 9.420; intrans., overtop, Il. 3.210; of the sun and stars, rise, Il. 11.735, Od. 13.93.
u(pe/rh (u(pe/r): pl., braces, attached to the yards of a ship, by means of which the sails were shifted, Od. 5.260†. (See cut No. 37.)
u(per-hnore/wn, ontos (a)nh/r): part. as adjective, overbearing, overweening, haughty; epith. esp. of the suitors of Penelope. (Od. and Il. 4.176, Il. 13.258.)
*(uperh/nwr: son of Panthoüs, slain by Menelāus, Il. 14.516, Il. 17.24.
*(uperhsi/h: a town in Achaea, Il. 2.573, Od. 15.254.
u(perhfane/wn, ontos: part. as adj., exulting over, arrogant, Il. 11.694†.
u(/perqe(n): from above, above.
u(per - qrw/skw, fut. u(perqore/ontai, aor. 2 u(pe/rqoron, inf. -e/ein: spring over. (Il.)
u(pe/r - qu=mos: high - spirited, highhearted.
u(per-qu/rion (qu/rh): linted of a door, opp. ou)do/s, Od. 7.90†.
u(per i/hmi, fut. u(perh/sei: throw beyond (this mark), Od. 8.198†.
u(per - iktai/nomai: doubtful word, only ipf., po/des d' u(periktai/nonto, stumbled from haste, Od. 23.3†.

*(uperi=oni/dhs and *(uperi=/wn: son of Hyperīon and Hyperīon, epithets of
Helios, with and without *)he/lios, Od. 12.133, 176, a 24, Il. 19.398.
u(per-kata-bai/nw, aor. 2 3 pl. u(perkate/bhsan: go down over, surmount. (Il.)
u(per-ku=/dantas, acc. pl.: of high renown, Il. 4.66, 71.
u(per-mene/wn, ontos (me/nos): part. as adj., haughty, Od. 19.62†.
u(per-menh/s, e/s (me/nos): high-spirited, exalted.
u(pe/r - moron: beyond, i. e. against fate, adj. as adv., usually written separately u(pe\r mo/ron.— Pl., u(pe/rmora, with the same adverbial force, Il. 2.155.
u(per - opli=/h: presumption, arrogance, pl., Il. 1.205†. The i= is a necessity of the rhythm.
u(per - opli/zomai, aor. opt. -ssaito: vanquish by force of arms; according to others, presumptuously blame, Od. 17.268†.
u(pe/r - oplos: arrogant; neut. as adv., arrogantly, Il. 15.185 and Il. 17.170.
u(pe/r - oxos, u(pei/roxos: eminent. (Il.)
u(per-pe/tomai, aor. u(pe/rptato: fly over, fly past (the marks), Od. 8.192.
u(perra/gh: see u(porrh/gnu=mi.
u(pe/rsxh|: see u(pere/xw.
u(pe/rtatos (sup. from u(pe/r): highest, on the top, aloft, Il. 12.381 and Il. 23.451.
u(perteri/h: upper part, awning, wagon-cover, Od. 6.70†.
u(pe/rteros (comp. from u(pe/r): higher; then superior, better, more excellent; outer (flesh), Od. 3.65.
u(per-fi/alos (root fu, fu/w): strictly overgrown, then mighty, Il. 5.881; in bad sense, overbearing, arrogant, insolent. —Adv., u(perfia/lws, excessively, insolently, Il. 13.293, Od. 4.663.
u(p-e/rxomai, aor. 2 u(ph/luqe, u(ph/lqete, subj. u(pe/lqh|: go under, enter, w. acc.; fig., *trw=as tro/mos u(ph/luqe gui=a, ‘seized,’ Il. 7.215.
u(p - erwe/w: only aor., u(perw/hsan, started back. (Il.)
u(per-w/|h: palate, Il. 22.495†.
u(perwio/qen: from the upper chamber.

u(per-w/i+on, u(perw=|on: upper chamber, upper apartments, often pl. in both forms. The u(perw/i+on was over the women's apartment, and was occupied by women of the family, not by servants, Il. 2.514, Od. 17.101.
u(pe/sthn: see u(fi/sthmi.
u(p - e/xw, aor. u(pe/sxeqe, part. u(posxw(n: hold under, Il. 7.188 (‘held out’ his hand); qh/leas i(/ppous, ‘putting them to’ the horses of Tros, Il. 5.269.
u(p - hmu/w: only perf., u(pemnh/mu=ke, is utterly (pa/nta) bowed down, Il. 22.491†.
u(ph/neika: see u)pofe/rw.
u(p - hnh/ths (u(ph/nh, under part of the face): with a beard; prw=ton, ‘getting his first beard,’ Od. 10.279 and Il. 24.348.
u(p-hoi=os (h)w/s): toward morning, adj. for adv.

u(p-i/sxomai (e)/xw), ipf. u(pi/sxeo, aor. 2 u(pe/sxeo, -eto, subj. u(po/sxwmai, imp. u(po/sxeo, inf. -sxe/sqai, part. -sxo/menos: take upon oneself, undertake, promise, tini/ ti, and w. inf., regularly the fut. (exc., pres. inf. explanatory of subst., Il. 10.40); also ‘betroth,’ ‘vow,’ Il. 13.376, Od. 4.6, Il. 6.93, Il. 23.209.
u(/pnos: sleep; epithets, h(du/s, nh/dumos, lu=simelh/s, pandama/twr, xa/lkeos, fig. of death, Il. 11.241.—Personified, *(/upnos, Sleep, the brother of Death, Il. 14.231 ff.
u(pno/w: only part., u(pnw/ontas, sleeping, slumbering.

u(po/, u(pai/ (cf. sub): under. — I. adv., underneath, below, beneath, of motion or rest, u(po\ de\ qrh=nun posi
 (‘for the feet’) h(/sei, Il. 14.240; u(po\ de\ qrh=nus posi
 h)=en, Od. 1.131; xeu=en u(/po r(w=pas, Od. 16.47; often to indicate the position of parts of the body (in ‘plastic’ style as if one were looking at a picture up and down), u(po\ gou/nat' e)/lu=sen (the knees ‘beneath him’), u(po\ d' e)/treme gui=a, Il. 10.390; sometimes causal, thereunder, thereby, Od. 8.380, Il. 8.4; thus to denote accompaniment in music, li/non d' u(po\ ka=lo
 a)/eiden (to it, the harp), Il. 18.570, Od. 21.411. — II. prep., (1) w. gen., of position or motion; under, out or forth from under; u(p' a)nqerew=nos e)lei=n, krh/demnon u(po\ ste/rnoio tanu/ssai, Od. 5.346, and thus often w. verbs of hitting; r(e/ei krh/nh u(po\ spei/ous, ‘from beneath,’ Od. 9.141; then of agency, influence, by, through, in consequence of; damh=nai, qnh/skein u(po/ tinos (‘at the hands of’), feu/gein u(po/ tinos (‘before’), Il. 18.149 ; u(p' a)na/gkhs
(‘from necessity,’ ‘perforce’), u(po\ dei/ous (‘for’), u(po\ fri=ko\s *bore/w, Il. 23.692. —(2) w. dat., of position, under, and w. verbs of motion when the resulting position of rest is chiefly in mind, pi=/ptein, tiqe/nai ti u(po/ tini, x 449, Il. 16.378; instrumental or causal, under (not ‘by’ as w. the gen., but rather denoting subjection), u(po\ xersi/ tinos qane/ein, o)le/sai yu=xh/n, gh/rai u(/po a=)rhme/nos, Od. 11.136; of power, mastery, de/dmhto la=o\s u(p' au)tw=|, g 305, Il. 24.636; and of accompanying circumstances, u(po\ pomph=| (‘under the guidance’), pnoih=| u(/po (‘with the breeze’), Od. 4.402. —(3) w. acc., of motion (or extension), under, but often where the idea of motion is quite faint, zw/ein u(p' au)ga=s h)eli/oio, thinking of the duration of life, Od. 15.349, Il. 5.267; of time, during, Il. 16.202, Il. 22.102.
u(po-ba/llw, inf. u(bba/llein: throw or lay underneath; interrupt, Il. 19.80.
u(po-blh/dhn: interrupting, Il. 1.292†.
u(po/ - bruxa: adj. as adv., under water, Od. 5.319†.
u(po-da/mnhmi: only mid., u(poda/mnasai, thou subjectest thyself, Od. 3.214 and Od. 16.95.
u(pode/gmenos: see u(pode/xomai.
u(po-dei/dw, aor. u(po/ddeisan, u(podei/sate, part. u(poddei/sa=s, perf. u(podei/dia, plup. u(pedei/disan: be afraid before, shrink under, fear, abs., and w. acc.
u(po-deci=/h (de/xomai): hospitable welcome, Il. 9.73†. The i= is a necessity of the rhythm.

u(po-de/xomai, fut. u(pode/comai, aor. 1 u(pede/cato, aor. 2 u(pe/deco, -e/dekto, inf. u(pode/xqai, part. u(pode/gmenos: receive, esp. of friendly, hospitable welcome, pro/frwn, oi)/kw|, Od. 16.70; also with a thing as subject, koi=tos, ph=ma, Od. 14.275; bi/a=s, receive silently, submit to, endure, Od. 13.310; undertake, promise, Il. 7.93, Od. 2.387.
u(po/ - dhma, atos (de/w, ‘bind’): pl., sandals.
u(po-dmw/s: under-servant, underling, Od. 4.386†.
u(po/dra: look sternly, darkly, grimly.
u(po-drhsth/r, h=ros (dra/w): underworker, attendant, Od. 15.330†.

u(po-du/omai, fut. u(podu=/seai, aor. u(pe- du=/seto, aor. 2 u(pe/du=, part. u(podu=sa, -du/nte: plunge or dive under the water, Od. 4.435, Il. 18.145; abs., go under to carry, take on one's shoulders, Il. 8.332, Il. 17.717; fig., pa=sin go/os, grief ‘penetrated’ all, Od. 10.398; w. gen., emerge from, escape from, Od. 6.127, Od. 20.53.
u(po/eike: see u(pei/kw.
u(po - zeu/gnu=mi, fut. u(pozeu/cw: put under the yoke, harness, Od. 15.81†.
u(po-qermai/nw: only aor. pass., u(poqerma/nqh, was warmed, Il. 16.333 and Il. 20.476.
*(upoqh=bai: a town in Boeotia, Il. 2.505†.
u(po-qhmosu/nh (ti/qhmi): suggestion, counsels, pl., Il. 15.412 and Od. 16.233.
u(po-qwrh/ssw: only mid. ipf., u(peqwrh/ssonto, were arming themselves, Il. 18.513†.
u(poki=nh/santos: v. l. for u(/po ki=nh/santos.
u(po - kli=/nw: only pass. aor., u(pekli/nqh, he lay down, Od. 5.463†.
u(po-klone/w: only mid., u(poklone/esqai, to crowd themselves together in flight before Achilles, Il. 21.556†.
u(po - klope/omai: conceal oneself under something, opt., Od. 22.382†.
u(po - kri=/nomai, aor. opt. -kri=/naito, imp. u(po/kri=nai, inf. -kri=/nasqai: answer (<*>ni/); interpret, o)/neiron, and abs., Od. 19.535, 555, Il. 12.228, cf. Il. 5.150.
u(po-kru/ptw: only pass. aor., u(pekru/fqh, was hidden, Il. 15.626†.
u(po/ - kuklos: with wheels beneath, wheeled, Od. 4.131†.
u(po-ku/omai, aor. part. u(poku=same/nh: become pregnant, conceive.
u(po - lei/pw, mid. fut. u(polei/yomai: leave over, mid., remain.
u(po-leukai/nomai: grow white below, whiten, Il. 5.502†.
u(p-oli/zwn, onos (comp. from o)li/gos): somewhat smaller, on a smaller scale, Il. 18.519†. Also written as two words.

u(po - lu/w, aor. u(pe/lu=sa, mid. aor. 1 u(pelu=/sao, aor. 2 u(pe/lunto: act., loose from under, undo, Od. 9.463; fig., gui=a, me/nos, make to sink or fail, paralyze (slay), Il. 15.581, Il. 6.27; aor. 2 mid., as pass., Il. 16.341; mid., aor. 1, secretly set free, Il. 1.401.
u(po-me/nw, aor. u(pe/meina, inf. u(pomei=nai: remain, wait, sustain, withstand.

u(po - mimnh/skw, fut. part. u(pomnh/-
sousa, aor. u(pe/mnhse: remind, put in mind of. (Od.)
u(po-mna/omai, ipf. u(pemna=/asqe: woo or court unlawfully, Od. 22.38†.
u(po-nh/ios: lying under Mt. Neium, Od. 3.81†.
u(po-pepthw=tes: see u(popth/ssw.
u(po - perka/zw (perkno/s): begin to grow dark or turn, of grapes, Od. 7.126†.
u(po - pla/kios: situated under Mt. Placus, Hypoplacian Thebe, Il. 6.397†.
u(po-pth/ssw: only perf. part., u(popepthw=tes, having crouched down timidly under and hidden themselves amid the leaves, peta/lois, Il. 2.312†.
u(p-o/rnu=mi: only aor. 2, toi=on u(pw/rore *mou=sa, in so moving strains did the Muse begin, Od. 24.62†.
u(po-rrh/gnu=mi (vrh/gnu=mi), pass. aor. u(perra/gh: pass., burst forth (under the clouds), ai)qh/r, Il. 16.300 and Il. 8.558.
u(po/- rrhnos (vrh/n): having a lamb under her, Od. 10.216†.
u(po - ssei/w: whirl around (laying hold) below, Od. 9.385†.
u(postai/h: see u(fi/sthmi.
u(po-staxu/omai (sta/xus): fig., wax gradually like ears of corn, increase, Od. 20.212†.
u(po-store/nnu=mi, aor. inf. u(psstore/sai: spread out under; de/mnia/ tini, Od. 13.139†.

u(po-stre/fw, aor. subj. u(postre/ywsi, opt. -eias, mid. fut. inf. -yesqai, pass. aor. part. u(postrefqei/s: turn about, turn in flight, trans. and intr., Il. 5.581, Il. 11.446; mid. and pass., intr., turn, return, Od. 18.23.
u(posxeqei=n: see u(pe/xw.
u(posxe/sqai: see u(pi/sxomai.
u(po - sxesi/h = u(po/sxesis, pl., Il. 13.369†.
u(po/-sxesis, ios (u(pi/sxomai): promise.
u(po - tarbe/w: only aor. part., u(potarbh/santes, shrinking before them, Il. 17.533†.
u(po - tarta/rios: dwelling below in Tartarus, the Titans, Il. 14.279†.
u(po - ti/qhmi, mid. fut. u(poqh/somai, aor. 2 u(peqe/mhn, inf. u(poqe/sqai: place under, mid., fig., suggest, counsel; tini/ (ti), eu)=, pukinw=s, Od. 4.163, b 194, Il. 21.293.
u(po - tre/xw: only aor. 2 u(pe/drame, ran under (the menacing arm and weapon), Il. 21.68 and Od. 10.323.
u(po - tre/w, aor. u(pe/tresa, inf. u(potre/sai: take to flight, flee before one, Il. 17.587.
u(po-trome/w, ipf. iter. u(potrome/eskon: tremble before.
u(po/ - tropos (tre)pw): returning, back again.
u(p-oura/nios (ou)rano/s): under the heaven, ‘far and wide under the whole heaven,’ Od. 9.264.
u(po - fe/rw: only aor., u(ph/neikan, bore me away, Il. 5.885†.
u(po - feu/gw: flee before, escape by flight, Il. 22.200†.
u(po-fh/ths (fhmi/): declarer, interpreter of the divine will, pl., Il. 16.235†.
u(po - fqa/nw, aor. 2 part. u(pofqa=/s, mid. aor. 2 part. u(pofqa/menos: be or get beforehand, anticipate.
u(po-xei/rios (xei/r): under the hand, ‘under my hands,’ Od. 15.448†.
u(po - xe/w, aor. 1 u(pe/xeua: pour, spread, or strew underneath.
u(po - xwre/w, ipf. u(pexw/rei, aor. u(pexw/rhsan: retire before one, retreat. (Il.)
u(p-o/yios (o)/yis): despised; a)/llwn, ‘by the rest,’ Il. 3.42†.
u(/ptios (u(po/, cf. supinus): back, backward, on his back; opp. prhnh/s, Il. 11.179.
u(p - w/pion (w)/y): pl., face, countenance, Il. 12.463†.
u(p-w/reia (o)/ros), fem. adj. as subst.: foot of a mountain, skirts of a mountain range, pl., Il. 20.218†.
u(pw/rore: see u(po/rnu=mi.
u(p-wro/fios (o)rofh/): under the same roof, i. e. table-companions, pl., Il. 9.640†.
*(uri/h: Hyria, a town in Boeotia on the Eurīpus, Il. 2.496†.
*(urmi=/nh: a port in northern Elis, Il. 2.616†.
*(urtaki/dhs: son of Hyrtacus, Asius, Il. 2.837 ff., Il. 12.96, 110, 163.
*(/urtakos: a Trojan, the husband of Arisbe, Il. 13.759 and 771.
*(/urtios: son of Gyrtius, a Mysian, slain by Ajax, Il. 14.511†.

u(=s, uo/s (su=s), acc. u(=n, pl. dat. u(/essi: swine, pig, sow or boar. u(=s or su=s ac
cording to metrical convenience, but the latter is more common than the former.
u(smi=/nh: battle, conflict, combat; kraterh\ u(smi=/nh, u(smi=/nh dhio/thtos, Il. 2.40, Il. 20.245. —u(smi=/nhnde, into the battle.
u(sta/tios, adv. u(sta/tion = the following.
u(/statos: last, hindmost. — Adv., u(/staton.
u(/steros: after, later; ge/nei, i. e. younger, Il. 3.215.—Adv., u(/steron, u(/stera, later, afterward, hereafter, Od. 16.319 ; e)s u(/steron, Od. 12.126.

u(fai/nw, u(fa/w, u(fo/wsin, ipf. iter. u(fai/neskon, aor. 1 u(/fhna: weave, i(sto/n, ‘at the loom.’ (The Greek loom stood upright, like the Roman loom represented in the cut, or like the Egyptian loom in cut No. 59.) Fig., devise, contrive, as we say ‘spin,’ do/lon, mh=tin, i 422, Od. 4.678.
u(fanto/s: woven, Od. 13.136 and Od. 16.231.
u(/fasma: something woven, web, pl., Od. 3.274†.
u(fa/w: see u(fai/nw.
u(f-e/lkw: only ipf., u(/felke, sought to drag away by laying hold below at the feet, podoi=in, Il. 14.477†.
u(f - hni/oxos: charioteer as subject (u(po/) or subordinate to the warrior in the chariot, Il. 6.19†.
u(f - i/hmi, aor. 2 part. u(fe/ntes: let under or down, lower, Il. 1.434†.

u(f - i/sthmi, aor. 2 u(pe/sthn, 3 pl. u(pe/stan, imp. u(posth/tw, part. -sta=/s: aor. 2, intrans., take upon oneself, undertake, promise, Il. 21.273, Il. 9.445; place oneself lower, submit, tini/, Il. 9.160.
u(-forbo/s (u(=s, fe/rbw): swineherd; with a=)ne/res, Od. 14.410. (Od.)
u(fo/wsi: see u(fai/nw.
u(f-ago/rhs: high-talking, big talker, boaster. (Od.)
u(y - erefh/s, e/s (e)re/fw), u(yhrefh/s: high-roofed.
u(yhlo/s (u(/yos): high, lofty, highlying.
*(uyh/nwr: (1) a Trojan, the son of Dolopion, slain by Eurypylus, Il. 5.76.— (2) a Greek, the son of Hippasus, slain by Deiphobus, Il. 13.411.
u(yhrefe/s: see u(yere=fh/s.
u(y-hxh/s, e/s (h)=xos): high-neighing, with head raised on high, Il. 5.772 and Il. 23.27.
u(/yi: on high, up, aloft; o(rmi/zein, ‘on the high sea,’ in deep water, Il. 14.77.
u(yi-breme/ths (bre/mw): thundering aloft, high-thundering.
u(yi/ - zugos: on the high rower's bench, high at the helm, high-throned, high-ruling. (Il.)
u(yi - ka/rhnos. with lofty head or peak, Il. 12.132†.
u(yi/-kerws (ke/ras): with lofty antlers, Od. 10.158†.
u(yi/-komos (ko/mh): with lofty foliage.
u(yi-peth/eis = u(yipe/ths.
u(yi-pe/thlos (pe/talon): with lofty leaves or foliage.
u(yi-pe/ths (pe/tomai): high-flying.
*(uyipu/lh: Hypsipyle, wife of Jason, Il. 7.469†.
u(yi/-pulos (pu/lh): high-gated.
u(yo/qen: from on high, aloft.
u(yo/qi: high, on high, aloft.
u(y-o/rofos (o)rofh/): with lofty covering, high-roofed.
u(yo/se: upward, aloft.
u(you=: aloft, on high; of moving a ship ‘far out’ in the roadstead, Od. 4.785.
u=(/w, ipf. u(=e, pass. part. u=(o/menos: rain; subj. *zeu/s, ‘sent rain;’ pass., ‘beaten by rain,’ ‘drenched with rain,’ Od. 6.131.

div1.head: *f
div1.entryFree: fa/anqen: see fai/nw.
faa/ntatos, sup. (root fav): most brilliant, Od. 13.93†.
fa/gon: see e)/dw, e)sqi/w.
fa/e: see fai/nw.
fa/ea: see fa/os.
*fae/qousa: daughter of Helius and Neaera, Od. 12.132†.
fae/qwn, ontos (root fav), part. as adj., beaming, radiant.
*fae/qwn: name of a steed of Eos, Od. 23.246.
faeino/s (root fav), comp. faeino/teros: bright, brilliant, radiant.
faei/nw, parallel form of fai/nw, the aor. pass. faa/nqh, 3 pl. fa/anqen being referable to either pres.: shine, give light.
faesi/-mbrotos (broto/s): bringing light to mortals, shining for mortals, epith. of the sun and of Eos, Od. 10.138, Il. 24.785.
*fai/ac: see *fai/hkes.
faidimo/eis = fai/dimos.
fai/dimos: shining; only fig., ‘stately,’ gui=a, w)=mos, Od. 11.128; of persons, illustrious.
*fai/dimos: king of the Sidonians, Od. 4.617, Od. 15.117.
*fai/drh: Phaedra, wife of Theseus, Od. 11.321†.

*fai/hkes: the Phaeacians, a fabulous people related to the gods, dwelling in Scheria, where they lived a life of ease, averse to war and devoted to sea-faring. The ships in which they escort guests to their homes, however distant, are themselves possessed of intelligence to find the way. The names of nearly all the Phaeacians mentioned are significant of the love of ships, not excepting that of Nausicaa (nau=s), the most charming of them all, Od. 5.34, Od. 6.4, Od. 8.244 ff.
faine/sketo, fainome/nhfi(n): see fai/nw.
*fai=noy: son of Asius from Ab&ymacr;dus, the father of Xanthus and Thoön, Il. 17.583, Il. 5.152.

fai/nw, fa/w (root fav), ipf. f<*>ae, fai=ne, aor. e)/fhna, mid. ipf. iter. faine/sketo, fut. pefh/setai, inf. fanei=sqai, pass. aor. 2 (e))fa/nhn, 3 pl. fa/nen, iter. fa/nesken, subj. fa/nh|, fanh/h|, inf. fanh=nai, -h/menai, aor. 1 (may be referred to faei/nw) faa/nqhn, 3 pl. fa/anqen, perf. 3 sing. pe/fantai, part. pefasme/nos: I. act., trans., bring to light, make to appear, show, te/ras, o(do/n tini, *b 324, Od. 12.334; met., show, reveal, exhibit, express, noh/mata, a)oidh/n, a)eikei/a=s *s 295, Od. 20.309; intrans., shine, give light, Od. 7.102, Od. 19.25.—II. mid. and pass., come to light, be visible, appear, shine, Il. 8.561; w. part. (yet not purely supplementary), Od. 4.361, Od. 24.448; w. inf., Od. 11.336, Od. 14.355, Od. 15.25.
*fai=stos: son of Borus, from Tarne in Maeonia, slain by Idomeneus, Il. 5.43†.
*faisto/s: a city in Crete, near Gort&ymacr;na, Il. 2.648, Od. 3.296.
falagghdo/n: by phalanxes, in companies, in columns.
fa/lagc, aggos: phalanx, line of battle, column.
fa/lar(a): burnished plates of metal, rising above the helmet, Il. 16.106†.
falhria/w: only part., falhrio/wnta, brightly shining, gleaming, Il. 13.799†.
*fa/lkhs: a Trojan, slain by Antilochus, Il. 13.791, Il. 14.513.

fa/los: (1) the metal ridge or crest of the helmet, extending from back to front, with a socket to hold the plume (see cut No. 122).—(2) in narrower signification, the rounded boss, projecting forepiece, in which the fa/los terminated, Il. 6.9, Il. 13.132.
fa/n: see fhmi/.
fa/nen, fa/neske, fanh/menai: see fai/nw.
fare/trh (fe/rw): quiver. (Cf. the cut, and Nos. 89, 90, 104.)
*fa=ris: a town in Laconia, south of Amyclae, Il. 2.582†.
fa/rmakon: herb, drug; as medicinal remedy, or esp. as magic drug, poisonous drug, draught, or potion, Od. 10.392, Il. 22.94, Od. 1.261, Od. 2.329.
farma/ssw: apply a fa/rmakon, of metal, temper; part., Od. 9.393†.
fa=ros, eos: large piece of cloth, a shroud, Il. 18.353; mantle, cloak, for both men and women, Od. 5.230.
*fa/ros: Pharus, a small island at the mouth of the Nile, Od. 4.355†.
fa/rugc, gen. fa/rugos: throat. (Od.)
fa/sganon: sword.
fa/sqai: see fhmi/.
fa/skw (fhmi/), ipf. e)/faskon: declare, promise, think, cf. fhmi/.
fasso-fo/nos (fa/ssa, fe/nw): doveslayer, the i=)/rhc, ‘pigeon - hawk,’ Il. 15.238†.
fa/tis, ios (fhmi/): report, reputation; w. obj. gen., ‘tidings’ (of the slaughter) of the suitors, Od. 23.362.
fa/tnh (pate/omai): crib, manger.
*fausia/dhs: son of Phausius, Apisāon, Il. 11.578.
*feai/: see *feia=/.
fe/bomai, ipf. (e))fe/bonto: flee, flee from. (Il.)
*feia=/, *feai/: a town in northern Elis, on the river Jardanus, Il. 7.135, Od. 15.297.
*fei/da=s (‘Sparer’): a leader of the Athenians, Il. 13.691†.
*fei/dippos: son of Thessalus, Il. 2.678†.
fei/domai, aor. fei/sato, aor. 2 red. opt. pefidoi/mhn, inf. pefide/sqai, fut. pefidh/setai: spare, w. gen.
feidw/: sparing, thrift; ‘one must not fail’ in the case of the dead, etc.
feidwlh/: sparing, grudging use, Il. 22.244†.
*fei/dwn: Phidon, king of the Thesprotians, Od. 14.316, Od. 19.287.

fen- and fa- (cf. fo/nos), fe/nw, roots and assumed pres. for the foll. forms, red. aor. 2 e)/pefnon, pe/fne, subj. pe/fnh|, inf. pefne/men, part. pefno/nta, pass. perf. pe/fat(ai), inf. pefa/sqai, fut. pefh/seai, pefh/setai: kill, slay; of a natural death, only Od. 11.135; fig., e)k d' ai)w\n pe/fatai, ‘extinguished,’ Il. 19.27.
*fe/neos: a town in Arcadia, Il. 2.605†.
*ferai/: Pherae, a city in Thessaly, on Lake Boebēis, the residence of Admētus and Alcestis, and of Eumēlus, Il. 2.711, Od. 4.798.
*fe/reklos: son of Harmonides, builder of the ship in which Paris carried away Helen, slain by Meriones, Il. 5.59†.
*fe/rhs: son of Cretheus and Tyro, father of Admētus, Od. 11.259†.
fe/ristos = fe/rtatos, used esp. in the vocative.
*fe/rousa: a Nereid, Il. 18.43†.
fe/rtatos: one of the superlatives to a)gaqo/s, best, bravest, etc.
fe/rteros: one of the comparatives to a)gaqo/s, better, braver, etc.
fe/rte: see fe/rw.
fe/rtron (fe/rw): litter, bier for the dead, Il. 18.236†.

fe/rw, subj. fe/rh|si, imp. fe/rte, inf. fere/men, ipf. iter. fe/reskon, fut. oi)/sw, inf. oi)se/men, aor. 2 imp. oi)=se, -e/tw, -ete, inf. oi)se/men(ai), aor. 1 h)/neika, e)/neika, opt. e)nei/kai, inf. e)nei=kai, part. e)nei/ka=s, also aor. 2 opt. e)nei/koi, inf. e)neike/men, mid. fut. oi)/somai, aor. 1 h)nei/kanto: I. act., bear, carry, bring, convey, in the ordinary ways not needing illustration; more special uses, of the earth yielding fruits, of rendering homage or offerings, bearing tidings, of winds sweeping, driving, scattering things, Od. 4.229, Il. 15.175, Od. 10.48; fig., ‘endure,’ Od. 18.135; ‘spread wide,’ Od. 3.204 ; h)=ra fe/rein (see h)=ra), kako/n, ph=ma/ tini, fe/rein kai\ a)/gein (agere ferre), ‘plunder,’ Il. 5.484. The part. fe/rwn is often added to verbs by way of amplification, so the inf. fe/rein (fe/resqai), cf. ‘to keep,’ Od. 1.127, Il. 23.513.—II. pass., be borne (ferri), either intentionally, rush, charge, Il. 15.743, Od. 20.172; or involuntarily, be swept, hurried along, Il. 1.592. — III. mid., carry off for oneself, bear away, esp. of prizes, victory, ta\ prw=ta, kra/tos, *y 275, Il. 13.486.

feu/gw, inf. feuge/men(ai), ipf. iter. feu/gesken, fut. feu/comai, aor. 2 e)/fugon, fu/gon, subj. fu/gh|(si), inf. fuge/ein, perf. opt. pefeu/goi, part. pefugo/tes, pefuzo/tes, mid. perf. part. pefugme/nos: flee, flee from, escape; esp. flee one's country, go into exile, i=(/keto feu/gwn, came as fugitive, Od. 16.424; often trans., qa/lassan, qa/naton, Il. 11.362; fig., with a thing as subj., Il. 8.137, Il. 4.350; mid.,
pefugme/nos, usually w. acc.; a)e/qlwn, ‘escaped’ from toils, Od. 1.18.
fh=: see fhmi/.
fh/ = w(s, as, just as, like, Il. 2.144, Il. 14.499.
*fhgeu/s: son of Dares, priest of Hephaestus in Troy, slain by Diomed, Il. 5.11, 15.
fh/ginos: of oak - wood, oaken, Il. 5.838†.
fhgo/s (cf. fagus): a sort of oak with edible acorns. An ancient tree of this species was one of the landmarks on the Trojan plain, Il. 7.22, Il. 9.354. (Il.)
fh/mh: ominous or prophetic utterance, voice, omen, Od. 20.100, Od. 2.35.

fhmi/ (cf. fari), 2 sing. fh/|s not enclitic like the other forms of the pres. ind., fhsi/, fame/n, fate/, fa=s(i/n), subj. fh=|(sin), fh/h|, opt. fai/hn, fai=men, part. fa=/s, ipf. e)/fhn, fh=n, e)/fhsqa, fh=sqa, fh=s, e)/famen, fa/men, e)/fan, fa/n, fut. fh/sei, mid. pres. imp. fa/o, fa/sqw, inf. fa/sqai, part. fa/menos, ipf. e)fa/mhn, fa/to (for pefasme/nos see fai/nw): say, declare, mostly of subjective statement, to express opinion, hence reg. const. w. acc. and inf. The ipf. and the pres. inf. have aoristic signification. No distinction between act. and mid. is to be sought. Often simply think, believe, Il. 2.37, Od. 1.391 ; o(/ g' a)nh\r o(/n fhmi, whom ‘I mean,’ Il. 5.184 ; ou)/ fhmi (nego), Od. 15.213.
*fh/mios: Phemius, son of Terpis, a bard in Ithaca, Od. 1.154, 337, r 263, Od. 22.331.
fh=mis, ios: rumor, common talk; dh/mou, ‘public opinion,’ Od. 14.239, cf. Od. 16.75; also to designate the place of discussion, assembly, Od. 15.468.
fh=n: see fhmi/.
fh/nai: see fai/nw.
fh/nh: sea - eagle, osprey, Od. 3.372 and Od. 16.217.
fh/r, fhro/s (= qh/r), pl. dat. fhrsi/n: wild beast, then monster, as the Centaurs, Il. 1.268, Il. 2.743.
*fhrai/, *fhrh/: a town in Messenia, in Homer's time belonging to the Laconian territory, Il. 5.543, Il. 9.151, 293, g 488, Od. 15.186.
*fhrhtia/dhs: son (grandson) of Pheres, Eumēlus, Il. 2.763 and Il. 23.376.
fh/|s, fh=s, fh=|sqa, fh=sqa: see fhmi/.
fqa/n: see fqa=/nw.

fqa=/nw, fut. fqh/sontai, aor. 2 e)/fqhn, fqh=, 3 pl. fqa/n, subj. fqw=, fqh=|(sin), fqe/wmen, fqe/wsin, opt. fqai/h, mid. aor. 2 part. fqa/menos: be or get before, anticipate, Il. 21.262; w. part. the verb appears as an adv. in Eng., fqh= se te/los qana/toio kixhme/non, death overtook thee ‘sooner,’ ‘first,’ Il. 11.451, Od. 22.91; foll. by pri/n, Il. 16.322.

fqe/ggomai, fut. fqe/gcomai, aor. e)fqegca/mhn, subj. fqe/gcomai: utter a sound, speak out, cf. fqoggh/, fqo/ggos. Since the verb merely designates the effect upon the ear, it may be joined with a more specific word, e)fqe/ggonto kaleu=ntes, called aloud, Od. 10.229, Il. 21.192, 341; fqeggome/nou.. ka/rh koni/h|sin e)mi/xqh, while the voice still sounded, Il. 10.457, Od. 22.329.
fqei/rw, fqei/rousi, pass. fqei/resqe: destroy, ruin; pass., ‘ruin seize ye,’ Il. 21.128.
*fqeirw=n, *fqerw=n: o)/ros, name of a mountain in Caria, Il. 2.868.
fqe/wmen, fqe/wsin: see fqa=/nw.
fqh=, fqh/h|, fqh=|sin: see fqa=/nw.

*fqi=/h, dat. *fqi=/hfi: Phthia.—(1) the chief city of the Myrmidons in Thessaly, on the Spercheius, residence of Peleus and Achilles, Il. 2.683.—(2) the region about the city, with Hellas forming the realm of Achilles, Il. 9.395, Od. 11.496 .—*fqi=/hnde, to Phthia.
fqi/menos: see fqi=/nw.

fqinu/qw, ipf. fqi/nuqon, iter. fqinu/qeske: waste away, perish, die; as a sort of imprecation, ‘to go to perdition,’ Il. 2.346; trans., waste, consume, oi)=kon, oi)=non, kh=r, ‘whose grief breaks my heart,’ Od. 10.485.

fqi=/nw, fqi=/w, fut. fqi=/sw, aor. 3 pl. fqi=san, inf. fqi=sai, mid. fut. fqi=/somai, aor. 2 e)/fqito, subj. fqi/etai, fqio/mesqa, opt. fqi=/mhn, fqi=t(o), inf. fqi/sqai, part. fqi/menos, pass. perf. e)/fqitai, plup. e)fqi/mhn, 3 pl. e)fqi/aq), aor. 3 pl. e)/fqiqen: trans., fut. and aor. act., consume, destroy, kill, Il. 16.461, Od. 20.67, Od. 16.428; intrans. and mid., waste or dwindle away, wane, perish, die; mhnw=n fqi=no/ntwn (as the months ‘waned’), fqi/menos, ‘deceased,’ Od. 11.558.
*fqi=os: Phthian, inhabitant of Phthia, pl., Il. 13.686, 693, 699.
fqi=s-h/nwr, oros: man - consuming. (Il.)
fqi=si/-mbrotos (broto/s): consuming mortals, ‘life-destroying.’
fqoggh/ = fqo/ggos.
fqo/ggos (fqe/ggomai): voice, merely as audible sound; fqo/ggw| e)perxo/menai, ‘with talking,’ making themselves heard, Od. 18.198.
fqone/w (fqo/nos): grudge, deny, refuse, tini/ tinos, Od. 6.68; w. inf., Od. 11.381, Od. 19.348; acc. and inf., Od. 1.346, Od. 18.16.

-fi(n): a vestige of several old caseendings, appended to the stem-vowel of the various declensions, (1st decl.) -hfi, -h=fi (but e)sxaro/fi), (2d decl.) -o/fi, (3d decl.) -e/sfi (but nau=fi); of persons only in two words, qeo/fi, au)to/fi. The form produced by the suffix may stand for a gen. (ablative), or a dative (instrumental, locative), with or without prepositions.
fia/lh: wide, flaring bowl, saucer, or urn, Il. 23.243.
fi=lai, fi=/lato: see file/w.

file/w, file/ei, filei=, inf. filh/menai, part. fileu=ntas, ipf. (e))fi/lei, iter. file/eske, fut. inf. filhse/men, aor. (e))fi/lhsa, mid. fut., w. pass. signif., filh/seai, aor. (e))fi=/lato, imp. fi=lai, pass. aor. 3 pl. fi/lhqen: love, hold dear, mid., Il. 20.304; also entertain, welcome as guest, Od. 5.135.
fil-h/retmos (e)retmo/s): fond of the oar, oar-loving. (Od.)
*filhtori/dhs: son of Philētor, Demūchus, Il. 20.457†.
*filoi/tios: Philoetius, the faithful herdsman of Odysseus, Od. 20.185, 254, Od. 21.240, 388, Od. 22.268, 286.
filo-ke/rtomos: fond of jeering or mocking, contemptuous, Od. 22.287†.
filo-kteanw/tatos (kte/anon), sup.: most greedy of other men's possessions, Il. 1.122†.

*filokth/ths: Philoctētes, son of Poeas, from Meliboea in Thessaly. A famous archer, he possessed the bow and arrows of Heracles, without which Troy could not be taken. On the way to Troy he was bitten by a serpent in the island of Chryse, near Lemnos, and the Greeks left him behind sick in Lemnos, Il. 2.718, 725, g 190, Od. 8.219.
filo-mmei/dhs (smeidia/w): laughterloving, epith. of Aphrodīte.
*filomhlei/dhs: a king in Lesbos, who challenged all strangers to wrestle with him, Od. 4.343 and Od. 17.134.
filo/-ceinos: loving guests or guestfriends, hospitable. (Od.)
filo-pai/gmwn, onos (pai/zw): fond of play, merry, Od. 23.134†.
filo-pto/lemos: fond of war, warloving. (Il.)

fi/los, comp. fili/wn and fi/lteros, sup. fi/ltatos, voc. at the beginning of the verse fi=le: own, dear, but it must not be supposed that the first meaning has not begun everywhere in Homer to pass into the stage of the latter, hence neither Eng. word represents its force in many instances, fi/la ei(/mata, fi/los ai)w/n, and of parts of the body, fi/lai xei=res, etc. Pl. fi/loi, dear ones, friends, one's own, Od. 4.475. Neut., fi/lon, fi/la, pleasing, acceptable; fi/lon e)/pleto qu=mw=|, ai)ei/ toi ta\ ka/k' e)sti\ fi/la fresi\ manteu/esqai, you like to, Il. 1.107 ; fi/la fronei=n, ei)de/nai tini/, be kindly disposed, Il. 4.219, Od. 3.277.

filo/ths, htos: love, friendship; filo/thta tiqe/nai, ta/mnein, met' a)mfote/roisi ba/llein, Il. 4.83, *g 73, Il. 4.16; also for a pledge of friendship, hospitable entertainment, Od. 15.537, 55; of sexual love, in various oft-recurring phrases.
filoth/sios: of love, Od. 11.246†.
filo - frosu/nh (frh/n): kindliness, friendly temper, Il. 9.256†.
filo - yeudh/s: friend of lies, false, Il. 12.164†.
fi/ltatos, fi/lteros: see fi/los.
fi/lws: gladly, Il. 4.347, Od. 19.461.
-fin: see fi.
fitro/s: trunk, block, log, pl. (Il. and Od. 12.11.)
flege/qw, pass. opt. 3 pl. flegeqoi/ato: parallel form of fle/gw, blaze, glow; trans., burn up, consume, Il. 17.738, Il. 23.197. (Il.)
fle/gma, atos (fle/gw): flame, blaze, Il. 21.337†.
*fle/guai and *fle/gues: a robber tribe in Thessaly, Il. 13.302†.
fle/y, flebo/s: vein, the main artery in, Il. 13.546†.
flih/: door-post, pl., Od. 17.221†.
flo/geos (flo/c): flaming, gleaming, Il. 5.745 and Il. 8.389.
floio/s: bark, Il. 1.287†.
floi=sbos: roar of waves, applied also to the roar of battle. (Il.)
flo/c, flogo/s (fle/gw): flame, blaze. (Il. and Od. 24.71.)
flu/w: foam or boil up, Il. 21.361†.

fobe/w, aor. (e))fo/bhsa, mid. pres. part. fobeu/menos, fut. fobh/somai, pass. aor. 3 pl. (e))fo/bhqen, perf. part. pefobhme/nos, plup. 3 pl. pefobh/ato: act., put to flight, tina/, Il. 11.173; douri/, Il. 20.187; mid. and pass., flee, be put to flight, u(po/ tinos or u(po/ tini, Il. 8.149, Il. 15.637; tina/, Il. 22.250.
fo/bos: flight in consequence of fear, and once fear, Il. 11.544 ; fo/bonde, to flight.—Personified, *fo/bos, son and attendant of Ares, Il. 4.440, Il. 11.37, Il. 13.299, Il. 15.119.
*foi=bos: Phoebus, epithet of Apollo, probably as god of light, with or without *)apo/llwn.
foinh/eis, essa, en (fo/nos): bloodred, dra/kwn, Il. 12.202 and 220.

*foi/ni=kes: the Phoenicians, inhabitants of Phoenicia, their chief city Sidon. They appear in Homer as traders, skilful in navigation, famous alike for artistic skill and for piracy, Il. 23.744, Od. 13.272, Od. 14.288, Od. 15.415, 419, 473.
foini=ko/eis, essa, en (-o/essai, pronounce -ou=ssai): purple, red.
foini=ko-pa/rh|os (pareia=/): purple or red-cheeked, epith. of painted ships (cf. miltopa/rh|os), Od. 11.124 and Od. 23.271.
*foi=nic: Phoenix.—(1) the father of Eurōpa, Il. 14.321.—(2) son of Amyntor, aged friend and adviser of Achilles. He tells the story of his life, Il. 9.434 ff.
foi=nic, i=kos: I. subst., (1) purple, the invention of which was ascribed to the Phoenicians.—(2) date-palm, Od. 6.163†.—II. adj., purple, red.
foi/nios (fo/nos): (blood) red, Il. 18.97†.
*foi/nissa: gunh/, Phoenician woman.
foino/s = foi/nios, Il. 16.159†.

foita/w, foita=|, part. foitw=nte, ipf. (e))foi/ta=, du. foith/thn, aor. part. foith/sa=sa: frequentative verb, go, go or hurry to and fro, roam up and down, e)/nqa kai\ e)/nqa, panto/se, pa/nth|, *b 779, Il. 12.266; of birds flying the air, Od. 2.182.
folko/s: bow-legged, Il. 2.217†.
foneu/s, h=os: slayer, murderer, homicide.
fonh/: massacre, murder, pl., ‘rending,’ Il. 15.633.
fo/nos (fe/nw): bloodshed, murder, also for blood, Il. 24.610; and poetically for the instrument of death, the lance, Od. 21.24 ; fo/nos ai(/matos, ‘reeking blood,’ of mangled beasts, Il. 16.162.
foco/s: sharp-pointed, of a head low in front, sharp behind, a sugar-loaf head, Il. 2.219†.
*fo/rba=s: (1) king of Lesbos, father of Diomēdes, Il. 9.665. — (2) a wealthy Trojan, father of Ilioneus, Il. 14.490.
forbh/ (fe/rbw, cf. herba): forage, fodder, Il. 5.202 and Il. 11.562.
foreu/s, h=os: carrier, of grapes in the wine-harvest, vintager, Il. 18.566†.

fore/w (fe/rw), fore/ei, subj. fore/h|si, opt. foroi/h, inf. fore/ein, forh=nai, forh/menai, ipf. (e))fo/reon, iter. fore/eskon, aor. fo/rhsen, mid. ipf. fore/onto: bear or carry habitually or repeatedly, u(/dwr, me/qu, k 358, Od. 9.10; hence wear, Il. 4.137, etc.; fig., a)glai+/a=s, ‘display,’ Od. 17.245.
forh/menai, forh=nai: see fore/w.
*fo/rku=nos: limh/n, harbor or inlet of Phorcys, in Ithaca, Od. 13.96†.
*fo/rkus, u=nos and uos: Phorcys.— (1) old man of the sea, father of Thoōösa, Od. 1.72, Od. 13.96, 345.—(2) a Phrygian, the son of Phaenops, slain by Ajax, Il. 2.862, Il. 17.218, 312, 318.

fo/rmigc, iggos: phorminx, a kind of lute or lyre. The crosspiece (bridge) was called zugo/n, the pegs ko/llopes. Played not only by the professional bard, and by Apollo, Il. 24.63, but exceptionally also by heroes, Il. 9.186. In form substantially like the ki/qaris represented in the cut.
formi/zw: touch or play the phorminx (lyre, lute), Il. 18.605; said also of one playing the ki/qaris, Od. 1.155.
forti/s, i/dos (fo/rtos): nhu=s, ship of burden, Od. 5.250 and Od. 9.323. (See cut.)
fo/rtos (fe/rw): freight, cargo, Od. 8.163 and Od. 14.296.
foru=/nw (fu=/rw): only pass. ipf. foru=/neto, was defiled, Od. 22.21†.
foru/ssw (parallel form of foru=/nw), aor. part. foru/ca=s: defile, Od. 18.336†.
fo/ws, fo/wsde: see fa/os.
fradh/s, e/s (fra/zw): prudent, clear, no/os, Il. 24.354†.
fra/dmwn, onos (fra/zw): observing, Il. 16.638†.

fra/zw, aor. fra/se, aor. 2 red. (e))pe/fradon, imp. pe/frade, opt. pefra/doi, inf. -de/ein, -de/men, mid. pres. imp. fra/zeo, fra/zeu, inf. fra/zesqai, fut. fra/(s)somai, aor. (e))fra(s)sa/mhn, imp. fra/sai, subj. fra/ssetai, pass. aor. e)fra/sqhn: point out, show, indicate; w. inf., e)pe/frade xersi\n e(le/sqai, showed the blind bard how to take down the lyre with his hands (i. e. guided his hands), Od. 8.68; so o(do/n, sh/mata, mu=qon, ‘make known,’ Od. 1.273; mid., point out to oneself, consider, ponder, bethink oneself, foll. by clause w. ei), w(s, o(/pws, mh/, Il. 4.411; devise, plan, decree (of Zeus), boulh/n, mh=tin, kaka/ tini, Od. 2.367: perceive, note, w. acc.; w. part., Il. 10.339; inf., Od. 11.624; ‘look to,’ Od. 22.129.

fra/ssw (cf. farcio), aor. fra/ce, part. fra/cantes, mid. aor. fra/canto, pass. aor. part. fraxqe/ntes: fence or hedge around; e)pa/lceis r(i=noi=si bow=n, the wall with shields, Il. 12.263 ; sxedi/hn r(i=/pessi, ‘caulked’ it (in the cracks between the planks), Od. 5.256; mid., nh=as e(/rkei+, ‘their’ ships, Il. 15.566.
frei=ar, atos: well, pl., Il. 21.197†.

frh/n, freno/s, pl. fre/nes: (1) pl., midriff, diaphragm, Il. 10.10, Il. 16.481, Od. 9.301. Since the word physically designates the parts enclosing the heart, frh/n, fre/nes comes to mean secondarily:—(2) mind, thoughts, etc. fresi\ noei=n, kata\ fre\na ei)de/nai, meta\ fresi\ ba/llesqai, e)ni\ fresi\ gnw=nai, etc. fre/nes e)sqlai/, a good understanding; fre/nas bla/ptein tini/, Il. 15.724; of the will, *dio\s e)tra/peto frh/n, Il. 10.45; feelings, fre/na te/rpeto, Il. 1.474.
frh/trh (fra=/thr, cf. frater), dat. frh/trhfin: clan. (Il.)
fri/c, fri=ko/s (fri/ssw): ruffling of water caused by wind, ripple.

fri/ssw, aor. e)/fricen, part. fri/ca=s, perf. pefri=/ka=si, part. -ui=ai: grow rough, bristle, as the fields with grain, the battle-field with spears, Il. 23.599, Il. 13.339; the wild boar as to his back or crest, lofih/n, nw=ton, t 446, Il. 13.473; shudder, shudder at (cf. ‘goose-flesh’), Il. 11.383, Il. 24.775.

frone/w (frh/n), subj. frone/h|si: use the mind, have living thoughts, live, Il. 22.59; have in mind, hence consider, think, intend; a)/ristoi ma/xesqai/ te frone/ein te, intellectual activity opp. to physical prowess, Il. 6.79; to express opinion, foll. by inf., Il. 3.98; sentiment, habit of mind, pukina\ frone/ein (intelligence), i)=so/n tini frone/ein, a)mfi/s, eu)=, kakw=s, be ‘well’ or ‘ill - disposed,’ Od. 7.74, Od. 18.168.
*fro/nios: father of Noēëmon, Od. 2.386 and Od. 4.630.
fro/nis, ios (frh/n): knowledge, counsel; much ‘information,’ Od. 4.258.
*fro/ntis, idos: wife of Panthoüs, mother of Euphorbus and Polydamas, Il. 17.40†.
*fro/ntis, ios: son of Onētor, pilot of Menelāus, Od. 3.282†.
*fru/ges: the Phrygians, inhabitants of Phrygia, Il. 2.862, Il. 3.185, Il. 10.431.

*frugi/h: Phrygia, a district in Asia Minor, lying partly on the Hellespont, partly on the river Sangarius, Il. 24.545, Il. 3.401, Il. 16.719, Il. 18.291. (Greek art is indebted to the Phrygian costume for the pointed cap, which is an attribute of skilled artisans like Hephaestus, and of shrewd wanderers like Odysseus. The cut, from a Greek relief, represents a Phrygian archer.)
fu=: see fu/w.
fu/gad(e): to flight. (Il.)
fugh/: flight, Od. 22.306 and Od. 10.117.
fugo-pto/lemos: battle-fleeing, cowardly, Od. 14.213†.
fu/za (root fug, fugh/): panic (flight).
fuzakino/s: shy, timid, Il. 13.102†.

fuh/ (fu/w): growth, form, physique;
joined with de/mas, me/geqos, ei)=dos, Il. 1.115, *b 58, Od. 6.16.
fu=kio/eis, essa, en: full of sea-weed, weedy, Il. 23.593†.
fu=kos, eos: sea - weed, sea - grass, Il. 9.7†.
fukto/s (feu/gw): to be escaped; neut. pl. impers., ou)ke/ti fukta\ pe/lontai, ‘there is no escape more,’ Il. 16.128, Od. 8.299.
*fula/kh: a town in Phthiōtis, on the northern slope of Mt. Othrys, in the domain of Protesilāüs, Od. 11.290, Od. 15.236, Il. 2.695, 700, *n 696, Il. 15.335.
*fu=laki/dhs: son of Phylacus, Iphiclus, Il. 2.705, Il. 13.698.
fu/lakos = fu/lac, pl., Il. 24.566†.
*fu/lakos: (1) the father of Iphiclus, Od. 15.231.—(2) a Trojan, slain by Leitus, Il. 6.35†.
fulakth/r, h=ros = fu/lac, pl. (Il.)
*fu=/la=s: the father of Polymēle, king of Thesprotian Ephyra, Il. 16.181 and 191.
